projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A CHAIN OF GOLDEN POEMS Embellihed with WIT, MIRTH, and ELOQUENCE. Together with two mot excellent COMEDIES, (viz.) The OBSTINATE LADY, AND TRAPPOLIN Suppos'd a PRINCE: Written by Sr Aton Cokayn.
LONDON, Printed by W. G. and are to be old by Iaac Pridmore, at the Golden-Falcon near the New-Exchange. 1

div.head: THE AUTHORS APOLOGY TO THE READER.
div.p:
THee poor trifles (courteous Reader) had not now become o troubleome to the World, if it had been in my
power to have prevented them: for at my going once out of London, I left them with a friend of mine, who dying, they were dipered into divers hands. Mr. William Godbid got my Obtinate Lady, and though he found it with the lat leaf torn out, wherein my concluion to the play with the Epilogue were; he procured ome acquaintance of his to upply the defect at the end, and o Printed it. And though that Comedy, be very much of it writ in number, he put it forth as if the mot part of it were proe. Here you have that defect much amended, and my own concluion and Epilogue added. I was fearful my Trappolin, and other Poems hould have run the like
misfortune; and therefore made a diligent enquiry after them, and when I had found them out could not get them delivered without parting with ome money, and promiing my honet friend Mr. W. Godbid, (after I had afforded them ome mall correction) I would betow them on him, (with my conent) for the Pres: For indeed without his (aitance) I hould not have recovered them out of a Gentlemans hands whom I will forbear to name. I hope there is nothing in the whole o amorous as to arrive at impiety, yet nevertheles could I have imagined them worthy the trouble of trancription, you will find many things here that had been omitted. After this general Apologie I mut
alo make my excue for ome particular pieces. I have been demanded by ome Perons of Quality and judgement, why in my copy of Veres before Mr. Fletchers volume of Plaies, I chiefly reflect upon the Mad Lover, my noble friend and kinman Mr. Charles Cotton, ent me that ingle Play in a Manucript, which I had divers years in my hands: therefore when I found the Players were prohibited to act, I writ thoe poor Veres with an intention to have had the Mad Lover printed ingle, and them to have waited on it; (which when the large Volume came forth) my Coin Cotton commanded from me, and gave the Printers. Next, I mut acknowledge I have been merry with
Mr. James Strong and his pretty Pamphlet. But eeing many thus make as bold with him, I preumed I might take the ame liberty. I mut only requet the chatwomen of Lin, to take no offence at thee Veres, I intended them none; if there be any of diolute life in that town, let thoe be accounted of as his Joanes and no other: I hope James Strong is of Coriats gentle dipoition, and will endure jeting with, otherwie (at his leiure) he hath my leave to be as pleaant with me. Some few things that I tranlated out of Latin and Italian, I have not inerted, as accounting them too wanton to breath in this chater clime: and in truth if any body (either through curioity, or by any other
accident) hould englih any uch pieces, it will be eteemed a dicretion in them to forbear publihing them.

Latly, I have made ome progres into a Play, to be called the Tragedy of Ovid, which (if my Obstinate Lady, and Trappolin take) I may be encouraged to perfect, and preent to you hereafter, with ome other things that are not yet put into method, fit for the Pres, if you be not cloid with thee mall Poems already, and hate a farther urfeit upon uch toyes: If this book hath the fortune to attain to a econd impreion, you may then hear farther from me: and in the
mean, while this is enough from

div.head: TO HIS NOBLE FRIEND Sir ASTON COKAIN on his Poetical compoures.

lg.l: SIr, though I cannot on uch praies hit,
As well may uit the wardrobe of your wit,
Rich and repleat; yet give me leave to aim,
And light my I'aper at your Delphick flame.
But how hould uch a dazeled ence as mine,
(Lot in high-waies of Excellence divine)
See to pas judgements on your lines aright,
That eem all g •• ded with Phoebaean light
From your rich brain effus'd, that to the skie
Rightly conformes in clear ublimity?
I almot hould have thought your nimbler oul
Had fire from Heaven, like fly Prometheus, tole;
But that whereas accured plagues he brought,
Wherewith Pandora's box was adly fraught,
You with choice things have blet us, uch as be
Treaures of wit, art, language, hitory.
How trangely winds your fancy here and there!
Like to your Anchor, built with treams more clear
That glide along as if they long'd to ee
Themelves ingulft in vat eternity.
Surely you drew from noble birds of Po
Thoe numerous weetnees that raviht o;
And from rich Naples and renowned Rome
Brought forth fine courthip and choice learning home.
Your Mue (impregnate with no common worth)
Thus travail'd for a fame, and brought it forth:
Whoe iue he that envies, let him hear
(Like Phrygian Midas) with a lengthn' deare
Nothing but cornes hot at him undry waies,
Yet take thoe pellets for a charge of praie.
Kick at uch currih laves, nor think them fit
To pick up at your chair the crumbs of wit;
But think, whilt other Mues eem to dance
After your meaures, they your praie advance.
Needs mut thoe wits or harh or heavy be,
That move not at your trokes of harmony.

div.head: Faults ecaped in •• e printing, are thus to be corrected.
div.p:
PAge 3. line 18. read revoke, p. 4. l. 23. r. skild, p. 9. l. 22. r. Our Crow fained King was lain. p. 10. l. 4. r. built ore Thames's id, p. 12. l. 27. r. Buxtons, p. 14. l. 2. r. both fi • e p. 16. l. 2. r. you, p. 29. l. 25. r. then, p. 32. l. 30. r. Mantin, p. 34. l. 19. r. mend, p. 37. l. 14. r. Laughere •
p. 41. l. 28. r. end p. 42. l. 3. r. if, p. 76. l. 2. r. that, p. 77. l. 1. r. Naides, and the word (flowing) to be left out, p. 91. l. 21. r. their p. 95. l. 20. r. Terni and Narni, p. 96. l. 24. r. Torre Griego, p. 97. l. 17. r. Corbiel, p. 102. l. 1. r. blet, p. 104. l. 26. r. Dad, p. 106. l. 14. r. whore, p. 107. l. 7. r. Cave's, p. 119. l. 2. r. Knyveton, p. 129. l. 3. r. Elveton, p. 142. l. 6. r. eunt. p. 165. l. 14. r. Atrides, p. 168. l. 6. r. at, p. 192. l. 10. (is) to be left out, p. 197. l. 26. the ingle o to be left out, p. 205. l. 26. r. Vergivian, p. 208. l. 19. read Buxtons.
From page 208, to page 257, the figure of one hundred is left out, which (uppoing Printed) the Errata's following are thus to be amended.

Page 215, line 12, read Griego, p. 216. l. 6. r. the, p. 218. l. 22. r. name, p. 222. l. 11. r. ite, p. 223. l. 3. r. Mater, p. 226. l. 25. r. hallowd, 230. l. 19. r. here, p. 235. l. 20. r. when, p. 240. l. 23. r. dear, p. 246. l. 7. r. ue p. 253. l. 15. r. the Em the, p. 254. l. 6. r. if 'tis, p. 259. l. 7 r. Mitrees, p. 260. l. 19. r. one, p. 265. l. 7. r. any 266. l. 24. r. game, p. 280. l. 24. r. Buxtons, p. 290. l. 9. r. ervingman, p. 299. l. 25. r. maidenly, p. 303. l. 20. r. extend. p. 311. l. 27. r. neat, p. 316. l. 26. r. Crema p. 320. l. 11. r. Laurana, p. 318. l. 6. r. I'm, p. 335. l. 21. r. her, p. 347 l. 10. r. none of them, p. 349. l. 1. r. thy, p. 352. l. 4. r. Lovers, p. 360. l. 2. r. dicloe, p. 360. l. 16. r. of it, p. 365. l. 18. r. licene, p. 397. l. 29. r. Mater, p. 415. l. 8. r. paint, p. 419. l. 25. r. Mattemoros, and where ever it is printed otherwie, p. 423. l. 21. r. at fifty, p. 226. l. 5. r. he, p. 428. l. 18. r. meant.

lg.l: THat which the Sulmo Poet ung, again
I do declare, but in a chaier train.
Of all the iters that do port upon
The bifront hill, and Phocion Helicon,
Thou unto whom this task doth mot belong,
Conduct my pen, & guide my faultering tongue:
Give me a cup of the Catalian pring,
That Remedy I may more weetly ing:
And acred Phoebus, patron of the Nine,
And God of Phyick, thy aitance joyn.
Henceforth no poor Inamorato hall
Be acceary to his Funerall.
Wherefore hould mighty Turnus fall beneath
The hand of Anchiiades in death?
'Tis hame that Dido hould depair and die,
Becaue the Trojan will from Carthage flie.
Wherefore hould Phillis for Demophoons tay
With her own Girdle take her life away?
And why in Phoebus Temple hould deceae
For his fair Dardan Las Aeaides?
If any of thee had but view'd our lines
Surely they would have been of other minds.
If Clytemnetra had this Poem read,
She had not done great Agamemnon dead,
For vile Aegitus ake; nor had his on
By hers, reveng'd the Kings detruction.
If Paris Alexander had but een
This work, he had not tole the Spartan Queen:
And Ilions gorgeous Towers yet had tood,
And fam'd Scamander never drunk the bloud
Of thoe couragious Princes that there dide,
To recue and keep back Atrides bride.
If me (brave Achelous) thou hadt known,
Alcides thee had never overthrown.
If Alcumena's glorious on had view'd
This Poeie, the fatall hirt embrew'd
With poion, and the Centaures bloud, had lain
Ueles, and he on Oeta not been lain.
I wih that Tereus had read us over,
For then he had not been a bloudy lover,
Nor had transfigur'd been. All thee I could
Have made more taid then Matrons grave and old.
But uch like ends hereafter none hall know:
For we will lack the Paphian Archers bow.
Wherefore (untoward Boy) art thou evere
To thoe that gladly would thy yoke hold dear,
If thou wouldt grant them uch felicity,
That whom they do affect they might enjoy:
And that their hearts hould never entertain
Such darts as lawles paions would contrain?
I will not be too difficult to follow
My Rules, though they be true they hall be hallow:
All you therefore that love in vain, or where
You hould not, give unto my precepts ear.
And gentle Ladies, you whoe tender hearts
Have felt the force of conquering Cupids darts;
Suffering in vain the burthen of his yoke,
Attend, and your affections Ile provoke:
For almot all my documents will prove
(If you apply them) Remedies of Love;
For what I write to men, you alo may
Make ue of, your own paions to allay:
Perform but my Injunctions, and you hall
From all your fond deires be looed all:
Know happy liberty again, and throw
Contempt on them that no regard would how.
Here many Remedies we write, that all
Of Liberty may us Phyician call:
One mind doth not poes all men, therefore
Our art of Antidotes doth publih tore.
Perhaps at firt thee Remedies may eem
Too difficult for you to follow them:
A new back'd hore grieves greatly at the bit,
But quickly after will away with it:
Likewie the Oxen do at firt conceive
The yoke intolerably full of grief.
I do not bid you, if you can obtain,
A meritorious mitres to refrain:
Our purpoe is to quench bae flames, and uch
As vainly burn; but honet not to touch.
If you have been where you have een a Las
Whoe marv'lous beauty your ubjection was,
Or whoe admired qualities prevail'd
So far, that they obtain'd when they aail'd:
Think when you are retir'd, if you can win
Her to your uit, which if you can, therein,
If it be good, perit, if not, proceed
To put in practice what you here hall read.
Be willing to perform what I do ing,
And thee from Cnidos there is hope to bring.
Not Podalirius, nor Machaon can
Unbridle the affections of a man;
Nor hield Apollo's on: none but himelf
Can unto him again retore his health.
What hould be done I can but onely how,
Which i you light, your elf is your own foe.
Now leave to love and do not (fondling) ay
To morrow you'l begin, and not to day.
The longer you affect the more you burn,
And therefore finding her too coy, return.
Doth not time make the little twig a tall
Advanced tree, hading the humble vale?
Will not a Current which one here may tride
Below, for uch a paage be too wide?
And the mall eeds which in the fields are own,
Unto high corn are they not quickly grown?
Strongly hun idlenes; take that away,
And Cupids bow breaks, and his lamps decay.
A tanding water daily putrifies;
But that is freh which through a channel hies.
As much as fihes do in treames delight;
As much as Bats affect the ilent night:
So much contented Venus is with eae,
For that the Fountain is of this dieae.
His Souldiers, the Wagge, the Idle makes,
And all the buie as his fomen hates.
By labour thou mait cure thee of this trouble,
Which unto thee will bring a profit double:
And though a edentary life ome hold
To be an eaie way, to grow in old
It is a buie coure, as they hall find,
That tudy and employ their brains and mind:
And thouand nights and dayes they mut betow
In learning, that deep Scholars mean to grow
Yet 'tis a pleaing toyl; knowledge being known,
Full recompence for th' Acquiition.
Keep one of our two Univerities,
And cloely there thy knowledge make to rie
By daily tudies; Cambridge our dear Mother,
Fair Albions eldet birth; or ele the other,
Her iter Oxford; Places far renown'd
For Education, and nobly crown'd
By weet-tongu'd Poets with eternal bayes,
Fully deerv'd by their melodious laies.
Or if thou pleaet, unto London go.

(Corruptedly from Lud •
-town called o)
The eat of Englih Monarchs, and the grave
Of more then any, ince Norman valour gave
It unto William (Harold being lain)
And the Realme from the Saxons took again.
There into one of her four Innes withdraw
Thy elf, and eriouly go tudy Law.
Or be a Souldier, and maintain his right,
Whoe caue is jut, o thou may't jutlier fight;
Though wie Ulyes had a beautious wife,
And chate, and young, he led a ouldiers life:
Had he a proud didainful mitres bin,
Frown'd on his ervices and corn'd him;
You may conceive he then would ooner far
Have left, and lighted her, and gone to th' war.
Or lead a Countrey life, where far from noie,
Pride of the Court, and City-vanities,
Thou may't enjoy thy elf weet days and nights,
And pend thy time in harmleer delights.
There thou mait hunt, or hawk, plant, graff, & find
Thouand diverions for thy troubled mind.
The noblet Romans many times would leave
Their pendent City, and in th' Countrey live:

l.U: elf (when it was at the height)

lg.l: Forook it, and in Caprae did delight.
If that the Lyrick Horace had liv'd at home
In his own Countrey-houe, and kept from Rome,
Perhaps he from's fond paions had been free,
As the chate Virgin Anaxarete.
If there thou pendet all the day in royle,
In wonted fire at night thou wilt not broyle:
For then weet leep you onely will requet,
That after wearinee you may have ret.
Travelling is a proved Antidote,
Whereby a double profit may be got.
I do not give thee counel to ubdue
Thy paions by ailing unto Peru:
Neither advie I thee to pas the eas,
To take a view of the Pyramides:
Nor into Italy where Romans old
The Scepter of the Univere did hold:
Nor into Spain, where John of Gaunt, the Duke
Of Lancater uch battailes undertook:
Nor into France, which our fifth Henry won,
And when he died left to his infant-on,
Who what his great victorious ire did gain,
Piece-meal to Charles the eventh did loe again.
The journey I enjoyn will not enforce
Thee to take hipping, but to ride an hore:
For will not England be ufficient
To cure thy wound, and to produce content?
Travel it through; but take along with thee
A friend or two to bear thee company.
I do not bid thee to go up and down,
Through every Village, and through every Town:
Onely the bet and notedt places view;
Whereof unto thee I will name a few.
To Troynovant, now called London, ride,
By new fair buildings daily beautifide,
And great reort of people; There thou mait
See how the Thames under a Bridge doth hat
Of nineteen Arches; Th • t o fair an other,
And trangely built, is carce all Europe over.
There thou mait ee the famous Monuments
Of our Heroes, fram'd with large expence:
There thou upon the Sepulchre mait look
Of Chaucer, our true Ennius, whoe old book
Hath taught our Nation o to Poetize,
That Englih rythmes now any equalize;
That we no more need envy at the traine
Of Tiber, Tagus, or our neighbour Seine.
There Spencers Tomb thou likewie mait behold
Which he deerved, were it made of gold:
If, honour'd Colin, thou hadt liv'd o long,
As to have finihed thy Faery Song,
Not onely mine, but all tongues would confes,
Thou hadt exceeded old Maeonides.
Thence unto Canterbury take thy way,
Famous for being our chief Arch-Bihops ea:
Where thou mait ee the ruines of the Tombe
Of that great Prelate, who whilom in Rome
Complained of his Soveraign, and did tand
Boldly himelf alone 'gaint all the Land.
Dover is worthy of thine eyes, from whence
Thou mait ee Calice lot no long time ince
By Philip, on to Charles the fifth, and her
That did again the Roman faith prefer.
Afterwards into Surry go, where you
Five of our Monarchs Palaces may view;
And Okam that renowned Village, were
William was born, the deep Philoopher,
Sur-named from his birth-place, whoe divine
Wit is oberv'd by Nations tranmarine.
To Hant-hire, Wincheter doth thee intreat,
A journey to vouchafe the ancient eat
Of the Wet Saxon Kings, where thou may't turn
Thine eyes upon Canutus royal urn.
From thence (if thou art of a noble race)
To Totnes ride, Brutus his Landing-place;
A gallant branch of Anchiiades
Flying from Italy through unknown eas.
In Someret-hire travel to the Bath,
A place frequented much becaue it hath
Waters for many a icknes good; yet I
Believe none there can cure loves malady.
And upon Glaenbury Abby daine
To look, where our Crow-fam'd King was lain,
And Joeph; and upon the Hawthorn-tree,
On Chritmas-day that blooms annually.
Wilt-hires Cathedral Church is of uch price,
That worthily it doth deerve thine eyes:
Wherein as many windows do appear,
As there be dayes in the divided year:
Wherein the Marble pillars parallel
The hours that in four quarters one may tell.
And latly where as many gates vouchafe
Entrance, as moneths a year completely hath;
In Bark-hire unto Windor Catle ride,
By Britih Arthur whiles re-edified:
Which glorious Catle at one time detain'd
Two captive Kings by our third Edward gain'd:
And in whoe Chappel thoe two Monarchs are
Interr'd, that toyl'd us with intetine war.
Saint Edmonds Bury is frequented much,
Becaue that thereabouts the air is uch:
Unto that town a journey take, and thence
To Ipwich go, by Danih violence
Sack'd and made deolate, but now o brave
That (through 't be none) we worer Cities have.
Although the King of the Eat Angles did
Reide at Thetford, yet I do not bid
Thee ee it: Lyn and Yarmouth more invite
Thine eyes, but Norwich mot deerves thy ight;
Norfolk chief glory, wherein rutick Ket
For the commotion died he did beget.
And take a view of Cambridge, wherein I
Compos'd this Poem for thy Remedy.
Hail honour'd Mother! O vouchafe o much,
That worthles I may thee a little touch,
Englands bright and right eye! now honour'd more
Then famous Athens was in dayes of yore,
Accept my wih. May all thy ources be
For ever ignorant of vacancie:
And thou arie unto that height of fame
That none comparatively may Oxford name:
Which oon would come to pas, if that our King
Would end what our ixth Henry did begin.
Trinity Colledge (unto which I do
For my own education my elf owe)
Invites thee to behold a pacious Court
And what it is, afterwards to report:
That Royal Fabrick rais'd by him that died
By Crook-backs hands, and is o magnified,
For that trange roof, will doubtles thee invite
(Within the walls) of it to take a ight.
For Colins ake (who hath o well expret
The vertues of our Faery Elves, and dret
Our Poeie in uth a gallant guie)
On happy Pembroke-Hall employ thine eyes.
Oxford our other Academy, you
Full worthy mut acknowledge of your view:
Here mooth-tongu'd Drayton was inpired by
Mnemoynes's manifold progenie;
And Sydney (honour'd by all Englih men)
In Catalie here dip'd his numerous pen.
From Oxford go to Gloter, and from thence
To umptuous Britow, whoe magnificence
For building every tranger much admires;
A City ituated in two hires.
Kencheters Phoenix, Hereford behold:
And Marcley hill whoe motion is o told.
In Worceters Cathedral Church you may
King Johns white Marble Monument urvey.
And Arthurs ad Jet Tomb, the eldet on
Of him that Boworth field from Richard won.
Thither a journey make. Then Coventry
That by Godiva gained liberty,
Be ure to viit; where at Gofford gate,
Hangs a Boars bone that ome do wonder at.
See Peterborough Minter: And the Leicet.place
Which econd Henry did o much deface,
For Earl Bous Rebellion. Lincolne grown
Far into Age, a City whilome known
More populous and great, do not pas by;
The Minter in it merits any eye.
Nor uffer fair and pleaant Notingham,
(Where the great Mortimer by thoe that came
Thorow a vault, was taken with the Queen)
By any means by thee to be uneen.
Thence unto Darby (for your Authors ake,
A Native of that Shire) a journey take:
Where in a Black-pot of renowned Ale
Drink unto me, wihing I may prevail
So far in Poetry, that my lov'd name
May be preerved by an endles fame.
Here Melborne Catle tood, wherein the Duke
Of Burbon was kept prioner, bravely took
In Agincourts great Battel, wherein we
Conquered by a double policy.
Repton a tation was to glorious Rome,
And yields unto a Saxon King a Tomb.
At Burton (in the Peak) nine Springs break out
Within a little compas, wondrous thought,
Becaue that eight of them are warm, and one
As if it were under the frigid Zone.
Here likewie are two Caves, whereof one doth
To tones turn water-drops that hang at th' roof:
The other (of which trange reports are told)
The Devils Are is called. Thee behold,
And Elden Hole, which had Aenaeas een,
He would have thought the way to Hell had been,
And the renown'd Elyium hades; for this
(To humane earch) remaines yet bottomles.
Stafford-hire (Trents producer) Lichfield doth
Adorn, and Shrop-hire Shrewesbury: See both.
On (Dublins oppoite) Wetcheter look,
Wherein of eight Kings Edgar homage took.
York-hire a City hath, our bet but one,
And a trange water that turns wood to tone
Kingstone on Hull a fine Town is, and which
Then many of our Cities is more rich.
Kendall that by the River Cane doth tand,
(Famous for cloth) is chief of Wetmorland.
Doubtles in Cumberland, Carleil by far
Is the mot eminent: See what thee are.
Upon New-Catle builded omewhat nigh
Severus wall, latly imploy thine eye.
What ever City it may be, or Town
Your Mitree makes her habitation,
You mut avoid it, and let no pretence
Occaion be of your not going thence:
No buines you mut value that may be
A prejudice to your recovery.
But you to leave your Mitrele may uppoe
A miery below the depth of woes.
Were but your body hurt you would endure
Fire, and Iron to haten on your cure:
Or were you ick, & abtinence could gain
Your health, from plentuous meals you would refrain,
And though a thirt even eem to burn you, yet
You would abtain from drink, and bridle it:
And now to cure your mind, and draw the dart
Of angry Cupid from your fetring heart,
You tartle and recoil: For hame be bold,
And the mind's health above the bodie's hold.
If you can pick a caue that may produce
Dilike of your coy Lae, thereof make ue.
Ill's ometime neighbour unto good: For o
Vertue (by errour) oft for vice doth go.
Judge all things in your Mitres at the wort,
For why hould you be kind to her that's curt?
If he be big made, eas'ly her eteem
A match befitting montrous Polypheme.
Is but her tature low? a Dwarfe her call,
That like a Serpent on the ground doth crall.
If he be lender, lean: If tall, uppoe
Her Charing-cros dres'd up in womans clothes.
If he be merry think her wanton: or
Reerv'dly fahion'd, as unbred abhor.
If in the Northern parts he hath been bred,
Say he her life mot clownihly hath led.
Or if in any City, or great Town,
That he hath been a gadder up and down.
What e're he is, be ure her to dipraie,
A thouand Girles dilike a thouand wayes.
If you perceive a want in her in ought,
By crafty means to hew't he mut be wrought:
As if he hath no voice, to ing, or dance,
If he be skilles in that art, by chance.
Hath he a big voice, or an ill dicoure?
Occaion her to talk, and think them wore.
Hath he an ill gate? ee her walk; and tell
Her merry tories, if her teeth be ill,
To make her laugh and hew them. If her eyes
Be weak, relate trange addet Tragedies
To force her tears; And if he cannot play
Upon the Lute, to play upon't her pray.
Never preume to take a walk alone,
But ay delight in ome Companion:
If any time the corching Lions heat
Compelleth thee into a Grove to get,
In imitation of Alcides trong,
A Phyloctetes bring with thee along,
With whom play, laugh, convere, and o to thee
Dione's Grand-child will no tyrant be.
Lovers, beware of olitarines;
A very dangerous thing for your dieae:
Let Crustamaena's daughter's w • ful Fate
(That walk'd alone through Forrets, and would waite
Upon the Thracian hore (as he did land)
In hope t'embrace Demophoon on the trand)
From all uch melancholy walkes deter
And warn you, by frequent remembring her.
In your bed-chambers have ome friends till leep;
That from your minds they may by talking keep
All amorous thoughts; o Venus will depart,
And leave in ret to each a quiet heart.
Beware of reading Love; take heed of thoe
That either pourtract him in vere or proe:
For amorous lines will many michiefs raie,
And make the Cinders of affection blaze.
Though the Arcadia be a book approv'd,
Arcadia mut not be by thee belov'd.
The Lady Wrothes rania is repleat
With elegancies, but too full of heat.
Spencers and Daniels Sonets do not view,
Though they are good, they are not o for you.
From feigned Hitories refrain thy ight,
Scarce one is there but is an amorous Knight.
Muaeus Englih'd by two Poets hun;
It may undo you though it be well done.
Harrington's Arioto do not touch,
For wanton lines carce any book hath uch.
And my old friend Drayton's Epitles you
(Being too oft and languihing) echew,
Be oppoite to Cupids law, and when
Thy tears are falling, forcibly mile then:
But yet mitake me not, as if I thought,
That unto freedome you might oon be brought,
And on a udden; no, he mut take time,
That o're a mighty Mountain means to climb:
So you reolvedly your health intend,
Y'are certain to arrive at happy end.
Talk not of Love. Alas! the very name
Is o enchanting that it will inflame;
Neither hear any, turn your head aide
Or preently their company avoide;
Daphne had yeilded to Heavens Charioter,
Had he but taid his wanton words to hear.
Drinking of wine forbear, and be to feed
Wary on meats from which lut doth proceed;
At every meal be ure to hun exces;
By eating little heat grows les and les.
Antonius one of the Triumvirate,
Competitor with Caear for the State,
With flowing Bowles, and with luxurious feats
Was entertain'd, and entertain'd his guets:
Which was the caue his lut o high did flame,
That life he lot for the Egyptian Dame,
And over all thoe Countreys to be head,
Wherein the Roman Eagles ere were pread.
If by ome light a Garter you have got
From her that will not love you, keep it not;
Or if you have a Bracelet of her hair,
Or any uch like toy, them never wear;
For urely thee are Cytheraea's Baites,
Which infinitely chat Diana hates.
Or if your Mitris heretofore hath bin
Kind unto you, and you have gloried in
Her bounteous favours, thought your elf above
All mankind grac'd, with th'honour of her love;
If under her fair hand you Letters have,
That he returns her heart for that you gave,
Fraught with o weet expreions as would draw
Even women-Haters under Cupids Law:
If he retreats and alters in her minde,
To you grows cruel that to her are kinde,
Aume a noble Courage, and condemn
To angry Vulcan every one of them;
Or if you have her Picture, end it home,
Or offer it a gallant Hecatombe
To your offended Love that he may know
You corn her Relicks that hath us'd you o.
Being in love with one, and cannot get her,
Affect another and you will forget her,
So Ariadne did when he did find
Renowned Theeus was to her unkind
In Naxos Ile, where he did her forake,

l.U: he did into her favour take.

lg.l: Affection divided you will find
To be a leer burthen to your mind.
As a great river with a mighty rore
Runs through the vales, and wounds the yeilding hore,
If into everal Channels it doth fall,
It les impetuous and maje •• icall
Will prove, and in an humbler manner glide,
Rob'd of it's former glory, trength, and pride.
So Love be •• ow'd on everal beauties will
Grow much les dangerous and an eaier ill.
When his diloyal Queen the Trojan Prince,
(With's beauty and his courtly eloquence)
Did win, and teal away, had Atrcus Son
But done, as many others would have done,
(And it had prov'd the bet) become a Lover
(For ure he had ome equals) of an other;
He in a lourihing and happy peace
Had liv'd at home in his own Court in Greece,
And many an Argive King at home had found
A Sepulchre, and not in Phrygian ground;
Therefore new Beauties eek to try, if you
Can part with any love unto a new;
And to that end frequent all Solemn Balls
All publick hows and umptuous Fetivals.
Conjecture that which is not: think that you
Are free from love, and that your thought is true:
When one becaue he would not drink doth make
As he were fall'n aleep, leep him may take.
If in the Wars you have a truty friend,
Your Cogitations to him always bend,
Thinking upon the hazard he is in;
And o your thoughts your Mitres hall not win.
Or if you have a Ship with riches fraught
Returning home, ay on it fix your thought;
Contemplating the fury of the Sea,
And how that many have been cat away;
Whereby your cornful Girl you hall forget,
Sith your imaginations are not et
On her, but on the Goods that Neptune hath
Within the power of his love, or wrath.
If that thy Mitres with a nimble hand
All the Lutes ravihing harmony doth command,
Or upon other Intruments can play
Equal to Orpheus, that did make his way
Through the Infernal Shades by his rare skill;
Hear her not play; It will increae thine Ill.
Or if he ings like Venus, when he fain
Her weary wanton Cupid would contrain
To lay his fatal quiver and bow away,
And in the Groves of Amathuia
Sleep by her ide, while on the Cypres Trees
A thouand birds warble their melodies,
Hear her not ing; Her voice will o allure
That her contempt you longer will endure.
Or dances he like to the Graces, when
They are retit'd from the abodes of men,
And Gods their pleas'd pectatours do become;
If he intends to dance avoid the room.
Imagine not a Rival; For o doing
You never will be able to leave wooing;
For, (to obtain the Girl from him) you will
Perit a vain Inamorato till.
The one-ey'd Cyclop, when he Acis found
Sitting with Galatea on the ground,
His Rival with a rent up rock did kill,
When he anothers did begin to be,
The more Oretes lov'd Hermione.
Refrain from Playes; Let not the Theatre
At all include thee; for by eeing there
One act an amorous paion, may make you
Your uit to your proud Lady to purue.
Becaue when you have een that he hath got
His Mitres, may conceive, why may you not?
Ah! his was but th' Invention of a brain,
Your Ladies corns runs in an higher train.
If you conveniently can, urprie
Your mitres dreings, o your wary eyes
Some trange conceal'd deformities may finde,
To eae, if not releae your Captive minde;
Which when you think upon (at leiure) more,
They to your liberty may you retore.
Mot of our Ladys when they do expoe
Themelves to view, may thank their cotly clothes
Rich jewels, feigned tatures, borrow'd hair,
And beauteous colours that unnatural are;
They would not ele eem objects of delight,
But homely women, uch as we hould light
And your didainful one perhaps being uch,
You ee the leat of her you love o much.
But rahly do not practie this; Be ure
She ueth art, or fly her chamber dore;
For a pure native beauty that doth corn
All helps of Art, aries like the Morn
In a cleer sky, and (dreing) may dicover
Sights too attractive for a lighted lover.
Do thee, and though affections fire hould blaze
Like Aetna in your breat, you thence would chae
Eaily all thoe flames, and after be
From all the Paphian vexations free.
Unfortunate Lovers many times (I gues)
All that reciprocally love do bles,
Think every tar (when they were born) did hine
Benignely on them, and the Heavens combine
To grace them with continuance of joyes,
As if they were above all mieries;
When it falls often out, a fervent love
A more extreme affliction doth prove.
Alcyone her Ceyx did prefer
Above all men and he all women, her;
Yet he did ee his body float to hore
Drowned at Sea but a few days before.
Therefore to Hymens Temple though they come,
And hear the oft Epithalamium,
And many dayes do live in joy and peace,
In depths of wretchednes they may deceae.
And many that for love do marry, be
After unfortunate, and not agree;
Almighty Jove that did Saturnia wed,
Bringing for love his iter to his bed,
Quickly neglected her; His wandring e • es
Not long being pleas'd without varieties;
As witnes Danae in the Brazen tower,
And Semele his daring't Paramour,
Laeda by him eteem'd mot beautifull,
And fair Europa riding on a Bull;
Calito (chat Diana) One of thine
Deceiv'd, and vitiated neer Nonacrine;
Married Alcmena in a threefold night,
And many uch too tedious to recite.
The • and the like of his Amours being known,
Juno's firm't patience was overthrown;
Who (by her much opprobrious language given)
Hath divers times even colded him from Heaven
Be gentle henceforth (Cupid) and invite
Reciprocally unto thy delight:
For bloodhed (wanton) is unfit for you;
Thy Sire-by-law hould dreadful Armes purue;
Tis he that may great Territories wat,
And make whole Kingdoms at his name agat.
Tis he not thou that ternly hould advance
(To the expulure of a Soul) a Lance.
Tis he that hould ound trumpets, and the noie
Of baleful Drums make penetrate the skies.
Lutes, Viols, Orpherions, uch as thee,
Not Mars his wrathful Muick thee hould pleae:
But be as cruel as thou wilt, my vere
Shall blunt thine arrows that they hal not peirce.
Our work we have concluded, and do pray
All thoe, whoe burnings Fits it hall allay,
To love our Memory, and peak our praye,
And (if we merit them) to give the Bayes.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: WHy Strephon art thou melancholy grown
And wil • not ue thine oaten pipe? hat known
Any ill news of late hath dul'd thy wit,
Made us unhappy, and thy elf unfit?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: 'Tis no Report, kinde Coridon, hath made
Me cloud my brow with orrow and be ad;
It is a caue more high, a caue that can
Detroy the joy of the mot fortunate man.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: And may I know it Strephon? Dare you trut
Me with a Secret, and conceive me jut,
Believe I will be ilent? If you dare,
I hould deire this Novelty to hear.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Ah, Coridon! I am in love with one,
The fairet Shepherdes was ever knowne;
Her Face is beauties abtract, wherein we
May (at perfection) every beauty ee.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: And art thou ad becaue thou art in love?
So Jove hould grieve becaue he reigns above;
There is no fate o high befalls a Swain,
As to love where he is belov'd again.
Tell me (my Strephon) therefore why art ad?
Is it becaue thy Dear will not be had?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: She cannot (Coridon) for he is wed,
And fine young Perigot hath her maiden-head,
As blithe a Shepherd as did ever ing
Neat Roundelayes unto our Goat-foot King;
He is an happy man, and doth enjoy
That beauty which I languih for, and dy.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Strephon, I grieve thou art enthralled o;
Deit betimes, and forward do not go;
Thy flames extinguih whilt they do begin,
For uch a Love is againt Pan a Sin.
And while yong Perigot lives what hope have you,
If he unto him do not prove untrue?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: I do confes I have none; neither would
Commit o great an evil, if I could;
I am enamour'd neither more nor les
Then Thenot, on the faithful Shepherdes:
I love her vertues, and if he hould fall,
My love to her would be no love at all.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Thou art an honet Swain, and our Feild-God
Will bles thee in thy Cottage and abroad.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: As I have faithfully to you replide,
So let none of my quetions be denide.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: They hall not (Strephon;) I hould be unjut
Unto your merits, if I did ditrut
Your ecreie in any thing I peak;
He that doth doubt his friend, doth friendhip break.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Is there no l • s whom Coridon doth like?
You, did the Paphian Archer never trike?
Or are you uch a man as never car'd
Whether a womans heart were oft or hard?

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Strephon, I love, but I do fear in vain,
Becaue rich Melibe intends to gain
A wealthier Shepherd for his daughter, one
Whoe fortune mut prevent thy Coridon.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: And would he merchandize his daughter? may
He long expect and never ee that day.
Steal her young Shepherd; never let her be
(Whom thou affects) ubject to alarie.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: But ere I aw my Mira, or did know
What beauties made her perfect, I did owe
My love to Galatea; but I lot
My labour, which good old Palaemon crot,
Becaue he did believe that I would prove
A careles Shepherd, and the Downs not love:
Judge (Strephon) that know't me above report,
If I be jutly cenur'd by him fort';
Do I not love the fields, and ue to play
On Oaten reedes many a Roundelay?

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: He that ays otherwie, he doth not know
Thy Nature truly, but becomes thy foe;
Becaue (being Ignorant) he doth undertake
So bold a Character of thee to make;
Were he acquainted with thy wayes, to thee
Palaemon would give Galatea free;
And think his age more happy then his youth,
That made a Shepherd his of o much truth.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Flatter not (Strephon) I do want thoe parts
That make a man be lov'd for his deerts;
Could I but ing uch neat fine Lays, as you,
I might believe thee praies were my due.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: And o you can if Tityrus ays right,
Who told me Dities you did well endite.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Now you do mention Tityrus, I mut
Be to his merits, and our friendhip jut;
He is a Shepherd (would he pleae to ing)
Might lengthen with his voice the peedy Spring:
Did he but know how much the downs he wrongs,
The woods and dales would eccho with his ongs;
He knows when Notes are over-harp, or flat,
And is the ablet Boy that ever at
Upon an Hillock, would he ue his Reed,
And joy his want on flock while it doth feed.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: He is an able Lad indeed, and likes
Arcadian Patorals, and (willing) trikes
A Plaudite to th' Epilogues of thoe
Happy Inventions Shaksphere did compoe;
Beaumont and Fletcher he will liten to,
And allow Johnons method high and true.
He prais'd you to me, and I do believe
He his own Judgement would not wrong to give
Feign'd Commendations; Do not (therefore) fear
Sith he approves your pipe, who doth it hear.

sp.speaker: Corid.
sp.l: Strephon, I thank both you, and him, & will
Be proud hereafter to make known my skill:
If I but pleae the few I mean it for,
To eek for vulgar praie I hall abhor.

sp.speaker: Stre.
sp.l: Coridon it is late: Farewel untill
We meet again upon this flowry Hill;
My Mater will make wonder at my tay,
I otherwie would not o oon away.

sp.speaker: Cori.
sp.l: Thy Mater's happy in thy care, Adieu:
As I will be in abence, be thou true.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: WHy art thou ad (fair Shepherdes) and o
Fil't Heaven with ighs of hidden inward wo?
What is the reaon that in thy freh years
Thou drown't thy lovely cheeks with howers of tears,
Withering the Roes that did flourih there,
And pal't thy youthful blood with heavy chear?
Behold the long expected Spring is come,
And joyful Birds are now no longer dumbe:
They every Grove that is do make a Quire,
Chirping in them the layes of their deire.
Our Lads and Laes that in winter were
Drowie like the dull eaon of the year,
Are merry now, and (upon all the Downs)
Kindly receive, and kindly give green Gowns.
Onely our Amarillis fain't of all
Mourns like a follower of a Funeral:
What is the caue? for I would gladly know
If it uch orrow doth deerve, or no.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Ah Thenot, reverenc't for thy hoary hair,
Of all the Shepherds that amongt us are!
To thee the oon't I would unload my minde,
That art in Counel wie, in pity kinde,
Wie, to advie me if I do amis,
And pitiful, to rue my wretchednes:
Know I have caue to weep, as long as I
Have any moiture left in either eye,
To tear off every hair from off my head,
And rage impatiently till I am dead.
O my Credulity! That did uppoe
There could be faith in any Lovers oathes!

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: Then tis for love that Amarillis thus
Diconolately liveth here with us:
But which of all our Boyes is o unwie
To light a Beauty of o rich a price?

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Knew't thou not Thyris, that had wont to keep
On yonder Hill a jolly flock of Sheep,
Who all the while they on the banks did feed,
Play'd merry tunes upon his Oaten reed?
Such ongs as Alta highly did eteem,
And for their quaintnes was in love with him;
The Daughter of rich Ionius, who was
Took with his pipe, like many an other Las.
But when my Shepherd all the ret did light,
And in my beauty onely did delight,
He did not care for all her wealth, and (tho
She was an hanome Wench) would never wo;
For uch Command I then had of his heart,
That I did think he never could depart:
Which being known, his angry Father ent
Him out of Arcadie in dicontent;
That being far remov'd, and forth of ight
He might forget his Amarillis quite.
And o I hear he hath; and yet he wore
Abence hould make his love not les, but more.
Ah, perjur'd man! He faithles and untrue,
Hath fally lighted me, and took a new.
O Thenot! Couldt thou think that Thyris, he
That made uch vows would ever faithles be?
His vows had he broke onely, it had bin
A pardonable and a venial Sin:
Thenot! can men weep like a Crocodile?
Have they their tears o ready to beguile?
He wept when we did part as much as I,
And now is guilty of uch perjury.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: Sad Amarillis, though I know thy youth
Cannot utain the breach of Lovers truth
Without Impatiency (For women when
They bear affection eldom change like men)
Yet know (in you) 'twere widom to remove
Your heart from him that hath o fail'd in love.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Ere I can leave my Thyris, Thenot, know
I mut want life; when I do backward go,
Jut Jove revenge my falhood; I will be
True as I was, though he hath lighted me;
Know honet Thenot that I am not Wind,
When I have etled once, to change my minde;
When I prove fale, Thou glorious Guide of day,
Change Eat and Wet, and run another way;
And thou pale-horned Queen of night contrain
The Sea to dulnes, neither wax nor wane;
The pleaant Ladon firt hall change his Coure,
And every River run back to the Source;
The fixed Stars weary of tanding hall
Amaze Atrologers be Planets all:
And toil'd Bootes (tired with his pain)
Leave travel off, and fix his evenfold Wain.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: Be comforted (weet Las) For ure when he
Returns again, again he will love thee.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Thenot, could I expect but o much good,
I here would live as merry as I cood,
And to our rural Pan each night and morn
Make faithful Orions for his Return.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: Trut me (young Amarillis) I have no
Doubt of him; but am ure it will be o:
An honet man may fall, and yet may be
Not ever in his fault; neither will he.
When he returns and finds that you have bin
True unto him, ahamed of his Sin,
His former faith he will renew, and more
Love Amarillis then he lov'd before.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Thanks (gentle Thenot) for thee words of joy,
Poor Amarillis to her Fortunes try,
And (if that me you ever thankles find)
Banih my name for ever from your minde:
Thy Speeches have rais'd hope he wil come back,
And me again into his favour take
And that on Holy-days (when all the Rout
Do port the medows and the fields about,
(Crowning with Garlands her that Dances bet,
Making her Mitres of our Country-Feat)
With howing Gambals on the dazy Green
And eating Chee-cakes with our Summer Queen)
I with my Shepherd (among th' others) hall
Dance many a merry Jig, and many a Brall:
For ince my Thyris from Arcadia went,
I olitary have liv'd dicontent;
When others have been playing, have at down
And moytned wth my tears the Sun-burnt ground.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: But leave uch adnes (Amarillis) now
And unto us thy Company allow;
For I dare lay the bet Lamb I have here,
He hortly will return, and love thee deare.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: My thanks again good Thenot; Ever be
Belov'd of Pan for comforting of me.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: And may our rural God (fair Shepherdes)
Thee with fruition of thy Wihes bles.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: I have no other wih but that my Swain
Would come to us, and be mine own again.
Happy the day when we by Ladon ide
Eat Cream, and kies mutually enjoyde:
And happy were thoe Nights, when on his knee
He by the Fire ide did dandle me!
How often as we at o hath thy Son
Thy Billy Thenot to th'old Woman run,
For apples to make Lambs-wooll! Never more
We two hall drink as we have drunk before.
But far more happy were thoe days of note,
When we from Martin did live far remote,
In thy kind Cottage, when I did not know
What 'twas to love and be foraken o;
There I have ung, and laugh'd, & laugh'd, & ong,
And been as merry as the day was long;
But ince my Thyris hath both woed, and won me,
And o forgotten me, he hath undon me.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: We hould have omething to divert this thought;
For Melancholy (Shepherdes) is naught.
I hope that now we very hortly hall
Hear on our Green that pleaant Patorall,
Which (of an Obtinate Las) young Coridon,
Thy love-ick Brother did write long agon;
Which Tityrus his faithful Friend approv'd,
A Shepherd for his able parts belov'd.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: When it is ong I will not fail to hear
For Coridons ake, whom I do love o dear;
To me that Patoral he oft hath aid,
While both our neighbor-flocks have fed, & plaid;
And (honet Thenot) many undry times
I unto him have read my Thyris rimes,
Wherein he prais'd me above woman-kind;
And little did I think thoe Words were winde.
But thoe few happy days are pat, and now
Sad care its always heavy on my brow.
Ere Thyris went none danc'd o much as I,
None laugh'd o chearfully, none did enjoy
So many nights of joy, and days of blis;
And all becaue I thought that I was his:
And if (when he returns again) he will
Receive his long-foraken Amarill,
The Lamb, which bet of all my Flock I prize,
Unto our rural Pan I'le acrifice.

sp.speaker: Then.
sp.l: Fair Shepherdes, be confident ere long
He will return, and quit him of the wrong
That he hath don himelf, increaing o
His former love that you no end hall know.
Tis time to fould our Flocks: For we have at
So long a talking that it is grown late.

sp.speaker: Amar.
sp.l: Thenot, Goodnight! And thanks for thy kind tay,
Heaven proper thee long to Arcadia:
For, if that thou, and ome few more hould die,
Our Countery oon the Patoral Mue would flie.

lg.l: AWay with Plays, and Sonnets! I will write
A dreadles Satyre hall the town affright,
And make the Gallants cure and wear that he
Meant this by him, and this he meant by me.
I will pare none, but warn; that each man learns
(When he applies) to minde whom it concerns.
But heark! I hear a friend: Away! And do
Not uch a thing; It hould not come from you:
Let needy Poets that cannot ell their Plays
Exclaim (out of their want) againt the days;
Or (whom a Lord for Dedication ows)
Tax him with all his faults, a way each knows;
Or let a depis'd Lover (whom of late
His Mitres for his veres jeer'd) go prate,
Tell how he paintes, who are her Bawds, & which
Of the young Courtiers comes to eae her Itch;
But not a man of our own ranke dicloe,
What either he by his experience knowes,
Or from his friendes relation; In this time
Not to perform but to be een's a Crime:
And there are many do grow wore when they
See vice reveal'd, caue then they know the way.
This cannot erve: I will unlode my pleen,
And pare no ulcers be they old or green.
Methinks I hear one peak; Sir, do your wort,
We hall not be the lat, not are the firt
That have by Paper-blurrers been defam'd,
And (when y'ave done) we will proceed unham'd.
I did believe as much, but I will on
Onely for my own recreation.
Ask but a Chamber-maid (which are the froth
Of vain dicoure) what her young Lady doth;
And he will certifie you of each change
Her humour hath, and every ubtile range
Her trange unbridled paions lead her to;
How he complains her Knight is grown untrue
Unto his vows and her, and therefore he
Seeks Patimes to divert her Melancholie;
Frequents the Theatres, Hide-Park, or els talkes
Away her pretious time in Gray's Inn Walkes;
Layes out what he can pare (to win his heart
By any means) for the lat helps of art;
And vowes (if nothing in her power lyes
To gain him) he'l no longer be unwie,
And pend her flourihing days in olitude,
Unfit, and unagreeing with her blood;
That there's a Gallant Courtier, young, and rich
In Natures perfectet Endowments, which
She yet hath lighted much; but now (tis thought)
She will requite her Husband, and be naught.
O Feminine Revenge! to brand her Name,
With Infamy, and Family with hame!
Nor is this all her News: She can dicover
Whom the old Knights daughter hath made her lover;
That he dotes on him o, he cannot keep
Her tongue from naming him though in her leep;
That he would fain be married, for the awe
She bears unto an unkind Mother in law;
How he's a younger brother, and • oth lack
Silver in's pure though ha's enough on's back.
O vanity of times! Secrets that hoo'd
Be lock'd within 's fat as our boomes blood,
And faults that hould be mended, and not known
(By uch like means) common dicours are grown:
Some will be cenuring things that are above
Their way, becaue uch things they do not love;
Sir, out of love unto you I am come
To certifie you, you give caue to ome
To laugh at you; y'ave writ a Play, and they
Say tis a hame for you to write a Play:
Beides you Poetry o much affect,
That you the better Sciences neglect.
O thou weet Charmer of the Soul • Why hould
This Iron age o meanly of thee hold?
Hat thou movd alvage beats, and rocks, & trees,
And cant not win upon the hearts of Thee!
Enjoy your earthen thoughts: minds full of fire
Can never grovel, but do all apire.
Madam! Tis true I've writ ome Plays, and wood
I had the happines to call them good,
I would be proud on't: for my love unto
And though ome think't a fault, I know it none;
There is no poyon grows on Helicon.
You are reolv'd: but I do think it fit
That you on better things emploid your wit;
And o I leave you. Madam, Fare you well;
And what I've aid, unto my Daughers tell.
Mend your own faults: be not o proud of your
One portion, as if no body had more;
And when that you have Suitors, do not care
Them away with looks like th'angry God of war.
But I mut leave her: For I ee another
That for her wit may call my Madam mother.
She is a young one, lately married to
A Lord: Now let us ee what he will do.
Sir, I am glad to ee you; Madam I
Rejoyce to hear of your good fortune; why?
You have a noble and rich husband; So
I did deerve for what I brought you know.
Were I but uch a man I would not wed
So low, and rather keep a ingle bed.
I am an Hogen Mogens daughter; good,
You may boat of your wealth, not of your blood.
Of my Husband I may. Indeed tis true;
But he was much to blame to marry you:
Sir, you do wrong me much: and I do pray
To me you would not dedicate a Play,
I corn to own uch Trifles; I did hear
'Twas your Intent, which if it was, forbear:
A Poet once of your acquaintance did,
But for his awcines he was well chid.
Madam know this, I do not write for gain,
My pleaure is the Guerdon of my pain;
And never with one mean to trouble you,
Though it were acted in a publick Stew.
I know the Poet you poke of, and know
It was his want that forc'd him thereunto;
He knew you was unfit for't, and that cant
Could undertand a Scene o ignorant.
Therefore learn this; The rich the poor do praie,
Not for their merits, but their tock to raie:
And tis no doubt but he did give you high
Titles of worth, yet knew himelf did lye.
Take your unpay'd for Coach, and to Hide-Park,
And (Madam) when the Cuckow ings, pray heark;
It is a muick you can manage; or end
For a Croud of Fidlers and their skill commend;
Know, that for you tis an impoible thing
The hear the weet and olemn Mues ing:
An earthen minde hath earthen thoughts, and they
That noble Souls have noble things urvey.
Madam adieu! Think of me what you will,
Of your Opinion I am careles till.
Whether this Lady angry be or no
I do not care at all; So let her go.
Go into Gray's Inn Walks, and you hall ee
Matter for Satyres in each Companie;
This Lady comes to how her new fine Gown,
And this to ee the Gallants of the town.
Mot part of Gentlemen thither repair,
To cenure who is foul, and who is fair.
Yon Lady in th'red Sattin looks o pale,
That eirher he hath th' Green-icknes, or is tale.
She in the Hat and Feather looks o like
An Amazonian Toer of a Pike,
She's fit for a fiery Captain: yon's a face
Pretty and beautiful at the firt Gaze;
But view it eriouly, and it is light.
What an old womans that with a young Knight?
Sure tis his Grand-mother, or great Aunt; alas!
He had much rather a walk'd with a young Las.
O, ays a young Lady to her brother, when
Did you ee o complete a Gentleman?
Has he not curious legs? fine curled hair?
How well the Suite is made that he doth wear!
I would my Husband were o handome: So
He is her brother wears, but he ighs no.
Yon Gallant's gate is like unto a Dance,
Sure he's return'd but newly out of France;
Yon's like a fools or clowns, I know not whether,
And (if h'as any wit) hee'l oon go thither,
Says a Lady to her husband: He replide,
See how that woman walks! with what a pride,
She very lately was a City-wife
But now a Lord o'th Court hath chang'd her life:
Her Husband being dead, and he left rich,
She for a title of more height did itch;
Which her good fortune got her: In her own
Conceit he is the onely happy one;
She thinks her Husband loves her, and I dare
Be worn that he for her doth nothing care.
When he at night comes in, towards him he trips,
And he mut kis her though he lothe her lips,
Which out of his affection he doth doe,
She thinks, but I have told you what is true.
Vain, windy honour! what a ought for thing!
'Twill make a Kettle have a ilver ring.
Survey a Tavern; Not a Room but will
Deerve a Satyre, they are all o ill.
Here is a Gentleman that hath a mack
Of riming with a Poet at his back,
And half a dozen of his drunken friends,
Who doth adopt him on for what he pends;
Praies his Poems for the bet that were
(Since H • ngist time) writ in the Englih aire:
And (For 'tis vain to go to Delphos now
For Oracles) Son! read my lines, and thou
(Cryes he) wilt ay Apollo never coo'd
(God of the acred Mues) write as good.
He wears as many oathes as he repeates
Veres, then calls for the dear't Fowl, and eates,
Beg's mony when the reckning's paid, and o
(Having fil'd his Tobacco-box) doth go.
Another chamber view, and you may find
Gentlemen taggering with wine as wind;
See healths drunk round & round; To her that lies
By Suffolk-houe, and hath the fine blackeies;
Unto whoe Lodgings he dares not repair,
Becaue he will not marry but an Heir;
To the rich Lady Widow that did invite
Him kindly unto upper yeternight, (great)
Who (though his means be mal, her joyntu • e
Without his company can eat no meat;
To the rich Citizens daughter (gallant Girle!)
The laft Mask full of Diamonds and Pearle.
Were you within the next Room, you might ee
A Gentleman with a great Companie
Of mical'd Captains, and Rorers that think (drink;
Oathes (Sugar-like) weeten each Glas they
A pretious Engle! Hug'd over, and over, and tyl'd
An hopeful park, or they are all beguil'd;
The Table full of Pottles, Pintes, and Quartos,
And they a humouring him with ome old parts
Of the lat Coranto's, or perhaps ome thing
Of Note, perform'd by the late Sweden King.
They call for what they lit, meaning that he
Shall pay the reck'ning for th' whole Companie;
Which when he hath, they teal what plate they can
Finger, and part, and laugh at th' idle man.
I'le not go up two pair of tairs, yet there
Could be Satyrical as well as here.
And now I end, deiring thoe that know
Themelves touch'd in thee lines away to goe
Silent, and mend; For every thing is true:
And though I neither do name him, nor you,
Believ't I could & that I would. But (faith!)
Would you not be revenged? Do; Show your wrath,
Of me go and write Satyres, for (I know it)
My faults will erve although you are no Poet.
HAving reolv'd in Numbers great and high
To ing our Brutus Flight from Italie;
How in this Iland he arriv'd, and fought
Till he it under his Subjection brought;
Here reing'd ome years in peace, & when he di'de
To his three Sons did all the whole divide:
And being prepar'd to write, a udden noie
Of a Coach did occaion me to rie,
Conjecturing whom it might be that did come,
Till a new day approch'd our Dining-room.
She was no ooner entred in the Place,
With her fair hand dipers'd Night from her face
By taking off her mask, and with a free
Well-pleaing Garbe look'd on the Companie,
(My eies being all the while fix'd on her face,
Atonih'd at her beauty, and her grace)
But I both igh'd and trembled; For I aw
The winged Boy did follow her in awe,
And was become her Champion, to ubject
All mankind at her feet that dare reflect
Rah looks on her. Alas! had I epide
The fatal God, ere I her Beauties eyde,
The ight of his reitles bow had oon
(With down cat eies) made me to leave the room.
To him he turning cornfully, did finde
No haft in's hand, I had it in my minde,
And aid; Why Truant, do you uffer thus
A rah preumptuous youth to gaze on us?
He humbly gave this anwer; Madam, you
May be appeas'd, he oon his fault will rue;
When he came hither firt, he did intend
A mighty Epick Poem to have pen'd;
But now that reolution will depie,
And court your favours in oft Elegies:
Before he had withdrawn his eies he found
His yeilding heart aaulted with a wound.
This aid, a pretty, and didainful look
She cat upon me, and her leave then took
Of thoe he came to viit, leaving me
Poet with ad thoughts of my Mierie.
Away (Great Mars) igh'd I, when he was gone,
And welcome (Gentle Venus) with thy Son;
The horrid wars that I did mean to write
(In tately numbers) of the Trojan Knight,
I mut convert to ofter Layes, and prove
All ways t'incline her noble heart to Love.
Fair glory of your Sex! when you have read
My name ubcrib'd, and find who's conquered,
Blame not my weaknes; know your eies are trong,
And can do what they will, or right or wrong.
I did not look to love, onely to ee,
And was enthral'd when I leat thought to be.
Be kind; or (if you needs will tyrannize)
Ile be your Martyr, burn me with your eies.
But let me live; For th' Art is more profound,
To ave a dying Man, then kill a Sound

div.head: 3. To my Mrs. before Mr. Mayes Lucan that I ent her.

lg.l: Pardon me Lady, that I dare invent
Lines neither worth your view, nor my intent.
Nero did murther Lucan, but I doe
Expect a life, and not a death from you:
With Pio and the learned Seneca
He treaon againt Caear did aay;
Yet's Emperour gave him leave to chooe by what
Means he would undergo the Law of Fate.
I never did conceive a thought that you
Might think offence, unles affection true;
And that hould not your indignation move:
The Gods will give us leave their Heaven to love
He lives unto Report, and o hall I
(If lain) demontrate your great Cruelty.
You are my Empres; under your fair hand
Send me what Detiny you will command.
My Fate is what you pleae to have it: I
Live by your kindnes, or your coynes dye.
Lady, in your applaue vere goes
As low and dull as heavy proe;
And your known worthes (would you ubmit
Your elf a ubject unto Wit)
Would blunt invention, and (ore'come
With trong Amaze) make Poets dumbe.
By what means then hall I declare
My thoughts at height, or what you are?
A world of Paper would but be
My love in an Epitome:
Fair Lady, therefore do not look
For my affection in a book:
Search my life through, and if you find
Not what I can do, be unkind.
Petrarch, for the neat Sonnets he did frame
In Laura's praie, obtain'd a Poets Name:
I of my Mitres write in vere, and how it,
And yet I do profes I am no Poet.
They feign, but I peak truth; what they invent
(Out of long tudy) for a Complement,
In me is earnet; Thoe rich words that they
Enforce upon ome beauties, I can lay
With reverence on you whom I adore,
And Times to come may as a Saint implore;
Then unto all may you propitious be,
I wih to heaven you now were o to me.
Believe, becaue thee are unmooth, my wit
Dul'd with amazement, and my hand unfit
To hold a pen o teddy as to write,
Let ome Offence hould frutrate my delight.
Your Beauty is my wonder: That you hould
Prove merciles, my fear: but my mot bold,
And happiet earthly wih is, That you may
With kindnes ave whom ele your beauties lay.
Lady I love, and (if you can
Believe there is a faith in man)
No one can think a Mitres fitter,
Nor any love a Mitris better.
When I do look on you, I corn
The roie bluhes of the morn;
When I do hear you peak, I know
No muick can o weetly go;
When I at firt your lips did touch,
I thought Jove never met with uch;
I tated Odours in your breath
Able to win a Soul from death;
All things that have been by you, mell
So fragrant after, and o well,
That Flora may be banihed,
And you elected in her tead.
My ences being yours, make all
My future days one Fetival:
And comfort me who now am ad,
Leat loing Senes I grow mad.
Now after tedious weeks of being mute,
The Mitres of my life I do alute.
As it is in your power to make each line
Of Poeie I write to you, divine;
(For if you kindly mile on them, you give
Ability enough to make them live)
So is it in your power (if you would pleae
To peak thoe words) to raie me unto eae;
For unto me, Enceladus doth lye
In flakes of Snow, and I in Fiers dye.
Do not believe I counterfeit, who think
Veres in your praie would trancolour Inke;
And your Glas an Elizium, where one may
Behold your Shadow ere your dying day;
And that reflection I had rather view
Then all the beauties in the world but you.
Had I your Picture reaonably wrought,
No Lady like it hould command my thought;
Pigmalion-like I would adore't, until
You did prove kind, or me my griefes did kill.
Think not I do diemble; For who can
Look on your face unmov'd, that is a man?
Who it'hath heard your voice, but he will ay
Your Tongue can charm all hearers to obey?
And who hath touch'd your lips, but like unto
A Lethe-drinker, forgets all ave you?
But I am extaied! you are above
My bet expreions though I am in love.
When I look on your Ribband-knots, I find
That my rah gazing eies have thral'd my mind:
For they become you o exceeding well,
That they have tide my toung, I cannot tell.
When I perceive the wanton Windes to play
With your unequal'd hair, amaz'd I tay,
And bles their happines; that they can move
Thoe amorous trees and not fall in love.
When you into Hide Parke do go, all there
To follow the race-riders do forbear,
And all of them unanimouly approch,
And (as if waiters) do attend your Coach;
That your fair eys may hine on them, whoe light
Doth et their hearts on fier at the ight;
And force vows from them, that for your dear ake
Of greatet toils they greatet joys would make.
But what do I do then! I nothing can;
Your beauties make a Statue of a Man.
I cannot look and talke to you like ome;
Lady! your matchles Beauties trike me dumbe.
But when I am retired, and alone,
My reolutions then do yeild to none;
Regard, reward my earnet love, and o
Raie me to heights of joy from depths of wo.
Lady, from Cornwall unto you I writ,
But my hard Fates kept you from eeing it.
How glad had I been if that you had known
That there I was yours much more then mine own!
Each wind that blew I lov'd, becaue I thought
The ound thereof might to your ears be brought;
Each Showre that came I wih'd of gold, and that
Jove-like I fell into my Danae's lap:
Each tar I aw put me in minde of thee;
But th'art too fair a little tar to be.
I went to Sea, and when I there was come,
I thought of him that to his Hero wom,
And wih't o you did love as he did him,
That like Leander I to you might wim.
But now I am return'd again, be you
As kind to me as you have found me true.
Awake my Mue put on thy bet attire
To ing her Beauty, and my raging fire:
Make all the world know, (ince he will not know)
That he is much to blame to ue me o.
Sweet, cruel, fair one! (unto all of thee
You may reply caues of my uneae)
For you are weet as flowry May's wet wind;
Why hould o weet a Creature be unkinde?
And you are fair, and fair, and weet mut be,
The reaon I endure your Cruelty.
Each Statue I ee makes me my Cae thus mone;
It hath a Body, you an heart of tone.
I fain would die, but thinking I mut come
To be a wanderer in Elizium,
I do detroy that infant-thought; for there
No Soul's o pure as is your body here.
Each night my troubled thoughts keep leep away;
That time's to me as buie as the day:
But you that are with never a care oppret,
Enamour the night Deities in your ret;
Old Somnus fears his wand may do ome ill,
And therefore charms your eies with kies till.
O that I knew the way whereby to move
My weet and cruel fair One unto love!
Will ighing do it? O you Gods of wind!
Lend me your breathes that I may igh her kind:
Will tears prevail? O that my eies would then
Melt out themelves into an Ocean!
Or may Entreaties win upon her ene?
Ait me all you Powers of eloquence;
Pity my mieries which are grown o high,
That you mut pity them, or I hall die:
And be not henceforth harh; That I may finde
My weet and fair One like a Goddes kinde.
Fair Mitres, though my fate is o advere,
That I could rather weep then ing in vere;
Yet one or two I'le force my Mue to write,
And you with your own Cruelty delight.
Me-thoughts when lat I heard the Nightingal,
She did not mention her own woes at all;
But every note that pat my litning ear
Did make me my own miery to hear:
It was a change worthy her skill, for he
Will ing the addet things, and therefore me.
Pity a man in Hell, for there I am,
I could not ele live o amidt my flame;
And make my joyes with all my ufferings even;
But two kind words, and I hall be in Heaven.
Dear Lady, from your eies there came
A lightning did my heart inflame,
And et it all on burning o,
That forth the fire will never go.
Be merciful, for I remain,
Till you be kind, in endles pain;
And (machles fair One) deign to know
That pity hould with beauty goe;
That comely bodies hould include
Mindes in them equally as good.
I will not doubt you until I
Have reaon from your Crueltie.
Since we deformed bodies finde
To be the Emblems of the minde;
Why hould not I purue that art,
And think one fair hath uch an heart?
Confirm Philoophie, which you
By being merciful may do:
And unto the eternal praie
Of your rich Beauty I will raie
A fame o high, that times to come
Of your deare name hall ne're be dumbe;
So you with Roalinde hall be
Eterniz'd unto Memorie,
With Stella live; names known as well
As Colin Clout, and Atrophel.
As kindnes in a Lady can
Preerve in life a dying man;
So veres (after he is dead)
Report will of her pread.
Return affection, and we then
Shall live though die, and live agen.
I have mine eyes and love: for who
Hath eyes to ee and doth not o?
Who can behold a lovely face,
Both full of beauty and of grace;
See pretty lips, and glorious eyes,
And not be chang'd though ne're o wie?
Rich Cherry-cheeks, and browes Divine,
And not deire would he were mine?
I have a Lady lately een
Far perfecter then beauties Queen;
Diana's vertues make her tai'd,
And Venus forme a lovely Maid;
Surely two Goddees have trove
To make a wonder of my Love:
No Beauty Venus lets her want;
And Dian hath made her a Saint,
To pray to Saints many deny,
And cenure for idolatry;
But none of them will ay I erre
If I with prayers petition her.
Deign therefore virtuous, beauteous Fair,
(You that are more then others are
For beauty whom all wonder at,
And for your vertues emulate)
Pity my heart by you enflam'd;
For cruelty be not defam'd:
Nor joy to ee my mieries rage,
Which your tongue onely can awage;
But a true ervice entertain,
Rewarding it with love again.

div.head: 14. Before a little Book of my own that I ent her.

lg.l: Lady, I do not give this Book alone,
But with't my heart, which you have made your own:
Cenure my veres as you pleae; but be
Kind to my heart, let you do ruine me.
I made thee little Poems, and (if you
Vouchafe your love to me) you make me too.
Be kind as you are fair, I wih no other;
So make a doubtful man an happy Lover.
Be kind (blind Boy) and let not her alone;
Tis tyranny in thee to hoot at one.
Me thou hat wounded, he untouch'd remains;
Slights all my Sighs, and credits not my pains.
If th' hat an Arrow (though but one) behind
Strike her, and make us both be of one mind.
Thou God of Love born in an happy hour
In ome freh Garden in ome flowry Bower,
I, by thy wings fill'd with the ighes of thy
Fat- • erter'd Subjects, by thy Quiver, and by
Thy fatal Bow, by Venus drawn along
Olympus Star-pav'd Courts (the Gods among)
If thou dot ever hope eternal Jove
Will eyes vouchafe unto the God of Love;
By thee and more I do beeech thine aide,
Or make me mine, or mine, this Angel-Maide.
Pity my miery, and take my part;
Or heal my wound, or wound her cruel heart.
Fair Love! Sole Centre of my thoughts! to you
I am a Suppliant, be my Judge and true;
Cenure my pa • ons, prayers, affections, me
Throughly and narrowly, and (if you ee
No fault in me, as you no fault hall finde)
Leave off your cruelty, and be you kinde.
Ue me according to my love, if I
Adore you not, let me unpitied die.

div.head: 16. At her going out of the Countrey.

lg.l: Farewell fair Saint! But when you are away
And far remote, think of me once a day.
When hall I ee again your Amber-haire?
Look on your tately forehead, arched fair?
View thoe two Suns, your heart-bewitching eies?
Your Noe, and Mouth, and all your Rarities?
Hear your weet tongue again, whoe words alone
Would make deaf Mortalls hear, if not a tone?
Not till I come to London: Phoebus, hie;
Drive not the Sun o lowly through the skie.
If thee hort dayes, thee Winter-days will eem
So tedious, then what hould I think of them
If they were Summer-Hours? Surely I
Should wih (like Phaeton) thou might't fall & die:
For in your abence I hall take delight
In Dreams of you t'wear out the longet Night.
I love, and that is all that I can ay;
My vehement thoughts take all my words away.
The more I think to write, I can the les:
His heart is afe who can his love expres.
Know I am yours much more then I can tell,
And ay (with grief) weet't of your Sex! Farewell.

div.head: 17. At my Return, having brought her the firt days Journey.

lg.l: Farewell again, Fair Mitres of my heart;
For you mut go, and I mut now depart.
My body doth return; my heart doth tay:
You it along with you do bear away.
Lay it by yours, thither it would withdraw;
The fire of mine the frot of yours may thaw.
Farewel dear eies: It will be tedious Night
With me as long as I do want your light.
Farewell weet mouth, encompas'd with a row
Of richet Cherries over and below;
The Nectar and Ambroia I hall want
That hang on them, and fat an irkome Lent.
Farewel bet tongue; Now thee I hall not hear,
I would not care if all things ilent were.
Farewell all fair! Beauty I hall not view,
Until again I do behold't in you.
All things befriend you; Hyems, do not frown
Keep Boreas till, and all his Brethren down.
Be of a kind Apect, and look not pale
With frot or Snow; not ullenly let fall
Showr's from thine eies; Be milde, that Phoebus may
Waite on my lovely mitres every day.
So he may hap to favour thee; which thing
May change the Winter to another Spring.
My lat Farewel: Till I in London ee
My Love again, I hall a mourner be.
Hail my Delight! whom I o well lov'd here,
Do now love there and will love every where.
I hope you do not doubt my faith: For I
Know I adore you o I daily die.
When you was here my paion was o great,
That I did bow and ink down under it:
But now y'are gone my Love is o extreme,
I am ditracted: when your happy name
I think upon, your beauty, Goodnes, all
What you include, I into madnes fall;
Rave at thee days that do divide us two,
At thee low hours that keep me from you.
Thus I affect: would you did love me o,
That when we meet there might not pas a No.
Tell me how doth that richet jewel, your
Unkindet heart againt all love endure?
Although Diana's Charms environ round,
And circle it, to keep it from a wound;
Yet Cupids Dart hath greater force then thoe,
And when he pleae can peirce it with his throws.
And I will make uch prayers to him, that he
Shall be reveng'd (unto the height) for me:
It's ears be not deaf as his eyes be blind,
I'le make him hear me, and he'l make you kind.
You cannot (fairet Maid) your Fate remove:
Yield therefore not by force, but will to love.
I will not now implore a Mue, not One
Of the inhabiters of Helicon:
Neither Apollo, he that doth above
Sing Sacred Anthems to eternal Jove:
If you (weet Mitres) will vouchafe to be
Gracious, and read, each line will come off free.
Since I beheld your Beauty I've forgot
My former pleaures, and now know them not:
I've no Delight but you, and you are o
Unkind to me you are my torment too.
Unmerciful Detinies! that do unite
A cruel torment with a weet delight.
But be you far more harder-hearted then
Was ever Lady yet to any man;
Though Daphne-like you hun, and run away;
Like Phoebus I behind you will not tay.
You are regardles, and will lend no ear
Unto my vows, nor my entreaties hear:
Deign therefore, you immortal Deities
That reign enthroned in the lofty Skies;
Hear, and redres my wrongs, pity my mone,
Or make her's fleh, or mine an heart of tone;
Or guide her tongue that thence kind words may
Or trik me deaf, or trik my Mitres dumb: (come,
Yet is her tongue all Muick, and o rare,
It makes me even to love my own depair.
For Neptunes ake, whoe Trident awes the Sea,
Pale Luna hine with an aupicious ray.
If thou dot love the bright delicious bride
Of Mulciber, Mars be thou on my ide.
By thy wing'd feet, and by thy Charmed wand,
A gracious influence, Mercury, I command.
For Alcumena's Night, and for her Child,
The Monter-Queller, Jupiter be mild.
If ever thou didt love Adonis deare,
Now Venus favour me in thy Careere.
If thou dot hope Jove will allow thee peace
In heaven, that did affor'd thee mall in Greece;
On Lovers (Saturne) gently mile, and joyn
(With th'other Six) to perfect my deign.
By all Ver's various flowers, and Autumns fruit,
Sol, I implore thee to complete my uit.
If me the Planets do befriend in this,
Her Cruelty cannot withtand my blis;
Againt the Stars there is no triving, he
Mut yield unto her Fate, which is to me;
And (Lady) if their beams be gracious, know,
I mean to have you whether you will or no.
My love (Dear Soul) is grown unto that height,
That when I cannot ee you I mut write:
By my affection, now I am from you,
You may perceive my former words were true.
Doubt me not (Lady!) rather doubt the Sun
(Dah'd out with Ocean waves) will ceae to run:
Believe the Moon, pale Cynthia of the night,
Will leave her Sphere, and on the earth a light;
And th' other Planets (frighted a this change)
Will tand till in a maze, and leave to range;
Believe old Neptune miing of his Deare,
Will be dul'd into calmnes out of fear;
Suppoe the earth wanting the Light Divine
That nourih't it, will never more be green;
Believe the earth agreeing yet with Heaven,
Into another Chaos will be driven;
Imagine what you will, true or untrue;
But never think I can be fale to you.
Know that if you affection will return,
That now Im'warm, and will hereafter burn;
That now I curb my paions; but will then
Give way unto them, love, and love agen.
We'l not be parted, be not you ingrate,
By Lands, or Seas, by friends or foes, or fate.
Dear Saint, I do love you o well,
You cannot think, nor I can tell.
As when from earth ome look on high,
And ee the Lights that grace the skie,
They think them mall, becaue they eem
Not unto them to be extreme;
So you perchance when you do read
My Love dres'd in o poor a weed
As my weak Mue can frame, will traight
Or think it counterfeit, or light:
But could my hand expres my minde,
You would no longer be unkinde;
For tis o full of love to you,
You cannot think, nor I can hew.
May you (fair Sweet) live long and happily:
But do not you live o that I mut dye.
Be kind; for if you chance to frown I fall:
Your No is equal to the Fates ad Call.
A curious Limner dares profes a Strife
With Nature, thinks with art to match the life:
O that my pen could draw my heart, and you
Be won (by certainties) to know me true!
How many thouand prayers would you read over!
How many vows profeed by your Lover!
What a poor martyr you would ee! An heart,
Dying in flames becaue you care not for't!
• hall I believe you always will remain
• o careles of me, and o light my pain?
• 'le not depair; when you leat think to be
Kind unto me, the Gods may pity me;
Make you with me in an affection joyn
