And mollifie your heart as much as mine,
To acred Hymen their high wills reveal,
And make him ign our Loves with his broad eal
Nor will I wih (if you do light me ever)
That you may love, and may be pitied never;
Far be it from me: onely that you may
Sigh once, weep one tear, and wear black one day
But I will hope you may be kind, and (though
Y'are trange o long) not always ue me o.
Pity your Servant; if I do not prove
Worthy of your love, then withdraw your love.

div.head: 23. To her reolved to go beyond Sea.

lg.l: Unkind, fair Mitres! are not frowns and Noes
Enough, to fill your Servant full of woes?
Can you not be cruel enough, unles
You leave this Kingdom, and do pas the Seas?
Like unto Caear would you have me fall
With many wounds, and triumph over all?
Though, when y'are gon my fate is ad, I will
Wih you all good though you wih me all ill.
May Neptune proud of uch a burthen, mooth
His old and angry Face, and fall in love;
May not an advere winde as much as breath;
That you may mile upon the Seas beneath.
Were I not wondrous true, intead of prayers
I hould ue imprecations, cure the tars,
Wih Neptune with his powerful Trident throw
The waters from the Centre, and below
In that Abys ink down your Ship, and then
The raging winds blow back the Seas agen
And cover you, that women henceforth may
Beware, and earnet love with earnet pay.
But I am patient, and (though in vaine
I love) I dare not therefore be profane.
May you arrive afely and oon, and live
In all felicity whil't I here grieve,
And igh, and weep for you; may not a thought
Of yours remember me, (be I forgot)
Let when you think how you have left me, you
Should give a top unto your mirth, and rue.
But one word more; it is not yet too late
To make a wretched Lover fortunate:
Let not my prayers, ighes, vows be pent in vain,
But as I do love you, o love again;
And we will go together, never part,
Till I your body have who have my heart;
Which had I in poeion, I hould finde
Ways oon enough to win your backward mind.
Although he cannot number thouands, even
With ome deform'd, whom Fortune more hath given;
Shall want of wealth (corn'd by true happines)
Reit my way, or make me love her les?
Yet hath he a fair Portion, and her Name
From one of our bet Houes, Coritane;
And he is beauteous as a cheerful day,
Or Venus riing from her Mother-Sea.
Are not her teeth the richet Pearls? and ure
He that hath Pearls enow cannot be poor;
Are not her radiant eies two diamonds fair?
And we all know that thoe tones precious are;
Art not her hairs of Gold? And what but it (fit?
Makes wrinkles mooth; Age, youth; unfit things,
Her beauteous Cheekes are Roes, uch as neither
The Spring can give, nor the cold Winter wither.
Her lovely Breats are Apples of more worth
Then ever the Heperides brought forth;
Arabian Odours, both the India's Good
She in one curious body doth include;
Cupid in nothing more his eies doth mis,
Then that he cannot ee how fair he is.
Jupiter for her would unthrone his Queen,
And Pluto leave his lovely Proerpine;
Neptune from Amphitrite would remove,
And Mars for her forake the Queen of love.
She's like a Soul before it doth depart;
Even all in all, and All in every part.
No man hath een her, but to every Sence
Of him he bettereth the intelligence;
He knows his eies are perfect in their ight,
That in no other Object can delight;
He knows his melling's exquiite that doth
When he hath felt her breath all others loth;
A perfume for the Gods mot fit, and weet
When they (at Counel) on Olympus meet,
And Iris they or Mercury beneath
Tis likely end for her o fragrant breath:
A free and unconfined touching her
Above the lips of Queens all would prefer,
Or acred hands of bounteous Kings; compar'd
The pretious Down of Phoenix's being hard
Unto her ofter skin: And her weet Tongue
Which chides in Muick, and enchantes in ong,
And trikes the ablet Rhetoricians dumb,
Is fit't to plead the peace of Chritendom;
He in the phere of happines will move
On whom he pleaes to betow her love,
And have the mot delicious Repat
That hall her Hymenaean Dainties tat.
You that are beauty in the Zenith, who
Can find no Equal whereoer'e you go,
My Love no longer cruelly depie,
But dart me mercy from your gracious eyes,
And we hall both be rich: For I am ure,
Themelves no happy Lovers ere thought poore.
Pat are my ighs, and woes, complaints, and tears,
Nor am I longer ubject to my fears;
Her frowns no more trike terrour to my oul,
Though I was wounded he hath made me whole.
Within the rank of happy Lovers I
Am now enrol'd, and march triumphantly
Ore all the Croes that before did tay,
And hinder me to enter in this way,
And ing the Boy-Gods praie, who (wanting ight)
Shot at my Mitres and did hit the White.
My happines is uch, that Times to come
Shall not complain I of my joys was dumbe.
Let him whoe Mitres is deform'd or old,
Not worth a Sonnet nor a Line, withhold:
Or (if on uch an heap of years, or ad
Chaos of features, he will needs run mad;
Looe the true judgement of his eyes, or think
That Channel water's Nectar he doth drink)
Let him profes he's happy ne're o much,
The World that ees her cannot think him uch.
'Twere fondnes in me, that what ere my youth
Writ in her praie I now hould ay was truth;
I would not if I could: but to be jut
To her, and to my elf, thus much I mut.
I'm o far from repenting of my choice,
That every day he's dearer in mine eyes.
Dear heart! and dearer to me then mine heart!
We'l live in love, and in our loves depart.
The World hall bles our Fates, and they that come
Into ad bonds, wih happy Lovers dumb

div.head: 1. On the Death of my very good Friend Mr. Micha • l Drayton.

lg.l: PHoebus, art thou a God, and cant not give
A Priviledge unto thine own to live?
Thou cant: But if that Poets nere hould dye,
In Heaven who hould praie thy Deity?
Thy life had been immortal as thy wit.
But Spencer is grown hoare, he that of late

Song Glorian •
in her Elfin tate:
And o is Sydney, whom we yet admire
Lighting our little Torches at his fire.
Thee have o long before Apollo's Throne
Carrel'd Encomiums that they now are growne
Weary and faint; and therefore thou didt dye,
Their weet unfinih'd Ditty to upply
So was the Iliad-writer rapt away;
Before his lov'd Achilles fatall day,
And when his voice began to fail, the great
<…> did aume his eat:
Therefore we mut not mourn, unles it be
<> none is left worthy to follow thee.
It is in vain to ay thy lines are uch
As neither time not envies rage can touch:
For they mut live, and will whiles there's an eye
To reade, or wit to judge of Poetrie
You Swans of Avon, change your fates, and all
Sing, and then die at Drayton's Funeral:
Sure hortly there will not a drop be een,
And the mooth-pebbled Bottom be turn'd green,
When the Nymphes (that inhabit in it) have
(As they did Shakespeere) wept thee to thy grave.
But I molet thy quiet; leep, whil't we
That live, would leave our lives to die like thee.

div.head: 2. On my dear Siter Mrs. Iabella Cokaine, who who died at Ashbourne about the 18th yeer of her Age, and lyes there buried.

lg.l: IT is an irreligious pride to turne
Away our eyes, and not to ee thine Urne.
For ure that body whoe blet oul doth keep
A Jubile in heaven, (while here aleep
It lies in holy earth) is every day
Bles'd by good Angels, that do pas that way:
And therefore we with reverence hould eye
The Sepulchres where Saints entomb'd do lye:
And every time that we do go or come
Nigh where thine Ahes lye, behold thy Tombe
But when we ee it, hould we weep our eyes
Dry of their tears, and then conclude in cries?
It is impoible that our complaints
Should make a Diapaon to the Saints.
• an Hallelujahs ong above agree
With tears on earth? Tis an Antipathie
But 'tis unnatural we hould be glad,
And 'tis Impiety we hould be ad:
We mut not grieve therefore, nor yet rejoyce;
But fix us in the mean, and hew us wie.
Be glad, that we believe her oul is crown'd
With endles Glory in Heavens ample Round:
Onely lament that we have lot our guide,
And (wanting her) are apt to wander wide
We need not bid thee leep ecure, that know
That God himelf rock'd thee aleep below.
Sweet Sainted Maid, thou meritet the Pen
Of Cherubims to hew thee unto men:
And dot deerve a bench of Poets grave
To tudy, and to write thine Epitaph,
Which in Moaick work with diamonds bright
Should be drawn out, and read by it's own light
A Titian, or a Bonarota hould
Cat thee a Statue of pure Ophir Gold:
Had't thou thy due, the eager earth would ure
Anatomize one India for Ore
And precious tones, a Pyramid to reare,
Lating and great as the Egyptian were,
To thy eternal memorie; and from
Th e eatern-lands bring all the plenteous um
Of pices and perfumes, and on the height
Of that rich monument burn them day and night
But 'tis a thing impoibly too hard
For men on earth to give thee thy reward:
Thy God, whoe power and love is infinite,
Thee hath, and doth, and ever will requite
Among the Chorus of Heavens Virgins pure,
To ing Divinet Anthems evermore.
The homely veres I have writ, he oft
Hath mil'd upon, approv'd them mooth and oft:
And if my pen hath power to give a fame,
Dear Iabella, here hall live thy Name.
Had I the deathles Homer's brain, and could
Sing lofty numbers like to Maro Old;
A wit to match Sulmonean Ovid, I
Had writ a Poem, not an Elegie.
Tis known, and I confes this is beneath
Her Life, and her expreions at her death:
Her reurrection plain will hew how well
She led her life, and bad the World Farewel.

div.head: 3. On the death of Henry Lord Hatings, Son to the right Honourable Ferdinand Earl of Huntingdon, &c.

lg.l: KNow all to whom thee few ad lines hall come,
This melancholy Epicedium,
The young Lord Hatings death occaion'd it,
Tempets of ighes and grones, and flowing eyes
Whoe yielding balls diolve to Deluges:
And mournful Numbers that with dreadful ound
Waite his bemoned body to the ground,
Are all, and the lat duties we can pay
The Noble Spirit that is fled away.
Tis gone, alas! tis gone, though it did leave
A body rich in all Nature could give;
Superiour in beauty to the youth
That won the Spartan Queen to forfeit truth,
Break wedlocks trictet bonds, and be his wife;
Environed with tumults all her Life.
His years were in the balmie Spring of Age
Adorn'd with bloomes ripe for marriage,
And but mature; His weet conditions known
To be o good they could be none but's own.
Our Englih Nation was enamour'd more
On his full worth, then Rome was heretofore
Of great V •• pa •• an's Jew-ubduing Heire,
The love and the Delight of mankind here.
After a large urvey of Hitories,
Our Criticks (curious in honour, wie
In paralleling generous Souls) will finde
This youthful Lord did bear as brave a minde.
His few but well pent years had mater'd all
The liberal Arts: And his weet tongue could fall
Into the ancient Dialects, dipence
Sacred Judeas amplet eloquence;
And Greek as rich as Athens ever knew:
Italy, France, and Spain, did all confes
Him perfect in their modern Languages,
At his Nativity, what angry Star
Malignant influences lung o far?
What Caput Algolls, and what dire Apects,
Occaioned o tragical effects?
As oon as death this fatal blow had given,
I fancy mighty Clarence igh'd in Heaven;
And till this glorious Soul arrived there,
Recover'd not from his Amaze and fear.
Had this befal'n in ancient credulous times,
He had been deifi'd by Poets rimes;
That Age enamour'd of his Graces, oon
Majetick Fanes (in adoration)
Would have rays'd to his memory, and there
On golden Altars (year ucceeding year)
Burnt holy incene, and Sabaean Gums,
That Curles of vapour from thoe Hecatombs,
Sould reach his Soul in Heaven: but we mut pay
No uch Oblations in our purer way:
A nobler Service we him owe then that,
His fair example ever t'emulate.
With the Advantage of our double years
Lets imitate him, and (through all Affairs,
And all Encounters of our Lives) intend
To live like him, and make as good an end.
To aim at brave things is an evident igne
In Spirits, that to honour they incline;
And though they do come hort in the Contet,
Tis full of glory to have done one's bet.
You mournful Parents whom the Fates compel
To bear the Los of this great miracle,
This wonder of our Times, amidt a igh
(Surrounded with your thick't Calamity)
Reflect on joy, think what an happines
(Though humane Nature oft conceits it les)
It was to have a Son of o much worth,
He was too good to grace the wretched earth.
As ilver Trent through our North Countries glides,
Adorn'd with Swans, & crown'd with flowry ides,
And ruhing into mightier Humbers Waves,
Augments the Regal Aetuarium's Braves:
So he, after a life of eighteen years
Well mannaged Example to our Peeres,
In's early youth encountring ullen Fate,
(Orecome) became a Trophey to his State.
Didt thou leep Hymen? or art lately grown
T'affect the Subterranean Region?
Enamour'd on bleard Libentina's eyes,
Hoare-howling Dirges, and the baleful Cries
Of Inaupicious voices, and (above
Thy Star-like torch) with horrid tombs in love?
Thou art; or urely hadt oppos'd this high
Affront of death againt thy Deity:
Nor wrong'd an excellent Virgin who had given
Her heart to him, who hath his Soul to Heaven;
Whoe Beauties thou hat clouded, and whoe eyes
Drowned in tears at thee ad Exequies.
The fam'd Heroes of the golden Age,
Thoe Demigods whoe vertues did awage
And calm the furies of the wildet mindes
That were grown alvage even againt their kinds,
Might from their Contellations have look'd down
And by this young Lord een themelves out-gon.
Farewel (Admired Spirit) that art free
From this trict Prion of Mortalitie.
Ahby, proud of the honour to enhrine
The beauteous Body (whence the Soul Divine
Did lately part) be careful of thy trut,
That no profane hand wrong that hallow'd Dut.
The Cotly Marble needes no friend t'engrave
Upon it any doleful Epitaph;
No good Man's tongue that Office will decline,
Whil't years ucceeding reach the end of time.

div.head: 4. On the death of my dear Couin Germane Mrs. Olive Cotton, who deceaed at Berisford the 38th year of her Age, and lyes buried at Bently by Ahbourne, &c.

lg.l: AMongt the many that hall celebrate
(With ighes and tears) this excellent womans Fate;
And with the many that hall fix a vere
(Sacred unto her Fame) upon her Here;
World! pardon me my boldnes, that intrude
Thee few poor lines upon thy Multitude:
They need not read them, I have my deire
If they but ee my name, and look no higher:
But with my Sadnes thou may't well dipence
A tribute due to her Departure hence;
For from my oul I honoured her, and grieve
That I've but uch mall means to win beliefe.
Others may aim with a victorious Rhime
To vindicate her from the rage of time;
Our ablet Poets, whoe each Ditick may
Both Bras and Marble Statues wear away,
Lat till the noble Soul again hall come
And take poeion of her ancient Roome
Converting all their Funeral Elegies
(By that Reunion) t' Epithalamies;
And o by olemnizing her jut worth,
Acquire themelves an endles Name on earth
I no Ambition have but to make known
Her merits, were my Admiration.
Her Converation harmles was and free,
For neither Pride nor ill Dicoure had he:
Her weet Conditions all the vertues were,
Not tudied, but habitual in her:
And (ere the fatal Feaver had begun
T'diturb her calm Soul's Habitation)
The beauteous body was a Palace fit
(Above all other) t'entertain in it
So Sublime, and o many vertues, uch
As made old Saints and martyrs prais'd o much.
But he is gone, and we are left behinde
To mourn the want of worth in Woman-kinde
For femal vertues (as our fears urmize)
Are all with her return'd to Paradie.
And there (bet Couin) may your welcome b •
A Crown of Glory and Immortalitie.

div.head: 5. A funeral Elegie on my Dear Couin Mistres Elizabeth Reppington, who deceaed at Ammington about the eighteenth year of her age, and lyes buried at Tamworth.

lg.l: THe Contemplation of death to prize
Above all thoughts of humane vanities
A Sublime widom is, and makes Amends
For uch ad Contemplations at our Ends.
Stifle therefore (my Mue) at their firt birth
All thoughts that may reflect upon the earth:
Be meraphyical, didaining to
Fix upon any thing that is below.
Fame et thy Trump unto thy lips, and ound
The world this ad newsfrom her hallow'd ground;
Elizabeth Reppington, that glorious Maid,
Hath left to guide us in this mortal hade
By her unparallel'd example; he
Hath chang'd all Finite for Infinity.
Her Grave all beauty doth include, for there
Two Suns eclips'd lie in one Hemiphere,
Enveloped with Clouds, thicker then thoe
Which the remotet Arctick doth impoe.
Her humble Lovers, that like Perians pai'd
Devotion to the Beams of her fair Head,
(Whoe hair their eyes in wonder did contain)
Continue to wih that Golden Fleece in vain:
Flowers more rich then graced Eden ever,

Lillie •
and Roes there to dut do wither
Oracles too are ceas'd again, they from
The temple of her mouth had us'd to come.
A lurid palenes its upon the skin
That did encloe the beau • eous body in:
As after a bright day Night do • h ucceed,
And clothe high Heaven in a mot horrid weed
Her hands a Conort were of muick, uch
As skilfully be • Intruments did touch,
Begetting harmony to emulate
What the Intelligencing Spirits create
By motion of the Spheres; yet now they lye
Uelely here through deaths Impietie.
You that hall chance to read in thee poor rhimes
This Virgins Fate, whoe life did grace our times,
Whoe Death this Nation jutly may lament,
She being of it the prime Ornament;
And many vertues mut a pattern prove
To all thoe generous Souls that vertue love:
Conider what a los her Parents have
Whoe Hopes are fal'n with her into the Grave;
(Her Graces grown to an unequal'd height)
Lying now leeping in the longet night.
Yet any Soul but hers would have been glad
So fair and pure Confinement to have had:
But more illutrious hers, like a bright flame
Broke looe, and is return'd from whence it came
Where he enjoys all joys, miles on our tears,
Wihing that ours as happy were as hers:
And her weet Company and Converation
We are depriv'd of, but by Contemplation
The maides that do in flowing Anchors treames
Conceal themelves from buie Phoebus beames,
(Upon whoe Banks he us'd to walk, and mile
On the low waters that pat by the while)
Her immature Diceae ceae not to mone
Under each Willow, and on every tone.
The woods of Amington, which oft times he
Grac'd with her Preence to hear harmonie
From the Innocuous Quiriters of the Aire,
Now murmure for her los in ad depaire;
The Dryades that there had wont to play,
Spending in weeping for her every day.
The Graces, that us'd thither to retire
To dance unto skilful Apollos Lyre,
As often ince as they that way do come,
Sit down, and ing an Epicedium.
Thus I could proecute; but being grown
Dull with o long a Lamentation,
My hand o trembling it can onely blot,
And Eies o fraught with tears that they ee not;
I leave the World (though orrow truck it faint)
To mourn her Los, and make up my complaint.

div.head: 6. A Funeral Elegie upon the Death of Mr. Thomas Pilkington, one of the Queens Muicians, Who deceaed at Wolverhampton about the 35. year of his Age, and lies there buried.

lg.l: AT the Report of o ad News ure oone
The grieved Nation will be out of tune
For Pilkington is dead, who did command
All Intruments with his unequal'd hand:
Matring all Muick that was known before;
He did invent the Orphion, and gave more.
Though he (by playing) had acquir'd high Fame,
He evermore ecap'd a Gameters Name:
Yet he at Gamut frequent was, and taught
Many to play, till Death et his Gam out.
He was facetious, and did never carp,
Making that Muick which came from him harp
His Flats were all Harmonious; not like theirs
Whoe ebbs in proe or vere abue our ears:
But to what end praie I his Flats, ince that
He is grown One himelf, and now lies Flat?
Others for Days mipent are charged with crime
But he a trict oberver was of time.
Nothing ecap'd his Study (by all votes)
Being mot perfect of mankind at Notes.
Though he was often in his Moodes, they were
Such as rejoyc'd all mindes, and pleas'd each ear
The Mues two-clif'd Hill he did urpas;
Whoe Muick had three Cliffs to do it Grace
With rahnes none his Credit could impair,
Who did oberve his Stops with o much Care
His Frets were gentle Ones, uch as would be
Stop'd with a Finger, and make Harmonie
His Family agree o in their Hearts,
That they did make a Conort of five Parts;
(To be a Pattern unto every one)
Himelf, his Wife, two Daughters, and a Son:
Though omtimes there might ome Diviion run,
Twas for the bet in the Concluion;
For each learn'd Mater in this Science knowes
Good Muick often hath from Dicords roe.
A Large his generous heart was and a Long;
His Life was wih'd by all the happy Throng
Acquainted with his worths: But (in the chiee
Of all his Dayes) Death made it be a Briefe.
Crotchets he had good tore, yet uch as were
Harmonious, full of Spirit, life, and aire.
His Life was but a Minum, till his prime
When as old Age hould lat out Sembrief-time;
His proved over hort, as if indeed
He were, Alas! to die by Quaver-peed.
Whoe Los our trembling Heart uch wie lament,
As they like Semi, and Demi-Quavers went.
So he is gone (as Heaven hath thought i • bet)
And (after all his pains) hath made a Ret.
Muicks bet Intrument his body made,
Wherein his oul upon the Organs plai'd:
But Death was likewie Sacrilegious grown,
Who rudely hath thoe Organs overthrown.
For other Exequies what need we call?
Play o're his Heare his own fam'd Funeral;
The doleful Aire that he compos'd, to mourn
For beauteous Reppingtons untimely Urne.
What need more words, when no words can declare
The Merits of a Man o wondrous rare?
He was too excellent for earth: And's gone,
To be in Heaven a prime Muician.

div.head: 1. To the Right Honourable John Lord Mohun Baron of Okehampton, my ncle in Law

lg.l: MY Lord, unto you now I have not writ
For Otentation, or to boat my wit,
I know it weak; this onely is to hew
How willingly I'de pay the debt I owe;
Which though I cannot, I hould be mot rude
To let my Silence prove Ingratitude.
I mut write therefore, though when I have done
I ret in ilent Admiration.
Be you but pleas'd to reade, although tis true
I cannot draw a line deerveth you:
So gracious Kings will give their Subjects leave
To gratulate the Bleings they receive.
Let our mot able Poets, uch as can
Feign vertues for a well deerving Man,
Expres with th'eloquence of all the Arts,
Half one of your Innumerable Parts:
I can but onely wonder and profes
I know o little that I cannot gues.
It were an eaier matter to declare
The heights and depthes that in each Science are:
All Labyrinthes that Dialect affords,
And (Critick-like) which are the hardet words.
Of you a Character would be a task
Maeonides and Maro would not ask,
If for preeminence they were to write;
It is o weighty, and their skill o light.
The fluent Singer of the Changes would
In imploration for Aide grow old:
And yet they were the Miracles of Wit,
Through all Times famous, and renowned yet;
Honour'd by Grandees of the world, and by
The Supreme beauty of weet Italy.
Witnes the conquering Macedonian Prince,
Who wept for envy Homer's eloquence,
And mighty Poeie rais'd to the Stars
Achilles Fame; and thunder'd not his wars:
And great Augutus who could eaily light
All other things, t'admire rich Virgil's height.
Witnes bright Julia too, who far above
The Roman Princes all did Ovid love.
Happy was Orpheus that in former times
(To admiration) did reheare his rhimes:
So was Amphion too, that long ago
His matchles skill in poetry did how.
Had they been your Contemporaries, they
(Whom all men did, and Salvages obey,
And rocks and trees) with all their tudy ne're
Could pen one line worth your attentive ear
Had great Aeacides your worthes, he o
Had not effected Hectors Overthrow:
He had been lain fairly or liv'd; for great
And worthy mindes unworthy Actions hate
Ajax was onely honour'd in the field;
Would you had pleaded for him, for the heild,
The Ithacan digrac'd away had gone,
And the blunt Souldier put the trophie on.
Comparions are odious; I digrace
You, to look on you by anothers face.
You Heaven-bred ouls whom Phoebus doth inpire
From high Olympus with Poetick fire,
Bewail no more thee ignorant wretched days;
This ingular Lord will not withhold the Bays.
You Siters that frequent the Thespian Spring,
And on Parnaus Io Paeans ing,
He hath been, and is now a Patron to you,
And in his own immortal Lays doth woe you.
Proceed my Lord, and let it be your Glory
No Chronicler dares put you in his Story:
For if your vertues vere cannot expres,
I mut believe that heavy Proe much les.
Again proceed, and let this move you to it;
Of your own worthes you mut be your own Poet:
Or let your vertues rule Amazements throne,
To be expres'd by no Mue but your own:
And (let from your own goodnes you decline)
Pardon each fault that is in every line.

div.head: 2. To my friend and Kinman Mr. George Giffard, who cal'd his Mitres the Green Bird of France.

lg.l: THe Necromancy of your love doth change
Your Mitres to a Bird, o to 'etrange
Her name from vulgar ears, and to conceal
Thoe harmles paages of love you teal:
And by this means be your heart what it will,
Your tongue's Platonick that can keep this till.
But ure your judgement and mot curious eyes
Fancie no bird, but that of Paradie,
The Phoenix, or a third of mighty worth;
A wonder and a Glory to the earth.
Jove's Eagle's too apiring to invite
Your mind to love, or love to apetite
The Doves of Venus you too gentle know;
And yours mut give you caue to court and wo.
Minerva's Owl is onely for the Night;
And your fair Mitres doth become the light:
Saturnia's Peacock hath a gaudy train,
But feet too coure uch Colours to utain:
Your Bird o curious is, he would dipere
The Clouds of proe, and make it run in vere.
She's not deriv'd from Magellanick Streights,
Where the mot numerous Parat-Covey delights:
But from a richer Soyle, and may perchance
The Dolphin wake, to court the Bird of France:
But Caears elf might conquer Gaul anew,
And with his victories not trouble you.
Your fair green Bird of France doth know her power
Superiour to the roughet Conquerour;
Whil't he reits no fort o trong as he,
Whoe victour mut her own conenting be.
Nor martial engine, word, or piece can move
Her from your love while he will be your love.
But if her Reolution alter, then
Her how to you will you retrieve agen?
Like the mad lover make your heart the ure,
And that will bring her, or he'l come no more.
Had Hymen lighted his aupicious Pine,
And you joyn'd happy hands before his hrine,
Then would not you and your admired love
The Changes imitate of amorous Jove,
Who like a Swan fair Laeda did compres,
And on her got the Twins Tyndarides?
But why ince Birds are of all colours een,
Do you call her you mot affect the Green?
The Firmament we ee attir'd in blew,
But that too heavenly a Colour is for you.
The earth is green; and you do think mot fit
That he be o, while he doth live on it.
The Sea is green, and Sea-born Venus was
Made beauties Goddes being mot beauteous Las!
And your fair One, whom you think Parallel
To her, you call the Green-Bird wondrous well.
All health I wih her, from each icknes free
But one, whoe cure I do commit to thee:
If the Green Sicknes he doth chance to get,
Your Love and Care of her may remed it.

div.head: 3. To the right honourable Ferdinand Earl of Huntingdon, &c.

lg.l: MY Lord, I have not ilent been o long
For want of zeal, but fear'd to do you wrong:
Could I but draw a line deerv'd your eyes,
Your name hould from the earth touch at the skies.
But as the meanet Peants came before
The greatet Caears Rome did ere adore;
And as the gracious Gods no more depie
The pooret then the richet Sacrifice;
So I (my Lord) preent my elf to you,
And this light humble vere unto your view.
Let our bet Heralds, uch as are mot good,
Sail up the mighty Current of your blood,
And from the ancient and mot glorious Stem
Of thoe that wore the Englih Diadem,
Blazon your pedegree, whil't I admire
Your fair Conditions, parks of honours fire.
To be born onely great, and not to be
Vertuous too, is, as we often ee
The morning Sun rie clearly in the Eat,
Preently after be with Clouds oppret,
And (after one fair chearful blaze of light)
The day prove tormy till it mix with night.
But this concerns not you; you are as far
From all unworthines, as is that tar
That by the vertue of the Southerne tayes
This Mas of earth, and water in its place
From earth: And as thoe oppoite Stars do poie
This Globe of earth, and Water midt the skies
Equally ditant, in all places, from
The Heavens that round it in Circumference come.
Or to decend; As Mahomets tombe doth fix
By vertue of two Loadtones them betwixt;
So you (my Lord) for weet Conditions known
Parallels to your high birth, tand alone
Unaim'd, and unarriv'd at, (to their ends)
Th' Amaze of all and honour of your friends.
Accept this graciouly my Lord! And know
'Tis but a Glimps of the repect I owe,
And but an Atome of the Service; For
Whole volumes would not be a Character.

div.head: 4. To a Lady that was o like another that I cal'd her Picture.

lg.l: I Call you Picture, and by your Conent;
Although I know you want no Ornament,
Nor any curious Arts ue, to upply
Any defect in you to any eye.
You then are none, and do want Colours o (now;
As heaven wants clouds or Summers earth wants
Both which do both deform; And you therefore
To ou • vy heaven and earth admit no more.
You then no picture are, but unto thoe
That can become enamour'd on your clothes.
Vandike, Mitten, Geltrop or Johnon may
Draw omething like you; As a Summers day
May in the fleeting Clouds well counterfeit
Similitudes of things here, and not hit;
For 'tis impoible to Limn you right,
As 'tis the earthly Globe without a night.
To make your eyes were to amaze us all;
Make in your face two Suns rie; And to vail
Their glorious motions, no eclipes there
Can be more beautiful then your brown hair;
So doth the brightet tar ofttimes repine
At it's own glory, and forbear to hine.
To name Apelles and to wih him draw
Your Portraicture, could he perform't 'twere law
To future Limners; but your beauties height
All imitation doth trancend outright.
Your Lips are like the roy buds of May;
And your even teeth the pearls of India;
Your mouth's the weetet Magazin of blis,
Where Cupids Dialect bet poken is.
Your loveliet Cheeks are the tru't Hemipheres
Of beauty, triumphing above your Peeres.
This your firt itting is; when you it next,
I hall be better pleas'd, and you more vext;
For I hall more admire your beauties tore,
Though you be angry th'are o lubberd o're.
TO love you (Lady) is but jut; we know
We have good eyes and Judgments that do o.
Your beauties are no Common Ornaments,
But Rarities, and plac'd (with excellence)
By Natures curious hand; That could entice
Even Jove from all his Glories, and the Skyes;
Make him reject his full triumphant way
O're Gods and men, and thunder cat away;
Depoe himelf from high Olympus, leave
Amaz'd the heavenly Deities, and beneath
Retire himelf on earth to gaze on you,
More wonderful then all the Goddes Crew;
Make him forake his tately Queens embrace,
Wie Pallas eyes, and amorous Venus Face,
His draughtes of Nectar fil'd by Ganymed,
And the weet Leons by Apollo plai'd;
His iter Juno had not been his Queen,
If you the •• atelie • beauty he had een.
His daughter Venus had not been ental'd
Goddes of love, but you the Goddes cal'd:
Nor had Minerva (with the fair gray eyes)
Been crown'd for widom 'bove the Deities,
Had Jove heard your dicoure; your words do fall
With uch a ravihing force upon us all.
Immortal Phoebus that with glorious beams
All Nations lights, and gilds all Ocean treams;
In all his Progres yet did never view
A beauty o upreme, and bright as you.
Had Phaeton liv'd till now, and skilful been,
He would have given his Chariot unto him,
Left the Star-chequer'd Court, and (from the skies)
A light on earth in ome unus'd diguie,
To court your miles, more precious then his throne,
And all the glories that attend thereon;
And (in your company) wear by a kis
He never was before in any blis.
Your eyes are not the Sun and Moon; for they
Are equal lights, and both do rule by day:
Your Noe is uch as doth become your face
Better, then the bet other in that place.
Your mouth exceedes the breaking of the day;
For that is weet when Night drives light away.
Your teeth urpas the milky way in Heaven,
More white then it, more wonderful, more even.
Your lips are mooth as Chrytal, red as is
Pure abtract rednes, bleednes to kis.
Your boom's a new paradie of joy,
And undicover'd to the vulgar eye.
Your hidden beauties do as much excell
All, all Art can invent, and all tongues tell;
As doth your body (magazin of joyes)
Exceed your clothes een onely by our eyes.
But were this all, you onely did preent
A curious Outide, picture, Ornament:
Your mind (brave Lady) is a thing above
All Objects yet of all the pat worlds Love:
It is o gentle, weet, and unconfin'd
In goodnes, that it makes the body, minde:
Like the Philoophers Stone that mixing with
Wore metals, doth to them gold-ubtance give.
Let them therefore that do not wonder, when
They have een you, be counted beats not men.
BEt of your Sex, and handomet to boot,
I here preent you with no marriage-uit;
My Fate is fix'd, and I contented am,
Although ometimes I court another flame.
I dare not wih a wrong to your deert;
(Far be uch thoughts for ever from my heart)
Yet mut not be o cruel to my elf,
As not from you to covet uch a wealth,
Arabia's rich perfumes are nothing to,
Nor all the Spices all the Eat can how.
Sure my deire can be no Crime in me,
Nor your Conent can your dihonour be:
Ele all the ancient Poets did devie
To cheat the modern with mot Stygian lyes.
Wherefore hould Jove neglect Saturnia's Love,
And all his endles happines above?
Aume o many various Shapes t'enjoy
With humane beauties enuality?
And glorious Phoebus cat his Rayes away,
With our fine Laes here below to play?
Although grim Pluto the Infernal flames
Endures; his rage Proerpin's beauty tames.
Cynthia, whoe chatity each Grecian pen,
And Roman wit, renowned left to men,
Victorious Love in triumph trampled on,
And made her wanton with Endimion.
Thee high examples we may imitate;
For Deities did nothing we hould hate.
They, whom all nations for Heroick oules,
And vertuous Actions, above the Poles
Have • nthroniz'd, did nought we hould condemn:
And therefore (Lovely One) let's follow them.
Strict Hymens rules wherefore hould we obey,
Which on themelves the Gods did never lay?
Is it more honour to oberve the lives
Of urly Cato's then the Deities?
Away with fear; 'Tis reaon prompts you to
What I deire, and love, me what to do:
And therefore do not bluh, unles it be
Becaue o many will envy thee and me:
Yet (Madam) know (after o much expret)
I honour vertue, and have writ in jet.

div.head: 7. To my Couin Mr. Charles Cotton.

lg.l: I Wonder (Couin) that you would permit
So great an Injury to Fletcher's wit,
Your friend and old Companion, that his fame
Should be divided to anothers name.
If Beaumont had writ thoe Plays, it had been
Againt his merits a detracting Sin,
Had they been attributed alo to
Fletcher. They were two wits, and friends, and who
Robs from the one to glorifie the other,
Of thee great memories is a partial Lover.
Had Beaumont liv'd when this Edition came
Forth, and beheld his ever living name
Before Plays that he never writ, how he
Had frown'd and bluh'd at uch Impiety?
His own Renown no uch Addition needs
To have a Fame prung from anothers deedes.
And my good friend Old Philip Mainger
With Fletcher writ in ome that we ee there.
But you may blame the Printers; yet you might
Perhaps have won them to do Fletcher right,
Would you have took the pains: For what a foul
And unexcuable fault it is (that whole
Volume of plays being almot every one
After the death of Beaumont writ) that none
Would certifie them o much? I wih • s free
Y'had told the Printers this, as you did me.
Surely you was to blame: A Forreign wit
Ownes in uch manner what an Englih writ:
Joeph of Exeters Heroick piece
Of the long fatal war 'twixt Troy and Greece,
Was Printed in Corn • lius Nepos Name,
And robs our Countreyman of much of's fame.
'Tis true; Beaumont and Fletcher both were uch
Sublime wits, none could them admire too much;
They were our Englih Poletars, and did beare
Between them all the world of fancie cleare
But as two Suns when they do hine to us,
The aire is lighter, they prodigious;
So while they liv'd and writ together, we
Had Plays exceeded what we hop'd to ee.
But they writ few; for youthful Beaumont oon
By death ecliped was at his high noon.
Surviving Fletcher then did pen alone
Equal to both, (pardon Comparion)
And uffer'd not the Globe, and Black-Friers Stage
T'envy the glories of a former Age.
As we in humane bodies ee that loe
An eye, or limbe, the vertue and the ue
Retreats into the other eye or limb,
And makes it double; So I ay of him:
Fletcher was Beaumonts Heir, and did inherit
His earching judgement, and unbounded Spirit.
His Plays are Printed therefore as they were,
Of Beaumont too, becaue his Spirit's there.

div.head: 8. To my Son Mr. Thomas Cokaine.

lg.l: YOU often have enquir'd where I have been
In my years Travel; and what Cities een
And • ai'd in: of the which therefore (in brief)
I (for your atisfaction) name the chief.
When four and twenty years, and ome moneths more
Of Age I was, I left our Englih Shore:
And in a thouand ix hundred thirty two
Went hence, fair France and Italy to view.
At Roy July the ixteenth we took Ship,
And on the eventeenth did arrive at Deipe,
Henry the fourths ecure retreat; where one
Night having lain I rode next day to Roan;
Thence in a Coach I did to Paris go,
Where then I did but pend a day or two.
Thence with the Lions meenger went thither,
And pas'd through Mont-Argis, Mollins, and Never.
In two days thence we did to Cambray get,
A City at the foot of Eglebet
At Maurein I din'd, and ix days pent
Among the Alpes with high atonihment.
There dreadful Precepice, and horrid ound
Of water, and hills hid in Cloudes I found,
And trees above the Clouds on Mountains top,
And houes too; a wonder to get up.
On Mount-Sinee's top I did ride o're,
A mooth, and pleaant Plain, a League or more
Upon the which a large Fih-pool there is,
And one o'th Duke of Savoy's Palaces:
At the Plains End, a little Chappel, and
A pretty Inn do near together tand.
That night we did decend 'bove half the way,
Where firt we heard Italian poke, and lay.
Next morn we down to Sua rode, full glad
When Mount-Sinee we decended had:
And that ame night to Turin came where we
Staid but a day the Beauties of't to ee.
There we took Coach for Millaine, and (by th'way)
A Dinners time did at Vercelli tay,
And at Novara lay a night, and tai'd
But at great Millaine one; uch hat I made:
And but at Crema one, and by the Lake
Of tormy Garda did a dinner take.
Through the low Suburbs of high Bergamo
I rode, and that night did to Brecia go,
For works of Iron fam'd; And having pat
Thorow Verona, by Catullus grac't,
Did at Vicenza dine, o forward went
Through Padoa, and (on the banks of Brent)
Saw many Palaces of pleaant Site,
And to the rich fam'd Venice came that night.
Thence (having tai'd there half a year) did go
Unto Ferrara by the river Poe,
Saving ome four miles, where a Coach we took,
When Phaetons fatal River we forook.
I at Ravenna din'd, Rimmini lay,
And the next Night did at Ancona tay;
A long days journey, wherein we betime
Pearo rode through, did at Fano dine,
For hanome women fam'd; And (in our way)
Rid neer mall, well-wall'd Siningaglia.
The next day at Loretto din'd, and there
View'd the Fair Church, and Houe fam'd every where:
Thorow long Recanati rode, and o
To Macerata in the Even did go.
Next day I din'd at Tolentin, and was
It'h Church of their renown'd Saint Nicholas.
Foligno and Spoletto having pat,
Terin, and Narin, took a Nights repat
Within Otricoli, I the next day
Din'd at Rignano 'ith' Flaminian way:
And in the Evening afterwards did come
Thorow the Port del Popolo to Rome;
Where what the holy week, and Eater could
To trangers view afford, I did behold:
Where that old Cities wonders I did view,
And all the many Marvels of the new.
Three weeks I there made my abode, and then
For Naples took my travels up agen:
Of all Fracati's Wonders had a ight,
And thence unto Velletri rode that night;
At Terrachina lay the next. Then through
The Kingdom pas'd at Mola, took a view
Of Old Gaeta; thence to Capua rode,
Where onely I dinners time abode.
So I to Naples came, where three weeks tay
Made me the wonders thereabouts urvey
I at Puzzolo was, there cros'd the Bay
(Fam'd for the bridge of proud Caligula)
To Baja, and that day a view did take
Of Aniana, and Avernus Lake.
The mortal Grott was in, and Sepulchre
Which murther'd Agrippina did interre:
Was in Sybilla's Cave, and on the Ground
Cal'd Vulcans Forge, yielding an hollow ound,
At Paualip pas'd through that hollow path
Which Virgil for its primet Glory hath.
Thee and the ret beheld: One day got up
On evermore moking Veuvius top;
Veuvius that two years before did throw
Such death and damage upon all below
Which burnt up gras, and trees did make appear;
And tore Griego that did tand too near.
Above three weeks I did at Naples tay,
Then (in a Galley) went to Genoa;
Which (in it) an Embaador did bear
To th' Cardinal Infante landed there,
Sent by the Vice-Roy to alute his hands,
Going t'be Governour oth' Netherlands
I there remain'd but a few days, but found
A veel that was for Mareilles bound;
I in it thither pas'd, but by the way
Did at Savona land, and dinner tay.
I at Mareille but two dayes abode,
And the next after to Avignion rode.
I din'd at Orange, and lay at Vienne,
And o to Lyons did return agen,
There tai'd a day, or two; and then did ride
Unto Roana on the Loyers ide:
About three days and nights along that treame
We went by Boat, till we to Briack came.
There we did leave the River, and next morne
Unto Mount-Argis did again return.
The morning after we from thence did go,
And lay that Night at pleaant Fountain-Bleau.
Thence we to Conbril went, and (on the Seine)
To Paris thence by Boat did come again.
There I above two moneths then made a tay;
Save on Saint Dennis wonders pent a day.
After which time I went to Amiens,
There lay one night, and went to Calice thence.
As my tay erv'd, what ever was of Fame
Or note I viited where ere I came.
Four days I was in Calice, then cros'd over
The Sea in eight hours pace, and came to Dover.

div.head: To my friend Mr. Thomas Randolph on his Play called the Entertainment, Printed by the name of the Mues Looking-Glas.

lg.l: SOme autere Cato's be that do not tick
To term all Poetry bae that's Dramatick:
Thee contradict themelves; For bid them tell
How they like Poeie, and they'l anwer well.
But as a tately Fabrick rai • ed by
The curious Science of Geometrie,
If one ide of the Machine pe ih all
Participates with it a ruinous fall:
So they are enemies to Helicon,
That vow they love all Mues aving one.
Such upercilious humours I de • ie,
And like Thalia's harmles Comedies.
Thy entertainment had o good a Fate
That whooe're doth not admire thereat
Dicloeth his own Ignorance; for no
True Moralit would be uppoed thy foe.
In the pure Thespian Spring thou hat refin'd
Thoe harh rude rules thy Author hath deign'd:
And made thoe precepts which he did rehere
In heavy proe, to run in nimble vere.
The Stagarite will be lighted; who doth lit
To read or ee't becomes a Moralit:
And if his eyes and ears are worth thine Ore
Learn more in two hours then two years before.
Thou hat my uffrage Friend; And I would fain
Be a Spectator of thy Scenes again.

div.head: To my friend Mr. Philip Mainger, on his Tragi-comedy called the Emperour of the Eat.

lg.l: SUffer (my Friend) thee lines to have the grace
That they may be a mole on Venus face:
There is no fault about thy book but this,
And it will hew how fair thine Emperour is.
Thou more then Poet! our Mercury, that art
Apollo's Meenger, and dot impart
His bet expreions to our ears, live long
To purifie the lighted Englih Tongue.
That both the Nymphes of Tagus and of Po
May not henceforth depie our language o:
Nor could they do it if they ere had een
The machles features of the Faery Queen;
Read Johnon, Shakespeare, Beaumont, Fletcher, or
Thy neat-lin'd pieces (skilful Mainger.)
Thou known, all the Catellians mut confes
De Vega Carpio thy foil, and bles
His Language can tranlate thee, and the fine
Italian wits yield to this work of thine.
Were old Pythagoras alive again,
In thee he might finde reaon to maintain
His Paradox, that Souls by tranmigration
In divers bodies make their habitation:
And more; that all poetick Souls yet known
Are met in thee contracted into one.
This is a truth, not an applaue; I am
One that at farthet ditance view thy flame,
Yet dare pronounce, that were Apollo dead,
In thee his Poetry might all be read.
Forbear thy modety: thy Emperours vein
Shall live admir'd, when Poets hall complain
It is a pattern of too high a reach,
And what great Phoebus might the mues teach.
Let it live therefore, and I dare be bold
To ay, It with the world hall not grow old.

div.head: To my Friend Mr. Philip Mainger on his Tragi-comedy called the Maid of Honour.

lg.l: WAs not thine Emperour enough before
For thee to give, that thou dot give us more?
I would be jut but cannot; that I know
I did not lander, this I fear I do
But pardon me if I offend; thy fire
Let equal poets praie whil't I admire.
If any ay that I enough have writ;
They are thy Foes, and envy at thy wit.
Believe not them nor me: they know thy Lines
Deerve applaue, and peak againt their mindes.
I out of Jutice would commend thy Play:
But (Friend) forgive me, 'tis above my way.
One word, and I have done: and (from my heart)
Would I could peak the whole truth, not the part:
Becaue 'tis thine, It henceforth hall be aid,
Not th'maid of honour, but the honour'd maid.

div.head: Of Mr. John Fletcher his Plays, and especially the Mad Lover.

lg.l: WHil't his well organ'd Body doth retreat
To it's firt matter, and the formal heat
Triumphant fits in judgement to approve
Pieces above our Candor and our love;
Such as dare boldly venture to appear
Unto the curious eye, and Critick ear:
Lo! the Mad Lover in thee various times
Is pret to life t'accue us of our Crimes.
Whil't Fletcher liv'd, who equal to him writ
Such lating monuments of natural wit?
Others might draw their lines with weat, like thoe
That with much pains a Garrion encloe,
Whil't his weet fluent vein did gently run
As uncontrol'd, and moothly as the Sun.
After his Death our Theatres did make
Him in his own unequal'd Language peak:
And now (when all the Mues out of their
Approved modety ilent appear)
This Play of Fletchers braves the envious Light,
As wonder of our ears once, now our ight.
Three and fourfold bet Poet, who the lives
Of Poets and of Theatres urvi't!
A Groom or Otler of ome wit, may bring
His Pegaus to the Castalian Spring;
Boat he a Race ore the Pharalian plain,
Or happy Tempe valley dares maintain;
Brag at one leap upon the double Cliffe
(Were it as high as montrous Temariffe)
Of far renown'd Parnaus he will get,
And there t'amaze the world confirm his eat:
When our admired Fletcher vaunts not ought,
And lighted every thing he writ as nought;
Whil't all our Englih wondring world (in's caue)
Made this great City eccho with applaue:
Read him therefore all that can read, and thoe
That cannot, learn; If y'are not Learnings Foes,
And willfully reolved to refue
The gentle Raptures of this happy Mue.
From thy great Contellation (noble Soul)
Look on this Kingdom, uffer not the whole
Spirit of Poeie retire to Heaven,
But make us entertain what thou hat given.
Earthquakes and thunder Diapaons make,
The Seas vat rore, and Irreitles hake
Of horrid winds a Sympathie compoe;
So that in thee there's muick in the cloe:
And (though they eem great dicords in our ears)
The caue is not in them, but in our fears.
Granting them muick, how much weeter's that
Mnemoyne's daughters voices do create?
Since Heaven, and earth, and Seas and air conent
To make an harmony (the Intrument
Their own agreeing elves) hall we refue
The muick that the Deities do ue?
Troy's ravih't Gamymed doth ing to Jove;
And Phoebus elf playes on his Lyre above.
The Cretan Gods, or glorious men who will
Imitate right, mut wonder at thy skill,
Bet Poet of thy times! or he will prove
As mad, as thy brave Memnon was with love

div.head: To my very good Friend Mr. Thomas Bancroft on his Works.

lg.l: A Done (my friend) lay pen and paper by,
Y'ave writ enough to reach eternity;
In oft Repoe aume thy happy Seat
Among the Laureats to judge of wit:
Apollo now hath cal'd you to the Bench
For your weet vein, and fluent eloquence;
Whoe many works will all rare patterns tand,
And deathles Ornaments unto our Land,
Belov'd, admir'd and imitated by
All thoe great ouls that honour poeie.
Againt th'approch of thy lat hour, when
He thee hall call from the abodes of men,
(In his own Quire (for thy exceeding Art)
Among renowned wits to ing a part)
Nor you, nor any friend need to prepare
Marble or bras a Pyramid to reare,
To thy continuall memory, nor with
A Mauoleum hope to make thee live:
All uch materials time may devour,
But ore thy works hall never have a power.
While nimble Darwen Trent augments, and while
The treams of Thames do glorifie our Ile,
And th' Englih tongue whiles any undertand,
Thy lines hall be grace unto this Land.
Our Darbyhire (that never as I knew
Afforded us a Poet untill you)
You have redeem'd from obloquie, that it
Might boat of wooll and lead, but not of wit.
Virgil (by's birth) to Mantua gave renown,
And weet-tongu'd Ovid unto Sulmo town,
Catullus to Verona was a fame;
And you to Swarton will become the ame.
Live then (my friend) immortally, and prove
Their envy that will not afford thee love.

div.head: To Mr. Humphry C. on his Poem entitled Loves Hawking Bag.

lg.l: SIR, I applaud your enterprie, and ay
Y'our undertaking was a bold aay:
But you have nobly don't, and we may read
A work that all old Poems doth exceed.
Avant you Grecian Mungrils, with your Scraps
Fal'n from linde Homers, or did Heiods chaps:
Muaeus too (for all Scaligers cracking)
With Hero and Leander may be packing.
Virgil be gon! we hate thy landrous tongue,
For doing the chat Queen of Carthage wrong.
Venuian Horace too hereafter may
Put up his pipes, and hearken to thy Lay.
Ovid, thy everal witty Poems, all
From hence to Pontus into exile call.
Valerius Flaccus, hang thy Golden Fleece
Before ome honet Tavern door in Greece.
Silius Italicus hence get thee far
With all the tumults of thy Punick war:
And Spanih Lucan quickly call away
Caear and Pompey to Pharalia.
Statius thy Theban tory leave to brag:
And liten all unto Loves-Hawking Bag.
Chaucer, we now commit thee to repoe,
And care not for thy Romance of the Roe.
In thy grave at Saint Edmonds Bury, thy
Hector henceforth (Lydgate) may with thee ly;
Old Gower (in like manner) we depie,
Condemning him to ilence for his Cryes.
And Spencer, all thy Knights may (from this time)
Go eek Adventures in another Clime.
Thee Poets were but Footpots that did come
Halting unto's, whom thou hat all outrun:
For Sol hath lent thee Pegaus the Nag,
To gallop to us with Loves-Hawking Bag;
And welcome (mighty Poet) that alone
Art fit to it with Phoebus in his throne.

div.head: To Mr. James Stronge Bachelour, upon his wonderful Poem called Joanareidos.

lg.l: WHat a fine piece of poetrie appears!
Such as hath not been een thee many years:
So trange for matter, and o trangly writ
That Joanareidos is matchles yet.
The Iliads and Odyes mut give way,
And fam'd Aenaeados yield up the day:
The high Autriados mut alo yield,
And Mortem • riados leave the field.
For where's that poet (all the world among)
That mut not vail the bonnet to James Strong?
Thou bachelour of Arts, or rather bungler,
Or bachelour in life to whom the tronglier (luts,
(What ele hould move thee to commend thy
That might't have pent thy time in cracking nuts,
Or looking birds-nets? or (what's bet of thee)
In eating butter'd cake, or toted cheee)
Hail our James Strong! (Strong James!) whoe every line
Draws like a cable all our wondring ey'ne,
And general applaue from friends and foes,
And many trangers up and down (he trowes.)
O 'tis a wondrous book; each word doth mell
As if't had omething in it of a pell:
The lines are charming, and (if I guee right)
They will bewitch women to cold and fight.
Old Robin Hood your wetern dames excel
Scarlet, and little John, and Adam Bell,
Clem of the Clough, and William Cloudelee,
And all the out-laws of the Greenwood tree.
Had Guy of Warwicke and the bold Sir Bevyes,
Stukely, and Jonny Armtrong made their levies
Of the mot valiant Souldiers of their time,
And come to this iege th'had been bet at Lime.
The Chubs in buff trembled, when (like to Turks)
The aw thy Joanes to rage upon the works, (plight,
They might have burnt their foes in piteous
Had they but been their bed-fellows a night.
But oh! their fury was o rah, they kept
That fire within, for thoe they did protect:
So (for their zeal unto the • aue) perhaps
They pay'd them with a plaudite of claps.
Merciles then they were (there is no doubt)
That par'd no friends within, nor foes without.
Nor within walls onely their valour lay,
But field too, as thy title page doth ay:
And I believe their mettle they have hown
Under ome Hedges, if the truth were known.
But I digres their power to relate,
It is a theme onely becomes thy pate.
I for thy pains (if uch there can be found)
Wih thee one of thy Joanes, and that Joane ound;
That thou may't lime her, and (on her) in time,
Beget a race of Joanes to fight for Lime.
O happy New-Inn-Hall! (where thou hadt luck
Such avoury dregs of poetry to uck)
For all will ay it henceforth mut excel
(For rhiming) Kates-Hall and Emanuel.
This Nation may report (upon their Oathes)
As Coriate did exceed for writing Proe;
So thou for penning an Heroick Song
Dot all urpas; In meeter being James Strong.

div.head: A Praeludium to Mr. Richard Bromes Plays.

lg.l: THen we hall till have Plays, and though they may
Not them in their full Glories yet diplay;
Yet we may pleae our elves by reading them,
Till a more noble Act this Act condemn.
Happy will that day be, which will advance
This Land from durt of precie Ignorance;
Ditinguih moral vertue, and rich wit,
And graceful Action, from an unfit
Parentheis of Coughes, and Hums and Haes,
Threhing of Cuhions, and Tautologies:
Then the dull zelots hall give way, and fly,
Or be converted by bright Poey;
Apollo may enlighten them, or els
In Scottih Grots they may conceal themelves.
Then hall learn'd Johnon reaume his Seat,
Revive the Phoenix by a econd heat,
Create the Globe anew, and people it,
By thoe that flock to urfeit on his wit.
Judicious Beaumont, and th'ingenious oul
Of Fletcher too may move without control.
Shakespeare (mot rich in humours) entertain
The crouded theatres with his happy vein.
D'avenant, and Mainger, and Sherly then
Shall be cri'd up again for famous men:
And the Dramatick Mue no longer prove
The peoples malice, but the peoples love.
Black, and White-Friars too hall flourih again,
Though here have been none ince Queen Mary's reign:
Our theatres of lower note in thoe
More happy days hall corn the rutick proe
Of a Jack-Pudding, and will pleae the Rout
With wit enough to bear their Credit out.
The Fortune will be lucky, ee no more
Her Benches bare as they have tood before:
The Bull take Courage from applaues given,
To eccho to the Taurus in the heaven:
Latly, Saint James may no Averion how,
That Socks and Buskins tread his Stage below.
May this time quickly come, thee days of blis
Drive Ignorance down to the dark Abys:
Then (with a jutly attributed praie)
We'l change our faded Brome to deathles Bayes.

div.head: To my worthy, and learned Friend Mr. William Dugdale, upon his Warwickhire Illutrated.

lg.l: THey that have viited thoe forreign Lands
Whence Phoebus firt our Hemiphere co¯mands;
And they that have beheld thoe Climes, or Seas
Whence he removes to the Antipodes:
Have follow'd him his Circuit through, and been
In all thoe parts that day hath ever een,
(Although their number urely is but few)
Have not (learn'd friend) travel'd o much as you;
Though in your tudy you have at at home,
Without a mind about the world to rome.
Witnee this o elaborate piece; how high
Have you oblig'd us by your Indutry!
We may be careles of our fames, and light
The pleaing trouble any books to write:
The Nobles and the Gentry (that have there
Concerne) hall live for ever in your Shire.
Our names hall be immortal, and when at
The period of inevitable fate
We do arrive, a poet needes not come
To grace an Here with's Epicedium.
Marble and bras for tombes we now may pare,
And for an Epitaph forbear the Care:
For, for us all (unto our high content)
Your book will prove a lating monument.
And uch a work it is, that England mut
Be proud of (if unto your merit jut;)
A grace it will unto our Language be,
And Ornament to every Library.
No old, or modern rarity we boat,
Henceforth hall be in danger to be lot:
Your worthy book comes fortunately forth;
For it again hath builded Killingworth.
Maugre the rage of war or time to come

l.U: hall flourih till the general doome:

lg.l: And the Holts Progeny hall owe as much
Unto your lines, as him that made it uch.
The Spires and walls of Coventry your pen
Hath built more lating then the Hands of men.
The propects of our noble eats you hall
Secure from any ruine may befall:
Our pleaant Warwick, and her Catle (that
Surveyes the treams of Avon from her eat)
Your Labours more illutrious have made
Then all the Reparations they e're had.
Victorious Guy you have reviv'd, and he
Is now ecure of Immortality.
Even my beloved Pooley that hath long
Groan'd underneath initer fortunes wrong,
Your courteous eyes have look'd o kindly on,
That now it is to it's firt plendor grown;
Shall light times devatations, and o're
The banks of Anchor flourih evermore;
For there's uch vertue in your powerful hand,
That every place you name hall ever tand.
The skilfullet Anatomit that yet
Upon an humane body e're did it,
Did never o preciely how his Art,
As you have yours, in your Cor • avian part:
You (in your way) do them in theirs exceed,
You make the dead to live, they poil the dead.
Now Stratford upon Avon, we would chooe
Thy gentle and ingenuous Shakespeare Mue,
(Were he among the living yet) to raie
T'our Antiquaries merit ome jut praie:
And weet-tongu'd Drayton (that hath given renown.
Unto a poor (before) and obcure town,
Harull) were he not fal'n into his tombe,
Would crown this work with an Encomium.
Our Warwick-hire the Heart of England is,
As you mot evidently have prov'd by this;
Having it with more pirit dignifi'd,
Then all our Englih Counties are beide.
Hearts hould be thankfull; therefore I obtrude
This tetimony of my gratitude.
You do deerve more then we all can doe:
And o (mot learned of my friends) Adieu.

div.head: To my learned friend Mr. Thomas Bancroft upon his Book of Satyres.

lg.l: AFter a many works of divers kindes,
Your Mue to tread th' Aruncan path deignes;
'Tis hard to write but Satyres in thee dayes,
And yet to write good Satyres merits praie:
And uch are yours, and uch they will be found
By all clear Hearts, or penitent by their wound.
May you but undertanding Readers meet,
And they will find your march on tedfat feet.
Although your honet hand eems not to tick
To earch this Nations Ulcers to the quick,
Yet your Intent (with your Invective Strain)
Is but to lance, and then to cure again,
When all the putrid matter is drawn forth
That poions precious Souls, & clouds their worth
So old Petronius Arbiter appli'd
Corives unto the age he did deride:
So Horace, Perius, Juvenal (among
Thoe ancient Romans) courg'd the impious throng:
So Arioto (in thee later times)
Reprov'd his Italy for many crimes:
So learned Barclay let his Lahes fall
Heavy on ome, to bring a cure to all.
So lately Withers (whom your Mue doth far
Trancend) did trike at things Irregular.
(But all in one t'include) So our prime wit
(In the too few hort Satyres he hath writ)
Renowned Don hath o rebuk'd his times,
That he hath jear'd vice-lovers from their crimes.
Attended by your Satyres, mounted on
Your Mues Pegaus (my friend) be gone,
(As er't the Lictors of the Romans went
With Rods and Axes (for the Punihment
Of Ill) born with them) that all vice may fly (nigh.
(That dares not tand the Cure) when you draw

div.head: To my mot honoured Couin Mr. Charles Cotton the younger, upon his excellent Poems.

lg.l: BEar back you Croud of Wits, that have o long
Been the prime Glory of the Englih tongue;
And room for our Arch-Poet make, and follow
His teps, as you would do your great Apollo:
Nor is he his Inferiour, for ee
His Picture, and you'l ay that this is he;
So young, and handome both, o tres'd alike,
Thar curious Lilly, or mot skil'd Vandike
Would prefer neither: Onely here's the odds,
This gives us better vere, then that the Gods.
Beware you Poets that (at ditance) you
The reverence afford him that is due
Unto his mighty merit, and not dare
Your puny thrids with his lines to compare;
Let (for o impious a pride) a wore
Then was Arachne's Fate, or Midas cure,
Poterity inflicts upon your fames,
For ventring to approch too near his Flames;
Whoe all-commanding Mue didains to be
Equal'd by any, in all Poey.
As the preumptuous Son of Clymene
The Suns command importun'd for a day
Of his unwilling Father, and for o
Rah an attempt fell headlong into Po;
So you hall fall, or wore; not leave o much
As empty names, to how there once were uch.
The Greek and Latine Language he commands,
So all that then was writ in both thoe Lands:
The French and the Italian he hath gain'd,
And all the wit that in them is contain'd:
So, if he pleaes to tranlate a piece
From France, or Italy, Old Rome, or Greece,
The undertanding Reader oon will find
It is the bet of any of that kind;
But when he lets own rare Fancy looe
There is no flight o Noble as his Mue:
Treats he of War? Bellona doth advance,
And leads his March with her refulgent Lance:
Sings he of Love? Cupid about him lurks,
And Venus in her Chariot draws his works
What e're his ubject be, he'l make it fit
To live hereafter Emperour of wit.
He is the Mues Darling; All the Nine
Phoebus diclaim, and term him more Divine.
The wondrous Tao that o long hath born
The acred Laurel, hall remain forlorn:
Alono de Ercilla that in trong
And mighty Lines hath Araucana ong:
And Salut that the ancient Hebrew-tory
Hath Poetiz'd, ubmit unto your Glory:
So the chief Swans of Tagus, Arne and Seine,
Mut yield to Thames, and vail unto your treine.
Hail generous Magazin of Wit; you bright
Planet of Learning, diipate the Night
Of Dulnes, wherein us this Age involves,
And (from our Ignorance) redeem our oules.
A word at parting Sir, I could not chooe
Thus to congratulate your happy Mue:
And (though I vilifie your worth) my zeal
(And o in mercy think) intended well.
The world wil find your Lines are great & tronge
The Nihil Ultra of the Englih Tongue.

div.head: To my learned Friend Mr. Thomas Bancroft, on his Poem entituled the Heroick Lover.

lg.l: FRom your retir'd abode in Bradley town
Welcome (my Friend) abroad to fair renown.
Nova Atlantis and Utopia you
Again expoe unto the publick view
By your Heroick piece; unknown before
To all Mankind, but Bacon, and to More.
To the tripartite world Columbus er't
The Wetern India dicover'd firt;
Yet after his more curious Survey
Vesputius much on's Glory took away,
By giving it his Name: So (though thoe two
Mot learned Lords did firt thoe countries hew)
You by your Antheon, and his fair delight
Far-ought Fidelta, skilfully unite
Utopia and Atlantis: what they two
<> to their Pens, they both owe you.
Nor Belgium, Italy, nor France, nor Spain,
Nor Graecia, nor Sicilia could contrain
(With their mot tempting Objects) your brave Knight
To yield ubmiion to a fale delight.
Although Sir Antheon did refrain to run
The montrous Coures of the Knight o'th Sun,
(Whoe Fablers o trange tales of him reheare,
That uch untruths never appear'd in vere)
Thoe Countrey beauties he depis'd, and pelf;
Others o'recome others, but he himelf:
And of all victories it is the bet
To keep our own wilde appetites uppret.
Hereby his prowes he did mot dicover,
And hence you term him the Heroick Lover.
Your fair Fidelta did not range about
topian Cities to find Suitors out:
A free well-order'd houe he kept, and there
Sir Antheon met with her, and married her.
Joy, or long life, I need not wih them either,
They in your Lines hall happy live for ever:
And you (for penning their high Epick Song)
With Laurel crown'd, hall live ith' Poets throng.

div.head: A MASQUE Preented at Bretbie in Darbyhire On Twelfth-Night. 1639.
The Prologue
div.stage: To be spoken by whom the Maquers hall appoint.

lg.l: TO you great Lord, and you mot excellent Lady,
And all this wel-met, wellcome Company,
Thus low I bow: And thank, that you will grace
Our rude Solemnities with uch a preence.

div.stage: The Lar Familiaris of the houe being proud of o much and great Company, and glad of their free and noble Entertainment, appears to congratulate the hopitality of the Lord and Lady, and speaks thee lines.

lg.l: BEtter then I could wih! Superlative
To all relations, not examples now!
I've known the Houhold Gods of Rome & Greece,
And all the good Penates of fam'd Troy,
Heard what they could triumph in, of their Fates;
Tell jovial tories of the frolick Greek • ,
And the great Banquets of fam'd Ilium;
Have been inform'd of Egypts glorious Feats
To entertain the Courtly Anthony:
Yet was there or Neceity, or pride,
Or empty prodigality in all.
Here is a Coure teer'd even, and voluntary;
And I rejoyce, as much as Ganymed,
Olympus Nectar, and Ambroia Keeper.
Here I grow fat with plenty of all orts
That either Seas, or Land, or Air can yield;
And here I live as well admir'd, as envi'd
By all the Lares of all other Places:
For there's a Contancie in my delights,
A blet Elyzium where I do not want
The tithe of any wih I ever thought.
The proudet Lares of the greatet Princes
May boat of tate, and languih in a noie,
Whil't here I live ecure, and do enjoy
As much of every thing, but fears and dangers.
And may it lat while Fate attends on time,
Until the upreme Deities of Heaven
Think you too worthy to adorn the earth,
And mean to fix you glorious Stars in Heaven:
And whiles there's air but to receive a Sound,
May your Names buie it to peak your praie
Continue ever matchles, as you are
A Pair without Compare, and but a Pair,

div.stage: A Satyre invited by the Loudnes of the Muick, and the perpetual concoure of people to inform himelf to what end all tended, comes boldly in, and meets with the Lar Familiaris.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: What means this bold Intruion?

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Friend, forbear,
Though I was born ith' Woods, and rudely bred
Among the Salvages, I have a mind
Apires the knowledge of great Princes Courts,
And to what end aimes all this jollity
In yours as well as others Palaces.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Dot thou approch to cenure our delights,
And nip them in the bud? Satyre! take heed
We'l hunt you hence through al the woods&launs,
And over all the brooks thine eyes have een.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: You threaten more perhaps then you can do:
What art?

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: I am this Palace Deity.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: I wih tho • wert a Servant unto Pan,
Or any God that doth frequent the Fields.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: So would not I: I'm better as I am.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Thy Ignorance bewitches thee to this:
Thou liv't among all fears, all noie, all cares,
While I walk merry under heavens bright eye.
We in the Fields are free from any Sin
Againt th'almighty Deities of Heaven:
We know no Law but natures; do not tremble
At Princes frowns; have neither fear nor hope;
And are content, a State the Gods exceed not.
You languih in a perpetuity
Of thoughts as unconfin'd as are your ends
You truly lavih all your faculties
In getting covetous wealth, which we contemn.
Your leeps are tarting, full of dreams and fears;
And ours as quiet as the Barks in Calmes.
The youthful pring makes us our Beds of flowers,
And heaven-bright ummer waheth us in prings
As clear as any of your Mitres's eies:
The plenteous Autume doth enrich our Banquets
With earths mot curious fruits, & they unbought:
The healthful Winter doth not pain our bones,
For we are arm'd for cold, and Heat in Nature.
We have no unkind loves in meads or fields,
That corn our tears, or light our amorous ighes.
Nor are we frantick with fond jealouie,
The greatet cure Iove could inflict on's Queen,
For all her curious earch into his Life:
We in the woods eteem that Beat the tateliet
That hath his head the richliet pread with horns.
The Golden Age remains with us, o fam'd
By your Athenian and Roman Poets.
Thus we enjoy what all you trive to get
With all the boundles riches of your wit.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Satyre! When I but ay th'art Ignorant,
Thy flourihing Boat is anwered at the full.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: But I deire a larger way.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: And take it.
Cant thou compare the Rags of nakednes
Before the tudied dreings of thee times?
And cant thou like a cold and tony Cave
Before the perfum'd Beds of Palaces?
Admire the Melancholie falls of waters,
Or whitling Muick of th' incontant windes,
The chirping dicords of the wanton Birds,
Above the Angel-voices of our Ladies,
And th'exquiite variety of Muick
Order'd to thouand everal Intruments?
Content to cloy thy homely Appetite
With Crabs, and Slows, and Nuts, and rude mixt herbs,
Before the tately Banquets of the Great?
How cant thou like Beats inarticulate voices
Above the Heaven-given eloquence of men?
Forake the Woods (fond Satyre) and but try
The unthought difference 'twixt them and us.
The Hills are fit for Beats: Convere with men,
And thou wilt never like thy Caue agen.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Thou almot dot perwade me: but then I
Shall leave mine old, and honet Company.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Thy new Ones hall exceed them. Her's a
Wil give thee wine as rich as is thy blood:
And her's a Cook will clothe thy bones with fleh Butler
As rich as was young Jaon's Golden Fleece.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Well: I will live with thee.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: And welcome Satyre.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Spite of the Fates, and Grecia's bet Protector,
I'le be Achilles, and o'recome by The Cooks Name. Hector.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: A reolution worthy thy Sylvanus.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: But for my lat Farewell unto the Woods,
• 'le hew you a wild Dance of nimble Satyres:
For we do dance as much as they that live
In Princes Courts, and Tiue-Palaces.

lg.head: Firt Song.
lg.l: YOU Satyres that in Woods
Have frozen up your bloods,
Advance your elves, and how
What great Pan's men can do;
Appear.
Here you had need beware,
And move as wift as Air:
Thee are not Sylvane Swaines,
But Courtly Lords and Dames Sit here.

div.head: The Antimaque.
div.stage: Satyres rudely but decently attired, stuck with Flowers, and Bayes-Chaplets on their heads, come in, and dance as many everal Anticks, and in as many everal hapes, as hall be neceary. Being ready to depart, two excellent youths in rich apparel, come triving in together; to whom the Lar speaks.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: What do you mean (weet Boys) to interrupt
Our ports? I pray you leave your wretling thus,
And do not trike your skins, too oft for blows.
He would out-run me, and be kit before me.
And he leave me among thee dreadful Satyres.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Whence come you?
We both were left i'th woods, and tempted by
Such things as thee to live abroad with them.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: What would you have?
I would go to my Father.
And I unto my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Who is your Father?
The ever honour'd Earl of Chesterfield,
Worthy of all his Titles by his vertues;
And full of Noble thoughts. A great maintainer
Of our great Grand-Fathers vertue, Hopitality:
The Feeder of the poor; whoe Gate's o open,
It doth not need the Office of a Porter:
Whoe Houe is now Delphian Apollo's eat:
For he's the Patron of all Arts and Wit.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: And who is your Mother, pretty One!
She is the Countes to that Noble Lord;
A Lady worthy more then earth can give her:
Rich in thoe vertues make her Sex admir'd;
A fair exceeder of the bet examples
That Greek or Roman tories e're produc'd:
Goddes of Tame, of Anchor, and of Trent.
She's uch an one as hath none equal to her,
And therfore you may very eaily know her.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: I know them both, and honor'd in my knowledge:
Sweet youth! yon'd is your Father, kis his hand:
And that (fair little One) th'unequal'd Lady
You asked for: go, and beg a kis of her.

div.stage: Here the Lord of the Houe gives his hand to his Son, and the Countes kies her Son. Then the Satyre peaks to his Companions.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Fellows, ince you have done, Farewel: I'le leave you
And all the rural Patimes of the woods:
I like this noble Company o well,
That I hereafter here intend to dwel.

div.stage: The Anti-Maquers depart: then the Lar Familiaris peaks to the Satyre.

sp.speaker: Lar.
sp.l: Now (Satyre) I will let thee ee how far
The Palace-pleaures do exceed the Woods.

div.stage: The Lar leads the Satyre to a curious bower, all deckt with the bet and finet flowers of the eaon: and opens a wide entry into it, where itting upon pleaant banks, full of the weetet herbs and delicatet flowers, he dicovers the Maq • ers: then preently invites them forth with this ong.

lg.l: IT is unfit we hould be dumbe,
When beauties like to thoe of Heaven
To grace our mirths are hither come,
And help to make our meaures even.
Then let us dance, and let us ing,
Till Hills and Dales with Eccho's ring.
Now it is fit our Souls hould know
No thought but what is full of pleaure;
That we our orrows hould out-go,
And tread them down in every meaure,
Then let us dance and let us ing,
Till Hills and Dales with Eccho's ring.
'Tis mirth that raieth up the Minde,
And keeps Dieaes from the Heart:
Sports harmles never were inclin'd
To cherih vice, but to divert.
Then let us dance, and let us ing,
Till Hills and Dales with Eccho's ring.

div.stage: Here the Grand Maquers come forth; the Ladys dret like the ancient Goddees; then the Lar speaks to the Satyre.

sp.speaker: Lar.

l.U: it, and oberve a while alone:

sp.l: For I do mean to mix with thee in Dance.

div.stage: Here they Dance what or as many Set-dances as they pleae, the Maquers being Men and Women, or onely Women: When they have danced all they intended, the Lar, or one of the Maquers invites the Spectator-Ladyes with this ong to joyn with them.

lg.l: COme Ladyes rie, and let us know
Now you have een, what you can do;
Harke how the Muick doth invite
All you to Solemnize this Night:
Then let the Sounds that you do hear
Order your feet unto your ear.
O rie! rie altogether,
And let us meet:
Muick's Divine, and well may joyn
Our motions rude unto a weet.
The Figures of the Magick Art
We'l equall in a better part:
Judicial Atrologie
Cannot cat uch an one as we:
Adde but your skill (as we deire)
And wee'l keep time to Phoebus Lyre.
O rie! rie altogether,
And let us meet:
Muick's Divine, and well may joyn
Our Motions rude unto a weet.

div.stage: Here all the Company dance what they pleae, and while they pleae; when they leave, the Lar, or one of the Maquers, ings this to the pectator Ladyes, as they go from them.

lg.l: LAdyes enough; we dare not
Tempt you to more then this;
Now may your Servants pare not
To give each of you a kis:
If we were they you hould have them
To recompence your pain:
O happy they that gave them,
And may give them again!
'Tis late; Goodnight: go leep, and may
Soft lumbers crown your eyes till day.

div.stage: This being ung, the Maquers, the Lar Familiaris, and the Satyre, go into the Arbour, which cloes on them.

div.head: An Epithalamium, deign'd for the Nuptials of Sir Andrew Knyvegton my Wives Brother, and Mrs. Elizabeth Stanhope of Elveton my Couin-german; Their Marriage prevented by her death.

lg.l: RIe amorous Virgins, rie and dres
The Bride, her Groome's in readines:
She wakes, and fain would call you from
Your Beds, but bluhes; therefore come.
The early Bridesgroom wears he knowes
You dream't to night of pleaing Showes;
Of Hymen joyning willing hands
To be ubjected to his bands;
Of Hymen joyning mutual hearts,
And Hymen joyning other Parts;
Or ele you did not leep at all,
For thinking what was to befall
To the fair Virgin, that to night
(Full of oft trembling, and delight)
Mut a pure Maiden go to Bed
And rie without her Maidenhead.
But merry Laes hat; It may
Be your own turn another day:
Attire her quickly, and while you
Are buied o laugh at her too;
And any of you would laugh to be
So happy, and o nigh as he.
Let her be dret as Juno, when
She tempted Jove, corn'd mortal men:
As the bright Cyprian Queen, when he
Did firt enthral War's Deitie:
As the delicious Memphian Dame
When he great Anthony o'recame,
Not by her Souldiers materies,
But beams of her al-powerful eyes.
Now he is ready, tay a while,
And let us ee her bluh and mile:
May all the Genial powers Divine,
Mot gentle weet One, now combine
And hower and power upon you two
All that you can deire, they do.
But lead her out; Now go together
To be of two made one, or either:
You go divided, and alone,
But mut return both of you One:
He mut be hers not his, and he
Mut not be hers, but his mut be.
Now they do walk triumphant o're
Thoe fears that troubled them before;
And all their friends attendants by,
All joyful for this day of joy.
She tudies not as he doth go,
How he again may anwer No;
But unto every thing ay I,
As all the Maides would that are by.
He happy man, oon to be blet,
Unto the Temple maketh hat:
And every minute hates that tands
Not 'twixt their hearts but 'twixt their hands
Behold! they are arrived where
They will be placed in one Sphere,
To run through a mot glorious Life
Of Love; mot bleed Man and Wife.
Th' Amazed Priet when he epies
The radiant beauties of her eyes,
Cannot believ't the Bride to be,
But an Immortal Deitie
Decended from Olympus Top,
Where they all drink in Hebe's Cup;
Or Cytheraea Queen of love,
Or the chat daughter of high Jove,
The new Solemnities to grace,
Or on the youthful Pair to gaze.
But when he's atisfi'd 'tis he,
He looks no more for fear that he
His heart hould deep enthral in love,
Pat any hope of a remove.
When both are willing and pat woing,
No Marriage can be long a doing:
The Paron asks, and they Conent,
Both eager of their own Content;
Though now and then he miles, and he
Doth bluh to think what oon mut be.
Now all is done that's to be done
Within the Church, and they are One
The Bride-men wih all joy betide
Unto the glad and bahful Bride;
And the Bride-maides do bid the like
To him: which he expects at night.
At their Return (with all the prayers)
Of all their Friends for happy years)
A Sumptuous Dinner doth invite
All to't with different Appetite.
Mot it to feed their covetous eyes
With the Brides matchles delicacies:
No other Object can remove
Their looks, and many roe in love,
Some old cold few, and their neer kin
Eat well, and many healths begin
To both their future days of joy,
And the oon getting of a Boy:
Such healths do often make her pred
Her beauteous face with udden red;
For Virgins often bluh to hear
Thoe things they long for, and love dear.
All Dinner-while a fine-voic't Boy
Sings many a Song, and many a Toy
Of Love, and of lot Maiden-heads,
And all the joyes of Marriage-Beds.
The Bridegroom happiet man of all
May afely take urvey (and fall.
Into no danger) of the weet
Delicious Bride; and he doth meet
His every look, and every mile,
And bluhes for't all dinner-while.
She is aham'd to look therefore;
And loves o he cannot give o're.
On fire and fire again they et
Their hearts, but careles are of it:
They know the night will come, and then
Th'are ure to cool themelves agen.
Dinner being done, the afternoon
Is tedious in regard of oon;
Yet with variety worn away
