Of ports belonging to that day.
They dance, and the fair Bride doth move
In conjuring circles of weet Love:
She treads o evenly as he meant
To make the ground an Intrument;
And ends up ounds o oft and rare,
Angels might dance unto that Aire.
The Bridegroom's blet by every tongue
Of all the merry various thronge,
To be an Owner of that One,
Whoe equal they have never known:
And he is counted happy too,
To be belov'd by him, o true
To her, and worthy unto all,
Both blet in equal Nuptial.
He now dares boldly kis, and oft
Doth give her hard ones; he him oft.
She is his own, and no delight
He wants, but what will come at night.
Though he's aham'd when he doth kis,
She's not content when he doth mis.
And thus the Afternoon being pent,
Time draws them nearer their content;
They go to Supper, not to eat,
But both to be reveng'd on meat:
Becaue, till that be done they know
To bed they mut not, cannot go.
Supper being finih't (and indeed
Too much time, knowing what's to ucceed)
The fearfull Virgin's lead away
Trembling at what he would aay;
And her undrees tell next morn,
What he mut rie, yet wih her turn:
And lay her in a bed o weet,
Jove would come down to't, did he ee't;
Where lies a jewel of richer ue
Then either India can produce.
The firt aault he wiheth done;
And he that it was but begun:
What between miles and fears, he lies
In the tru't poture to entice:
And carce dares ee who looks upon her,
Thinking her honour her dihonour.
Her Bed doth eem the bower of blis,
Where every weet and pleaure is:
Her eyes two Lights divine, to mile
On all, and comfort them the while:
Her delicate hair (that's onely found
Upon her Cheeks) a net on ground
Of puret Marble, et to take
Not onely Mars, but all that make
On high Olympus top abode;
Even every tern, and gentler God.
Her Lips the twins of Lovelines,
Like roes on a bank, that bles
The eyes of all the lookers on;
From whence a Zephyrus doth come,
So weet, and calm, as it would oon
Turn every thing into perfume.
The pleaant Garden of Delight,
Her cheeks mantled with red and white,
Seem like the early morning, e're
The Sun comes in our Hemiphere.
The Stately Column of her Neck,
Is onely worthy to protect
Beauties rich Palace, her fair head,
As mooth as Ivory polihed.
She was in bed, and we no more
Could ee of all her wondrous tore.
Now comes the Bridegroom, now o blet,
His onely mierie's not undret:
He helps, and they do help him treight;
(Few Men do linger on this night.)
Who oon tands in his Shirt, whil't he
Doth hide her Face, aham'd to ee:
But by her ide he's quickly laid
And kies the fair bahful Maid.
When they hop'd all would leave the Room,
The Bridal Poet in doth come:
A Ceremony he exclaimes
Unfit for Hymens youthful flames,
And all the company prayes, (If we
Mut eat it) let it our breakfat be:
And many thought the Virgin kind
Was alo of her Bridegroom's mind.
The Company laugh'd, and aid 'Twas jut
For him to do as others mut:
There is no help, he doth obey,
And eats to get them oon away.
The Poet being done, they wih
Goodnight, and leave them to their blis.
Now he and he are equally
Blet, and poet both of their joy:
And Innocent Love his Part doth play,
And recompences long delay.
Love's is no Coward Fight, although
A Friend meets Friend, and Foe not Foe;
It is a battel weet, not cruel,
And yet an even and naked duel:
No timorous giving back, yet trife
Perpetual 'twixt man and wife.
As Nilus in one channel bound,
Runs long through Egypts fertile Ground,
And yet at lat into even Currents
Divides his wift and plenteous Torrents,
And eparated o runs on
Till it mix with the Ocean:
So, happy Pair, I wih may prove
Your fruitful and aupicious Love;
May you pas through a fortunate
And glorious Life, and know no fate
Siniter whiles you live; and from
Your Loves an hopeful Off-pring come,
That may grow great, and equal good
As you are now, and as their blood:
To honours highet Zenith climbe,
And fix there till the end of time.
As this, I wih full of delight
To you all nights; and o goodnight.

div.head: 1. To the Right Honourable Philip Earl of Cheterfield, Baron of Shelford, &c. My Uncle.

lg.l: MY Lord, you are my Patron; and I'le tell
The reaon why, then judge if I do well:
None of thee Epigrams are worth a ruh;
And naughty Wine doth need a gallant buh.
Though (Generous Reader) now and then I write
Veres that jutly may appear too light:
Yet on my word (and you may credit me)
In jet I make them for varietie;
And do protet to all cenorious men,
They flow not from my heart, but from my Pen.
What a beginning is, you fain would know,
And it therefore unto you thus I how:
You are exceeding naught; be good, and o
Of a beginning you example how.
School-fellows when we (Friend) together were,
The veres that I writ you lov'd to hear:
Soon as I can I will requite the ame;
In the mean while receive this Epigram.
But this is nothing you reply: In troth,
And your applaues then were little worth.

div.head: 5. To my Couin germane Mrs. Olive Cotton.

lg.l: Supicion, Grief, Didain: Fame, Beauty, Truth,
Wrongeth, conumes begets: keeps, wounds, indueth
Friendhip, life, hatred: deeds, the mind, the bet.
You want the firt three, and enjoy the ret:
Supicion hate, hun grief, abhor didain,
Love fame, keep beauty, and in truth remain.

div.head: 6. To my worthy Friend Mr. Harbert Aton.

lg.l: When we at Chenie School together were,
I knew you often to abue a Boy,
Whom, when he did to you for pity cry,
You beat the more; but good Sir! Do you hear!
Is not this true, when he to you did mone
Did he not then lament unto At • n?

div.head: 7. Of my elf, when I was motion'd to a Judges Daughter.

lg.l: I hate to lacquey humours, and detet
Some things as vile, though others think them bet.
I mut not loe my freedom for a face
I cannot dote on; nor refrain that place
Nor company I like; think Poets poor,
Of Captains too prejudicately, endure
No ight of Wine, judge Playes unlawful be;
A fraudulent hadow men can onely ee.
Hypocriie I do abhor; and woo'd
My Life hould be chearful as well as good.
I know I have pies on me, but I light
Their vigilancie, and dare take my delight.
I may obtain another Mitres, know
No uch contraints for her, nor undergo
Cenure for things I hould do: I prefer
My liberty, and friends much above her:
Not that I do dilike that beauty; o
I hould erre foully from a truth I know.

div.head: 8. Of my taying Supper with my Couin Mrs. Olive Cotton.

lg.l: If that the Seas were gentle, there would be
No violent Tides, waters would run as free
When they mix with the Ocean, as at firt
When out of their original rocks they burt.
If that the winds were quiet, and would tay
Enclos'd in rocks under their Sovereigns way;
The frighted Lilly would as firmly grow
As the great't-bodied Beach, and never bow.
If that wie Fate had not appointed what
Our lives hould aim to, either this or that;
Rebellious man would make his will his rule
To live by, and his Soul his body's fool.
I meant not to have tai'd: but mut relate,
Ladies do what they pleae like Seas, Winds, Fate.

div.head: 9. An Epitaph on my younger Brother Mr. Thomas Cokaine, who died at Bath about the 18th year of his age, and lyes there Buried.

lg.l: Paenger tay, and (though thou art
Of Flint) weep e're thou dot depart:
For underneath this tone lies he
Who was Heavens Epitome.
Mourn, if thy Friend, that he did take
His flight o oon, and thee forake:
Or (if a tranger to his worth)
That he unknown to thee went forth.
What old men are o long about,
He learn't to do e're he went out;
The Art of dying well: And o
May all by him. Now thou mai't go.
On hopefull youth, and let thy happy train
Redeem the Glory of the Stage again:
Leen the Los of Shakespeares death by thy
Succesful Pen, and fortunate phantaie.
He did not onely write but act; And o
Thou dot not onely act, but writet too:
Between you there no difference appears
But what may be made up with equal years.
This is my Suffrage, and I corn my Pen
Should crown the heads of undeerving men.
Heroick Caear that did overcome
So many Nations, triumphed in Rome,
Was by a Lady's eye captived o
That amorouly he did both court and woe;
And never quiet was till he enjoy'd
Fair Cleopatra her young brothers bride:
Illutrious Anthony did leave the Care
To be Romes Emperour, and forook the War,
Left all his Souldiers in a doubtful Fight,
And on the Seas purued his fled delight.
Since uch great mindes by Love enthralled be,
Wherefore, alas! wonders the world if we?
May married couples lawfully enjoy
The Sweetes of Love till they themelves do cloy,
And mut the ret their cenures undergo
For the ame thing which they o often do?
We mut not have fruition where we woo'd,
But onely there where we do know 'tis good.
A circumtance doth make a thing unjut:
For th'chatet Love is but a Lawful Lut.

div.head: 12. To young Maides, tranlated out the 3. lib. De Arte Amandi.

lg.l: Venturae memores jam nunc etote enectae:
Sic nullum vobis Tempus abibit iners.
Dum licet, & veros etiam nunc editis annos,
Ludite: unt anni more fluentis aquae.
Nec quae praeteriit rurum revocabitur unda:
Nec quae praeteriit hora redire potet.
tendum est aetate; cito pede labitur aetas:
Nec bona tam equitur quam bona prima fuit.
Think often on old Age, and it's decayes,
And o you will not loe your flourihing dayes.
Whil't you enjoy fit years, young wenches, play:
For years like peedy waters teal away.
Pat treams will never be cal'd back again:
Nor will an hour return, though pent in vain.
Ue youth, for it quickly away doth pas,
And time to come's not as the former was.
Thus far the Roman Poet. But alas
That book the caue of his exilement was:
And (if you follow the advie h'ath given)
'Twil work you a wore banihment from Heaven.
Away (fond thing) tempt me no more;
I'le not be won with all thy tore.
I can behold thy golden hair,
And for the owner nothing care:
Thy Starry eyes can look upon,
And be mine own when I have done:
Thy cherry ruby lips can kis,
And for fruition never wih:
Can view the Garden of thy cheeks,
And light the roes there as leeks:
Can hear thee ing with all thine Art,
Without enthralling of mine heart:
My Liberty thou cant not wrong
With all the Magick of thy tongue:
Thy warm Snow-breats and I can ee,
And neither igh nor wih for thee:
Behold thy feet, which we do bles
For bearing o much happines;
Yet they at all hould not detroy
My trong preerved Liberty:
Could ee thee naked as at firt
Our Parents were when both uncur't;
And with my buie earching eyes
View trictly thy hid rarities;
Yet after uch a free urvey,
From thee no Lover go away.
For thou art fale, and wilt be o,
I ele no other fair would wo.
Away therefore, tempt me no more,
I'le not be won with all thy tore.

div.head: 14. Of my Mitres, written at Venice

lg.l: I thought when I was far remov'd,
My Mitres I hould not have lov'd;
But having een another Fair
(As in all Cities Beauties are)
My former paions hould forget,
And here a new affection et.
But Venice, though fam'd every where
For matchles Ladies, cannot bear
My thoughts from her whom I unkind
(Though he the caue) have left behind.
Had he not been a cruel One,
But lov'd, I then had tai'd at home:
And be he far more harher then
Tigers half tarv'd, or alvage men;
Abroad he hall not kill me, I
In my own Countrey will go die;
And vow ome true friend to engrave
Upon my Stone this Epitaph:
Here lies the Man, whoe faith him lew;
Who till had liv'd if been untrue.

div.head: 15. To Mrs. Mary Coke, an Acrotick

lg.l: M y buie eyes lately captiv'd me o
A bove my trength, I know not what to do.
R etain my Liberty I could not: all
Y our beauties, Lady, needs mut make a thrall.
C ould I but hew my heart, which I deire;
O n it your Picture you might ee entire.
K inde therefore be, and let it be your will
E ffectually to ave, and not to kill.

div.head: 16. To my Uncle Sir John Stanhope, an Acrotick

lg.l: S ir, to be ilent unto you, would be
I magin'd ill by you, thought wore by me;
R eaon I have to write, and therefore will:
I cannot with my thoughts it and be till.
O ver and over let me earch my heart,
H ere you, and there I find in every part.
N o man was ever to another bound
S o much as I to you; for you have found
(T o make your elf more matchles) uch new
A s the Invention would extort a praie. (wayes,
N ature was kind to me, and I do bles
H er care, to give me uch an happines.
O nely t'have been your friend had been a fate,
P roud to have made me ever: but my State
E xceedes; I am your Nephew, and you do
Increae my joy, and make me your friend too.
Shall I be ilent then? I can as well
Make my elf worthy as refrain to tell.
You are my wonder; every word you peak
Vice trembles at, and thinks that he hall break.
No top hath vertue, but you do remove,
Cating the ame away out of your love.
Live long, and glory in your worth: for you
Equal your will, exceed what others do.
I love a Las, whoe eyes are Stars Divine;
Whoe teeth are pearls et in a ruby line;
Whoe mouth's a acred pell, and doth encharm
Her coldet hearers hearts, and makes them warm;
Whoe hairs are curls of God, and can compel
The God of Love himelf to love her well.
But be he cruel; would here eyes were not
Such Heavenly Stars, that they might be forgot;
Would her teeth were not pearls, but far from fair,
That I for them at all might nothing care;
Would her mouth were an homely one, and all
Her hair would change the curious hew, or fall:
For if my Mitres force me to depair,
I cannot chooe but wih he were not fair.

div.head: 18. To my Couin Mr. Charles Cotton, an Acrotick.

lg.l: C ouin, I write to you that you may know
H ow much I love you, and how much would
A ll that I can I will do, and have good (how:
R eaon to do much more, and if I coo'd.
L ong time I have deired to expres
E ach thought I have of my own happines;
S uch you have made me by your love, and do
C ompel me each day more to honour you.
O 'tis a noble part in you to make
T rue friendhip whereoe're you undertake.
T hus you do live, and living o you may
O mit the care of your departing day;
N o death can raze your memory away.

div.head: 19. To my very good Friend and Couin Mr. Roger King.

lg.l: I love, and o do you; but know you whom?
Faith that ame party bet that firt doth come:
And my love is as contant as her tay;
Why hould I love her when he goes away?
If you are of the ame mind, we are then
Two contant Lovers though not contant men.
We both are till in love, but fix not; for
We the new Object evermore preferr:
And that affection urely is mot wie
That comes not from the heart, but from the eyes.
Weep out thine eyes (Thalia!) why are they
Unmelted yet into an Inland-Sea?
Drown all thy landerers with them; uch as dare
Affirm thee guilty, and thy name not fair:
Or rather corn their Ignorance that frame
Unworthy Calumnies againt thy Name.
Mnemoyne, thou mother of the maides,
And you weet Siters that in Acra hades
(Retired from the troubles of the Earth)
To many a lating vere give fortunate birth;
Do't not offend you that the Comick Mue
Should uffer uch affronts, and high abue?
Becaue that I frequent the thronged Stage,
I'm cenur'd by the malice of this Age
Of Levity; but I depie the frowns
Of rigid Cato's, and the his of Clowns.
Illiterate Fools may pleae their gluttonous tat
At dinner with ome Epicure-Lord, and wat
Their precious dayes in riot; whil't I feed
Mine ears with all the wit thee Times do breed.
Sing loud, Thalia! Noble Souls will love
To ee thy Servants in their Socks to move:
And may their ends be Tragical that hate
The harmles mirth thy Comedies create.
I do profes I'm one that do admire
Each word refin'd in true Poetick fire:
And do approve of natural action, where
Fables eem as true paages they were:
And love our Theatres of worth, where we
May thee in all thy everal drees ee.

div.head: 21. An Epitaph on my dear Couin German Mrs. Elizabeth Stanhope, who died at Elveton about the 20th year of her age, and lies there buried.

lg.l: Here lies a Virgin, and (in tead
Of loing of her Maiden-head;
For he hould oon have been a wife)
Bereaved of a noble Life:
Stanhopes lament, and Ratcliffes mourn
Before her ad untimely Urne.
But uch a orrow is too light
For caue of o extreme a weight;
Droop Elveton, and Darbyhire,
No Green, but black perpetual wear:
May April howers to Heavens tears turning,
Make all May-flowers pring up in mourning.
Weep all that ever knew her, or
Rather all that have heard of her.
For trivial Deaths let's mourning wear
Of black, for her of cloth of hair:
Or let us eneles clothes depie,
And how our adnes in our eyes.
Let's melt our hearts though they be tones,
And weep our eyes to Diamonds.
Which (being touch'd by deaths cold hand)
Congeal'd may on her Marble tand.
Any dicoure let us detet;
For ighs and grones expres us bet.
But who is this that we in uch
A orrow mut lament o much?
Elizabeth Stanhope; now you know,
Go mourn until you die for wo.

div.head: 22. An Epitaph on my dear iter the Lady Boteler, who deceaed about the 34th year of her Age.

lg.l: Here lies the Lady Boteler, who ran through
Two States of Life, and both of them o true
And jut were known to all that knew her, that
Her, her urvivers all may imitate.
The Virgin, and the matrimonial life
She blet with her example: And o rife
Her memory doth flourih, that it can
Not die, while there on earth lives one good man.
Cokaine her own name was: Elveton gave
Her Life, Tutburie death, Ahbourn a Grave.
I thank you (Lesbia) for your lips, and miles,
Your pretty courthip, and your amorous Wiles
Her breath was weet as Venus bower of blis,
Her joyes uncounterfeit, and not remis;
Her skin was mooth as calmet ummers day,
And warm as are the temperate Noons in May:
Her mind was willing, and her body laid
In th' truet Garbe to tempt who durt invade.
There wanted nothing to complete our joyes,
Had not the houe been liable to pies;
For I do value more a Ladies fame,
Then atisfaction of my highet flame.
Thus much in jet, now to peak truth is time;
I'm glad we parted, and ecap'd the Crime.

div.head: 24. An Epitaph on a great leeper.

lg.l: Here lies a great Sleeper, as every body knows,
Whoe Soul would not care if his body ne're roe.
The buines of life he hated, and choe
To die for his eae for his better repoe;
And 'tis believ'd when the lat trump doth wake him,
Had the Devil a bed, he would pray him to take him.

div.head: 25. An Epitaph on a great Wencher.

lg.l: Here lies a great Wencher, and dead I dare wear,
For were he alive an whore would be here.

div.head: 26. To my honoured Friend Mr. Marmaduke Wyvel.

lg.l: Sir, I have ever honour'd you, and do
Owe all fair ervice I can pay to you:
But (Friend) I owe you more then this, yet hall
(With all the peed that may be) abolve all.

div.head: 27. An Epitaph on Mrs. M. H.

lg.l: Here lies a body whoe oul went hence
Fuller of Glory then Innocence:
What her life wanted to make high
Her worth, he wrought when he did die:
And now when all her fight is done,
Her Foes mut ay that he hath won.
Let her faults perih with her breath,
And none think of her life, but death.

div.head: 28. To Mr. Nathaniel Hazard and his Wife, on their Marriage.

lg.l: Blet Pair Goodnight! The Prologue now is done:
Your wooing's pat, and both of you are won.
The weets of Love remain, the Play's behinde,
To yield delight to a long longing minde.
May all fair fortune crown your happy Lives,
You out-love husbands, and he out-love wives.
May every night and day, and day and night;
And hour and minute be to you delight.
May all my wihes proper, and may you
Never repent y'are one, and wih you two:
And (for your Epilogue) when you return
To earth, may all that know you for you mourn.
Why (excellent Corinna) do you throw
Your gold away for durt to lay on now?
For o, compar'd unto your whiter skin,
The Linen is you veil your body in:
For like a Diamond taken from a rock
You would appear unclouded of your mock.
Beauty and Honour are great names; and they
Here and hereafter differ many a way.
Beauty half Age detroyes; and none can be
Enamour'd on the fair't Anatome.
Immaculate Honour eaily diperes
All Cloudes that hover o're Heroes Heires.
Beauty triumpheth over humane kind,
And mighty Love enthrones in every mind.
Honour didains bae Actions, and would have
A noble life to be our Epitaph.
The fair Lycoris doth deire a long
And flourihing Spring of beauty, ever young;
Her many years to wear away in mirth,
And Heavens epitome to have on earth:
Her dayes in muick, and in feats; and nights
(Between her lovers Armes) in oft delights;
But with o cunning Carriage to enjoy
This momentary fale felicity,
As to deceive the curious world, that for't
She every where may have a fair report:
And that (when he enters the Grave's decent)
Honour may fix upon her Monument.
Mary a Chambermaid, a brown-eyde Las
Complain'd that he all day in labour was;
I laugh'd at her implicity, and aid,
Surely at Night then you'l be brought to bed.
Katherine a Kitchen-wench merrily aid
That lame men were the bet to pleae a maid:
I ask'd her why? She wittily repli'd,
They that have Legs defective love to ride.

div.head: 33. Of the Infamie of his Mitres.

lg.l: Rumor ait crebro notram peccare puellam:
Nunc ego me urdis auribus ee velim.
Crimina non hae • unt notro ine ficta dolore:
Quid mierum torques? Rumor acerbe tace.
Of falhood Fame my Mitres doth accue:
Would I were deaf, and could not hear the newes.
This is not forged without my uneae:
Why dot thou vex me? cruel Rumour, peace.
Pone arcum Paean, celereque reconde agittas:
Non te virgo fugit, ed tua tela timet.
Phoebus thy Bow and Arrows hide; for he
Thy weapons feats, but doth not fly from thee.

div.head: 35. To my Couin Mr. Charles Cotton.

lg.l: Pardon my boldnes (Couin) that defames
Your name among my trivial Epigrams:
Yet I before have ometimes us'd you thus;
For in my Eclogues you are Tityrus
Our good old Chaucer ome depie: and why?
Becaue ay they he writeth barbarouly.
Blame him not (Ignorants) but your elves, that do
Not at thee years your native language know.
Our Spencer was a Prodigie of wit,
Who hath the Fairy Queen o tately writ:
Yield Grecian Poets to his Nobler Style;
And ancient Rome ubmit unto our I'le.
You modern wits of all the four-fold earth (worth)
(Whom Princes have made Laureates for your
Give our great Spencer place, who hath out-ong
Phoebus himelf with all his Learned Throng.

div.head: 38. To my Noble Couin Colonel Ralph Sneyde.

lg.l: When the lat pring I came to Keel, and found
Old Hopitality on Englih Ground,
I wonder'd: and (Great Sydney) did prefer
My Sneyde uperiour to thy Kalander.
All things are neat, and Jovial Plenty keepes
Continual Fetivals by years, not weekes:
He good decai'd Houe-keeping doth revive,
And doth preerve our Englih Fame alive.
So liv'd our worthy Ancetours, and o
May you till you the oldet Man may grow
Within the Land; and ripe for heaven go hence,
Bemon'd as far as known. Poets th'expence
Of time and paper both may ave that day,
The Poor your lating't epitaph will ay.
Farmo one afternoon was drunk extreamly,
Wherein he curs'd, and wore, & ly'd, not meanly.
One ask'd him whence (when he had's wits again)
So many vices did proceed, o vain?
Marry (quoth he) as I do truly think,
They came not from my heart, but from my drink
The ecret caue of Ovids ad michance
Was eeing or being een in dalliance.
They that dare act that vice hould chooe their time,
And not add candal alo to the crime.
Sir, in your Epigrams you did me grace
T'allow me 'mong your many Friends a Place:
T'expres my gratitude (if Time will be
After my death o courteous to me,
As to vouchafe ome few years to my name)
Freely enjoy with me my utmot Fame.

div.head: 42. To the Lady Elizabeth Darcy, my Couin German.

lg.l: Madam, the greatet Ladies of pat Times
Kind Influences upon Poets rhimes
Have from their gracious eyes betow'd, and made
Them Heaven with their Inventions to invade
As the Pelignan Poet honour'd by
The upreme Princes of weet Italy,
Who inging her (under Corinna's Name)
Fill'd the whole Roman Empire with her Fame;
Which having pread from his immortal vere,
Is now renown'd through all the Univere.
And (Madam) you will do your elf no wrong
T'encourage a good Poet in his Song;
And to your mercy you no Injury do,
If you forgive this toy I've ent to you.

div.head: 43. To my worthy Friend Colonel Edward Stamford.

lg.l: Great-oul'd Achilles was a noble Friend;
Hector for valour every where renown'd;
Thouands the bounteous Caear did commend;
Antonius the bet natur'd man was found.
What need I earch for more in Rome or Greece?
You (in you) have the vertues of all thee.

div.head: 44. To my Couin German Mrs. Cordelia Harryes.

lg.l: When as in Cornwall at Powlmaggon, I
Enjoy'd that weet retired Companie.
Methought that houe afforded all the blis
Poets can feign there in Elyium is.
My Lord and Lady (blet in wedlock) led
Their dayes in as much quiet as in bed
They pent their Nights; fit couple t'entertain
Hermes and Jove, walk't they on earth again:
And their Houe to be made a Temple, where
Concor'd and peace triumphed all the year.
But old Philemon and his reverened wife
Led a mot poor though a contented Life.
My Lord Mohun liv'd in a plenteous wie,
Able to feat the wandring Deities.
You and your Siters Graces eem'd to grace
Your Parents firm Affection, and the Place.
So live the blet, and bet: and o may I,
While you a more trancendent Life enjoy.
You boat that you are beautiful, and wear
A everal rich Gown every week i'th' year;
That every day new Servants you do win:
But yet no vertue have to glory in.
One of les beauty and les bravery, and
Servantles, ooner hould my heart command.
Beauty will fade, and ruines leave behind;
Give me the lating beauty of the mind.
Servants and clothes are the Enammel oft
Of bodies too luxurious and oft.
Leave vaunting (Lydia) therefore till you can
Speak one true vertue, and I'le hear you then.

div.head: 46. Of a Room in an Ale-houe that we call the Apollo.

lg.l: This Room with Mirth and jets we hallow
Unto the Deity of Apollo
And (although here we do want Wine
To conecrate before his Shrine,
To abent Friends) we do prevail
In plenteous Pots of mighty Ale:
Such as it eemes great Dis did love,
Who Ceres daughter from above
Did teal; uch drink as will contrain
Ceas'd Oracles to peak again;
And noble Spirits will infue
Into the poor't and humblet Mue:
And Men in all the humours dres
Of Ovids Metamorphois.
An Ant by drinking this is grown
To be a luty Mirmydon:
The rutick Numa it will bring
From Plow, and make him Rome's great King:
Deire in coldet boomes move,
Quickning Pygmalion's marble Love:
Againt Troy's Conquerours combine,
And turn the victours into Swine.
Then welcome all that hate the Folly
Of Solitary Melancholy,
Love mirth and jets, and mean to hallow
This Room unto the great Apollo.
Talking with Delia I did perceive
A natural Perfume in her fragrant breath;
And could not chooe but gather many a kis
From her weet lips, Portculliies of blis.
Like a Chamelion I could live, and pare
All other things to feed upon that air.

div.head: 48. Ca. Germanici Auguti Epigramma de Puero Thraceni.

lg.l: Thrax puer atricto glacie cum luderet Hebro,
Frigore concretas pondere rupit aquas:
Dumque unae partes rapido traherentur ab amne,
Praeecuit tenerum lubrica tecta caput,
Orba quod inventum mater dum conderet urna,
Hoc peperi flammis, caetera dixit aquis.
A Thracian Boy on frozen Hebrus plai'd,
Till with his weight a breach i'th Ice he made,
Which from his body cut his tender head,
The ret being by the Waters wallowed.
His Mother igh'd (betowing 't in an Urne)
That I brought forth for waters, this to burn.
Germanicus was Druus Son, o'th high
And the illutrious Claudian Family;
An eminent Poet; to whom Ovid ent
His Roman Kalander from Banihment.
His Couin Agrippina was his Wife,
By whom he many children had. His life
(At thirty four years age in Antioch)
Tiberius (by poyon) from him took.
Of all his many Poems nothing came
Unto our Times, but that one Epigram.

div.head: 50. To my very good Friend Mr. Francis Lenton.

lg.l: Sir, many years ago when you and I
Frequently kept together company
With Mater Lightwood, and my Noble Brother
Sir Andrew Knyveton, and ome few uch other;
Tom Lightwood made each following Anagram
(Which I illutrated) upon your name,
While (at the Fleece in Covent Garden) we
Drank roundly Sack in Roen Cans, and free.
There all was done in jet, and o was took:
Pray laugh at them again now in this book.
Filpot! What Pot? A Roen Canne:
Who hall? Frank Lenton hall, that man,
But mut he then turn Tapter? No,
But fill for him he drinks unto.
He (like a mall Wit) corns to put
My Friends health in a little Cup,
But (like a Generous valiant man)
His mal't health drinks in a whole Can:
But Poets Drink is urely Wine;
No Ale-houe trah makes men Divine.
Why then Filpot, and Roen Can,
Except he be a Malt-drink-man?
He's nothing les; Glaes being mall,
In Cans he doth drink Sack to all.
His Anagram is true, and o
His ack doth him true Poet how:
He therefore is a Gallant man,
And owneth Filpot Roen Can.

div.head: 52. Francis Lenton. Anagram. Nann Colts fire.

lg.l: Nann Colts Fire, That is Love: For Love's a Flame;
But ure Nann Colt then is ome curious Dame.
It may be not: For he may carry perhaps
Nann Colts fire in his Breeches, have her claps.
Then Nann Colt is unound, and likely he,
Why hould he freher then his Mitres be?
Nann Colts fire once did burn his heart: but lo!
It now hath etled in a place below.
I thought that Poets Wits hould be of fire,
And not their bodies; that flames did apire.
<…> burnt Frank? Be not dejected; o
<…> of Wine hath been you know,
And yet the better for't; and o mai't thou
By leaving her upon a olemn vow.
But thou may't be her fire another way,
The Man that doth her heart and paions way:
A goodly fortune, to expres deire,
To have thy brains ditil'd by Nann Colts fire!

div.head: 53. To the World, of Nan Colt.

lg.l: If there be Lady that this Name doth own,
Or (of inferiour condition)
A Woman in the world; world! witnes bear
We did not mean (by this) to injure her:
We knew none uch, he found it in his name,
And (thus much aid) I hope w'are free from blame.

div.head: 54. To Mr. Francis Lenton, refuing wine.

lg.l: Dot thou endeavour (Franke) to leave thy drink
That made thee uch high raptures write & think?
Or art a weary of the Mues? for
What els could make thee Phoebus Sack abhor?
It is our grief, our mourning, and thy hame,
That the Queenes Poet, and a man of name,
Should drive Apollo from his breat with a
Fine glas of ix hillings, or a dih of Whey.
Redres our orrows, and return again
To wine, and make thy head like Charles his wain.

div.head: 55. Francis Lenton. Anagram. Not Nel; Cis, Fran.

lg.l: Not Nel, for he is fair and ound and weet;
But Cis, for he's as common as a treet.
Why hould a Poet that can drink bae drink,
After a Lady that's deerving think?
Or why hould you, becaue your Characters
Are good, expect a Mitres like the Stars?
Becaue your Anagrams are rich to you,
Would you a Mitres rich in beauty too?
Not Nel; Cis (Fran) is thine, and ue her well,
That's make her tympanous belly rightly well.
Blame not thy fortune but thine eyes; or ure
Some dark nights port behind, or 'gaint a dore.
What though he be decai'd like wither'd roe?
She is no ancienter then her bet clothes.
You'l ay this Anagram is naught: but hew
Your reaon, for we all do know it true.
However 'tis unfortunate, you'l ay:
For Poets Loves hould be as bright as day.
It is your name (good Fran) doth tell he's foul,
And makes the world acquainted with her oul.
But you will ask, why may not Cis be fair,
And Nel the homely One beneath compare?
This will not help you Fran: for Nel is known
Famous for beauty, witnes Sparta Town:
And Cis is yet, and hath been ever ince,
A common name for every Kitchen-wench.
You mut be patient therefore, and may thank
Your name for this fine beat; NotNel, Cis (Frank.)

div.head: 56. To my very good Friend M. Thomas Lightwood.

lg.l: Sir, that I do expoe thee trifles to
The world, which we (in jet) writ long ago,
Pray pardon me: for (I am ure) I do
A greater wrong unto my elfe then you.
After o many troubles, they remain
Once more to make us laugh at them again.

div.head: 57. To my noble Couin Mr. William Milward.

lg.l: When I have wanted company ometimes,
I've made my elf merry with writing rhimes;
And I do hope that reading them you will
Laugh too, and pardon what you finde too ill:
For worth your approbation here is nought;
My whole book being a continual fault.

div.head: 58. To my worthy Friends the two Colonel William Bales.

lg.l: So lov'd the two Alcides as you two:
So did Alcides and Paeantius do.
In the ame teps that Noblet friends have mov'd,
And with as firm a love as they have lov'd,
You hand in hand have walk'd, and work'd as high
And glorious Actions of Amity,
Striving each others affection to out-go:
Yet (from your Spheres of Honour) look'd below
On me, and me into your friendhip took;
Who here have link'd you (with me) in my book:
And that fair Fortune that your hearts inclines,
Grant us a life immortal in my lines.

div.head: 59. To my dear Couin Mr. Robert Milwand.

lg.l: Whil't you retir'd at Alop in the Dale,
With Poets and Philoophers convere;
And o're Voluminous Law-books do prevail,
And thoe hours you from tudy teal, depere
Into your Oeconomical Affairs,
You mixe much pleaure with ome eaie cares.

div.head: 60. To my noble Friend, Mr. Marmaduke Wivel.

lg.l: After o many in the Englih tongue,
Whoe happy Mues, Epigrams have ung,
I have too boldly done, and writ in vain
To get repute by following that train.
When I bethink me that great Johnon (he
Who all the ancient wit of Italy
And learned Greece (by his indutrious Pen)
Tranplanted hath for his own Countreymen,
And made our Englih tongue o well, that now
We carce an equal unto it allow)
Writ Epigrams, I tremble, and (intead
Of praie) beeech a pardon when I'm read.

div.head: 61. To my honoured kinman Mr. Henry Kendal the younger.

lg.l: Your Grand-Mother was hopitable, did
Invite me often to her houe, and bid
Me hearty welcome; And I hope to prove
The like effects hereafter of your love.
Poets of old were Prophets held; and I
For once will venture on a Prophey:
You hall at Smithsby flourih, gain the Hearts
Of all your Countrey by your worthy Parts.
Soft Virgins, you whoe tender hearts are prone
To yield unto your own detruction,
Reit all vicious flames, and you will find
The Glories of an undefiled mind;
Preerve your bodies as a Magazin
That doth contain the richet Treaure in;
For Diamonds, Pearls, and Stones of highet price
Heaven lov'd virginity mainly out-vies:
Patavine Chatity enjoying more
Content, then Acts of a A prime treet in Old Rome. Suburran Whore.
'Tis mean to yield ubmiion unto Sene,
When virtue hopes o great a Recompence.

div.head: 63. To the truly Noble Sir Arthur Gorges.

lg.l: Thoe worthy Romans that corn'd humble things,
Created, and obliged after-Kings,
Amidt their thoughts of highet honour, ne're
Conceiv'd Imaginations 'bove your phere.
The Babylonian Euphrates may
For ever run, and Tybris never tay;
The plenteous Rhine continually peed on,
And Danubie, each to it's Ocean,
And not out-go your fair and high repute,
Which doth amaze the world, and trikes me mute.

div.head: 94. To Sir Andrew Knyveton my wives brother.

lg.l: Wonder not why among o many of
My Epigrams, I do not oftner coff,
And taunt of men, oberving when they halt,
And tax them martly after for their fault.
I know that Epigrams hould either be
Satyres reduc'd to an Epitome;
Or els in choicet Language hould invite
(Being what you pleae) the Readers with delight.
Troth! I in coffes but little do prevail,
Which is the caue that I no oftner rail:
And have for Eloquence but what you ee;
And therefore all my friends mut pardon me.

div.head: 65. To my Couins Germans Mr. Cromwell, Mr. Byron, Mr. Ratcliff, and M. Alexander Stanhope.

lg.l: The worlds four Parts, and all the various Seas
And Rivers that embrace them thouand wayes,
Perfect the Globe terretrial, et it fix't
Equal the circumvolving Heaven betwixt:
So you four (joyning in a Sympathie
Of an unmach'd, fraternal Amitie,
Sought to for noble Soules, by all that can
Under and Honour, or a Generous man)
Are courted on all ides, and truly do
Love them reciprocally that love you;
So that your friends and you do jutly tand
The Centre of fair Friendhip in the Land.

div.head: 66. To my Couin Mr. Charles Cotton the younger.

lg.l: In how few years have you rais'd up an high
Column of Learning by your Indutry,
More glorious then thoe Pyramids, that Old
Canopus view'd, or Cair doth yet behold!
Your noble Father (that for able Parts
Hath won an high Opinion in all hearts)
May like the elder Scaliger look down
With admiration on his worthy Son.
Proceed fair plant of Ex'lencies and grow
So high, to hadow all that are below.

div.head: 67. To my honet Kinman Sir John Reppington.

lg.l: I pray you (Sir) impale your Woods, that we
In them the hunting of the Buck may ee:
By which good deed you will be ure to pleae grounds;
The Naiades, and Hamadryades;
Honouring the woods and brooks that grace thoe
And raie a tately Eccho by your Houndes,
T'invite Diana to your Groves; that he
A partner in your rural ports may be:
Or peirce the beauteous Goddes Venus ear,
And bring her down from her celetial phere
To be pectatres of your game; brought thence
To guard ome young Adonis from Offence.
By making you a park all this is done,
A pleaant Grace unto your Amington.

div.head: 68. To my Brother in Law Colonel Will. Nevil.

lg.l: The old luxurious Romans vaunts did make
Of gutful Oyters took in Lucrine Lake:
Your Eex better hath, and uch perchance
As tempted Caear firt to pas from France.
How did thoe ancient Worthies captive all
The humbled world unto their Capitol!
Yet from it's highet Towers could not urvey
So rich a Countrey as (from Holt) you may.
The noble Brutus, vertuous Portia,
Luckles Antonius, chat Octavia,
Soul-fix'd Paulina to her murther'd Lord
(The learned Seneca) uch worthes afford
As have atonih'd Ages; yet your bet
Of wives may jutly with them all contet.
You then enjoying a full Fortune, and
The delicacies may eat of Sea and land;
Your dayes pend at a houe of o fair ite,
And (with a o deerving wife) each night:
Conider (ince that you poes all this)
If y'are not happy, who the Devil is?

div.head: 69. An Epitaph on a Penitent Bawde.

lg.l: Here lies a good woman (to peak but the truth)
Who liv'd by her Tail all the days of her youth:
And when he was old, and none could endure her,
Stuck till to the Fleh, and became a Procurer:
Yet was at her death o full of Remores,
That he cri'd a peccavi for all her lewd coures.

div.head: 70. An Epitaph on an old Bawde.

lg.l: Here lies an old Bawde whom the grave hould have gotten
Fourty years ince, for then he was rotten:
Now here he doth lie for all People to pis on,
(For fear of Doomes-day) in a tinking Condition.
But enough of this buines; for well we may think
The more we tir in it the more it will tink.

div.head: 71. To my Couin Mr. William Milward.

lg.l: Whil't you at Chilcote live, and I at Pooley,
Let's every Week meet one another duly;
Talk of our long Acquaintance, and the trange
Things that have hapned ince this mighty change:
And drink a Glas of honet Countrey-Ale
To all our abent Friends at every Tale.
Es de vidrio la Muger,
Pero no e ha de provar,
Si e puede, O no quebrar;
Porque to do podria er.
Y es mas facil el quebrar e,
Y no es cordura ponere
A peligro de rompere
Lo que no puede oldar e.
Yen eto opinion eten
Tados, yen r'azon la fundo,
Que i ay Danaes en el mundo.
Ay pluvias de Oro tambien.
A Woman is of Glas, or weaker,
And hould not be put to the proof;
Or if he be, not as to break her;
Which is a thing facile enough.
Glas is crack'd with an eaie troke:
And it no widom is to put
That within danger to be broke,
Which never can be older'd up.
All men of an Opinion are,
And it upon this reaon ground,
That if there any Danaes were,
Gold Showers alo would be found.
A ervant maid in Winter wahing clothes
Upon the banks where pleaant Arnus flowes,
A paenger epi'd her, and did ay
I wih (weet heart) you had a warmer day.
She look'd upon him in a pretty nuff,
And then repli'd; Sir, here I've fire enough,
Laying her hands you may gues where. He mil'd
To hear her anwer come o quick, and wild:
And (pulling out his weapon) aid (fair Wench)
Light me this Candle then e're I go hence.
A few untoward Boyes hapning together,
Started a Quetion t'be reolved whether;
And from the younget put it to the oldet,
What part about a Woman was the coldet.
The firt a knee did ay (in his Opinion)
Was the cold't place of any female Minion.
The next recovering from ome thought he tuck at,
Said he conceiv'd it needs mut be her buttock,
By feeling cold (but he was but a Noddy)
When he takes up her clothes to eae her body.
The third then pake (with very earnet urging)
The breats he did imagine of a virgin.
Maid, or no maid, the fourth cri'd, 'tis no matter,
The cold't place ure lies between wind & water.
After the Quetion thus being vext and hammer'd,
Oh! igh'd a Lover (lately grown enamour'd)
(Who ever peaks the truth may be the boldet)
Of a coy Ladies parts her heart's the coldet.
I (quoth the ixth) from all of you do vary,
And am of an Opinion quite contrary:
Warm every where to th' purpoe (Pox confound
They all laugh'd, aying, he might thank his riot,
And they gues'd him a Clap by his trict diet.
My Hotes heard them, (grunting on her Palet)
And wore, an old Woman as any Sallet
Was cold & wholeome: And (to clear this riddle)
She to him call'd; Son! you may come and fiddle:
But he eem'd bahful, and refus'd the Grannum;
Swearing, what Lut is in thee beats to dam u'm?
One cleaving Billets for a Courtezan,
(Viewing her beauty) was a wounded man:
He igh'd, and mus'd, and did his work neglect;
So that he came and him for Loytering check't.
He tanding more amaz'd; he aid, peak (friend)
What dot thou aile? Why dot not make an end?
Recovering from's atonihment, he thought
That faint hearts never fair Atchievement wrought:
And (Mitres) aid, A great deire I have
To lie with you: She anwered him, peace (knave)
I corn o bae a Clown. For all this he
Pli'd her, and at the lat they both agree:
A Crown of Gold he was to give her: o
She pluckt her Clothes her favour to betow,
And with her white hand clapt her whiter Thigh,
Saying's this fleh fit for a Sawyer? Fye!
He hearing this look't on his Gold again,
And aid, is'e fit to give this to a Quean?
And o the Goodman chanced to recover,
(Saving his mony) and went home no Lover.

div.head: 76. Of a Gentleman of Venice, and his Mitres.

lg.l: A Gentleman of Venice (as the mot
Of them themelves do put unto that cot)
Kept a fair Mitres, and did every day
(In olace) weare with her ome hours away.
Coming one Afternoon (with an Intent
To pend ome time in amorous blandihment)
He found her undipos'd, and newly laid
Groning, and ick, and cover'd on her Bed.
He (eeing this) igh'd adly (Love) I fear,
I'm now but troubleome in taying here;
An other time I'le viit you. Pray tay,
Quoth he: Introth you hall not go away;
Come it down by me: Heark you (Servant) I
Am ner'e o ick, but on my back can ly.

div.head: 77. To my especial Friend Mr. Henry Thimbleby.

lg.l: Platonick Love mut needs a Friendhip be,
Or els Platonick Love's a Gullery:
Love is (as Johnon in's NewInne hath prov'd)
Deire of union with the belov'd:
And cannot onely be a gazing at;
But a trong Appetite t'incorporate.
Why do you praie a Ladies Beauties o,
And (in a ilence) let her vertues go?
Leave trifling; for we gather (by your uit)
Your marriage hortly will your words confute.

div.head: 78. The Florentine Dutches, and her Woman Dwarfe.

lg.l: A great Duches of Florence ome years ince
Had a She-Dwarfe of quick Intelligence,
And a urpaing beauty; whom (above
Her other Servants) he did highly love.
Nanna, I bear thee uch good will (he aid)
That I've a great deire to have thee wed
One of thy Size, but handome as might be;
Becaue I Children fain would have of thee.
Madam (he anwer'd I) have ometimes been
Within your Cellar, and your veels een;
And (which did me with a trange pleaure trike)
The great and leat had bunge-holes all alike.

div.head: 79. To my honoured Friend Sir William Peral.

lg.l: Sir, you are every where belov'd, and hould
I ay admir'd, my words a truth woo'd hold.
You mater all the Arts, and can dicoure
Of any cience from the very Source
To the full growth of it: From Pole to Pole
Nature hath made you Doctor of her whole.
What others have grown old about and gray,
You have acquir'd by a more gentile way:
For what they an Herculean Labour make,
To you is but a oft Sympoiack.
Your quick, all-apprehending brain is uch,
It dictates wonders; which are prov'd as much.
Let not this (Sir) eem flattery, and offend:
I write but what I think; And o I end.

div.head: 80. A Deign of an Epick Poem.

lg.l: I ing the valiant deeds and brave exploits
Of Brutus, equal to the Worthies Nine:
And the adventures trange of wandring Knights
Famous in ours, and Countries tranmarine;
From Italy their high aupicious flights,
Directed hither by the fates Divine:
And how fair Ladies (in their bloomy years)
Became enamour'd on thoe Cavaliers.
A work Heroick, worthy to be writ
In tately numbers equal to their deeds;
And by no humble, and no vulgar wit
By one that onely knows but oaten reeds;
But by an able Poet that can fit
Each Lover, and each Souldier in their weeds,
That knows to draw a Line o firmly wrought,
As neither Time nor War can bring to nought
But eeing none this Task to undertake,
And fearing thee great Actions might die;
Neglected cat all into Lethe Lake,
Becaue that ome malicious enemy
Hath won upon this tupid Ile to make
It think them Fictions rais'd by poetry:
I (out of zeal unto o great a truth)
Preent this poem to our Englih youth.

div.head: 81. To my vertuous fair Couin the Lady Trentham.

lg.l: Madam, I dare not blame this Age, nor call
Any vice in it Epidemical:
You are immaculate, and of o high
A vertue, that you awe Impiety.
Your Heart is a pure Heaven, where nothing is
Admitted that can be conceiv'd amis.
The Poets Flight of vertues I contemn,
And patient • low Atrea's after them:
You are their Sphere of happines, and do
Entertain all the Goddees in you.
You bear that holy Martyrs name that did
Die for her chatity, Saint Winnifrid,
An honour here you do her; and when you
Shall meet in Heaven, he will return your due:
You there will the precedent Saint appear,
And he your name eternally then bear.

div.head: 83. To my old Friend Mr. Rob. Grovenor.

lg.l: Sir, we have heard of Slanders of that height,
As if to Paradie they directed right:
When (out, alas!) it is a foul offence
Any way to traduce an Innocence.
Thoe Crimes that are by ome on others thrown
Guiltlely, they do make thoe faults their own:
And the jut Judge their punihment will give
Due to the ins that they have lander'd with.
Beides his Soul he within vengeance bounds,
That with a truth a reputation wounds:
Your Friend and mine o much abus'd doth fall
Under the Firt, and not the lat at all.
To talk of things commonly known and true,
No mulct from Heaven will unto us accrue.
But ure he of a blet Condition is
That hates of any one to peak amis:
That hath a merciful and candid thought,
And thinks all good, rather then any naught.
Heaven by a potles life is won, and by
The patient bearing of an Infamy.

div.head: 84. To my honet Couins Mr. Robert Milward, and Mr. Roger King.

lg.l: You bet of Friends, and my bet Friends, that me
Have many years grace'd with your Amity;
My lines you honour with your worthy Names,
(A lating Glory to my Epigrams:)
As Princes Stamps upon bae metals do
Make them prove currant, and of value too.

div.head: 85. To Sir Francis Boteler, my brother in law, from Ahbourn.

lg.l: How Chritmas teals upon us, as in fear
To be oppos'd by the bold Presbyter!
And how you part from us againt this Time,
As if you thought to meet it here a Crime!
But oh inevitable buines when
Old Chritmas we meant to have trick'd agen,
In's long neglected uual Ornaments,
You have prevented it by going hence:
So your Departure we accue to be
Guilty (by chance) of an Impietie;
Tom Hurt, Will Taylour, and my elf hall mourn,
Till you recover our joy by your return.

div.head: 86. To the right Honourable Henry Lord Hatings Baron of Loughborough.

lg.l: My Lord, when in my youth I (for ome while)
Did leave the pleaures of our native Ile,
And travel'd France and Italy, I pent
(Methought) my Time in a mot high content;
And was o far from longing to return,
That I when I was ent for home did mourn.
And doubtles you are pleas'd, who now enjoy
A Calme after a torme of jeopardy.
Homer his Iliads might have writ of you;
And (as our fear prompts) his Odyes too.
But we will hope the bet, and that you may
(As er't Ulyes to his Ithaca)
Return to England (all thoe tumults pat)
And finde it crown'd with happy dayes at lat;
Be reconcil'd to every own, and know
(Among o many Friends) no ingle foe.

div.head: 87. To my Noble Couin Mr. Henry Hatings of Branton.

lg.l: Sir, ince our firt acquaintance, ever through
Our Friendhip with the Noble Loughborough,
What tumults have we een, and dangers pat,
Such as in graves have many thouands cat!
And yet we live (thanks to the Powers Divine)
And love, I thank your Friendhip gracing mine.
I needes mut ay uch troubles diagree
Both with my Genius as well as me.
Though Poets often ing of Wars, and with
A mighty vere an Eccho eem to give
To the hrill Trumpet, or the loudet Gun
That thunder rores, and preads detruction;
Yet in a weet retreat from care and noie,
They draw thoe lines that make thoe Sympathies;
And though I am no Poet, I confes
I am enamour'd much of Quietnes.

div.head: 88. To the right honourable Charles Lord Cokaine, Vicount Cullen.

lg.l: My Lord, you have an honet Heart, and known
To be of a mot weet Condition;
A Grace unto our Family and Name,
And every where of a mot candid Fame:
This is a truth; but let you hould uppoe
(If I proceed) I flatter'd, here I cloe.

div.head: 89. An Epitaph on my worthy Couin German Colonel Michael Stanhope lain at Willoughbie-Fight, and lyes buried in the Church there.

lg.l: Here Michael Stanhope lies, who fought and dy'd,
When prop'rous fortune left the Regal ide:
He of a dauntles minde by all was known,
And of a Noble dipoition:
Yet his conditions, and his valiant Heart
Could not prevail with Death to tay his Dart;
For here he lies, and doth (by's Fall) expres,
Great Courages do often want Succes.

div.head: 90. An Epitaph on my dear Couin German Mrs. Olive Cotton.

lg.l: Paenger tay, and notice take of her
Whom this Sepulchral marble doth inter:
For Sir John Stanhope's Daughter, and his Heir
By his firt wife, a Berisfor'd lies here.
Her Husband of a Noble houe was one
Every where for his worthes belov'd, and known.
One onely Son he left; whom we preage
A grace t'his family, and to our age.
She was too good to live, and young to die,
Yet tay'd not to dipute with detinie;
But (oon as he receiv'd the ummons given)
Sent her fair Soul to wait on God in Heaven.
Here, what was mortal of her turns to dut,
To rie a Glorious Body with the jut.
Now thou may't go: But take along with thee
(To guide thy Life and Death) her Memory.

div.head: 91. To my Couin German Mr. John Stanhope of Elveton.

lg.l: When in an Epigram I did alute
Your other brothers, and of you was mute,
The reaon was becaue I did not know
Whether that then you were alive or no.
Your afety I congratulate, and wih
You a long Life of as long happines.
This Tribute of my Love to you I give,
Under the Honour of your Name to live.
Great Caears vaunt is known to all, who aid,
That he did come, look't on, and conquered:
But when to Egypt he did come from Rome,
And aw the Queen, he then was overcome:
But (to prove rather he was not beguil'd)
Her he o'recame; for he got her with childe.

div.head: 93. An Epitaph on my mot honour'd Kinman Colonel Ralph Sneyd, who dy'd in the Ile of Man about the 40th year of his Age.

lg.l: Here lyes a body that gave Lodging to
A Soul as noble as the world did know;
It was well-organ'd, handome, manly, and
Of equal tructure to the bet o'th Land:
Yet was unworthy of the Soul was given,
And therefore dy'd caue that fled back to Heaven.
Here Colonel Ralph Sneyd doth lie; In brief
The joy of mankind living, now the grief.
To peak too well of thouands afer is
Then of one ingle Peron once amis;
Happy is he therefore whoe wary tongue
Wiely refrains to do another wrong.

div.head: 95. To Elveton a Town in Darbyhire.

lg.l: Dear Elveton, that art a grace
Unto the Shire where I was born;
And Elveton, that art the Place
Where firt I did alute the Morn;
The noble Stanhopes are thy praie,
Whom thou afford't a birth, and Urne:
And may they flourih there always
Till th'world to Chaos doth return.

div.head: 96. Of Venice, Tranlated out of Sannazarius.

lg.l: Viderat Adriacis Venctam Neptunus in undis
Stare urbem, & toti ponere jura mari:
Nunc mihi Tarpejas quantum vis, Jupiter, arces
Ob • ice, & illa tui maenia Martis, ait

Si pelago Tibrim praefers, urbem aspice utram
que
Illam homines dices, hanc pouie Deos.
In Adriatick Waters Neptune aw
Venice, that layes on the whole Sea a Law:
Object Tarpejan Towers, Jove, whil't thou wilt,
He aid, and walls by thy Mars Off-pring built,
Prefer't thou Tyber! view both towns, and th'ods,
And thou wilt yield men that made, this the Gods.

div.head: 97. Of the Gratuity given the Poet.

lg.l: The noble Senate for the fair renown
(From his immortal pen) fix'd on their town,
Crown'd (with ix thouand crowns) the Poets wit;
'Would I had half o for tranlating it.
The tree a Grace to Eden did appear,
Yet was prohibited our Parents there:
So Women as earths glories we eteem,
And yet how mch are we forbidden them!
It pleaes Heaven to keep us all in awe
(To try our duties) by a rigid Law.
In Paradie a Woman caued all
The ruine of mankind by Adams fall:
What wonder then if they o'recome us here
When w'are more weak, and they perhaps as fair?

div.head: 100. An Epitaph on Mr. John Fletcher, and Mr. Philip Mainger, who lie buried both in one Grave in St. Mary Overie's Church in Southwark.

lg.l: In the ame Grave Fletcher was buried here
Lies the Stage-Poet Philip Mainger:
Playes they did write together, were great friends,
And now one Grave includes them at their ends:
So whom on earth nothing did part, beneath
Here (in their Fames) they lie, in pight of death.

div.head: 101. Of Augutus Caear, and Marcus Antonius.

lg.l: Augutus was to Ovid too unkind,
Who him not onely banih't, but confin'd
Him; had the noble Anthony o'recome,
He might have led his life, and di'd in Rome.
But of thee two great Romans this is known,
Caear caus'd others deaths, Marcus his own.

div.head: 102. To the Lady Mary Cokaine, Vicountes Cullen.

lg.l: Madam, I hear you do intend to grace
Your Ruhen with your preence all this year,
You cannot honour a more noble Place,
If you reolve the Countrey for your Sphere;
And Lords and Ladies enjoy happiet dayes
When in their homes their right Orbs they appear:
So Stars do glorifie Heaven that keep their Orders,
When Comets do preage ruines and murders.
Madam, I do recant what I have writ,
As avouring too much of a countrey-wit,
And I fear Clownihnes: for where hould your
Fair Sexe live but in London evermore?
Bright Ladies in the Countrey, we eteem
As the Sun haded by the cloudes doth eem;
So Pearls lie hid in Shells, and Diamonds o
Upon their olitary Rocks do grow.
As Stars grace Heaven your beauties do the town,
Which is the proper Sphere for them to own.
Hat therefore up; you here will prove a Star
Of Glory, who move there irregular.

div.head: 104. An Epitaph of Colonel Ferdinand Stanhope Son to the Earl of Cheterfield, who was lain about Shelford, and lies there buried.

lg.l: Here underneath this monumental Stone
Lie Honour, Youth, and Beauty all in One:
For Ferdinando Stanhope here doth ret,
Of all thoe Three the mot unequal'd Tet.
He was too handome and too tout to be
Met face to face by any Enemy;
Therefore his foe (full for his death inclin'd)
Stole baely near, and hot him through behind.

div.head: 105. To my Wives Neece Mrs. Elizabeth Pegge.

lg.l: I thank my Wife for my o neer relation
Unto a mine of vertue of our nation.
To name your handomnes I do decline,
As to tell Ethiops the Sun doth hine:
You are as witty as the Lesbian Las,
Who the tenth Mue o oft accounted was:
And chater then the glorious Roman Dame
That kil'd her elf for vicious Tarquin's hame.
Thus I could proecute your Worths, but know
Y'had rather Heaven then men hould judg you o.

div.head: 106. To her Brother Mr. Tho. Pegge.

lg.l: The various manners you of men have een,
And have in divers forreign Cities been;
And after three years travel are come home
From Bruells, Paris, and more glorious Rome,
To fix you here for all your future Life;
I wih y'a vertuous, rich, young, handome wife.
My Mall, how we deire both to go down,
And till how buines tayes us in the town!
Since Plays are ilenc'd by the Presbyter,
And Wine is grown o very naught and dear;

l.U: eems frowning like a Step-dame now,

lg.l: That look'd before with o erene a Brow.
Away therefore, and let us haten home
To our Loves pledges our dear Mall and Tom.
Hubert Wypart a Leigios ome years ince
My Servant was i'th Countrey, and from thence
Ask'd leave to go to London to be by
At a Friends death of his condemn'd to dy;
For he (he added) loves me o I know,
That he three hundred miles and more would go
To ee me hang'd; we could not chooe but laugh:
Hubert had leave to go; but's Friend got off.

l.U: ell good Ale; and ince we do thee grace

lg.l: To call thy Room Apollo, and the place
With mirth and jets raie Oracles in, be ure
Thy drink have trength to make them both endure:
For it would an Impiety be of thine,
With bae Ale to pollute bright Phoebus Shrine.
In lien of Eatern perfumes we will pay
Sacrifice of Verinas every day.
Though we by mighty Liquor fall ometime,
'Tis accidental, and a generous crime;
A fate that upon trictet Friends awaites,
When thoe that drown themelves in brooks,
What Vulcan's wife ell Ale! Thanks Venus for't;
The Goddes though did ue another Sport.

l.U: ince thou likewie art a Black-miths wife,

lg.l: Imitate omewhat the Cyprian Queen in life.
But thou art old, and honet: therefore get
A young Wench to fill drink that may be fit.
But thou too much of vertue hat; therefore
Sell Noble Sack, and we will ask no more.

div.head: 111. An Epitaph on Mr. Iaac Coe who died about the 40th year of his Age.

lg.l: Here Mater Iaack Coe of Lincolns-Inn,
A Glory to that houe, and to his kin,
Doth buried lie; which Los we needs mut mourn,
And pay our tears as Tribute to his Urne:
But how can we call this his Sepulchre,
Whom all his Friends do in their hearts inter?
Zoilus, thou ay't my Epigrams are wore
Then any that thy Cenurer did cure:
Zoilus, I am of thy Opinion too;
And therefore (pray thee) make no more adoo.
One, two, three, four, five, ix, even, eight, nine, ten
Have lain with Lupa, and all luty Men,
Such as their Boats of trength in each place tell.
Yet none of them could make her Belly well.
But Lupa vaunts of this; that he doth hate
Her Belly hould confirm what Men do prate.
A landerous tongue oft Innocence traduces;
But when the Belly tells, farewell Excues.
One, two, three, four, five ix, even, eight, nine, ten,
Eleven, twelve, thirteen, fourteen, fifteen Men
Sixteen, eventeen, eighteen, and nineteen more
Cloe hath tempted to make her an whore.
Count how many he hath wih'd he had lain under,
And you will find it come t'a pretty number.
Yet none of them have ever known her bed;
For Cloe till retains her Maidenhead.
Sure he's unhanome then! No; he's a Las
As beautiful as ever Hellen was.
She is oberved by o wary pies,
That hitherto he could not play her Prize:
But twenty t'one e'relong he'l find a time
To cheat their eyes, and perpetrate her Crime.
Some gallant Rivers do neglected run,
And have no viewers but the contant Sun,
The olitary Moon, and Beats that by
Their hollow banks do feed themelves to die:
Whil't upon Thames, the Glory of our Ile,
Fair Towns, and Palaces, and Catles mile:
But above all London (that doth embrace
Thoe prightly treams) affords the chiefet grace.
'Tis well it is o big; or ele this Town
(Would in the Beer that's drunk) oon quaff it down

div.head: 116. To my fellow Travellour Mr. Maurice La Meir, alias Ardenville.

lg.l: How many Cities have we een, together?
But now I wih we might een one another.
Porphyrius! that is enough to tell,
He that doth all things ill doth nothing well.
An Epigram's is too hort for uch a matter,
His faults but touch'd at brief deerve a Satyre;
And as an expert Archer hits the white,
So on the Black his Poet needes mut light.
She is his own, and he is happy much,
Becaue beides himelf none doth her touch:
But 'tis not for repect to him, or her;
For he's o foul all men do her abhor.
She contant is to him againt her minde,
And he t'her, 'caue he can no other find.
A wedding olemniz'd, becaue none els
Would court them to divide them from themelves:
And it is fit they hould be married, when
None els will have that Woman, or Woman Man.
The beats are coupled; and 'twill be no wonder,
If like beats they agree, or part aunder.

div.head: 120. An Epitaph on Mr. Humphry Cumberford who died in Tamworth about the 34th year of his age, and lyes there buried.

lg.l: Here Mater Humphry Cumberford doth ly,
Who was a Man of truth, and honety.
A Lady Knighted him (to his good fate)
Whoe Honour o cap'd nulling by the State.
Belov'd he was by all of every ort,
From Bes of Bow-Mill to the very Court.
He dy'd a maid, or (if he did do ill)
'Twas not his Nature, but againt his will.
But let him ret in peace; and may we all
Wih, we may die as well when death doth call.
That Lent is weet, devout Clarinda ayes,
And why? he feeds on weet-meats mot thoe days.
But pardon me that thus traduce your merit;
You keep the fleh low to advance the Spirit.
Go trivial Book, and when thou art abroad
Be humble where thou find't a kind abode.
If at thy errours any mile, give way,
It is not handome in thee to gainay.
They gave ome money for thee; and 'tis fit
That (for their money) they ome laughter get.

div.head: 1. To the Fellow-Commoners of Trinity Colledge in Cambridge.

lg.l: GEntlemen, in my youth I pent ome years
Within your walls; but few, it plain appears
By this poor Book, which I an offering make
Unto you, for your recreations ake:
Not that I do preume that you may finde
Any thing in it worth your eyes, or minde;
But that the view of thee light toyes may raie
You to accomplih works deerving praie.
When you have laugh'd enough at thee, pray take
(Each of you) Pen in hand, and better make:
Which would a noble emulation prove,
And (from our rank) an Obloquie remove.
Reader, (becaue I would ecape the fury
Of all thy Tribe, the grand, and petty Jury
That it on Books, and Wits) I do profes
Although this Book be mall, the Wit in't 's les.
Having thus cenur'd it, I need not fear
What others ay, or wih them to forbear.
Why hould you read it therefore, you exclaime?
Becaue y'ave bought it read it o're for hame.

div.head: 13. To Mr. Tho. Harper a Printer.

lg.l: You Printers, and the Stationers do raie
Unto your elves a fame, if not a praie:
For be the Authour what he will, you give
Stamps of your Names on's Book, and with him live.
But if Errata's you prevent, you raie
Not onely to your elves a Fame, but praie.
Wherefore hould Virgil wrong the Carthage Queen?
Was it through Ignorance, or out of pleen?
If he unwittingly eclips'd her Glory,
The ablet Poet was unskil'd in Story:
If he through malice tax'd her with uch guilt,
It was 'caue he Romes dreaded rivall built.
But he might think (though her he did debae)
To be in his Lines any thing was Grace.
Couin, I hope each Star when you was born,
Did Heaven with a benign apect adorn:
And every glitering jewel of the sky
Dipene their Good to your Nativity.
You being weet-condition'd, having mov'd
All men to honour you (o well belov'd)
Nobly decended, bred to all the Arts
That give a man renown for worthy parts;
To a great fortune heir, and a brave eat,
(For what then Ruhton can be held more weet!)
Married to a fine Lady, the firt day
Of her youths pring (whoe ripe and flourihing May
Of Beauty, till is years to come; yet he
Handome as fancy can think woman t'be)
Inheritrix unto a grand etate,
(And yet her excellent vertues far more great)
We needs mut gues the Heavens your friend, and know
(Y'ave o much Land upon't) the earth is o.

div.head: 6. To Mrs. Elizabeth Cokaine, his Lady.

lg.l: Hail Maid, and wife! But (Couin) I wih you
Had chang'd that name (were older) for a new.
But this is not enough without another:
I wih you quickly too an happy Mother.
Ruhton and Roter both expect you hood
Unite them trictlier by o great a good:
Cokaines and Trenthams then their joys will tell;
So till a Chritning come (Couin) Farewell.

div.head: 7. To my honet kinman Mr. John Cokaine.

lg.l: When at your Pigeon-houe we meet ometime
(Though bawling Puritans call it a Crime)
And pleaant hours from erious thoughts do teal
With a fine little glas, and temperate Ale,
Talk of Sir Cokaine, and how near
He was alli'd to Will the Conquerer,
Atteted by the ame Mr. John Cokaine of Ruhton, my Lords Couin Germane, who had an ancient evidence to prove it. Liv'd in his reign at Henningham Catle, and
That lately there his Bow and Arrows did tand,
That there his Sword and Buckler hung, and that
(If they have cap'd thee Times) th'are all there
Some fall aleep becaue healths are but few, (yet;
And care not for uch Tales though ne're o true.
So as (through too much drink) we ee leep come
On others, it for too little falls on ome.
Dulcinea (it eems) bears me a grutch
Caue of my Love to her I talk o much.
To love, and have no vent at all, would break
An heart, therefore give Lovers leave to peak,
But be appeas'd (fair Maid) for I'le be worn
I love thee vertuous, vicious O thee hould corn.
Sir, that your Lady Couin-german is
Unto my wife (and yet I boat of this)
Is not my amplet glory; I rejoyce
That to the world your friendhip I may voice.
Whether in one that I affect above
Others, I honour hould or friendhip love,
Is now become my doubt; but oon I hall
(By contemplating you) o'recome it all.
What is anothers Honour unto me,
If our affections want a Sympathie?
And how can any friendhip have a tamp
Of worth upon it, that doth Honour want?
Honour and friendhip hould Concomitants be,
And (in as near relation) hould agree,
As Light doth with the Sun; for Honour doth
Keep friendhip from all flawes; they both eem both.
The grand example of your excellent parts
(The wonder, and delight of noble hearts)
Honour and friendhip (to their plendid height)
Do in all great and generous ouls unite.
Malice it elf no tain can tax you with,
But that unto me you your friendhip give:
And (Sir) I am o proud on't, that I mut
Unto your mighty merit be unjut;
(In this let envy cenure how it will)
Pray honour me with your fair friendhip till.

div.head: 11. To Mr. Richard Grey of Adderton, my worthy kinman.

lg.l: Sir, you Platonicks do defend too much,
And I gues talking o may make you uch:
Yet 'tis not in your nature, I uppoe;
For omething you may love beides their clothes,
Their converation, and their vertues in
The tender female Sexe: but you have been
So long a champion for Platonick love,
That you conceit it a digrace to move
From your aerial tenents; pray you leave
This argument, and all their hopes deceive,
That gape after your wealth when you are gone;
Marry a wife, and leave it to your own.
But (if your humour you reolve hall lat)
Make me your heir, and all my trouble's pat.

div.head: 12. An Epitaph on my Noble Couin Mr. Edward Reppington, who deceaed about the 24th year of his age, and lies buried in Tamworth.

lg.l: Stay, whooe're thou art that paet by,
And notice take who here entomb'd doth ly:
For Edward Reppington (the hopes, and heir)
Of Ammington and Adderton lies here.
He was a Gentleman of o much worth,
That he hath left few equals on the earth;
As early Fruit for Princes got, even o
(Being ripe for Heaven) he hence o young did go.
The Reppingtons, and Seabrights hould rejoyce
For giving being to uch ex'lencies;
Although (through Natures weaknes) they yet mourn
That's mortal part is faln into his Urne:
They that would be belov'd as he, mut grow
In vertue as in years; think on't, and go.
How rude is mankind grown! avager far
And more inhumane then the brute beats are!
When our firt great Grandire enjoy'd the joys,
The walks, and Groves of glorious Paradie,
When in the State of Innocene he tood,
(That little while he was completely good)
And ere his beauteous Mate was made, He then
Was King of beats, and not a King of men.
Robin, thy Ale, and company are both
So good, that I to leave thee oft am loth.
But yet thy Bill for Boots and Shoes forgi'me;
And then (I'le promie) you hall oftner ee me.
For then to pend I hould have o much more
Which hould be yours; So I would quit my core.
Rome! once the conquer'd worlds great Head, and yet
The Queen of Cities, and deerving it,
Thy ruines are more glorious to behold
Than our new Palaces glittring with gold
And richet Tapitry: thy Statues broke,
Thy Amphitheatres half faln, the troke
Of Time upon thy Obeliques, and
Decayes of Emperours; Termes do command
A reverence from our eyes; Each tep in thee
Puts us in minde of ome Antiquitie.
Triumphant Arches (though half buried) how
Which way victorious Caears once did go.
This was the earths Metropolis; In it
Hitorians, Oratours, and Poets met
From all the Provinces; and herein they
Wore many a day and many a night away
In frolick Banquets, made Suburra own
More joyes then on Olympus e're were known.
But various plenty of delicious Wine
Completes thy Praie, and makes an end of mine.
The gentle female Sexe that doth affect
Liberty o, doth liberty neglect:
For (for the fahions ake) they are content
Their clothes hould be their trict Imprionment.
Beauty is but opinion of the Liker;
And Cupid's no good archer, but a triker.
His rage he trangly doth employ, and parts
(At random carelely) with all his darts;
And all thee michiefs, and thee mieries
We do impute unto his want of eyes:
But we may bles our fates that he is blind;
Ele war (for beauty) would detroy mankind.
Galla hath till her maidenhead; And why?
She is unhandome, and her price too high.
Yet he would fain be rid of it; but none
Will pay o dear, therefore 'tis till her own.
So (although her deires be thus unjut)
Her covetounes doth overpoie her lut.
Ever to love a Las o fair as he
Loeth no judgment, but doth ettle me
In an opinion, that I would have no
Zeal in affection, but for her, to how.
All men admire her much who ever yet
Beheld her face: And hall I wrong my wit
Exprely to declare I like her not,
To whom I owe as much as I have got?
Have I my Sences? I can try no way
But by approving her; my eyes urvey
All Objects, but like none like her; my ears
Receive no Muick like her voice: her tears
Compoe the puret Nectar: her oft touch
Lends torn Prometheus eae; and body uch
A perfume doth evaporate, that he
Yields choicer weets then in Arabia be.
Although, Bettina, I profes'd deep Love
Unto you, in the Epigram above,
Mine was no want on flame; though I admir'd
Your beauties, I fruition ne're deir'd.
All your dicoure was of uch pretty tuff,
That I (methoughts) could never hear enough:
Your converation did my motive prove;
So mine a friendhip was, and not a Love.
Why crooked Chams dull treams o lowly move,
It is, caue it with Cambridge is in love?
Poor river! thy Amours as vain decline,
For water Schollars care not for, but wine.

div.head: 22. To my ingenuous Friend Mr. Alexander Brome on his Eay to tranlate Lucretius.

lg.l: I know a Lady that hath been about
The ame deigne, but he mut needes give out:
Your Poet trikes too boldly home ometimes,
In geniall things, t'appear in womens rhimes,
The task is maculine, and he that can
Tranlate Lucretius, is an able man,
And uch are you; whoe rich poetick vein,
And general Learning perfectly can plain,
And mooth your Authors roughnees, and give
Him uch a robe of Englih as will live,
Out-wear, and all uch works exceed, and prove
This Nations wonder, and this nations Love.
Therefore proceed, (my friend) and oon erect
This Pyramid of our bet Dialect.

div.head: 23. To my dear Couin-Germans Mrs. Anne, Mrs. Elizabeth, Mrs. Phillipia, and Mrs. Dorothie Stanhope, Siters.

lg.l: Lincolne was, London is, and York hall be
The mot renowned City of the three,
Is an old aying: but I now mut tell
Limby (near Nottingham) doth all excel:
Where live four Stanhopes of the female Sex,
Who (to produce them equals) would perplex
The Land; to which (for all things highly good)
They the bet pattern may be undertood.
My weet, fair Couins! all the worlds four parts
(By Imitation of your rare deerts)
May grow in vertue; you a mirrour be,
Where what they hould be womankind may ee.

div.head: 24. To my ncle (in law) Mr. Richard Sutton.

lg.l: When you and I meet Mater Bancroft, we
Envy no mirth of any Company:
We all love cordially; his Wit and Sack
Make us enjoy our elves and nothing lack.
We Covetounes depie and, cares let fly
In Spanih moke, and conecrate to joy
The hours we pend; and when Sol leaves the skies
Drink our next merry meeting, and o rie.
Ahborn (where many years our Cokaines name
Hath been (as Cambden tells us) of ome fame)
Though in the Peak thou tand't, thy fertile ground
(That like a Lover doth embrace thee round)
The Medows needes not envy, which the Thames
Saluteth (in his paage) with his treames.
The banks of Dove we think we do abue,
If unto thoe compar'd, of York-hire Oue.
Our fruitful oil we do prefer to that
Which holy Dee o long hath murmur'd at,
For not affording him a peedier way
To pay his waves to the Virginian Sea.
Severnes and Trent's it envies not and thence
We do conclude yields none preeminence
If I commend too much, 'tis not a skill
I would profes, but onely my good will:
Yet other praies I (to this) could joyn;
If Betty Sheepy would draw better wine.

div.head: 22. To Mrs. Elizabeth Sheepy of Ahbourne.

lg.l: Betty, your wine is good: and yet we know
You may get better; which we pray you do.
Our Countrey-wits would then leave clubbing
In Darby-Ale, and chang their penny-Pots (groats,
Into fine Venice-glaes (parkling full)
Of generous Sack, and be more bountiful.
Your Talbot then would rore, and Poets ing
That there did run the true Catalian pring.
Your husband honet Tom (that's ick) it would
Recover oon, and make him live t'be old.
Get therefore (Betty) the bet wine you may:
And we will tyle you our Mnemoyne.

div.head: 23. To my dear Couin Germans Mrs Stanhope, and Mrs. Iabella Hutchinon; Siters.

lg.l: Let others praie Nottingham for the Site,
The River Trent, and propects of delight,
Mortimers Cave, and (now) the ruine ad
Of one of the bet Catles England had:
I ay that you two are the chiefet grace
(By living there) that doth adorn the place.

div.head: 24. To Mr. John Young, of the Bear in Powlesworth.

lg.l: Though Puritans on in their grumblings go,
Be merry Mater Young, whil't you are o.
What though their enles zeal bark at your Bear?
If the Bandogs venture to come o near,
Keep uch trong drink hall take them by the Crown,
And pluck the hypocrites of Piety down.
Making them do homage unto your ign,
And think it (though an Image 'tis) divine.
Whilt Monuments of Bras and Marble tand,
Whilt Ships do grace the Seas, and Cities Land,
And Men do walk upon the Terrene Ball;
So ure (undoubtedly) will women fall.
Yet let not this the females onely taxe,
Men fall on them that fall upon their backs.

div.head: 32. To Mr. Ralph Rawon lately fellow of Braen Noe Colledge.

lg.l: Though I of Cambridge was, and far above
Your Mother Oxford did my Cambridge love;
I thoe affections (for your ake) remove;
And (above Cambridge) now do Oxford love:
But I recant that change, and ay where e're
You live, that a third Academie's there.
You conquer humane paions, and enhrine
All vertues that the Schooles did e're define;
And to uch height mater all learned Arts,
That I know none your equal for all Parts:
Therefore what place oever you hall pleae
To grace with your abode on Lands or Seas,
(Although in frozen Thule) I far above
My Cambridge, and your Oxford hall it love.

div.head: 31. To my mot honoured Couin the Lady Mary Fitzherbert of Tiington.

lg.l: Madam, the Peak is famous far and near
For a great many wonders that are there;
Pooles-Hole, the Devils Elden-hole, the well
That ebbes and flowes, make Darbyhire excel
The andy hill that ever falls away
And yet (in bulk) doth uffer no decay:
And Burtons Baith (though in a village town)
Abroad our County give a fair renown.
Thee and the like do far and near invite
Strangers, and natives to delight their ight.
But thee are Grotts, Waters, and Hills, and uch
As we have one that doth exceed them much:
Your beauties, and your many vertues peak
You the chief Wonder that doth grace the Peak.
Naples the Romans old Parthenope.
(Built under Hills, upon the Midland-Sea)
Thou to Compania (mot delicious Part
Of Italy) the primet Glory art.
The Princes, Dukes, the Counts and Barons that
(In great abundance) there do make their eat,
And flourih in all joyes this Life can grant
To humane kind, others I leave to vaunt:
Above all things that honour't I preferre
The all renowned Virgils Sepulchre;
And think that Virgil dead gives more renown,
Then all thoe Lords alive, unto that Town.
The Zelots here are grown o ignorant,
That they mitake Wakes for ome ancient Saint,
They ele would keep that Feat; For though they all
Would be cal'd Saints here, none in heaven they call:
Beides they May-Poles hate with all their Soul,
I think, becaue a Cardinal was a Pole.

div.head: 34. An Epitaph on Mr. Will. Davenport, a Couin-German of my wifes, who dyed at Henbury his own houe in Chehire, and lies buried by his wife at Dubridge in Darby-hire; he being aged about 29.

lg.l: Here William Davenport lies, and (Stranger) know
That he was high in worth that lies o low.
He had a noble oul, and liberal mind,
A generous courage, and behaviour kind;
Sir Thomas Milwards daughter was his wife,
Whom he urviv'd, and led a widowers life.
Our age was proud of him, though (in his prime
Of years) Death gave a Period to his time:
He left two Daughters, and a potles fame,
VVhich evermore hall wait vpon his Name.
That you are vext their Wakes your neighbours keep,
They gues it is, becaue you want your leep:
I therefore wih that you your leep would take,
That they (without offence) might keep their Wake.
Hail beauteous Virgin! you whoe glorious hair
Jutly with Ariadne's may compare:
VVhoe eyes are Globes of puret fire, whence flahes
Th' enamour'd Nation oon would burn to ahes,
Did not your mighty modety delight
(VVith their fair lids, and veils) to cloud their ight.
Your features are uch wonders, they can finde
No Parallels throughout all VVomankinde.
How fine your hands are! And how weetly they
Command the Lutes delicious Harmony!
Your Figure with your Form o right agrees,
That you are Natures exquiitet Piece.
Pretty ones we your feet mut gues to be,
That toots are unto uch a graceful Tree;
Whoe leaves your clothes are & conceal uch things
As would in Queens raie envy, Flames in Kings.
Your own affection caue of fruit mut prove,
VVhich yet none of our ex could ever move.
You are all fair without, and ure within
Your fairer oul's a glorious Cherubin:
He of mankind will lead the happiet life,
Whom you hall honour to become his wife.
When I in Rome made ome abode, I oft
Urban the Eight beheld, and often laught
To think how here our Zelots bawld him down,
And Preach'd him for the whore of Babylon;
He eem'd a gallant Prince, and they that look,
May find him a fine Poet by his book.
Though bawds have ometimes beards; none ure did ee
A Woman ere have uch a beard as he.
But they were more mitaken in their peeches,
Tho, virtuous women may, whores wear no breeches:
Beides, no wencher would betow a doit
To lye with uch an whore a winters night.
My friends, I wih you would forbear your running
