After this whore; and henceforth how your cunning
(Leaving this ubject, to no purpoe vext)
To follow in the lieu of it your text.
Sir, I conceive that you are in the Lit
Of thoe that think the Pope is Antichrit:
Could you get one of them with child, alone
It hould be you that made the true Pope Ioan.
Princes you are, have Dukedomes, two, or three;
I wih you would give one of them to me:
But that were to rob Peter to give Paul,
Or rather to rob both of them for Saul:
For I a Lay-man am, and (which is wore)
I think a Poet, by my empty pure.

div.head: 41. To my wife on the birth of her daughter Iabella.

lg.l: I in this econd Daughter wih you joy,
Yet hould have had more, had it been a Boy.
Girles are (by far) more chargeable; And (when
Boyes are grown up) les care will erve for Men.
You ay a Nun you mean her: uch another
(I think) you do intend as was her mother.
But whether he live Maid, or prove a wife,
I wih her a long, healthful, happy life.
So I do leave you with your new Delight,
Till you and I do meet again at Night.
I have been at Loretto, and did there
See the fam'd Houe, which I'le not argue here;
Do onely wih (when I from Earth remove)
That I may ee where he abides above.

div.head: 43. An Epitaph on Mr. Thomas Pilkington, one of the Queens Muicians, who dyed at Wolverhampton about the 35 year of his age, and lies there buried.

lg.l: Muicks prime Mater of our Land, this tone
Covers; For here lies matchles Pilkington:
He was the oul of Muick, did contain
All orts of it in his harmonious brain.
A trange malignant Fever et a trife
Between his oul and body; ceas'd his Life.
So with his oul the oul of Muick fled,
Leaving that Science fainting, though not dead.
Though oft his work was playing, it was uch,
As all Muicians cannot do o much
With all their works. In brief, the richet Part,
The bet Epitome of all that Art
And choiet Muick (that ere ravih'd ear)
(Put out of tune by death) lie buried here.
Zoilus reports never a line I write
Deerves t' appear before a wiemans ight:
Zoilus, at this I nothing do repine;
But ay (thou being a Fool) th'are fit for thine.

div.head: 45. An Epitaph on my dear iter Mrs. Lettice Armtrong, who deceaed about the 43 of her age, and of Mrs. Lucy Cokain, who dyed about the 34 of hers, and lye both buried at Ahborn.

lg.l: Lettice and Lucy here (two iters) lye,
So contant to each others company,
Death could not part them long; for four years pace
Reduc'd them both to this Sepulchral place.
There was no difference 'twixt them all their Life,
Save one liv'd ingle, th' other was a Wife.
They both were virtuous; left this world behind
In hope the Glories of the next to finde.
Their Coffins lye o very cloe, it doth
Appear, as if one Grave contain'd them both:
As their loves did unite them; o the tone
That both of them doth cover, is but one:
And (more to hew their mutual hearts) it hath
For both (upon it) but one Epitaph.

div.head: 46. To my Couin Mr. Thomas Cokaine of Manciter.

lg.l: You boat your Manciter was once a Town
(When here the Romans govern'd) of Renown:
That Aderton from Ruines of it grew
To be o pacious, and o fair of view.
I yield unto your Truthes, and adde one more,
Aderton drink makes Manciter o poor.

div.head: 47. Upon the Marriage of Mr. Edward Tilly, and Mrs. Anne Fleetwood.

lg.l: So all your fears are pat; you both are ped,
And have no trouble but to go to bed:
Where (what young married couples love the bet)
I wih you a good night with little ret.
I on the top have of Veuvius been,
There laid me down upon my breat, and een
Into the mighty Rupture, whence the moke
Proceeds, that often eems the skies to choke:
Torre de Guego din'd at, which I found
(With that Hills calding treams) much burnt and drown'd.
As with (their quarries) Hills build Cities, o
They (with their vomits) them may overthrow,
Buchanons oathes at Murries ervice were;
What he would ay audacious George would wear.
Poets would lye I've heard, but never one
That would forwear himelf but Buchanon;
Yet he a famous Poet was: what though?
Serpents may lurk in flowers of fairet how.

div.head: 50. To Mrs. Anne Adams, my mothers Coin-german

lg.l: Whilt you the generous Trenthams name enjoy'd,
And knew not what it was to be a Bride;
You in delicious Bruels wore away
Mot of your virgin-years beyond the Sea,
There you did thinke to lead a ingle life;
But thanks to Iohn that won you to his wife.
Who (when you did return to England) found
That way to fix you on your native ground:
For you together live, as if heaven meant
To make you (though not richet) mot content.

div.head: 51. To my highly honoured Couin-German, Mr. Arthur Sanhope, on to the Earl of Cheterfield.

lg.l: I do rejoyce at the repect you bear
To Bretby, by your choice of living there:
My Lord o great a houe kept, that by none
(Of all our Noblemen) he was out-gone:
And you o neatly and gentilely live,
That all that know you Commendations give.
If my Lord Stanhope comes, and you remove,
May you be follow'd by all good mens love;
That (whereoere you live) there may be een
No change, but alteration of the Scene.

div.head: 52. To Mris. Elizabeth Kendall, my wives Niece.

lg.l: Twycros I cannot chooe but envy, where
Such ravihing Muick is, and I not there.
You, and your iter Frank Pegge every day
So rarely ing, that wondring Queens would tay
(To liten to your Layes) from any port,
And prize (that while) your houe above a Court.

div.head: 35. To Mr. Humphrey Moley, and Mr. Humphrey Robinon.

lg.l: In the large book of Playes you late did print
(In Beaumonts and in Fletchers name) why in't
Did you not jutice? give to each his due?
For Beaumont (of thoe many) writ in few:
And Mainger in other few; the Main
Being ole Iues of weet Fletchers brain.
But how came I (you ask) o much to know?
Fletchers chief boome-friend inform'd me o.
Ith'next impreion therefore jutice do,
And print their old ones in one volume too:
For Beaumonts works, & Fletchers hould come forth
With all the right belonging to their worth.

div.head: 54. To my much honoured Couin Sir Francis Burdet Baronet.

lg.l: The honet Poet, Michael Drayton, I
Mut ever honour for your Amity,
He brought us firt acquainted; which good turn
Made me to fix an Elegie on's urn:
Ele I might well have par'd my humble tuffe;
His own weet Mue renowning him enough.
In Warwick-hire your houe and mine tand neer,
I therefore wih we both were etled there;
So we might often meet, and I (thereby)
Your excel'nt converation oft enjoy:
What good hould you get by it? truly none:
The profit would acrue to me alone.

div.head: 55. To Mrs. Anne Gregon of Ahburn.

lg.l: Y' are good, and great, and had you had ome itch
For wealth, and married God be here, had been rich:
But money you contemn'd (it doth appear)
Content to live a widdow by good Beer.

div.head: 56. To my weet Couin Mrs. Iabella Milward.

lg.l: Your noble father Sir Iohn Zouch (when you
Was very young) occaion'd you to view
Virginia, took you thither, where ome years
You pent, till you had moitned with your tears
His and your eldet iter Katharine's Tombe,
Interr'd o far from Codnor their old home.
After o ad a los you thought it time
To return back unto your native clime,
Where your (by all men honour'd) husband found,
A richer Prize then all the pacious ground
Known by Veputius urname ere did give;
And may you long together happy live.
Arthur our Worthy, whoe grand fame in war
Shall evermore load Fames triumphant Car,
This Marble covers; nobler dut then thoe
For whom the Pyramids of Egypt roe.
Had but his life reacht out to his intent,
Queen Artemiia's wondrous Monument
Had been his Sepulchre, and not his tombe;
His merits would have roe to uch a umme.
Nothing but treaon foul could periodize
The Progres in his Saxon victories:
And Glaenbury Abbey loudly boats
That it contains the Terrour of their Hoats.

div.head: 58. An Epitaph on Henry the fourth of France,

lg.l: Forbear thy rude approch, bold Paenger:
Henry the Great, the fourth of France lies here.
His claim unto that Crown he knew o right,
That he for it unarm'd did often fight.
The word of Mars, Minerva's Lance, and Gun
Of Mulciber fear never made him hun.
Cover'd with fire and bullets by his Foes,
He wore them not as Terrours, but his clothes.
What Spain, France, and the League could not command
With their united force, a murtherers hand
Did perpetrate: Ravilliac truck him from
The top of all his Glories to his Tombe.
As the bright Sun (throughout our Hemiphere)
His coure being finihed) ets full and clear,
And the next morn again doth beauteous rie,
And with his beams decks both the earth and skies:
So he (after a life triumphant led)
Did bid the world adieu, and here lies dead:
And when the lat day comes (return'd from dut)
Shall glorious rie, and live among the Jut.
Fame's a trange Good, and a trange Evil, that
Doth often give too much, and oft detract;
And ometimes jutice doth, and hits the Mean,
Avoiding each extravagant Extream.
Let us preciely to our duties tick,
And Fames wort malice hal not wound to th'quick:
Or if it gives us that which is above
Our merits, why uch flatteries hould we love?
Doth Fame the virtuous right? 'tis well. We hall
Ele each have's due after his funeral.

div.head: 60. An Epitaph on Mr. Ralph Fitzherbert who dyed at Ahby de la Zouch about the 22 year of his age, and lies there buried.

lg.l: Cornet Fitzherbert (who in many a Fight
Lord Loughboroughs Colours bore in the Kings right)
Lies here inter'd: His skill in Muick gone,
And his good parts all cover'd with this tone.
He was too brave to find an Enemy
To kill him; and therefore in's bed did dye.
Yet was he young and virtuous: but alas!
On youth and virtue death no pity has.
Learn therefore (Reader) that no humane tate
Is afe; and alwayes live prepar'd for Fate.
Once born the bet mut dye: why (therefore) then
Should Death inflict uch terror on us men?
Faint-hearted ouls they are that fear to run
The common Path which there's no hope to hun.
A Life to Heaven and Earth in jutice led,
Will give us leave to live in no uch Dread;
They that o pas their dayes, the world hall find
That they a fair Report do leave behind:
When thoe that otherwie do wat their Times,
Shall fill Poterities mouthes with their foul crimes.

div.head: 62. To Mris. Katharin Pegge my wives eldet iter.

lg.l: Although this age is againt Croes et,
I cannot quit me of my Croes yet:
But welcome any Cros that comes, we ay;
It may be for our goods another day.
So let us ever to the Powers divine
Our elves, and what belongs to us reign:
That no Properity may be allow'd
So to exalt our mindes to make us proud;
And no Adverity deject us o,
But patiently we may it undergo.
Then let our Croes go, or Croes come,
Whilet we can ay, the will of Haaven be done.
Cambridge one doth commend, Oxford another,
And would have one prefer'd above the other.
VVhen they are bet term'd equals: And no other
Such Foreign Place comes near the one or th'other
This my opinion is: who would an other,
May leave to trouble me, and ask another.

div.head: 64. To Mrs. Elizabeth Nevil, my wives younget iter.

lg.l: If you at Wetow-Lodge do live I there
Do often wih my elf to be o near
My mother Cambridge: If at Holt you live
In Leiceterhire, I there my elf would give
The Pleaures of that gallant Seat, whoe ight
Affords fine Propects various in delight.
Or if you live at Creing Temple, then
Colcheter Oyters and Sea-fih invite
Thither ofttimes my longing appetite.
But pardon me thee vanities: above
All thee, I your weet converation love,
And your good husbands noble Company:
Thoe things I talk'd of, but would thee enjoy.
Your zealous Ignorance doth oft dipraie
Our Poets whatoever that write Playes:
So mall a pittance you of learning have,
Their wort of Playes doth all your works outbrave;
And I your zealous ignorance dipraie,
Telling you fam'd Nick Machiavil writ Playes.
But you to write a Play think an offence,
Is it not wore to preach o much nonence?

div.head: 66. To Mrs Francis Shalcros, and Mrs. Julia Boteler my Niece, on their wedding night.

lg.l: To bed (fair bride) your happy groom
(Full of deire) doth long to come,
Now lye down by her in a trice;
Your Genial bed's a Paradie.
Though he's to loe, you are to get,
Her Zone unti'd untiddles it:
You need not any weet forbear,
Both moving in your proper phere.
I need not wih you joy; you have
What Heaven can give, or Lovers crave:
But truely wih (unto this height)
It may lat both your lives. Good night.
I've been importun'd by ome friends to tell
How I approve your veres; I ay well:
Nor dare I otherwie that undertand
You have a deperate Courage, heavy hand,
And a long word. Thoe few that do not matter
The trifle cal'd their lives, may corn to flatter:
And o do I, wearing that you write Works
Will pleae the Chritians, and amaze the Turkes.

div.head: 69. To Mr. Clement Fiher of Wincott.

lg.l: Shakpeare your Wincot-Ale hath much renownd,
That fo'xd a Beggar o (by chance was found
Sleeping) that there needed not many a word
To make him to believe he was a Lord:
But you affirm (and in it eem mot eager)
'Twill make a Lord as drunk as any Beggar.
Bid Norton brew uch Ale as Shakpeare fancies
Did put Kit Sly into uch Lordly trances:
And let us meet there (for a fit of Gladnes)
And drink our elves merry in ober adnes.
Your Indutry to you the art hath given
To have great knowledge in th'outide of heaven:
Beware let you abue that Art, and in,
And therefore never viit it within.

div.head: An Epitaph on Mrs. Brigit Allibond, who dyed at Chenye about the eighteenth year of her age, and lies there buried.

lg.l: Here Brigit Allibond doth buried lye;
Whoe too much love occaioned her to dye.
Inatiate thirt of gold! Her Servants friends
Sent him to travel, and workt' both their ends;
There he deceas'd: which ad news thrut the Dart
Of death through both her ears into her heart:
So Love chang'd Darts with Death, Love too unkind
To kill the body with the wound oth' mind.
Virgins hould mourn her los; And (by her) men
May ee how Maids belov'd can love agen.

div.head: 72. An Epitaph on Lycica, who forc'd her husband to counterfeit his Religion.

lg.l: Here lyes Lycica, that was full of Evil:
And (therefore to be fear'd) gone to the Devil.
Now (eeing he and he have et all even)
Her Husband may walk in the Rode to Heaven.

div.head: 73. To Mrs. Francis Pegge, my wifes Neece.

lg.l: You once did think to be a Nun, but now
I hope you will forbeae that acred vow;
And if you will be making vows) pray take
An husband, and an holy vow him make:
So whether you become a Nun, or wife,
(Under a vow) you may lead out your life.

div.head: 74. To Mr. Gilbert Knyveton, and Mr. Thomas Knyueton my wifes Brothers.

lg.l: Pray take an houe, and o continue on
The hopitality you have begun:
For of uch means none handomer did live,
Or to their friends more generous welcome give.
Though you from Bradley are remov'd, make known
To noble minds each Country is their own.

div.head: 75. To my iter Mrs. Katharine Weton.

lg.l: We were two brothers, and five iters; now
They are all dead, alas! ave I, and you:
All that Affection that among us was,
Let us therefore on one another place:
So we (for Brothers, and for iters love)
An Emulation hall in others move.

div.head: 76. To my Couin Mr. John Milward.

lg.l: Of women ome are foul, and ome are fair,
Some virtuous are, and others are as bad:
Some go in poor apparel, others rare,
Some melancholy are, and others glad:
Some are at their prime, others decaying are,
Some are reerv'd, and others to be had:
Some timorous are, any thing others dare,
Some dull and mop'd, and others blith, and mad:
Some humorous are, others of freakes beware,
Some love to keep rheir homes, others to gad:
Some high in virtues do themelves declare,
Others are overwhelm'd in vices ad.
Ovid would take of all to pleae his ences:
Give me a glas of Sack, and chooe you wenches.

div.head: 77. An Epitaph on Mr. Peter Allibond, Fellow of Lincolne Colledge in Oxford.

lg.l: Here buried lies within this hollow ground,
Oxfords prime glory, Peter Allibond:
His Learning Lincolne Colledge hath renown'd,
And few the road to his high Parts have found.
Death in his Proctorhip gave him his wound,
And (thereby) hindred him to go his Round;
And here hath laid him in a leep o drown'd,
Not to awake but by th' lat trumpets ound:
From hence then to arie, and to be crown'd
(We hope) with joyes, where all joyes do abound.

div.head: 78. To my Niece Mrs. Iabella Boteler.

lg.l: Your iter Iulia's married well, and o
(Sweet Niece) I wih you were dipos'd of too.
You the green icknes languih in, and ure
For that an husband is the proper't cure.
What tho child-bearing pains on women drawes?
Sweet-meats (by th' Proverb) hould have owre auce.
You make a Violl peak: your nimble hand,
That intrument eems onely to command.
How meanly many play! trike o amis,
That (at their want of skill) the trings do his:
Like rety hores they fale teps do make,
And the vext trings with very hame to hake.
VVell tun'd that would agree, they wrong o far,
Their artles violence doth make them jar.
So they but crape, abue the trings, and tick;
How dull the quicket are to you more quick!
Some few with their oft hands may pleae; but you
Pleae not alone, but raie amazement too.
Your fingers on the neck, and hand on Bow,
The motions of the Intellect out-go.
Such is your playing: But if you would write,
How much you Works all mankind would delight!

div.head: 80. An Epitaph on my Father Mr. Tho. Cokain, who deceaed in London, about the of his age, and lyes buryed in St. Giles's Church in the Fields.

lg.l: Stay Paenger, and read under this tone,
Here Thomas Cokain lyes, Sir Edwards on.
Mapleton gave him birth; but far from home
At London he deceas'd, and this his Tombe
Too mean a Monument for his great worth;
But virtue never findes reward on earth.
He was his families Heir; but (tranitory
Knowing all terrene wealth) chang'd his for glory.
And here his body oft repoe doth take
Till him the Angels Trumpets hall awake.
Two Cats fell out, and one an other lew;
May all Cats o to one another do:
Yet I can them endure, would be their friend,
But that they company o oft offend.

div.head: 82. Of the Englih, Spanih, and French.

lg.l: The Spaniards love the Englih, they them hate;
The Englih love the French, and they hate them;
A trange capriciounes of humane Fate,
<> Nations hould affect whom them contemn
Depied Lovers need not to complain,
Seeing tis known whole kingdomes love in vain.
The Belgians hate all but themelves; wherefor
Becaue no nation ele can them endure.
What hould the reaon be of uch an hate?
For aid receiv'd they have been o ingrate.

div.head: 84. To Iabel Manifold of the Black Swan in Ahb

lg.l: Heark Ibel Parker! Ibel Hood! But hold,
Thee names might erve were hers not Manifol
Pray anwer, were your husband in the grave,
Soon after would not you another have?
If other women divers men hould ue,
They would digrace their names for uch abue:
But (without bluhes) you may hear it told,
That you (of Men) have lain with Manifold.
As great a wonder as black Swans ome gues,
So trange a thing an honet Hotes is.
It is believ'd that there no black Swans are
But you are, and are honet, o more rare.

div.head: 86. An Epitaph on my mot honoured kinman Ferdinando Earl of Huntington, who deceaed at his houe in Donnington Park about the 48 year of his age, and lyes buried at Ahby de la Zouch.

lg.l: Here Ferdinando Earl of Huntington
Doth lye inter'd under this Marble-tone;
VVhich will weep drops of dew, if we refrain
To hed our tears; yet weeping is in vain.
Nor ighes nor tears will call him from his urn;
Our griefs then let's to imitation turn.
Let's emulate his worthy Parts (for uch
His Qualities were) and we hall merit much:
For each man may report that paeth by,
Courteie and good Nature here doth lie.

div.head: 87. To Henry Right of the Cock in Pouleworth.

lg.l: Harry, what ere thou dot (by day or night)
(Though it be never o amis) th' art Right:
Though ome for doing wrong taxe thee in pight,
Contemn their malice; for th' art known t' be Right.
Let thy Guets ober go to bed, not fight,
And all thy reckonings be as thou art, Right:
And lead an upright life, that thou mayt light
On Heaven at lat, and there thou t' be mot Right.
Neither do husbands heed, nor Heaven above
(For the mot part) high-pirited women love
Are they in errour? through their ignorance,
And elf-opinion they prove eldom Saints.
And husbands who are tide unto uch wives,
Uually live with them unquiet lives.
To wed meek women men are mot inclin'd,
And Heaven it elf affects the humble mind.
In thalamis Regina tuis hac nocte jacerem,
Si verum hoc eet, Pauper ubique jacet.
Queen, in your chamber I hould lye to night,
If a poor man lyes every where, were right.
Who made this Ditich it is fit I tell,
Which I have Englih'd but indifferent well;
I think Tom Randolph: Pardon what's amis
In my tranlation for my gift of his;
Whom you and I o well did love and know,
When Cambridge (for his wit) extol'd him o.

div.head: 90 To my honoured Couin Mr. Baill Fitzherbert of Norbury, and his Lady.

lg.l: Baill Fitzherbert did Iane Cotton wed,
And he hath blet him with a Sonne and Heire;
A Couple fortunate i'th Genial bed,
And in all other things an happy pair.
This is my judgement of your worths, and you
(By all your actions) confirme it true.

div.head: 91. To my noble Couin Mr. Charls Cotton the younger.

lg.l: D' Avila, Bentivoglio, Guicciardine,
And Machiavil the ubtile Florentine,
(In their Originals) I have read through,
Thanks to your Library, and unto you;
The prime Hitorians of late times; at leat
In the Italian Tongue allow'd the bet.
When you have more uch books, I pray vouchafe
Me their perual. Il'e return them afe:
Yet (for the courteie) the recompene
That I can make you will be onely thanks.
But you are noble-oul'd, and had much rather
Betow a benefit, then receive a favour.
Your Basford houe you have adorned much;
And Bently hopes it hortly hall be uch:
Think on't; and et but Bentley in repair,
To both thoe Basfords you will how y'are Heir.

div.head: 93. To my honoured friend Mr. Samuel Roper.

lg.l: Make Darbyhire by your mot able Pen,
Allow you her obliging't Countrey-man;
From dut and dark oblivion raie her Glories,
And (from old Records) publih all her tories.
So you (with Mr. Dugdale) hall remain
Your Countreys honour; other Countreys tain.

div.head: 94. To Mrs Mary Cokain my eldet daughter.

lg.l: Becaue I fear my fate is not o good,
To give you uch a portion as I wou'd:
Your Education I intend hall prove
Some atisfaction to you of my love.
Muick and Dancing I would have you taught,
And all the skil that is by needles wrought:
All orts ofhouwifery that hould be done,
(From your own chamber) to the meanet Room:
And (to give full perfection) to walk even
(Whilt here you live) in the right road to Heaven.

div.head: 95. To the right honourable the Lord Winfield Cromwell Earle of Arglas, my noble kinman.

lg.l: My Lord, a hare y'ave given me in a Grove:
But how hall I requite o great a Love?
If ever I (in any of my land)
Should Gold or ilver find, you hall command:
I hope to get much money by your Lead,
If tore of ore God Plutus there hath hid:
But hould I gain no riches from your ground,
Yet I may boat that there your love I found.

div.head: 96. To my worthy friend Mr. Henry Turville.

lg.l: Mot of thee are too long and naught, tis true;
I wih them faultles both for me and you:
For I your candour would provoke, not blame,
And (to my elf) acquire ome little Fame.
Cupid is careles and doth hoot at random,
Strikes a young man, and oftentimes a Grandam
Yet neither he Phyician is, or Surgeon,
To cure the wounds his eneles Darts do urge on,
Either by any med'cines, or Inciion:
The nuptial bed is Surgeon and Phyician.
When you do preach of Mountain Ararat,
And how Noahs floating Ark firt taid thereat;
Though your loud voice doth fill the acred houe,
Your Sermon bigge with mountains drops a Moue.

div.head: 99. To my honoured Couin Mr. Charls Cotton Iunior.

lg.l: Donne, Suckling, Randolph, Drayton, Mainger,
Habbington, Sandy's, May, my Acquaintance were:
Iohnon, Chapman, and Holland I have een,
And with them too hould have acquainted been.
What needs this Catalogue? Th' are dead and gone;
And to me you are all of them in one.

div.head: 100. To Mr. John Adams, my Couin.

lg.l: When we at Pembletous in Roter meet,
Time that before went low flyes very fleet;
The reaon is, an eaie thing to think,
A knot of Jovial Blades, and mighty Drink.

div.head: 101. Of a Roome in cal'd the Minerva.

lg.l: Approch not you dull ouls, that durt and muck
Do grovell in; follow your ordid luck:
Athens no Fame had for mechanick Arts,
But by thoe generous pirits of nobler Parts.
They that are Wits, and love the Wits, may come,
Convere and tipple in this jovial Room;
Pallas admits none ele: For know, the Owle,
Her acred Bird will (at their entrance) howl.
Herein the Grécian Sages do convere,
And here the Poets their high lines rehere.
Here Tully and Demothenes doe plead,
And Plato here and Aritotle's read:
For this the Epitome of Athens is,
And teaches all the Liberal ciences.
Such is the companies dicoure: Then hence
All earthen-minded Brats of ignorance;
And welcome the ingenious to this pring
That makes the Orator write, and Poet ing;
To the Philoopher new truths dicovers,
And courage gives to the faint-hearted Lovers.
To thoe lets drink (Converion from their Crime)
That over Ale and Beere can pend their time,
That on their Errours they may may turn their back,
And in Minerva's Fane here tipple Sack:
For Ale and Beer breed Flegm, engender Pains;
But rich Canarie elevates the Brains.

div.head: 102. To my honoured Friend Mr. Caevilan Burton.

lg.l: Where will you do your elf o great a right
To let your Englih Martial view the light?
You will oblige this Nation by your pains,
Thoe 'pecially to whom the Latin's trange.
And he (in the Elyian hades) will mile
To heare he peakes the language of this Ile.
Of all the writers of the Roman Part,
Bellarmine, thou the mot confuted art:
How happens thy ill Fortune, that we call
Thy confutation, if we drink up all?
A Poet and a Traytour is uch news,
Mercuries and Diurnals do not ue.
Gallus a Traitour; Gallows a Reward:
But ure Augutus did not prove o hard.
He put him to a nobler death we hope;
Poets hould live by linesn, ot dye by'th rope.
Welcome (good Sir) to truth, and welcome to
The way to Heaven which you directly go:
May we your tedfat footteps follow even,
And (tis no doubt) we hall arrive at Heaven.
Marvel not (Friend) that oftentimes I write
As if in drinking I did take delight:
I (at my bet) am ill enough, and hate
To make my elf a Beat at any rate.
Of Mirth and companie I ometimes think;
The caue that now and then I write of drink.
The ancient Epigrammatit Catullus,
Propertius, and the amorous Tibullus,
Are often bound together: whats the reaon?
They all weremerry Blades at every eaon;
Whilt they did live they often were together:
And now th' are dead th' are bound up o in Leather.

div.head: 108. To my Son Mr. Thomas Cokaine.

lg.l: Let others glory in their Hawks and Hounds,
Their golden heaps, and Circuit of their Grounds,
Their gallant Breed of Hores, and their meat,
Dret o, that Heliogabalus would eat;
Their Mitrees (whoe Beauties would inflame
Unknown Lands Salvages, and make them tame)
Themelves, and them o richly dres'd, that you
The Heavens (without a Cloud) would think in view:
Give me a tudy of good Books, and I
Envy to none their hugg'd Felicity.
Momus doth carp that I do write o few
Lines on this Theme, and ayes th' are not enow:
I to a hundred thouand write tis true,
And worth o many (for your worths) are you.

div.head: 110. To Mr. Robert Creitton Dr. of Divinity, formerly Oratour and Greek Profeour of the Univerity of Cambridge.

lg.l: Among the many friends that I do name,
Neglected I do mention you, 'twere hame.
You were my Tutour; and tis fit I how
The world a Part of the Repects I owe:
Let this poor trifle be an atome of it,
Although to my digrace and your no profit.
Expect from your learn'd Pupils Works of Art;
I can preent you but a grateful heart.
Hitories of all ages do declare
High-pirited women noble things have done:
One hall erve mention'd in particular,
And he the brave Ioeni an Amazon.
Bonduca long the Romans force withtood,
And eal'd her love t'her Countrey with her blood.
Momus doth grumble; Prethee pare me not:
Th' excception's jut thou hat againt me got.
I writ Catullus, and the other two,
Were all of them Contemporaries, tis true:
Valerius ere they flourih'd dy'd, I know it;
Poets may feign, in that hold me a Poet:
With truth of Hitory I was too bold,
As men tye knots on Ropes to make them hold.
How in your company I do delight!
A Pleaure to my ears, as well as ight
When on the Harpecals your iter Win
Doth play, and you upon the Violin;
I with that muick am affected much,
She plays o well, and eke your Art is uch.
Hat t'us, and when (with playing) you are weary;
A Bottle of rich ack hall make us merry.
Nan Hill, th'art good and great: Think it not better
To grow up to a Mountain, and be greater:
With marriage therefore do not be beguil'd;
Y'are made a Mountain if y'are got with child.
But marry (Nan Hill) if you hould grow wanton,
Rather then to be wore become a Mountain.

div.head: 115. To my honoured kinman Mr. Edward Darcy.

lg.l: Repair your houe at Newhall, and hat down,
And leave the noie of this expenceful Town:
You here deprive your elf of many a good
To be enjoy'd by Countrey-olitude.
Pretend not want of Companie; For I
Will waite upon you oft, that live thereby.
You may reply you better would; I grant it:
Keep a good houe there, and you need not want it.

div.head: 116. An Epitaph on Mr. Gilbert Knyveton, my wives Brother, who deceaed in London about the 38 year of his age, and lies buried at St. Giles in the fields.

lg.l: Stay Paenger, forbear thy hat,
And read whom Death herein hath plac't:
For Gilbert Knyveton here doth lye,
A haking of mortality.
All Ethicks he his practice made,
On Chritian foundation laid.
His Life was noble, and his Death
A rich oul did to heaven bequeath:
His los we therefore hould not mourn,
But (for our elves) to adnes turn;
Lament that we do want o much
Of thoe great worthes that made him uch.
Let's tudy him, and imitate o,
That we may prove like him: Now go.
Men do olicite Women, they contemne,
(If they are bahful) to importune them:
Man was made firt, and therefore hould begin;
Do Women? They 'gaint Modety do in.
A Catholick German knit his angry brow,
And cal'd Frier Martin Luthers wife a Sow:
But uch his Paion was it did run ore,
She could not be a Sow that was a Boar.
Againt Saints Fats the Puritans do bawl:
And why? To th' Fleh they are addicted all.

div.head: 120. To my brother in law Mr. William Nevil.

lg.l: Dare Cambridgehire, leave off to boat
Thy Univerity o crot:
And Cambridgehire, forbear to vaunt
Of Ely, fam'd for many a Saint;
And Wetow-lodge henceforth let be
The primet glory that's in thee;
Where plenty, neatnes, and a right
Well-govern'd houe yield full delight;
VVherein you and your Lady give
Example how the good hould live.

div.head: 121. To Mrs. Alice Nevill, his iter.

lg.l: Y'are virtuous, young, and handome; and I dare
VVith Sydneyes Queen of Corinth you compare.
Between you I no difference can write;
But he was lighted, you your ervants light,
You may relent, and I do hope you will:
If prayers prevail not, Cupid ue thy skill.

div.head: 122. To Mrs. An & Mrs. Mildred Nevil his daughters.

lg.l: Henceforth our Englih youth may ceae to glory
In famous Sydneys celebrated tory:
For you two iters hortly mut incite
Some matchles pen your happy lives to write;
That unto all this land it may be known,
Pamela and Philoclea are out-gone.
Marry in Lent! tis trange; and yet no treaon
You ay, although unuual that eaon:
Marriage is not, but the olemnization
Forbidden then, and y'ave a dipenation.
The Church hath favour'd you; hew it your duty,
And prize 't henceforth above your Ladies beauty.

div.head: 124. To my honoured friend Major William Warner.

lg.l: Playes, Eclogues, Songs, a Satyre I have writ,
A remedy for thoe 'ith amorous fit,
Love Elegies, and Funeral Elegies,
Letters of things of divers qualities,
Encomiatick Lines to works of ome,
A Maque, and an Epithalamium,
Two Books of Epigrams: All which I mean
Shall (in this volume) come upon the Scene;
Some divine Poems, which (when firt I came
To Cambridge) I writ there, I need not name;
Of Dianea neither my Tranlation,
Omitted here as of another fahion.
For heavens ake name no more you ay, I cloy you:
I do obey you; Therefore (friend) God b'wy you.
This little Work I've done, which time may wat;
Or Ioves dipleaure into darknes cat:
But I will hope the bet, and that it may
Lat (after I am ahes) many a day.

div.head: EPIGRAMS. The third Book.

lg.l: GEntlemen, and my Countrey men! pray look
With courteous eyes upon this trivial Book:
For I preent it to you, that it may
Show my repects to you another day.
Why to the Lords I write not you enquire:
I hould not be o bold, though I deire.
But (to avoid prolixity of words)
Gentlemen they are, though you are not Lords.
Two Books of Epigrams I've writ before,
Yet (Gentle Readers) I preent you more:
Behold the third here offer'd you; but what
It will prove, good or bad, I know not yet.
May it likewie obtain your candor; els
Henceforth (for me) write Epigrams your elves.

div.head: 3. To the Right Honourable Philip Earl of Cheterfield, Baron of Shelford, &c.

lg.l: Philip the econd! Earl of Cheterfield!
I a requet have, and I hope you'l yield:
Yet I (in modety) long time have tuck
From making it; And 'tis but for a Buck:
Betow one on me, and on this good reaon,
I will not ask again till the next eaon.

div.head: 4. An Epitaph on Elizabeth the Lady Reppington, who deceaed at Ammington, about the 50. year of of her age, and lies buried at Tamworth.

lg.l: Here underneath this Monumental Stone
Elizabeth the Lady Reppington
Doth lye inter'd: And therefore whooere
Thou art that paet by, awhile forbear
Thy hat, and read, and weep; for he's unjut
Unto the merits of her precious dut,
That doth not drop his Tears in howers; for he
Is worthy of eternal Memory,
Worthy of torms of ighes, Thunder of Grones,
To mourn her los with due afflictions.
The ea-bright family that gave her birth,
Hath gain'd thereby a glory on the earth.
Happy her husband in o good a wife!
Happy her children to receive a life
From uch a Magazine of worthes as he!
A fair example for Poterity.
To name her virtues, is to name them all;
She was their Centre, he their pure White-hall,
Their Court, their Palace, where heaven did rejoyce
To ee uch Cherubims without a vice.
She was their Paradie, and her bright oul
The Diety that did command the whole.
But O! there is another heaven, ele ure
Her oul had never left a place o pure.
Earth is not the reward for virtue. Look
Upwards, that's towards her, he is a Book,
A Directory for thy life; which read,
And practiced, thou wilt be o prais'd when dead.

div.head: An Epitaph on my honoured Couin Mr. John Reppington, who deceaed at Ammington about the 25 year of his age, and lies buried at Tamworth.

lg.l: Here lies Iohn Reppington, that came to be
(By Edwards death) Heir of his Family:
As t'him his elder brother did give room,
So he t' his younger, witnes by this tomb.
He a few weeks after his mother di'd,
And of the ame (new term'd) dieae beide;
So he a mot obequious on was found,
That waited on his mother under ground.
He was good natur'd, bore an honet mind,
Belov'd by all men, and to all men kind:
And had no foe but death, who (too evere)
Hath cat an Heir o young and hopeful here.

div.head: 6. To Mr. Charles Hutchinon my Couin German.

lg.l: Couin, I long to ee you married well,
And long (at Rawlion) to ee you dwell.
Then I hould oft wait on you, make ome tay;
It being (from Pooly t' Ahburn) in the way.
So I hould make your houe mine Inne; what tho?
W'are friends, and neer a kin: Pray be mine o.

div.head: 7. To Mr. Francis Fitzherbert of Lincolnes Inne, my kinman.

lg.l: To love, and not to love; it is all one
If you do let the Fair belov'd alone:
And to love once, unles you do love ever,
Is a light toy, and was an earnet never.
Therefore (to hew you true affection have)
Your Mitrie wed, and love her to the grave.

div.head: 8. To Mr. Will. Stanhope the younger my Couin German.

lg.l: Why do you live o long a Batchelor?
Is it caue you the femall ex abhor?
Or do you fear women are troubleome,
And therefore loth into their yoke to come?
If uch opinions do your minde enthrall,
Marry a wife, and he'l confute them all.
Quintilla talkes too much, and why is it?
Becaue Quintilla hath but little wit:
And at each thing he peakes, he doth laugh after;
A Fool is known by an exces of laughter.

div.head: 10. To my mother Mrs Anne Cokain.

lg.l: Let none our Ahbourn dicommend henceforth;
Your Gardens hew it is a place of worth.
What delicate Sparagus you have growing there,
And in how great abundance every year?
What gallant Apricocks, and Peaches brave,
And what delicious Nectorins you have?
What Mellons that grow ripe without thoe Glaes
That are laid over them in other Places?
What Grapes you there have growing? and what wine
(Pleaant to tat) you made lat vintage time?
Plant Vines; & (when of Grapes you have got tore)
Make wine enough, and I will ask no more:
Then Mr. Bancroft (in high lines) hall tell
The world, your cellar's Aganippe's Well.

div.trailer: The ret are to be made.

lg.l: I Saw a proud fair Las to day,
Whoe beauties equal thoe of May:
She is as weet as flowers new blown;
Much pity he hould lie alone.
What would you give to bles your ight
With uch an object of delight?
I wondred at her delicate hair,
Mulcibers Net o oft and rare,
T' entangle even the Gods above,
And fill their hearts with gentle love.
What would you give, &c.
I gaz'd upon her beauteous eyes,
Loves exquiitet Palaces:
VVherein as many Cupids be,
As there are men that dare them ee
VVhat would you give, &c.
Het tately forehead was o fair,
That Iris Arch is no compare:
Match'd onely in lame Vulcans bride,
Unequal'd in the world beide.
What, &c.
Her weetet Mouth doth far excell
The Delphian certain Oracle:
Tis Loves bet muick, all ears charmer,
All hearts enthraller, and blouds warmer.
What, &c.
Her pretty hands I did epy,
Fitter for kies then an eye:
They were o mall, I cannot look
For uch again but in a book.
What, &c.
Her boome, Beauties weet champain,
The Poets Elizium I do fain.
Not white with now, but a electer
Colour, all overtrow'd with Nectar.
What, &c.
The two brave Thrones of beauty, her
Fine admirable Breats prefer
Before Olympus, or Mount Ide,
Where Iove mot happy might abide.
What, &c.
She had her clothes on, and I could
See no more, but to ay am bold,
That there was too much beauty under
To be look'd on for love and wonder.
What would you give, &c.
You Ladies fair,
That worthy are
Of all to be beloved,
And yet have hearts
So hard that darts
From eyes have never moved.
You cruel Saints,
That light complaints,
And corn to pity any;
I hope to ee
The time when ye
Shall be in love with many.
Which when I hear,
Then I will wear
That you are rightly fitted:
And that himelf
The little Elfe
On you hath well acquitted.
But do your wort,
I'm not accurt,
My Mitris is no coy one:
For he is kind,
And hath no mind
Within her to detroy one.

div.head: The third ong, being an anwer to O no, I tell thee no.

lg.l: Away I ay, away,
I no longer can delay,
And my heart forbids me tay:
It wears by thy quint eyes,
That could never entice
Foul Porters or Footboyes;
By thy Ruby noe, and lips lilly white,
And thy teeth with yellow dight,
Nere to come, nere to come again in thy ight.
It wears by thy dry'd skin
Thy boome within,
And thy paps lank, and thin;
And by thy durty golls,
That be to carry coles,
And rake dut out of holes;
By thy beatly form, and thy foul gouty feet,
That can carce cros a treet,
Nere again, nere again thee any where to meet.
By my hatred it wears,
Thy crook-back, and lave-ears,
Thy threecore and odde years,
By thy breath that is
So trong, that (with a kis)
It would kill a Cockatrice.
By my lat farwell, this kicke on thy breech,
And thy old alt Itch,
Nere to ee, nere to ee thee again thou witch.

div.head: The fourth ong, being a fictitious Relation.

lg.l: Let every man beware, for fear of tout Hugh Nunnick,
To peak ill of his Cornwall, or to dipraie Boconnick.
For he's a Cornih Chaugh, and not of it ahamed,
And born was near Boconnick at a place needs not be named.
He hath been very merry all from the mount to Lanton,
Where about many a May-pole, and many a green he hath danc'd on,
At Letithel, and Bodman, at Truro, and Polmagon
The courteous Lad Polwheel and he have toed many a Flagon.
He plaid at foils before his Worhip Sir Iohn Trelany,
Where on the eyes, and foreheads, and mouthes he hit a many.
There was a cudgel-play not long ince at Penwarden
Where he did break a Contables head, and the hins of a Churchwarden.
At Foy, he almot lot his eyes with too much laughter,
When he was at the wedding of Pru the Mayors fair daughter.
He was invited to venion, but the Paty being open,
There nought was in't but Apples, and they but meanly oken.
At Tap-houes he drank Syder with the old Lord Roberts Brewer,
And cuft him ere he parted, for aying he was truer:
Then the Hotee railed, and aid that he was foxed:
She ly'd like a tinking Baggage; he could have drunk an Hoghead.
At Okehampton town old Sherry gave him th • taggers,
Where he was o unruly, they lodg'd him among the Beggars.
At Exeter a Chine of beef he had, the firt he eat o •
And you my friends that hear this ong, he wore • was a great one.
He pent his money in rambling, and o was fain • rook on
Al the way from Salssbury until he came to Okeham
Where he lives very merry; For he is that town Carrier,
And never left his trade but once, to be Grave Maurice Warrier.
It is an offence to love, and to love you;
VVou'd I were blind, or you were true.
VVhy hould there be a mine of joyes within
Your Body, and to know't a in?
If I do ay I love, I'm ure tis fit,
If I have judgement, or have wit:
For your deerts are wonders that would move
Not onely mine, but any's love.
Some half-oul'd men that cannot tell what tis
To love or hate beyond a kis;
By eeing you do kindle a trange fire
VVithin them, and your weets deire.
You need not clothes, nor art, nor with a mile
Hope any mans heart to beguile:
Your Coynes, your Neglects, your Frowns will do
More then all Ladies ele that wooe.
Tis not my weaknes, but tis your deert,
I am not owner of my heart:
The puppet-play that by water goes,
The word of Guy, or Iohn of Gaunt.
We wie, &c.
Let zealous faters trudge a foot,
And toile their legs to hear a Lecture,
And there be chok'd with an Hebrew root,
At which the Miniter doth conjecture.
We wie, &c.
They that are gluttons, and love meat,
And it had rather be devouring,
The greay Cook-hops may repleat;
VVhil't we our full cups are out-pouring.
We wie, &c.
Y'are welcome all unto this place
That fears no Contable or Church-warden:
Here we will ing and drink apace,
And light the ports of Paris-garden.
We wie
Do them depie;
For we will tay here,
And with whole flaggons baite our own bear.

div.head: The eighth ong, upon the firt expedition into the North under the late King.

lg.l: Will you hear a ong
Shall do no body no wrong,
And yet was writ at randum
By a friend of mine
Ore a glas of wine,
So great it would make a man dumb.
He wanted no matter,
To have made it a Satyre,
And abus'd all towns-men, and Nobles:
But he thought it unfit
o to wrong his wit,
To bring himelf into troubles.
To all his friends
He ends his commends,
And praies them when they are drinking
To forbear to prate
Of matters of State,
And leave them to th' Councels thinking:
Nor to take it in nuff
If a man in buff
Doth come into their chamber;
As if they thought
All Souldiers were naught,
And a contempt was in armour.
Nor when they are drunk
To think of a punk,
For fear of the flux, or weating;
But away to creep,
And (at home) go leep,
And leave it a friendly meeting.
He would have them next
Not to be perplext
If their mitres be cruel;
Nor to fight with them
Whom they do eteem;
Let they be jeer'd for the Duel.
If a man love one,
And her heart be gon,
And plac'd upon another;
Let him do the ame
In little Cupids name,
And that will pleae Loves mother.
Let him that is forth
Going to the north,
Have his health drunk every itting;
And all good ucces
Wih'd unto the Englih,
And all things ele befitting.
Let the ouldiers obey
What the captains ay,
Let they digrace their profeion;
And ave their blows
From their friends for their foes,
And all their angers expreion.
Let us fight for our King,
And fame will ing
Of us an endles tory;
The Chronicles will tell
That we did well,
And liv'd and dy'd in glory.
O Cupid ue thy bow,
Thy deity declare;
Make all fit people know
Thy force that living are.
But hoot aright (good boy)
And mutual fire contrain;
For it is tytanny
To make our love in vain.
Let Matrons peevih be
Whoe lookes time hath decaid:
But let no youthful he
From earth deceae a Maid.
Let Ethiops froward prove
Whom nature hath made back:
And they thy pleaures love
That no perfections lack.
Make every man love one,
And him his mitres too;
So Hymen hall not moane
For wanting of his due.
The young ones of each ex
Will thereby have content,
And not hereafer vex,
To fat o long a Lent.
Curle every hair, mile with your eyes,
And enchant
Any Saint
With the rare muick of your voice:
Show your breat,
Or your bet,
Me you no way have to entice.
Dance to weet numbers, to excel,
Being o quick,
'Rithmetick;
And o mot evenly, and o well,
That out wonder
May not number
Thoe oft teps your feet do tell.
Take your weet Lute (which is the pirit
Of muick)
And ue it
Unto your highet praie of merit:
Though each ound
My ears wound,
My heart nereles hall freely bear it.
Were all your clothes o rich and fine,
As you were
In her phere
Bright Citheraea to out-hine;
Yet they hoo'd
Not my blood
Warm like unto a glas of wine.
In hope to conquer at firt ight,
To each part
Add all art:
And to provoke an appetite,
To your will
Joyn your skill;
Yet all your magick I hall light.
Let you and I together go
In the pring,
When birds ing;
And I'le wear to talk, not wooe:
Or when heat
Makes us get
Into an Arbour, I'le do o.
I cannot be a thrall to her
Who I know
Heart doth ow
To another, and him prefer;
If my uit
Mis the fruit,
I the tree can well abhor.
Yet (Lady) witnes all we ee,
Tis not I
That deny,
Nor is it you that diagree:
Honour o
Slight you do,
That I in love can never be.
Wherefore hould gallants be ad,
And keep houe like an owl all day?
Sure they that do o are mad,
Or want money a hot to pay.
Then let's drink off our pots,
Our glaes and our bowles:
The refuers all are ots,
And men of narrow oules.
Our honet hotes doth ing, our honet hotes doth ing
With a pot of ale
In her hand, that is tale,
Sing hey ding, ding a ding, ding.
Leave thinking of London ack,
Of Rhenih, Claret, and White
Such chargeable liquors lack,
And in an Alehoue delight.
If our drink be trong of the malt,
And boyled enough withal,
I wonder who can find fault
With uch a good cup of ale.
Our honet hotes doth ing, &c.
If any two be fallen out,
And ready a duel to fight,
Let them drink together a bout,
A whole day or a whole night:
And that will make them friends,
And have no mind to quarrel,
Without their bloods expence;
Such vertue is in a barrel.
Our honet hotes doth ing, &c.
If any man be in love,
And cannot his mitres get,
Let him all buines remove,
And go and drink a fit.
Good company, and good drink,
And an houe that will reckon right,
Will make a body think
Time pent in love's no delight.
Out honet hotes doth ing, &c.
If a man want money or clothes,
And hath but a friend to pay;
Good liquor will banih his woes,
And make him a merry day:
It Phyick is for each grief,
And medicine for all dieaes;
The labourers ole relief,
And all his toile appeaes.
Our honet hotes doth ing, &c.
A pot of pic't ale and a tot
Is good for a mornings draught;
And meat either boyl'd or rot,
For dinner, if it be alt.
'Twill make ones liquor go down
Without harking, with delight;
And Gentleman make, or clown,
To leep without waking all night.
Our honet hotes doth ing, &c.

div.head: The twelfth ong.
The wenches complaint, Non e maggior tormento.

lg.l: I can no greater torment find
Then ly with one I cannot love
Each minute eems a year confin'd,
So lowly then do minutes move.
When me his hap 's to kis, or touch,
I with him am offended much.
If he doth chance to me to ay,
Can it be poible (my Dear)
You o abtemious are from play
That you (againt your will) ly here?
I am enforc'd in complement
To tell him I have much content.
Imagine Ladies, you that know
What a vexation it is,
If from my heart I peak or no,
And do not counterfeit all this:
For when to him I turn my back,
I mouthes at him in hatred make
All that enamoured are of me,
VVhom I cannot affect again,
Thus from their paions I do free;
I have no pleaure in their gain:
And (ifthey think I any take)
Tis with their money I it make
Thee four firt Stanza's are tranlated out of Italian; the end in the original omitted as too wanton, and this lat added for a concluion. Women that are by want oppret
And therefore yield unto this vice,
Know all the world they do detet
Embraces that are not their choice.
The want of mony is unjut,
To make them ubject unto Iut.

div.head: The thirteenth ong.
William the Conquerour to Emma the Miliners daughter of Mancheter.

lg.l: Hellen of Greece I hould depie,
And Creida unhandome call;
Poppaea would not pleae mine eyes,
My Emma o exceeds them all.
When he doth chance to combe her head,
She catters night upon her face;
Her lovely brown hair being pred,
Thoe clouds forbid our eageret gaze.
Envy about her can uppoe
No fault at all, but in her clothes.
When her fine hand th' Eclipe removes,
And lets her eyes dart forth their beams,
Our hearts are burned by our loves,
And quenched by our Optick treams.
Let her weet eyes, ore-glorious lights,
Should fire on one another reflect,
And burn themelves to endles nights,
Her delicate noe tands to protect.
Envy about, &c.
Her lips themelves in love have kit,
And married were by her weet tongue;
Her dear heart gave them to the Priet,
And all th' Epithalamium ong.
Her even and little teeth all clad
In white, as white as puret now,
Intead of bridemen wait mot glad,
And for the bridemaids likewie go.
Envy about &c.
Her pretty ears this Paradie
Do guard without a Gun or word;
Vertue commands in chief, and vice
Dares not approch though in a word.
Her neck doth eem the milky way
Unto the Tempe of her breat,
Where two fine hills nipples diplay,
Like two uns riing eat and wet.
Envy about &c.
Her lovely hands (when they do tir
Through motion he unto them lends)
Add everal graces unto her,
And beauty hake at fingers ends.
Thee are her glories that we know,
Her envious clothes conceal the ret:
Happy is he that o can woe
As win her to reveal the ret!
Envy about her, &c.
Let fancy work till he be kind;
And lay her on a bed of Roes,
Terra's incognita's to find,
And it a paradie dicloes.
Her belly like a bed of creame
Appears unto our curious eyes,
Upon whoe top you may eteem
The Navil like a cherry lies.
Envy about her, &c.
Her mountain-thighs we doepy
Cover'd with warm perpetual now:
Ah what a treight between doth ly,
No Magellan did ever know!
Her neat-made legs forth tretched ly
On heets reembling a calme Sea,
And (like to Promontories) try
To frame a afe and pleaant Bay.
Envy about her, &c.
Her pretty feet like lands-ends eem,
Whoe toes likes Fairies do appear
To tempt beholders to eteem
No beauty uch, and t'enter there.
Tis like (fair maid) you yet may boat
That trifle cal'd virginity:
How many joyes you then have lot!
Therefore away with uch a toy.
Envy about her, &c.
When you hall gracious be but thus
To meet in groves or amorous beds;
Young Kings and Queens hall envy us,
And we will get new maidenheads:
And when we do refreh awhile,
You like a Princes bride hall rie;
And Art and Nature both hall toyl
To dres you glorious as the skies.
Envy about you hall uppoe
No fault, and wonder at your clothes.

div.head: The fourteenth ong.
Emma's anwer to William the Conquerour.

lg.l: Great conquerour, you do a wrong
Unto your judgement, to compare
Poor Emma (in your amorous ong)
To Ladies o renown'd and fair.
The hair that grows upon my head
I have no caue to glory in;
It is as brown as is my bread,
And can (I hope) tempt none to fin.
My clothes are homely as my form,
I wear them but to keep me warm.
My humble eies (when I am up)
To read my office are employ'd,
And unto houe-affaires to look,
And not to gaze abroad in pride.
I hope no want on beams they cat
To work to any an uneae:
Therefore my noe needs not be plac'd
As Contable to keep the peace.
My clothes are homely, &c.
My lips will erve a country wench,
So alo will my northern tongue;
It with my heart agrees in ene,
What I think peaking, and no wrong.
My teeth are like to other girls,
Nor even, nor white, but in the mean:
I know they are but bones, not pearls,
And lut I were, were they not clean.
My clothes are homely, &c.
My ears will erve to do the part
Which nature did deigne them for;
The love of vertue's in my heart,
And to hear lewdnes I abhor.
I wonder why my neck you praie;
As other maidens are o 's it:
So is my breat, which I adaies
Ue to weare cover'd, as is fit.
My clothes are homely, &c.
My hands employ'd in houwifries,
To ow, to pin, or ele to card;
Cannot be oft, not being nice,
And 't is no hame to have them hard.
Such is poor Emma, and no better,
VVhom (royal Sir) you o commend:
And I beeech you therefore let her
Her poor life in plain truth to end.
My clothes are homely, &c.
Let not your fancy be unkind
Unto your elf, ill thoughts to raie:
My wearied body at night doth find
A bed of flocks or traw alwaies.
My other parts you pleae to name
Are ordinary as the ret;
And I in truth do bluh for hame
To hear them o by you expret.
My clothes are homely, &c.
I cannot from my tears refrain
To hear you tax virginity:
How many martyr'd virgins reign
In heaven for keeping chatity!
And (in the dark Abys below)
How many wretched ouls do grone,
For lighting here their honour o,
As heathens have far better done!
My clothes are homely, &c.
I hope I never hall become
Ungracious in o a high a wie,
To protitute to any one
A jewel heaven o much doth prize:
If I (to pleae my friends) hould wed
To any honet neighbours child,
I am reolv'd the marriage-bed
To keep (my life through) undefil'd.
Though me then better clothes transform,
Ile wear them but to keep me warm.
Here's a Health to a merry old inner,
A Glas of trong Aquavitae,
That for a crown and a dinner
Will get you a Wench will delight you.
Becaue that you are not for Ale,
Here's a Health to a Wench in trong Beer;
Although he (like it) be tale,
She may happen to cot you dear.
Here's a Health in Ale to your Dear,
That lately hath erv'd in the Kitchin;
A bouncing Watcoteer,
A remedy for your itching.
Here's a Health to the Earls fine daughter,
In Rhenih with Lemmon and Suggar,
Who (with this well ballanc'd) will after
Give liberty to you to hugge her.
Unto the Green-icknes Maid
Here's a Health in parkling White,
Though yet he be never o taid,
She may alter her mind ere night.
Unto the new married wife,
An Health here is in neat Claret;
Though her poue lead a jealous Life,
And her tongue out-prattles a Parret,
To the jovial widdow at lat,
An health we will drink in Sack
Her contitution's in hat,
You may quickly gues what he doth lack.
Now you have o freely drunk
Their healths, and merrily round.
Each of you may go to his Punk,
They are yours a mite to a pound.
Bút now I've thought better on't,
Y'ad bet to leave drinking and whoring
For virtue hereafter will vaunt,
When vice hall receive a great cowring,

div.head: The ixteenth Song, of two lovers.

lg.l: Two lovers lately that for ome years pace
Enjoy'd in each others looks an heaven of blis,
Are parted, and have left their uual gaze,
He on her beauties, and he upon his.
Behold what alterations time can raie
In humane breats, and etled contancies:
Great Love, we do accue thee of our crime,
And thank for our recovery onely Time.
As I have een a crooked river run
Through Meads and moorih grounds in oblique coure,
So lighly tealing as no way it won,
And no intention had to leave the ource;
And never roar'd at all till it begun
Into another tream to yield its force:
So no dilike her cunning Fahion how'd,
Till all her Favours he from him betow'd.
Long he her lov'd, and long he lov'd again,
And both did glory in each others heart:
Cupid in each breat kept an equal reign,
A mutual court of joy without all art;
Without disimulation or didain,
Without the leat offence to either part,
Till a new love poet her yielding mind,
After o long continuing true and kind,
He afterwards retreated (as was fit)
Cal'd home his heart, and quench'd the mighty fire,
With drinking Lethe to his former fit,
That had o long enthral'd him to deire.
And (generous pirit) that hat conquer'd it,
All hail! And welcome to the acred Quire
Of Freedoms Temple, where bright Truth dicovers,
And laughes at all the follies of all Lovers.
I love a Las as fair as ere was een,
Yet have I never een if he be fair:
Grandees her uitors have and ervants been,
And they that wooe her now great Nobles are
How can I therefore think that he will dain
To look on me? I fear I love in vain.
Unto the Beauty which I do o deire
I will make hat, to ee how fair he is;
And though I find my betters wooers by her,
I will be bold, and all my thoughts expres;
Which when I have done, will he therefore dain
To pity me? I fear I love in vain.
Ile tell her that her hairs are golden Twines
Able t' enamour all the Deities;
And that her eyes are two celetial ignes,
More glorious then the twelve within the skies.
When I have told her this, will he then dain
To love me too? I fear I love in vain.
If (when that I have aid what I can ay,
And made what Protetations I can make)
She will be proud, and coy, and ay me Nay,
Though nere o fair, my heart from her Ile take
I will not ubject be to her didain:
The world hall never ay I love in vain.
I wonder why by foul-mouth'd men
Women o lander'd be,
Since it o eaily doth appear
Th' are better far then we.
Why are the Graces every one
Pictur'd as women be,
If not to hew that they in Grace
Do more excell then we?
Why are the liberal Sciences
Pictur'd as women be
But t' how (if they would tudy them)
They'd more excell then we.
And yet the Senes every one,
As men hould pictur'd be;
To make it known that women are
Les enual then we.
Why are the virtues every one
Pictur'd as women be;
If not to hew that they in them,
Do more excell then we?
Since women are o full of worth,
Let them all praied be;
For commendations they deerve
In ampler wie then we.
You are too proud to love, and are too kind
To hate: what therefore is your mind?
Think you none worthy of you, 'caue you know
That you hould be admired o?
And will you not hate, 'caue you would
Not be a maid when you are old?
Though nature hath been liberal in your parts,
And you (for jewels) do wear hearts
If you your elf do onely like and love,
You in a wrong phere for you move.
As you were made to love, beide
So you were made to be enjoy'd.

div.head: The twentieth Song. A Ballad of Darbyhire.

lg.l: Dear Polyhymnie, be
Aupicious unto me,
That I may pread abroad
Our Shires worth in an ode,
Merrily chanting.
They that our Hills do blame,
Have no caue for the ame;
Seeing the Mues lye
Upon Parnaus high,
Where no joy's wanting.
Upon Olympus Hill
Hebe Heavens cup doth fill:
And Iove of Candy Ile
Doth the Gods reconcile,
When they do wrangle.
In France at Agincourt
(Where we fought in uch ort)
Behind an hill we did
Make our Archers lye hid,
Foes to entangle.
The long commanding Rome,
And old Byzantium,
Lisbon in Portugal,
Are ituated all
Upon Hills trongly:
All therefore that protet
Hilly ground's not the bet,
Are of their wits bereav'd,
And all of them deceiv'd,
And cenure wrongly.
The Peer of England known
Darby's Earldom to own,
Is honour'd by the tyle
Of King of Mona's Ile
Hereditary.
Why hath Orantus found
A Channel under ground
VVhere t'lye hid, but for hame
VVhen it hears Darwins name,
VVhich Fame doth carry?
VVhy do the Nymphs (believe)
Of Nile, it down Rocks drive;
Unles it be for fear
Trents glory hould go near
To overgo them?
The Spaw Luick Land hath,
And Sommeret the Bath:
Burtons (dear County) be
As famous unto thee
As they unto them.
For King Mauolus Tomb,
Lango's known by each Groom;
And the Campanian Lake
Doth very famous make
Italies confines;
The walls of burned tone
Eternize Babylon:
And the large Devils vault
Doth Darbyhire exalt,
VVherein no un hines.
The Pike to Tennariff
An high repute doth give;
And the Colos of bras,
VVhere under hips did pas,
Made Rhodes apire.
Tunbridge makes Kent renown'd,
And Epome Surryes Ground:
Pools-hole, and St. Annes VVell
Makes Darbyhire excell
Many a hire.
Here on an Hills ide teep
Is Elden hole, o deep,
That no man living knowes
How far it hollow goes;
Worthy the knowing
Here alo is a Well
Whoe Waters do excell
All waters thereabout;
Both being in and out
Ebbing and flowing.
Here's Lead, whereof is made
Bullets for to invade
Them whoe pride doth prevail
So far, as to aail
Our Brittih borders.
Our Lead o much may do,
That it may win Peru;
And (if we chance to meet
A Spanih ilver Fleet)
Commit great murthers.
Diana's Fane to us
Extolleth Epheus:
The Sand-hil, and deaf tone,
Do Darbyhire renown,
Worth Admiration.
Windor Berks doth commend,
And Eex Audley-end:
We of our Chatsworth boat,
A Glory to our coat,
And the whole Nation.
Spain doth vaunt of it's Sack,
And France of Claret crack;
Of Rhenih Germany:
And of thy Ale peak free
My gallant County.
Now I have made an end,
I wih you to commend
Either the Authors wit,
Or me for inging it,
Out of your bounty.
Ah me! I have inned o,
That the thought of it is my woe;
That my eyes
To the skyes,
Nor my prayer
Neither dare
I to lift, but here mourn below.
What therefore, had I bet here to it,
And lament for my faults in unfit
Sorrow? no;
Who doth o,
Spends his fears,
And his tears
All in vain any mercy to get.
My oul, mount thou then aloft,
And beeech him tha't angred o oft
He eaily can
Pardon man,
Being inclin'd
To be kind
With real contrition, and oft.
What though my many foul trangreions do
Exceed all the tars in our view;
Do overcome
Motes it'h Sun,
And urpas
Blades of gras?
His merits do exceed all thee too.
His mercies exceed all thee,
And all ins wherewith men him dipleae
Every igh
He did give,
Every wound
That is found
On his body could a world releae.
And therefore for hame if not for love,
(Yet love is all fear and hame above)
Let us hun
Hell, and run
In heavens way,
Whiles t'is day;
For from thence is no ad remove.

div.p: THE OBSTINATE LADY A COMEDY Written by ASTON COKAIN.

list.item: Carionil. A young Lord. The counterfeit. Negro, and cal'd Tucapelo.
Lorece. A phantatick gallant. His brother.
Iaques. An old imple daughter of Vandonae's.
Roinda. Polidare his wife, cal'd Tandorix.
Lucora. The obtinate Lady her daughter.

lg.l: BRave crown of Gallants welcome! May this place
Meet expectation; you afford us grace:
We joy that uch a multitude divine
Of Planets in our little Spheres do hine;
And that beides our Horizon is tuck
With leer lights, we do eteem't good luck.
For the great favour, may each everal cene
Affect you more, then Hebe's Nectar Heaven.
We can but wih't: for if y'are come to day
In expectation of a faultles play,
Writ by learn'd Johnon, or ome able pen,
Fam'd, and approv'd of by the world, you then
We diappoint: our Poet had never yet
Hies condemn, or hands commend his wit.
Troth, Gentlemen, we know that now a daies
Some come to take up wenches at our plaies;
It is not our deigne to pleae their ence,
We wih they may go dicontented hence.
And many Gallants hither come (we think)
To leep, and to diget their too much drink:
We may pleae them; for we will not molet,
With drums or trumpets, any of their ret.
If perfum'd wantons do for eighteen pence,
Expect an Angel, and alone go hence,
We hall be glad withall our hearts, for we
Had rather have their room then company:
For many an honet gentleman is gone
Away for want of place, as look ye you:
We gues ome of you Ladies hither come
To meet your ervants wh' are at dice at home;
You'l be deceiv'd, and therefore will dipraie,
And ay this is the wort of all the plaies
You ever aw: but keep your cenures (pray)
Until you meet them here another day.
Our Poet is not confident, nor doth
Ditrut his work, but labours 'twixt them both:
He hopes it will be lik'd, and well; if not,
'T can be but hi'd at wort, and oon forgot

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: SHe has out-gone my belief by't,
I did not think that project would have fail'd;
I cannot peak her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Alpian now is not more cold.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Her dipoition is mot trange.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: 'Twere eaier far
To purn the oultry Cyclops Anvil down,
And kick it thus into Atomes in the air,
Then to obtain her love;
It were, my dear Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O think not o Carionil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Have I not caue?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: At lat after a contant and a brave puruit
She may be won.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Could I but hope o much,
Did all the tars malignant influences
Threaten fate oppoite to my happines,
I would not deem them worthy my obervance,
But perevere till I obtain'd, or fell.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Conjecture till the bet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis eaier to advie then to perform;
Had you, Falorus, been o oft dimit
Comfortles, cornfully ent away,
By her own lips, (O heavens!) you could not think it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I could and would.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: With hope friend?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Yes with an aurance.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Upon what ground would you build it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Upon a womans frequent diimulation.
Can you believe, when envious clouds deprive
Your eyes from the uns beams, that it hines not?
In thee times young Ladies for a while
Do mantle their affections in dilike:
Let not an ignorance of Virgins wiles
Diturb your noble breat with weak depaire;
Carionil aume a confidence,
Were you inferiour unto her in blood,
Or any whit deform'd, after her nayes
You might upect the period but eeing
'Tis known, as noble blood runs through your veins,
And that nature compos'd you in a mould
As excellent as he was form'd in, and
With ubtance of as beauteous a glos;
You need not let doubts puzzle you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay and admire with me; exalt your eyes to happines.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Your Mitres and her Woman, my Carionil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lucora, She's a trancendent of Epithets.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I ee a Lute: let us ecape their ight,
And it is likely we hall hear her ing.

sp.speaker: Lucora.
sp.l: Now give it me. Is it in tune?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Forbear awhile to play upon the pheres,
Ye ervants to the Deities: the Gods
Will blame you, if your muick keep the ayr
Of her all-ravihing harmony from their eares.

lg.l: Sweet Diana, vertuous Queen,
By heavens edict Guide of night,
That dot affect the medows green,
And dot in freh-leav'd woods delight;
Like to thy Nymphs, uffer me
To conecrate my elf to thee.
Thou that for lut diddet transform
Rah Actaeon to a Hart;
Either mot trongly Maidens charm,
That men may never them divert
From purity, or ele make
Them other Harts for virgins ake.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How! a votres to Diana,
The heavens forbid that injury to earth.
Had the deceitful Syrens uch a voice,
And bodies of o rare a form, I would
Nere come on hipboard, for fear of being drawn
To drown my elf by wimming after them.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: I do not like her Madam.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Who ever yet poke ill of Daphne? fie!
Banih uch impious cenures from you.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Troth, Madam, I hould have been glad to a been my Lady Apollo.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.p: O rellih more of purity Nentis. Alas, 'tis a fraile comfort can come with a husband.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: I think otherwie indeed Madam.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Be all uch thoughts remote from my breat,
My reolution hall be never to marry.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now you have heard her thoughts Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: That he diguies not her love you mean.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: True, and I am mot mierable.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My happy friend you will be.
Tis an ignorant common cutome among young ones to do o.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But he's a fixed tar, and cannot move.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Fixed in your heart tis likely,
But otherwie I doubt, nor do you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Y'ave • ird a feeble belief within me, Friend,
That the excellent Lucora may be won,
And I will nourih it unto ome height.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A neceary that none mut want, which do
Deire fruition of thoe whom they wooe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O honet Iaques!

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: My Lady preents her ervice to your Lordhip.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She is in health I hope.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Very well. And I am glad to ee your Honour o, though I ay it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She is not towards another husband yet?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: No certainly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Methinks her fortunes hould give her a various choice. You are elewhere employed I perceive: remember my bet repects unto your Lady.
Y'ave heard of my couin Vandona, Falorus?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But very little.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: She's the mot phantatick piece of womankind I ere chang'd breath with, but a young one, wealthy, and truly not unhandome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Lorece does intend to make love unto her.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your brother, my Falorus?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yes, o he told me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: May he obtain her if you wih it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Her etate would make the match a good one.
Is this the boy you o commended to me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis he, and think him you worthy the praie I gave him.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: He'l come and wait upon you at night, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis well Anclethe.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You poke him not unto his merits.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are beholding to my friend (Ancleth.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Your Lord's in health?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: And deires to peak with your Lordhip,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where may I find him?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p: He'l be at his lodgings thee two houres.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I'le wait upon him preently.
I am his ervant. Carionil, I mut take my leave.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The Gods go with you. He may be my father in law, but will not if he can prevent it: Adieu friend.
O my Anclethe! thou cant not gues the world of torments I nourih here; I cannot number them my elf, and becaue I cannot, I fear the Gods will not.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: What can you ail my Lord?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cant thou imagine me free from miery?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Indeed I did.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, there's a Lady (he's above all Ladies,
And were he pitiful, I hould wear a goddes)
That does deny me happines.
As thou hat me, Idalian Archer, o
On her ue thy eternal tringed bow:
Draw to the head thy haft, and let it fly;
For love but love there is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Wretched Cleanthe! to what a multitude
Of woful ighes my detinies have driven me!
Could all the tears that I abundantly have wept,
But find that recompence I dare not look for,
O they were howers to be belov'd like thoe
That deck the pring with bravery! Carionil
(For whom I languih in diguie) it eems
Hath etled his affections on a Lady
Does not return him love. May he continue
Obtinate ever: but I mut blame her judgement,
Who can behold a man (with all the art
Of nature) fram'd to curioity,
And heare the world report his vertues equal
Unto his form, and not admire and love him.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Now my young weet face! what pretty foolih whimies trouble thy pate, that thou looket o compoedly?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Sir, I am as I ue to be.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Then you ue to be curvy. Ue the Tavern once or twice a day. You mut not be o melancholy.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: It bet becomes me.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Cant thou wear?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: The Gods forbid.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Cant thou ing.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.p: Not worth your hearing Sir.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Say't thou o! Then will I omething worth thine.

lg.l: Of ix hilling beer I care not to hear,
A barrel's not worth a carret,
I as others think, that there is no drink
Like unto Sack, White wine, and Claret.
Diana's a fool, and me hall not rule
To live a bacheller ever;
For I mean not to tarry, in her livery, but marry,
And quickly, believe me, or never.
And I and my wife will lead uch a life,
As he hall think well befel her;
For throughout the year we'l tipple March-beer
And eldome be out of the Cellar.
All Sto • ical prate, and Diana I hate,
With her maidenly curvy advices:
Green icknes upon her, weet Venus I honour;
For wenches and wine are not vices.
Woo'd Baceus the knave had met with this brave
Diana, this whey-blooded Lady;
For the credit of 'th grape he had made a rape,
And got a puiant babie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: Y' are not melancholy Sir, your brother is more olemn.

sp.speaker: Core.
sp.p: I melancholy! I corne it boy. Yet I'me not o merry as I was wont, the young gunner Mr. Cupid had omewhat tam'd me: but I am good mettle till (thank my jovial fates) and will ound melodiouly, my young Paris.
Welcome to Hercules noble Theeus. Good boy,
Go wait on thy mater.
How do't, thou old magazine of precious knavery?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I am glad to ee your Worhip well.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: My noble milner of words, thou that dot grind thy peeches with a merry pronunciation, wilt be my boome, my cabinet, my friend Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I will obey your good Worhip.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Liberally poken! when I have opened me, will you be privy?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Very ecret and officious: it is good manners in me, your command hall wedge my tongue, hedge my heart, and tye a true lovers knot upon it with the trings of it.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Thou art an honet clod of earth, Iaques.
Tis pity the malicious un-hine warm'd thee not into a diamond.

sp.speaker: Iaques.
sp.p: Your Worhip peakes above my brains.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: I am marvellouly enamour'd on your Lady, Iaques. Vandona is my Mitris.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Wonderful news! Is my Lady your Worhips weet-heart?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Yes. But ignorant of my affection yet.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I could be drunk were you my Mater, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: I would have a Wine-cellar o'th purpoe. My etate Iaques is but mean: It mut be craft mut get her: Knowet thou any poible way to win her?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Sir, I am paing empty of invention, but wherein I can pleaure you, tell me at any time, and I will not fail you. But the Gods bles your good Worhip: Sir, would you marry her?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Yes my old truty Perithous. Why dot wonder at it?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: She does nothing all day but read little Comedies, and every night pendstwo or three hours on a great Tragedy of a merry fellow Dametas, and a company of trange-nam'd learned Lovers, he's no more houwife then you or I Sir, on my own proper knowledge, I wear, vow and protet it.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Thou art too earnet my old-fac'd Saturn, I think her not the wore woman. Houwifery is the uperficies of a genteel female, and the Parentheis of a Lady, which may well be left out.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You are a Scholar, your bookhip hall direct me.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Who's that? knowet thou him Iaques? He walkes corantoly, and looks big.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And like your Worhip, this tide firt brought him to my eyes.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: He came not by water, did he old Boy?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I meant Time Sir, the London word.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: When we this paion into us receive,
Our former pleaures we do loath and abandon

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Leave, by your leave.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: If it were foolihnes in us to take
Affection, why did heaven two exes compoe?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Make, would make Rhime.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Why Period to the Phoenix doth fire give,
But becaue it doth againt nature conit?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Live, he hould ay. This is ome very mal Poet.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Ile on, and am reolved to preferre
My life to be a ervice unto her.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: What an affected utterance has this fellow!

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: He'l nere make good Ballad warrant him, that will not rhime when he may.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: The Catatrophe was in • hime though. He would be lik'd for a tage Poet.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Noble Heroes! the Gods intend your fortunes to your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: An Academical Idiome: enquire his name Iaques, he delivers his mind after the garb of a Signior.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Have you a name friend?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I anwer to Draculemyon.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Good Sir, let's trudge hence; this is ome great Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Are you a Necromancer?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Mr. Lorece, I fear he is ome Saracen, he looks o dimal.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Art thou a Panim, peak?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: For all your great looks Termegant is an Idol.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I am nor one nor other, but your Honours vaall, and a poor Englihman. Wilt pleae you to hear the Muick of Helicon?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Law you now Sir, how one may be deceiv'd! I believe the whoron is a Fidler. Can you ing (irra?) anwer me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I am no Fidler; but live by my tongue and legs: will you hear me (noble Sir) peak a Parnaian Oration, or ee me meaure the ground with a dance?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: What aiet thou Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Why now Sir, tis dinner time with my Lady, and I dare not neglect her, neither will I my own tomach, and therefore for me he may hew us a fair pair of heels, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well then—pend this for me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Y'are, Sir, the bet part of a moralit: you are mot liberal.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Come Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I follow you Sir, farewell goodman Draculemyon.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: The Gods bles me, there's a name!
Proceed Phyginois, and be fortunate;
This project will furnih me with mony to cloth me
Both fahionably and rich enough, and then
I dare aail my Nentis with ome confidence:
Politick Lovers eldom mis.
Smile heaven upon my plot, that there may be
A crowned Period to my policy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: HOw do you like Lucora?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: She's a Lady above my thoughts, much more my tongue.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Could not you wih her yours? I have a deire to make her o.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Ambroia Hebe's Cates are for the Gods:
Princes he doth deerve to wooe her love.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You undervalue her my Lord;
The bet is not too good for him that gets her.
Your breeding has been worthy your decent;
I've known you from your Infancy, and am
Deirous to make you mine.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: He enforceth me to an acceptance. I mut temporize with him,
Mot worthy Polidacre, I cannot attain to a greater happines on earth, then to bear the name of your Son in law.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thank thee my Falorus. Ile go preently, & get my daughters conent. As you hall not want beauty with her, o you hall not money. Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am your mot humble ervant, my Lord.
VVhat envious Star when I was born, divin'd
This advere Fate, who having uch a beauty
Profer'd him, would refue it? The pin'd man
VVhom Poets phantaies have plac'd in Hell
