VVith fruit before him, had not uch a cros.
The true regard I bear unto my friend.
The brave Carionil mut not be lighted;
The acred truth of friendhip ever hoo'd
By force enfeeble all rebellious blood.
VVell met my dear Carionil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am happy in your company: y'are my hearts bet treaury, Falorus.
sp.l: But give me leave my friend.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: O! I ee the caue; your Mitris.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Retire ye Clouds, and weep out howers of woe,
Becaue ye may no longer tand and gaze
On her, for whom the heavens their circuits go,
That they may ee, and wonder at her face.
Dear Falorus withdraw your elf awhile.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: The Gods ait your uit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thanks worthy friend.
sp.p: Hail natures mot perfect work, and the continual Idea of my admiring Soul, for whom (if it be your will) I mut dye, and by whom (if it is your pleaure) I hall live, live in an unpeakable felicity by enjoying you, who hall dye happily for wanting you, and I cannot live in uch a penury.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: VVoo'd I had uch a ervant: I hould not erve him curvily.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
Honour your poor adorer, Lady, with a gracious look of your beloved eyes, and my miery for
you, both with commieration and remedy.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: My Lord, if you preume upon a womans
Feign'd carriage to her wooers, leave it now.
For (if you'l give me leave) I'le call to witnes
Every particular Deity we adore,
That I will never have a husband: and
For your aying you mut dye for me, I hold it
A common Complement of idle Lovers;
And wih you o much happines, that you
May live well without me.

sp.speaker: Cario.
sp.l: O be not o unmerciful!
Let not that tongue erre into virulent words,
VVhich could have cal'd Euridice from Hell.
Had your mot excellent mother (fairet Lady)
Inexorable been, you had not been,
Nor Crimon Roes ever pread upon
Your lovely cheeks, nor had the world dicover'd
Two Planets more: hath nature liberally
Heaped the raret perfections (he could give
Mortality) upon you to no end?
No urely, not can I believe that he
Ment to encloe a mind infractible
Within a body o powerful to ubdue.
As you (even your dear elf) was daughter to
A beauteous mother, o you alo hould
Indebt the world unto you by your iue:
Be not o cruel therefore (dear Lucora)
Let not your tongue degenerate from your form.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Sir, you have heard me peak what I intend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be not a Tygres Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Any thing but a wife:
Sir, I mut leave you, and leave you this humour;
The Court hath many Ladies, take your choice.
Nentis!

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Mad am

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come my Lord take my counel.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I could ue him kindlyer.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What ay you Lady?

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Nothing my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Doth a fair face preage a cruel heart?
I't not a meer full contrary in Nature,
That the oftet body hould be hard't to win?
Nature is grown decrepit, and all things
Sublunary erre againt her rule of order.
Stir not then thou glorious Fabrick of the heavens,
And periodize the Muick of the pheres.
Thou ever yet fat fixed Globe of earth,
Whirl round in a perpetual Motion.
Ye Stars and Moon that beautifie the night,
Change rule with clear Hyperion, and o cat
Succeeding time into another mould.
Then with thy powerful beams, Apollo, draw
The Ocean into clouds, and drown the world:
So there a new creation may befall,
And this life be a life celetial.
O all my happines on earth, my true Falorus!
Lucoraes beauty triumphs in my breat,
And hortly will detroy me: There's no beat
That haunts the vatet Affrican wildernes,
Of uch a merciles contitution.
She'l never marry man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: She will Carionil. Her father would have her, and he has not o much evil to contradict his will: where then can he make uch a choice as you? that in a duel, your Grandfather did kill hers, y'v e heard her oft protet he valued not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Does he deire it, or does your love flatter me into a little poibility of obtaining her? Alas, if he could like me, her father would very difficultly conent. He loves not my family.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Polidacre could not hinder you, were he willing. But (friend) her father means to marry her. His own lips offer'd her to me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O ye jut heavenly powers! then I am lot,
Sunk into miery beneath a park
Of this lives happines.
Falorus, you hall not have her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I would not wrong my noble friend o much.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A puff of wind and gone. For her who would not
Do all mankind an injury, and out-act
In horrid deeds all thoe that ere profe'd
Licentious Atheime? unheath your word;
I will not take that life baely away
Which next unto Lucoraes I eteem,
Yet tay.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: He's frantick! withdraw this frenie O ye Gods.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You are my friend?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I have been o accounted by you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Let me conult it out, hall one word.
Na (which is les) one illable (friend extract
Out of me all the interet that I
Have to Lucora, by affecting her:
But this is a afe medium, a true friend
Exceeds all words, and yllables at height;
A man may, nay he hould poize equally
His love, and part unto his friend the jutice of it,
Which is the full half; o that it appears
They hould be lov'd by's as we love our elves.
But to a Mitres who would not give more?
Who can chooe to give more? the love that we
Bear to a friend, it is an accident, a meer one:
But tis our nature to affect a woman,
And 'tis a glory to preerve a Mitres
Entire to ones elf without competit ors.
My reaon's atisfi'd: no friendhip can
Keep in the word of any rival'd man.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Collect your elf Carionil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You'l fight with me?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I do not wear a weapon for uch a Quarrel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What more affliction! yet tis againt manhood,
(A mot ignoble murther) to take his life
Who makes no oppoition. And yet if death
Prevent him not he will be his. Sad fates!
You hall not have Lucora.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You wrong our amity by this upicion:
I wear I will not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Conider (dear Carionil) I grieve
To ee my friend o over-paionate,
It is a weaknes in you to be pittied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My love ore-way'd my reaon: pardon me
My bet Falorus, I believe your vertue
Would not act uch an injury againt
Your own Carionil.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Shall we walk? and I'le tell you all that pa'd
'Twixt me and Polidare.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am a thouand waies obliged yours.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are my Carionil, I wih no more
From you then a perpetuity of love,
And that our hearts may never be unti'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You are too worthy for my friendhip.

lg.l: Fair Antiphila hath hair
Would grace the Paphian Queen to weare;
Fit to tune Heavens Lute withall,
When the Gods for muick call;
Fit to make a vail to hide
Aurora's bluh each morning tide;
Fit to compoe a crafty gin
To take the hearts of lookers in;
Able to make the tubborn kind,
And (who dilike it) t'be judg'd blind:
Though it is oft and fine, it ties
My heart, that it in fetters lies.

sp.p:
It is a great I know not what. I have not Poetry enough in me to give it a name. Thee Lovers
are the prettiet fooles (I think) in the world. And t'were not for them I cannot tell what we women hould do. We deire nothing more then to be praied, and their love to us will do it beyond our wihes. I gave Philander upon his long importunity a lock of hair, and ee into what a vein it has put him! I'me orry he had it not a week ooner, I hould then perhaps a had a Sonnet-book ere this: 'tis pitty wit hould lie obcurely in any, if a lock will give it vent. I love him not; I hood rather chooe his father, who is as earnet a uitor to me as he: yet I know, becaue of his age, very few Ladies wood be of my mind; but as yet I care for neither of them.
Now I mut expect an aault, 'tis in's ear already, he's very fine.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My dear Anniphila, you have receiv'd.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Your veres (Sir?) I have.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I am your true adorer for them Lady.
Wood your white hand had done me the honour it did them!

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: In what Sir you mut explain.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: That a touch of your skin might have ravih'd me into happines.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: The Lock has alter'd your dicoure, I wood it had hut your mouth.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ther's no need of that (excellent Antiphila) I wood rather deprive my elf of my tongue, then that any word of mine hould be offenive unto you

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: You relih too much of the Court.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Polite words can never mibecome a peaker who hath uch a ubject.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Am I your ubject? you have cal'd me Mitres.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You are my Saint Lady, and I mut pray to you.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Saints hear no prayers ome ay.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Pray you hew otherwaies by granting mine.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Have you any more papers?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: My mouth hall peak mine own errand.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: You mut pardon me now Sir, I mut leave you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: She yet is obtinate: but I am free
From doubt he will continue in that way;
There is no caue of fears in womens nayes,
For none of that ex means the thing he aies.
sp.p: Now Tandorix! where's my father?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Faith I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You are one of the melancholiet ervants he keeps.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: It pleaes you to ay o Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: They all report o of you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I cannot tell Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Y'are overlonely: be merrier, you hood put your elf into more companie, you hould Tandorix; I repect you for my mothers ake, for whoe lat ad letter you was entertained here.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I thank you (Sir) for your kindnes.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Farwel Tandorix.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My on perceives my adnes, but the caue
Deerves it fully; tis now above a year
Since I did write that I did drown my elf,
And bare the Paper to my husband, when
I thought his memorie was omewhat lot,
And I inur'd unto this habit, drawn
To't by a fond deire to know if he
Would keep his promie to me, with which oathes
He oft hath made, that never (if he hould
Survive me) he would take another wife;
But he (as other men) eteems no more
Of perjury then common breath; 'twere fit
That husbands vows upon the ands were writ.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I Am beholding to thee Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I will be dutiful to your Worhip.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I hould be glad to cope with your Lady, now methinks I am of a prompter expreion then uual: Lovers and the Mues are cater-couins.
My Vandona, Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: I mut vanih like a mit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Farewell grave Titan.
Ile out with a Poetical Soliloquie in her hearing for my Preludium.
The gaudy Stars are not more full of glee,
When golden Phebus etteth in the Wet;
Nor do the cheerful Birds with more delight
Rejoyce at the new Livery of the pring;
Then I to have this miracle of beauty
Enter within the knowledge of miue eyes.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: He peaks well, I woo'd he meant earnet. The Gentleman eems very deerving: but he is omething wild.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: She hall be toutly accoted. Impudency is a very happy quality in a wooer.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: A comes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
Lady, you are not a puny in the Court of Cupid,
and therefore (I hope) need not the tedious circumtances of an annual ervice. I am bold to tell you plainly, I love you, and (if I find occaion) I will maintain it boldly.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I pray you (Mr. Lorece) deit.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Never my weet Vandona; my decent (I know) you doubt not, and my affection you need not. Whilet I live I hall love you, and (if you die) your memory.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I hall be catch'd. We widows are glas mettal, oon broke.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I can do no more Lady, and I will do no les.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Your habit, carriage, and dicoure, Sir, hew you a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My boldnes he means. Sweetet Vandona, I have been one. The habits, conditions, and ituations of many great kingdoms I have exactly gathered into my table-books: and alo my fortnights obervation of the Antipodes.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: O trange! have you been there? I wonder how you came thither.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I will tell you Lady. When I was bound thither, I was in Aia at Taxcallau; there we took hip, and in a pair of Oares ailed to Madrid, the Catholique Kings Court. From thence to Naples in Savoy, from Naples to Crenia, and thence to Alexandria, where againt a tree we uffered hipwrack. Into a new Phaluk therefore we got us, which was rigg'd for Francfort, where hortly after we arrived, victual'd our Gondalo, and threw
away our freh water.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Tis a great way thither.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thence we went to Lisbon, and after to Mantua, and the next morning we came to the Antipodes, at twy-light i'th afternoon.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What ights aw you there Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: So many ights (dear Lady) that they almot made me blind.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Relate a few.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Firt, Lady, the King is no man.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I believe you Sir, for it never could enter my mind that any man inhabited there.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: There they have no houes, but the Emperours Palace, where Sir Francis Drake was entertain'd, after he had hot the Pyraenaean Gulfe, upon the Mediterranean mount in Ruia.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Where then lies all the Court, I wonder?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: In the Court Mitris.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I gues hem but cold lodgings.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Your Ladyhip is mitook: they are never a cold; For the Sun, being never above a hundred degrees above Saturn, makes that Climate as hot as Norway. They at the Antipodes hear with their noes, mell with their ears, ee by feeling, but tate with all their Senes: for they are the mot inatiable gluttons under the cope: and feel not any thing;
For they cannot be hurt.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: This is wonderful. And I cannot imagine how their enes can be o contrary to ours.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No! did you never hear (excellent Vandona) that they are oppoite to us?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: O yes! I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will now tell you Madam omething of the South Indies.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Has not the Mogul of Peria his bread thence?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The King of Spain hath his gold there, of which the Hollanders took a great prize, when they won the ilver Fleet.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: How I was mitook!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
I will give you the ituation of the Countrey. Some of the ancient Geographers, as Heliodorus, the Knight o'th Sun, Amadis de Guale, and Palmerin de Oliva, affirm it to lie a thouand Italian miles from the Ithmos of Corinth •
but ome modern writers, as Don Quixot, Parimus, Montelion, and Mervin, ay it is a Peninula in Arabia Foelix, where the Phoenix is. But learned Hollinhed affirms, the South Indies are eparated from Armenia by the Calidonean Forret, from Aia Minor by the Venetian Gulfe, and from China by a great brick wall. There intead of Chery-tones children play with Pearls: and (for glas) the windows are of broad Diamonds. Hunters there have no horns but the Unicorns; no water runs there but Scamander, Simois, Aganippe, Hippocrene, and the like. There are no hills but Olympus, Ida, and Parnaus. No valley but Tempe of Acra and Margiana; no men but of the off-pring of Scipio Affrican, Iulius Caear, Alexander the Great, Hector,
Hanibal and Hercules.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: It is a pleaant Countrey ure!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will now tell you the conditions of our neighbour Nations. The Spaniards are humble, the Italians chat, the French peaceful, the Dutch ober, and the Irih cleanly. I came at lat to Virginia, where I aw nothing more worthy mention then an honet woman who cat her elf into the ea becaue no body would lie with her. In concluion; at Iames Town Port I took hore, and the next morning (after a long and tedious journey) arrived in Wales.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And what did you there Mr. Lorece?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: As oon as I could I went to Merlins Cave, which is obcurely ituated on the top of a Beech, where all the night he lay on the ground.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What was he Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: He was an intricate Prognoticator of firmamental Eclipes, and vaticinated future Occurrents by the myterious influences of the ublime Stars, and vagabundical Planets; generated he was by the inhumane conjunction of an Incubus; And was immur'd alive in a cave, by the preeminent Magick of the Lady of the Lake.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: You frequent Playes, do you not?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: They are mot commonly my afternoons employment.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I like him the better for it.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And you have read many Hitories?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Many, Lady. I am a worm in a book, I go through them.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: This pleaes me too
Farewel Sir.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Admired Philoclea, leave me not o.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Your conent Lady.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Expect that a month or two hence.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Dear Vandona, weet Mitres!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Indeed you mut.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Nay, weet Oriana.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Y'are two importunate.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Excellent Claridiana, Polinarda, Taurana, Bradamant.
It makes no matter, I am ure to have her: how ome women are taken with trange tales!
sp.l: Next time we meet I do not doubt to get her,
Hercules could not wooe a Lady better.
sp.p: Now my old Anchies! how dot true penny! Be merry Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Is he tender-hearted?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Repectful and pliant.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Good truth I am glad on't Sir; my Lady (though I ay it) is of a very good nature, my mind alwaies gave me he would be coming on.
I beeech your Worhip to be a good Mater to me.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: Thou halt find me o.

div.head: Scena ecunda.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: IMperious Love (that hatet whom thou woundet, and lovet thoe bet thou dot let alone)
sp.l: If my obequious duty unto thee
Can move thee to commieration,
Intruct me how to win him, and (when I
Dicloe my elf) ait a wretched woman;
For it is in thy power to work my blis.
He dotes upon a Lady that regards
None of thoe mieries he undergoes
By languihing for her, with one fair troke
Thy ignominy redeem: thou art cal'd blind,
Becaue how thou dot hoot thou dot not mind.
But what availes it me thus to implore,
Or rather to reiterate thoe deep wihes,
Millions of houres can witnes I have ay'd,
And yet find no help? Ah my dear, and ever
Mot lov'd Carionil, would thou wert o
Strongly inflam'd as I, or didt conceive,
Truly didt know, what miery lies here!
I think (though thou hadt uckt a ravenous Wolf)
It would overcome thy nature, and thereby
Transform my orrow to felicity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I cannot hope, a letter I have writ
To my Lucora, can find that acceptance,
And bring o good ucces I wih it may:
Sure never man o paionately ado'rd
A Lady of o froward a dipoition;
If I could know the caue he is unkind
I would detroy it, or detroy my elf.
Anclethe! art thou there my boy? alas!
Why dot thou weep?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: To ee the orrow you are alwaies in,
And not to know wherefore. Though I(Sir)am
Both young and little, I both dare, and would
Venter my life to do your any ervice
That may redeem you happy daies again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Alas poor boy! it is pat thy redres;
Yet I do thank thee for thy love unto me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord, a ervant of my Lord Polidacres.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tandorix! what news?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: The Lady Lucora commanded me to deliver this Paper to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Tis mot welcome, would my heart could read it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I wih he had my daughter: for he's a noble gentleman.
My Lord, command you me any ervice?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Onely my dear repects unto the Lady that ent you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Farewel Anclethe.

sp.speaker: Car.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: I am orry that (againt my ue) I cannot anwer you more civilly; but I am blameles: The fault being in your foolih paion, and not my deire. If in fairer terms you hould receive my reply, I am ure you would think it ome beginning of love to you; according to your deire I have none, and I wih your love was o as mine, o we might be friends: yet I love you as a Gentleman of my acquaintance; but if any more you rouble me with letters or courting, I will hate you. So I end,

sp.l: • er own Lucora! I cannot now conceive
This Lady of a humane nature, ure
A woman cannot have o harh a mind,
So I end! what will he end o alwaies?
O then that I might end even now! that all
The orrow that poeeth my whole body
• n every member, would mutiny againt
My heart, that o I might die peedily!
s it not miraculouly trange, that this
• oor microcome, this little body, hould
Contain all the orrow this great world can
nflict upon it, and not ink beneath
o huge a burthen? one hill does overcome
The trugling of Enceladus a Giant,
And yet I tand, I live: what, am I of
Lucora's temper, impregnable? oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Alas my Mater! good my Lord, collect
Your trength, and be not thus effeminate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I'me manly boy: for women cannot tell
What thing affliction is, their tony hearts
Relent o little at it in their lovers.
Oh! I hall never have her! now I give
Liberty to a jut depaire to wrack me:
And it mut ever do o. What a Chaos
Of miery is an unfortunate Lover!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I pray you (Sir) put off this vehemency of paion, he will relent.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Never whil't I live.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: She will indeed, I know he will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Woo'd he would love me after I am dead for her:
It were ome happines to think that, Anclethe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I doubt not but he will hortly be yours (my Lord)
And weep for joy to hear me make relation
Of this ame violent paion you are in now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art a good boy, but this Lady, O my heart!
Could itting down in Caiopeia's chair,
And kicking proud Arctophylax from the skie;
Could topping the Septentrian evenfold teame,
And putting out the tarry Eagles eies;
Could wimming violently up thoe Rocks
From which the Memphian Nilus tumbles down;
Could the compelling of rah Phaetons Sire
To change his coure, and run from north to South
Could the adventuring to undertake
A journey through Affrickes dread't wildernes,
When the Aeolians do loudet breath,
And vale the Sun with andy mountains height;
Enforce her to repent the Tragedy
By thee attempts drawn on me, he hould find
What truth of love was in her ervants mind.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Keep back his hands, O heavens, from violent deeds,
Let him not offer injury againt
His own dear life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have pratled too much: but I ha done.
No longer hall my happines be delaid,
Nor the dipleaed detinies any more
Jeer the ad depth of wretchednes I live in,
Thus—Here I fall her cruel acrifice.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Hold, for heavens ake hold.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis too late to prevent:
Patience Anclethe! commend me to Lucora,
That Angel beauty without Angel pity:
Tell her my wofull tory, how (ere ince
Thou knew't me) I have languihed for her;
That I have pent whole nights in tears and ighes,
What days in olitude to think of her;
That I did uffer her unkindnes, while
I had a dram of patience left within me:
Tell her how her mot cruel letter rais'd
A depair higher then my trength, and that
Under her trange unkindnes I am faln.
Weep not Anclethe! I am faint, truck dumb.
Fly paionate oul into Elizium.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: O my dear Lord, brave young Carionil,
I'le wah thy wound with tears, top it with ighes:
Unkindet day that ever wore the un!
Thou art accurt for giving light unto
His hand to guide it to an act o much
Beneath manhood. O me! I am undone!
What now will my diguie avail me,
Foolih iter Lucora! O ye heavens,
Where lies our difference? are we not the ame
By birth on both ides, of one ex? ure nature
Degenerates againt it elf, or this
Untimely—O ye Gods I dare not name it,
Nor will I believe it; he is alive,
So uddenly the world cannot be ruin'd,
Which is if he be lot; all vertue gone,
All valour, piety, and every thing
Mortality can boat of. My Lord, noble
Carionil! he doth not hear me, alas!
I am for ever mot deolate of women
Injurious heart-trings break, why do you tie
Me to a life millions of degrees more lothome
Then the forgetful epulchre of death?
Would ome commierating benevolent tar
(Which carries fate in't) would in pitty to
My miery, take me from it: for love he
Lies here this bemoaned pectacle; and hall
My paion be undervalued? tears, nor ighes,
Nor Dirges ung by me eternally,
Can parallel our loves at full, 't mut be
The ame way, and it hall; the ame blade
Shall be the intrument, and I receive it
Tragediouly here on my knees; wood ome
Kind body would interr us in one tomb:
Be firm my hand, and bold.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Anclethe!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord Carionil cals, i • t you! then—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: But I mut hold you, and bereave your hand.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And you may alo die, your friend is lain;
My noble Lord Carionil is dead,
The paper in his left hand yet, that brought
His reaon into uch ubjection,
That he even frantickly did tab himelf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I will extend my life till I have read it.
This Lady is a rough blown ea, on which
His worthy life has foully uffer'd hipwrack:
I have her! not Mercury pleading in her defence
With Oratory able to tint Ioves wrath
(When he has bepoke thunderbolts of the Cyclops,
To wreak ome injury) hould ever win me
To her bed. Polidacre, mew her up
Like Danae in a brazen fort, or ele
Make her to anwer with her life this murther
She's acceary to: proud piece of vanity!
I do want words to give my thoughts expreion;
So much I hate her. Prithee Anclethe pardon
My injury againt thy ret, for holding
Thee in a life o loth'd as this is to thee:
Ile lead thee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Withhold awhile my Lord: he groans.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Thou art the caue Lucora, and I mut not
I blame thee:
I truck not that blow right, but this hall do't.
Wam fainter then I gues'd, I have not enter'd.
B hat! who has tole the Stilletto from me?
oy! Anclethe, retore it as thou lovet me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Carionil, I joy you are recovered:
Death is grown courteous, or by this you had
Been wandring in the Elizian groves.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My friend Falorus!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Your loyall friend. Give me your hand and rie:
—I'me glad to ee
Your wound no wore. Twas care and willingnes
To die bereft you of your Senes. I will hew you
How you may win your Mitris—you hear me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I like it we I: it may prevail, I hope
It will.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Anclethe had lain himelf had I not come.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Good boy, thou wert too kind.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord I never hall deire to urvive you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Divulge my death.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I will not fail.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Why (my Carionil) would you engage
So much your elf to any of that ex,
As for a direpondency to lay
Violent hands upon your elf?
Intruth (my friend) I wonder at it jutly
You merit more then they can atisfie
With their endeavours all of them.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Proceed not (good Falorus) in this language.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What good do women! old Amphitrite's face
Is not o full of wrincles, as they are Ofvices.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No more, as you regard (what alwaies yet
You have profet) our long continued friendhip.

lg.l: O women, mot admired Creatures! how
Can the jut heavens thee peeches o allow?
What good do women! I do ay what ill?
Who do perform what men can onely will.
Why have we ears, if not to hear the ound
And acred harmony their tongues compound?
Why have we tears, if not to weep when we
Do chance a woman dicontent to ee?
Why have we eyes, if not to look upon
Their beauties, natures high perfection?
Why have we tongues, if not to praie them, when
They lander'd are by railings of ill men?
Why have we reaon all, if not to deem us
Happy, becaue ome women do eteem us?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are their worthy champion: what I aid
Was out of paion for Lucora's dealing.
I will report y'are dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I hall be obliged unto you by't.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: My clothes are almot made, and every thing
That does belong unto the habit of
A gentleman, I have prepar'd me richly;
For in thee garments I dare not accot her.
I had good fortune to come with Cleanthe,
Who hath been very bountiful unto me.

div.stage: Enter Polidacre, Roinda, Antiphila, Lucora, and Nentis.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Lady, I take it very kindly you
Would do me uch an honour as viit me:
It hall be my tudy to deerve it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: My Lord, this is too ceremonious:
Pray you let us walk.
I much approve of this Aire:
I know no place o weet about the City.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How obervant he is! he would fain make it a match, and I think he is willing enough. But I hall prevent them with amazement.
I will ee further in it firt.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: The heavens (worthy gallants) be erene as long as you preume under the afety of them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Know you this fellow Tandorix?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: His name is Draculemion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O! I have heard of him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Tis ome frantick.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What wind brought you hither?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: That which (noble Sir) hall blow me all over the Univere to do you ervice.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thank you for your complement, your Captainly protetation.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Brave Bevy of gallants, my pure being Millions of degrees voyder of money then my heart of courage, I deire to empty my mouth of words, to fill up the vacuum of it, if you pleae to lend me your attention, and afterwards to commemorate (with munificence) the worth of my Oration.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sweet Antiphila, what ay you?

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: He peaks o trangely I would hear him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Draculemion, you know what to do.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Hail (but fair weather) I that have been the favorite of incontant fortune, and term'd worthily by the worhipfull title of a gentleman, am now deba'd into an humble fugitive. Commierate this wonderful change (mot excellent Auditors) and let your recompence be a help, again to retore me, and a tory to exalt me towards the fatigium of my pritine felicity, and (at your connivence) I will pot afoot to Mexico, drink your healthes till I'me ick, and kill any I hear peak irreverently of you. Thee, and more then thee will I accomplih, though to my perpetual ignominy, or diolution of my life, conditionally you will betow fluently upon your lave o undeerving a little.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Heres for all the company.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Will you give me leave to be grateful?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes urely.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Ile not deire the Mues to repleat
My willing genius with poetick heat:
This ubject doth trancend them: Ile deire
Apollo to this Lay to touch his Lyre.
Thou Charioter of heaven, that dot invet
Thy wift-hoof'd Courers in the dewy Eat
(With harnes work'd by Mulciber) to light
The world, and diipate the clouds of night;
For Phaetons ake (not unto me unlike)
Thy weetet notes unto this ditty trike.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If the Exordium be o long, t'will be tedious before the concluion.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Dimis him therefore.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Farewell Draculemion.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Would I might kis thee before, Nentis.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Madam, how do you like the Lord Falorus?

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: Very well my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Him I have often motion'd to Lucora,
And he hath conented to marry her, would it not
Be a good fortune for her think you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Indeed I think it would.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: How ay you now Lucora?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For he is a much applauded gentleman,
Of good conditions, and of weet behaviour,
Whoe company is every where acceptable;
He deerves a good match, uch a one as your daughter is.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How ay you girle! was any thing I told you
Of Falorus, a falhood? Come prethee do thy elf a good turn,
And take him, do Lucora.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dear Father, pardon me, indeed I have not
Any deire yet to marry.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sure you have! Bethink you, and peak wier.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Truly I have not Sir,

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Y'are a tubborn wench, and I am orry
It was my hard fortune to be thy father:
Your hrewdnes hal not carry you through o freely
(As you believe it will) it hall not maiden.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Do not chide her. She will be rul'd by you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed Madam I had rather live as I do.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: No I believe not that. There is ome one
Or other farre inferiour unto him
Whom he's in love withall, perhaps ome vile
Scumme of the Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Dear Sir, you conceive amis of me; for I
Love no man yet, and hope I never hall
Be of another mind.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Tis fale, I cannot believe you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If ever I hould Id'e hate my elf to place
Affection on a man of bae birth, or
Uneemly qualities.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: Be not angry Sir.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: I pray you marry (Madam) for it is
A tate wherein one may ecurely kis.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Leave thy foolery,

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l:
O tis a fine thing to have a coach of
ones own, to go to a play when you will,
And be retrain'd from nothing you have a deire to do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Marriage is no uch liberty as you make it.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Think of my will: I give you time.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: They have hard fortune (which the Gods remove)
That (where they cannot) are compel'd to love:
I woo'd he had Carionil; I eteem not the ancient Enmity
Between the families.
Now Draculemion, how do you?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: At your beck, and in good health, brave parks of generoity.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I mut needs attend my Lord, otherwie
We would have had one pint together.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: Thou art a joviall Lad. Farewell.
sp.p: O my Nentis! thou art a worthy Andromache, and dot deerve Hector the couragious Trojan Wagg.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: They are not here.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: I mut to my trick agen.
Divine Apollo, and the Mues nine,
Can ye behold his ruine, unto whom
Ye have vouchafed acred Poeie?
Or ee him leep under a hedge i'th field,
Who hath o often on Parnaus lain?
Or eek the River for to quench his thirt,
Who at Boeotian Hippocrene hath
Pledged Mnemoyne in full-fraught Cups?
Or wander bareleg'd, who upon the Stage
Hath acted oftentimes in Sockes and Buskins?
Or ee him tan'd for want of an old Hat,
Whoe Temples (unto his immortal praie)
Ye have o richly view'd begirt with Bayes?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Daculemion! I am glad to find thee: l' • e have a peech.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: Your VVorhip hall.

As yet the contentious night has not exterminated Hyperion from the celetial Globe; who daily ueth to hawke with the firmamental Eagle, and to hunt Ura Major round about the Forret of the skie, to go to plow when he wants Corn with Taurus, and (when he is hungry) to eat Aries, and at night (when he comes 'ith VVet) to court the Lady Virgo to be his bedfellow, whom becaue he cannot obtain, he lahes on his hores, and goes and reports his tubbornnes to his friends at the Antipodes. Nor as yet hath the Trumpeter Boreas blown tormy Clouds into our Horizon to deprive our eyes from the powerful radiance of his orbicular and refulgent head. Nor as yet am I weary to do you ervice, nor will be while I am able.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Here's for you.
sp.l: VVhat a wordy nothing thou hat poken?

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: You have given me current ilver for it.
Y'are a bountiful gallant.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: My father is my Rival, and I find
To him Antiphila is mot inclin'd.
What the Fates will we never can prevent,
And (till the end) we know not their intent.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A Potion he hath took, and is orecome
By the deceitful working of't, and lies
As if he had no interet in this life.
Lucora I have ent for, that we may
See how he'l take it, for by her carriage now
We hall perceive if there be any hope.
What will the Lady deign her preence here?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: She will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Falo.
sp.l: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And is at hand of entring.

sp.speaker: Falo.
sp.l: Prithee Anclethe, bid them bring out my friend.
Though once Carionil did not believe
My protetations to him to relinquih
All title to Lucora, yet I meant it:
Were he a Lady farre more excellent,
And richer in the ornaments of Nature;
Did he exceed the fairet of her Sex
More then fine-featur'd Mars the ugliet Satyre;
Were her tongue Muick, and her words enchanting,
And her conditions gentle like a Goddes.
I'de rather carry Aetna in my breat,
Then be diloyal to my friend, farre rather.
sp.stage: Enter Cleanthe, and Servants putting forth a Bel with Carionil upon it.
sp.l: Thou art mot dutiful, Anclethe;
O Art! Natures mot curious imitatree,
How like a body late depriv'd of life
Does he lie leeping without motion!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord, the Lady Lucora,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Draw back:
But tay you here Anclethe.
I thank you Lady for this favour to us;
Were Carionil alive he would requite it.
He would unto the utmot.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord,
I'me orry that a gentleman reputed ever
Mot wie, and voyced by a general fame
To be complete and perfect in all goodnes,
(The which Carionil was) hould thus detroy
The great opinion all the world had of him:
His depriving himelf of his own life
For that foolih affection he bare me,
(I having often told him that he pent
His ervice barrenly, and that it would
Yield him no fruit) was uch a weaknes in him,
That his lives honour his deathes hame hath ruin'd.
Hither I came at his dying requet,
Which (his Boy told me) was to have me ee
What my obduratenes hath urg'd him to;
For o he term'd it: his deire is atisfi'd:
Were he alive agen I could not love him.
Si • , I hould love him les for the poor weaknes
This act accues him of, I hould, believe me;
And o my Lord I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Had I been his Mitris he had liv'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Stay Lady,
Shew more repect, for truly he deerv'd it.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: But kis his lips, if you will do no more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Boy and all.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: Speaks reaon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: His will I have accomplih'd. Farewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hath he a heart? or if he have, what mettal or tone is it of?
Dot thou not think (Anclethe) that man happy
Who's free from all the moletations
That are concomitants to affection,
And to the grievous bondage of a woman?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord contingently.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thy timeles inexperience doth deceive thee.
Believe me boy, there does not live a woman
Who more then complementally is my Mitris.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, you do not fear to love one of them?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Yes: and the Gods keep me till in that fear.
Sure uch another as Lucora put out Cupids eyes.
O women, women!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Truly my Lord I do believe all Ladies
Are not cruel; indeed I do.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thou art too young to be upected, otherwie
I hould think that ome ubtile fale one had
Beguil'd thy youth. Nature has work'd the Potion out.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord recovers trength.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How it?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: How does my friend?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Repeat my detiny.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Receive it with as calm a quietnes
As I deliver it: your ear!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Vouchafe him patience, O ye Gods.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: When huge-wav'd Rivers from the earths high banks
Precipitate themelves into the Ocean,
Will tilnes follow? Can you think then, can you,
I may be quiet? was Iove o, when the great
Brood of the Earth, the Giants did aay
Olympus conquet? Can I then a poor
Dejected man be calm; when all the miery
The world can end it pours on me fully?
Aeolus, run thy ventrous word again
Into the Rocks, and give an Iue to
The winds, that they may with their irefull blats
Remove the world from off it's tedfat hinge.
Or blow the Pole-Stars out, and o let fall
This Globe we breath on. Or (by whirlwinds force)
Both Sexes collect together, and carry them
In't places oppoite; The one into
The Arctick, the other the Southern Regions,
And let them of themelves propagate the like:
So womens Tyrannies can do no ill,
And men perform what one another will.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: This favours frantickly.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Deprive him not of reaon, but exalt
Him to himelf, O heavens! Ah me!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis true. The ea is alwaies full of water,
(The Lands do relieve it) and yet has no caue
For lamentation, but wofull man
Hath but a few, indeed a very few
Salt tears to mollifie the burthenous draught
Of miery which his malignant Stars
Compell him to endure.
What? his Mitris venome obtinacy? not poible,
Tis unufferable, above our frail carriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: The word friend, waies all titles of honour down,
And therefore not by them, but that I beeech you
Not to neglect your elf. I've lately known
The time when death almot inevitable
Could not unfix your thoughts. This caue is weaker.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Believe me friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Believe you! I would believe thee friend,
Didt thou affirm aburdet contraries:
That the Sun was extinguihed, and the bright
Moon was blown out, and all the Stars were faln,
And nature (yet harmonious) diordered
Into another Chaos, I would believe you:
For rather then you hould pronounce a falhood,
Things that are not would be.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Alas! you are ditempered;
I grieve to ee you o for o poor a caue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: It is a weighty one, and if the brave
Fam'd off-pring of Alcmena had endur'd it,
He had enlarg'd his labours to thirteen,
And been another wonder to the world.
But (noblet friend) you know the Hitory,
How he the knotty club did lay aide,
Put off the rough Nemaean skin, and don'd
Maidens apparrel, for the love he bore
To ruin'd Picus daughter, young Iole.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: But he nere offer'd violence to himelf.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: He did not Sir, be counel'd by your friend,
Do my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He had not caue, he did return him love;
And (except in this cae) I would uffer
Beyond expreion from another hand,
Without a thought to ue my own. But you
May ay I'me paionate: tis right, I am o
I know't, and you cannot expect les from me.
Were I as free from love as you have known me.
You hould not taxe me with that fault, although
Untable fortune made an Irus of me:
But you may call this boating.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Far be it from me, tis a perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Ah, Alas!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Leave ighing boy prethee.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come,
You hall be temperate again (my friend)
And have fair likelyhood to obtain your Lady.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Impoible!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I've form'd the plot already, you mut be, draw near.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: How a Negro, an Ethiopian! t'is frivolous.
She is too obdurate, mot obtinate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hath he not refued the bravet and handomet gentlemen of this kingdome?
You cannot deny it. Be therefore counelled,
She that cannot love a man of a better complexion,
On one of them may ettle her affection.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have ome hope again, you hall tay with my friend, refue it not I prethee.
For many conveniences it is neceary; I every day hall ee thee, and hortly will take thee agen.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord, I beeech you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nay, my Anclethe let me not ue words,
As thou dot love me deny me not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, I am charm'd, and will obey you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Come, lets walk, and I'le intruct you fully.

sp.p:
THis London wine is a parlous liquor; twill turn you a mans head o long round, that at lat 'twill et it where his heeles hould be: another
glas ont had prov'd me a reeler, a cotqueane, which I was never brought up to; I learnt a ong of my old gra • am, many a good ballad he would have ung me by the fire ide ore a black pot, but your city wine is a more tinging liquor. She left me a very fair cow, but a villanous thief tole me her, (foul cheeve him for it) and ecap'd I know not whither: but alls won, much good do him with it, my Ladies Worhips ervice is better then a team of oxen. But the ong mut not be forgot.

lg.l: All that about me it,
Laugh at my pleaant wit,
And neither cough nor pit,
Till I have done a.
For I will ing a ong,
That fitly hall be long,
To a cow and not wrong
Mount Helicona.
Don Quixots Roinant,
And Sancho's ae errant,
And Bankes his hore do want
What he may brag of.
They would ones breech much gall,
And give one many a fall,
Sufficient therewithal
To break ones crag off.
That Jove did love a teed,
I yet did never reed;
But by all tis agreed
Io he loved.
No beat upon the field,
Doth man more profit yield,
Whither alive or kild,
As may be proved.

sp.p: Well, I'le to my chamber and leep awhile, otherwie I't ha a foule deal of do to keep me on my legs this afternoon,
Iaques is now a very Barnabey!

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: His ma • ch is extraordinary, ure the rogue's drunk,
He's o very deaf—

The report is that Doctor Aritotle cat himelf into the ea, becaue he could not (with all his rambling Philoophy) find out the natural caue of the ebbing and flowing of it: but (had his good cholarhip been troubled with my Mitris) he might a jolted out his brains againt a rock, for his dulnes in inventing a method of wooing to win her Ladihip withal. I here will it and mue.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Indeed Madam I will be very erviceable unto
you, if now and then you will uffer me to be blith and full of merry moods.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Iaques! where ha you been?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: At the pigget. Is it not a very rainy wet day?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Thou art well wahed within.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Tis a very dark day: the un hines clear tho.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: T'hat a light head Iaques.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And yet I cannot bear't tedfat on my houlders, wine's montrous trong.
Let me ee who am I?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Th'art a fool.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: The play's the better for't.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Y'are a drunken coxcomb, go.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Thou captive Greek, I am a Beglerbeg.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Thou woot be a beggar and thou leav't not thy drinking.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Thou me Roxalana! am not I the great Sultan?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: A booby.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You hew your breeding to upbraid the Majety of the Grand Signior.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Peace, no more fooling.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You are drunk with north countrey Balderdah, you keep no wine, water your kitlings with beer, nothing but wine hall be drunk in my court.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I hall be troubled with him ele. Embaadors wait your return at your Palace.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: We will withdraw: end the Bahaes after me, they hall preent me wine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Is he here?
I hall be courted certainly, and perhaps hall yield.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.l: Mot welcome happiet Genius of my life,
Dearet Vandona, let your lilly hand
Enrich my lips.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Y'are very complemental, ervant.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.l: Mitris, faith I love you, as for millions of caues,
So alo for a natural demeanour,
It howes you are no of-pring of the City.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: You would marry none, ervant?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: No, ix thouand pounds cannot hide a quint eye, a crooked back, or a red head, or a muddy face, though they may gild them.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: This is very Satyrical, but there be Beauties of all coloured hair, eies, and complexions.

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: I at any time will carry you to a Play, either to the Black Friers or Cockpit. And you hall go to the Exchange when you will, and have as much money as you pleae to lay out, you hall find me a very loving husband in troth dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: But ervant, you have been a very deboit gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Forget what y'ave heard, and you hall hear no more on't. But we are extravagant, come, let's to'th joyner.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: To whom, and for what Mr. Lorece?

sp.speaker: Lore.
sp.p: To Hymen in his affron coat, to be married.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Some other time, a month hence will erve.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Then mut I court another bout.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What you pleae Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O Cupid the Bow-man,
I am not thy foe man;
For I love this woman,
As well as I know man.
And therefore I pray thee,
From michief to tay me;
And quickly to lay me
In bed with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What call you this Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Tis my imploration, and ode.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Y'are very fluent Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: And yet neglected. But Ile make Cornelius Gallus peak Englih, and he hall wooe for me.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: What ay you ervant?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Be you attentive, and you hall hear.
My weet Vandona, fine and comely las,
(Whoe beauty Milk and Lillies doth urpas,
And the weet Roes, both t •• white and red,
Or Indian Ivory new polihed)
O pread, O pread abroad thy yellow hair,
Like glorious gold, hining all out as fair:
Thy puret Alablater neck, and how's
VVhich (from between thy graceful houlders)
Open thy Starry eyes, and let us view (growes;
Their browes above them of a Sable hew:
And both thy Roeal cheeks let us epie
Beautified with a natural Tyrian die.
Put forth thy lips, their Corral let us ee,
And (Dovelike) gentle kies give to me.
Of amorous life my breath did draw out part:
Thoe kies peirc'd meto the very heart.
Why didt thou uck my blood (O cruel he?)
Henceforth thy dugges (like Apples) hide from me,
Which with Ambroiack cream hall well thy breat,
Dicloeth Cynamon I yield, and bet
Delights arie from thee: yet thy Paps cover,
Whoe growth, and beauty, do make me a lover:
For eet thou not, that languihing I lye?
A man half dead how cant thou thus detroy!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: This is meer flattery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Tis but a park (Madam) an almot inviible atome of truth, which can carce be dicern'd in the Sun-hine of your perfections, credit me Madam

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: They are mot childih will believe all that their ervants ay, my mot poetical Servant.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Mot obdurate Lady.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Will you wrangle?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Was ever Widow o hard to win? Sure your husband got not your maidenhead you are o backward.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Adieu Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not yet I pray you weetet Lady, if—

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Pray you trouble me with no more peeches.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O cruel reply to a Lovers uit!
If ever you have felt this paions pain,
If ever you would pitied be your elf,
Or if you know that Love hath power to kill;
For all thee (which you heretofore have been
Subject unto) commierate a heart
So full of love for you that it will break.
If you deny:
But if you will remain inexorable,
And frown on him who ay mut fawn on you,
I wih my fortune may be yours, and that
If ere you love you may be erved o.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: I'm but a woman, and thee words would move
A tupid rock to pitty, Sir I can
Reit no more, your tongue has magick in't:
You have overcome me, and enjoy your conquet.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My dear widow, let me kis thee for this! thy dare of wearing black is almot out. O my joy! methinks I could out-ing old Homer, the nine Mues, and put their Patron Apollo our of fame.
sp.stage: Enter Falorus, Ceanthe and Phyginois in brave apparel.
sp.p: My Vandona, yonder is my brother, he will be glad to hear of my good fortune.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Who's he?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: A friend of mine (my Lord)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I hall be deirous (Sir) both for your own, and for Anclethes ake, to be better acquainted with you.
May I demand your name?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Your ervant is cal'd Phyginois.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How have you ped brother?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: She will be cal'd your iter: alute her, go kis her for't.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Lady, I hope my brother will deerve you,
By proving an affectionate husband to you.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Madam, I am a tranger, but will endeavour to make my elf known unto you by any ervice I can do you.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: My Nentis doth excel her iter

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Come brother, will you go with us?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile wait upon your Mitres.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My faithful friend, may all thy wihes proper,
And a fair end crown them mot happily.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: Sweetet of Ladies!

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.p: Thou didt prefer goodnes before the raiing of thy houe.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: It grieved me to think o noble a Lady hould be o poorely dipos'd of;
My brothers birth, nor forunes could deerve you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I was ignorant, and might have undone my elf.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: I did pitty you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: And ever have oblig'd me to you for't.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.p: If your iters woman Mitres Nentis be obtinate, and you proper;
Hereafter you may do me a multitude of favours.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I nere will fail to do the bet I can; now let us follow them.
sp.l: Love is a paion not to be withtood;
And (until hearts be mutual) never good.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Carionil olus like a Negro, in trange apparel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: AN houres life is like the various year,
Which hardly bears one form a fortnights pace:
He ure deerves repect that to obtain
His Mitres, thinks all trouble a content.
Thee two years have not had o many quarters
As I diguies, carce as many daies
As I devies, and yet to no purpoe:
What I may do in this I cannot gues;
But for mine own purpoe mut hope the bet.
My late long reidence ith Spanih Court, when I lay there Leiger Embaador,
Hath made me peak the Catilian language perfectly;
Which will be my great furtherance, becaue
Polidacre affects that tongue exceedingly;
And I know will gladly give me a free acces
Unto his houe at all times.

l.hi: Porque de mi, Lucora haze un Negro.

sp.l: They hall not ee me yet.
sp.p:
Sir, your daily importunities have o mov'd me that I mut yield unwillingly, onely I requet to have
our marriage defer'd a month dear Sir, do not deny me this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I thank thee girle.
Welcome Falorus: my daughter's yours after four weeks be pat.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Worthy Sir, y'are too bountiful. Mot excellent Lady, you will make my fortune envied. I mut diemble yet, for I will not wrong Carionil.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: I like this well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But I will rather die then have him

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I do not doubt my friend.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I have laboured much for you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now I'le dicloe my elf, and counterfeit the Negro as well as I can.

lg.head: Taken forth of Acaucana.
lg.l: Y pues en todos triempos, y occaiones
Por la caua comun in cargo alguno,
En battallas formadas, y equadrones
Puede uar delas armas cadauno:
Por las mimas ligitimas razones
E's licito combate de uno a uno,
A pie, a cavallo, armado, diarmado
Oraea campo, abieto, or a etocado.

sp.l: Don Carionil, would I could hear of thee!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is the brav't proportion'd African I ever aw.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I will peak to him.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes Sir I learnt your language at Bruels.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I hall be mot glad (Sir) to be acquainted wi • you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Grave Nelides years be doubled (mot honourable Hero upon you; your courteie has won one of the greatet Ethiopian Lords to become your ervant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What an unequal'd carriage he is of!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You look, Sir, like a noble Gentleman, I alute you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, Don Carionil mait thou proper, your Mitres has conented a month hence to marry me, but doubt me not my friend.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: According to the Ethiopian cutome,
Great Lady, I adore your pantofle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You are a worthy, and a noble Moor.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This is your hadow; you hall command me fair one.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I heard you mention Carionil.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis true,
When we were in the Spanih Court together,
I being commanded thither an Ambaador
From th' Emperor of both the Ethiopias
And of the mighty kingdoms and vat countries
Of Goa, Caffares, Fatigar, Angote, Xoa,
Barne, Balignazo, Adea, Vangue and Goyamine,
He wrong'd me, and I am come hither to eek him;
And with my word to punih his rude language.
If you will tel me (Sir) where I may find him,
You hall eternally oblige me to you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He is lately dead Sir.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You do but jet.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I was with him when he died.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then he had not o honourable an end as I intended him.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: If I hould not eem too inquiitive, I would deire to know your quarrel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am much taken with this object

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You may command me any thing.
We meeting in the preence one afternoon
('Mongt many things) did happen to dicoure
Of Ladies; he aid that none of all the world
Were o beautiful as the Spanih:
I that had read in many hitories
The Englih have the bet and loveliet faces,
Did tell him o, yet could not change his mind;
After long altercations he grew hot,
sp.p: Gave me the lie reprochfully; which forced me to tell him, that though I owd o much honour to both the Majeties of our great maters, as not for private wrongs to diturb our Embaies: I meant before I died to viit his countrey, and call him there unto a trict account.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I thank you for your free relation;
While you intend to tay in England, ue
My houe at your pleaure, I pray you do,
Your company will be alwaies welcome to me;
And I love the Catilian language, which
You peak both readily and purely:
May I demand your name?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Tis Tucapelo, and I'me ubject to
Great Pretor Iohn (whoe powerful Scepter awes
Sixty two Kings) and in Garama live
Magnificent for ilken palaces.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: His behaviour is without upicion

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Tis dinner time or nigh, pray you be my guet; You hall be very welcome (Sir) both now and at all times.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'le wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Falorus, let me intreat your tay.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You hall command me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Injurious tyrant Love! Nentis!

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Stay a little.
How frail is any womans reolution!
I that o eriouly have often thought
Never to change my name, am now become
A lave unto a Moore; I feel the mighty
Fabrick of all maiden vertue totter.
What may befall me wore? but I may as well
Withtand a volley of hot, and as eaily,
As reit thee new deires: tis very trange
That I who have denied the earnet uit
Of o complete a Gentleman as was
Carionil, and neglected his friend,
(For I will rather teale away, and do
Mean ervices to my inferiors,
Then be his wife) hould dote upon a peron
Some Ladies carce dare look upon, a Moor,
A un-burnt Moor I'me • tter tranger to.
What would my father ay if he hould know
My thoughts? banih me ever from his ight,
And never more think of Lucora's name.
But Love is not confin'd to the opinion
Of others. O this is a revenge for my
Slighting of brave Carionil; yet if
He were alive again I could not love him.
Alas I am undone! O that my Fates
Had been o kind as to have wrought my heart
Fit and propene to have requited him?
Nentis, will you be ilent of my love?
Be o good Nentis.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Why, Madam, will you have this Blackamoor? me thinks my Lord Falorus is a handomer man by much. Alas! he will take you beyond ea.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nothing is trong enough to divert me.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Your ecrets (Madam) are as afe in my breat as yours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Befal what will, I am reolv'd.
Affection that doth tend
Not crookedly, but to a noble end,
Is worthy; and they tubbornly repine
At their creation who from it decline.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: SWeetet Antiphila!

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.p: I wonder Sir, in what I have o forfeited my faith that I cannot be credited.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Urge me not, Lady, unto a belief,
That will be my detruction:
Delay me rather with a little hope,
And ave me from depair.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I can but ay what I have aid already.
You do not trut my tongue; Pray take a parchment,
And there incribe a ad and olemn Oath;
And I'le ubcribe that I will never have you.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: The fatal Ravens hoare crying
Is Thracian Muick unto your reply.
Would I had heard a thouand Mandrakes groan,
So you had left me in ilence.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I pity you, but did you know me truly, you would bles my denial (young Philander.)

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Bles it! O Lady,
Durt I but be o horribly prophane
As to cure any thing you pleae to do,
I would go tudy imprecations, and
Vent them in places that are haunted by
Wild walking devils; but my grand affection
Condemns that violence. Do not then uppoe
That thongh you were a Suc • ubus, I durt
Utter uch impious breath. Be all the faults
(That either truth or Poets fictions
Have hewn in women) in you, I will love you
With erious admiration.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I will releae your affection.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Impoible.
• ot the fairet creature (by diligent earch pick'd out
Of all the infinite Myriades of beauties,
Selected from the pacious kingdoms of
The Earth, and I might chue her freely)
Should win upon my heart to dipoes you;
She hould not Lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You will not hear me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then may eternal deafnes eize upon me:
Speak Lady, and though you do ay the lat
Word I hall ever hear, I will with joy
Be mot attentive. The dark cave of leep
Is not more quiet.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I am contracted.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You are not Lady.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Unto my father?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Then entence his ure death by naming him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Will you detroy the man I love?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: And you him that loves you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What is done cannot be undone

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It hall

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You mut not know his name therefore.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: If there be any manhood in his breat,
He hall dipoe himelf: Ile challenge him
By uch ure circumtances (and et the papers
On publick places by the Play-Bills) that if
He dares but ue a word he will be known.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: So you will publih my digrace.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Too true, O Lady, dear Antiphila,
Give me his name. I will not kill him foully,
We will meet fairly: I may die upon
His word, and you thereby be freed from my
Unworthy uit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, promie me one thing, and I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here is my hand, you hall charm me.

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I mut lye, and groly, to be rid of his Courthip.
sp.p: It is Tandorix. You mut not peak it unto any, or quarrell about it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Tis not: you mock me (weet Antiphila.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed Philander I do not.
You will be ecret for my ake, untill
I do releae you of your promie.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Y'ave had my hand: ilence mut be my death.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Ile leave you Sir, and build upon your word,
For I perceive you are dipleaed.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: This tis to be a fool: which is the truet,
And briefet definition of a Lover.
What fury facinated o my ences,
As wilfully to make me become a lave
Unto the childih paions of a woman?
On this occaion wood I undertood
The addet Epithets of Necromancy,
That I might joyn them to this ex: O my heart!
I am orecome with rage, and will be rather
A perjur'd Mahumetan, and wade
Through treams of blood into her arms, then a
Soft-concience'd as, and let this villain have her:
Could envious hell uppoe a body of
So delicate a compoition, cood
Within it lodge a mind o poor and worthles?
This is a womans weaknes no, tis a baenes
Cannot be match'd in all the faults of man.
But why am I o angry? I will hew
My fury, not in idle breath but deeds.
And this hall be the time; thou bae ambitious
Slave, before we part thou diet.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: O good Sir, why? I nere offended you,
Heaven knows I love you bet of all the world,

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Thou art the hinderance of all the blis
I could expect or wih for upon earth.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Sir, let me hear the reaon of your rage,
And (if you find that I have injur'd you)
I will not beg for life.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Find it! I know it clearly,
And will not honour thee, vile man, o much
As't let my tongue joyn uch unequal names.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I undertand you not: Dear Sir, be plain.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Art thou prepar'd to die? if not, kneel here,
And pray thy elf into a readines.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: Be not o violent.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Repent.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Let me undertand my offence; the chryome child
Is not more innocent of wrongs to you,
Then guiltles I.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: The tears of Crocodiles!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I humbly do upon my knees implore you
That you thus rahly will not take away
The life you never can retore, and will
Bewaile for in an overlate repentance.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: To heaven, and not to me make orizons.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I am reolv'd.
For your deceaed mothers ake (at whoe
Sad funeral letter I was entertaind
Into your fathers family) and for
Thoe tears and ighes, and orrows he did weep,
Groan, and expres at her delivery of you,
Be merciful unto a faultles tranger.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: A tedious and an exquiite torture for
Thy death hould not deter me from it. My mother
(Could he arie out of her watry grave,
Appear in both our views, and be an eloquent
Suppliant unto me for thy life) hould not
Prevail to win me to it.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Then nothing will atisfie, keep in your word;
I am your mother, draw off this Perriwig,
And my face will etablih your belief.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: It does indeed; here protrate on my knees
For my rude language I do crave remiion.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: And you obtain it and my bleing too;
But you deerve blame for your violent fury.
O let me kis your gracious hand, and eal
My pardon on your happy lips.
Why did you grieve us for the ad report
Of your untimely end?

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: You hall know all anon. But yet conceal
My being, till your fathers love be ripe,
And grown mature for a econd marriage;
I pray you do.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Mother, I will.
Now I've good hope Antiphila will be mine.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And Lady you hall not wih any thing
(If that an humane power can obtain it)
But I will make it yours. I hope you do
Not wrong my love with a upicion
That I cannot perform what ere I promie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do not, Sir, ditrut your affection:
But give me leave to doubt I hall not live
According to my content in Aethiopia.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mot noble Lady, I that have een both places,
Dare promie you, you will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I cannot tell Sir, I mut believe you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: For thee few words (whoe weetnes doth exceed
Vat and elaborate volumes of eloquence)
May all the joyes that ever have made happy
The numerous Queens and Emprees that have
Been ornaments and glories to the world,
Meet unto their perfection in you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Tucapelo! when I did ee you firt,
I fell in Love as deep as Lady could.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: And may I dye when (in unperfect thoughts)
You do repent your choice: Mitris, I can
Make famous Gamara as pleaing to you
As is your native Countrey: You hall find
Delights above, not equal to your mind.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, your company hall be all things unto me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You hall not touch one drop of water, but hall
Be of more virtue then the Thepian pring,
Where reverent Poets of the former times
Quaft off huge bowls to great Apollo's health.
Young virgins (whoe weet voyces do exceed
Mnemoyne's daughters) hall ing you a leep
Each night, and (when you grace the happy woods
With your rich preence) they hall make a conort
With the innocuous queriters of the pring,
To entertain the Mitris of my life.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: And I go thither they hall teach me to ing—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Jewel-tippets of your ears hall weigh
The curious points of precious Iicles,
When Leo breathes hot vapours on the earth.
Your edulous laves (enrich'd by noble bloud)
Shall bear your Litter through the tedious treets
Of Gamara, while all the gallant youth
Within it runs to wonder at your beauty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I do believe you love me o much Sir,
That you will hew it all the wayes you can:
And I do thank you for it, and love you,
And I will hew it all the wayes I can.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O happiet peech my ears did ever hear!—
Amphions muick made not uch a ound;
Nor Orpheus Lute that tam'd the tubborn pleen
Of hells inhumane dogge, when he did play
For the redemption of his ravih'd poue;
Nor Phoebus (when unto his gold-trung Lyre
He for uperiority did ing
His weetet Anthems and bet Madrigals
Againt ambitious Pan) made harmony
To parallel the weetnes of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If that all my endevours can deerve
At this height your affection, by my fault
It never hall decreae.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You over-act me much, but never hall
Have thoughts beyond me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I pray you pare my company a while;
A while I would be private with my woman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Lady, I will do things unwillingly
At your command: but give me leiure (fairet)
To print my heart upon your heavenly lips,
Ere my departure hence—The Ottoman Emperours
In their immene Seraglio never aw
Your matchles features in their numberles
Succeive multitudes. I am o blet,
That my exceive joyes cannot be guet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nentis!

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Unfold thy heart unto me: Let me know
What thoughts thou hat of me.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: I may offend.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed thou halt not.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Then I do wonder (Madam) that you will
Betow your elf (I think) unworthily.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: This is unpleaing to you, I will be
Hereafter ilent: I have offended you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: No: proceed.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: You are a Lady untill now untain'd
With any blot (ave obtinacy to
The brave deceas'd Carionil) and will you
Give the world reaon, a good one (pardon
My honet boldnes (Madam) to taxe your judgement;
And (which is wore) your virtue for this choice?
Is not Falorus far more worthy of you?
Marry him (Madam) and live till in England.
I'me ure my counel would be econded
By all the friends you have, did they but know
As much as I. But (Madam) if you have
Settled your affection pat recall, and are
Reolved, I will be mot obedient
And ecret unto all your purpoes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And wilt thou go to Aethiopia with me?

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: If I do get no Servant before, and if
You will (if I dilike the country) give
Me liberty to return home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mot willingly.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: My Lord Falorus.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: If I can find the leat opportunity
I will try (Nentis) of what mettal th'art made.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I hope (Mitris) our company
Is not unwelcome to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: By no means Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: How gently it pat her tongue!
For that weet word I kis your hand, dear Lady.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Where did you leave my father my Lord?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Above a reading Guicciardin.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Sir, I can perceive when I am flatter'd.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: Earnet expreions of love deerve a better name.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: Why Sir, I cannot believe you love me.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: You need not doubt of that, Mitris, I do
With as much fervency as ervant can;
I do beeech you Lady to believe me.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: They are of eaie faiths that believe all their ervants ay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What ail you my Lord? you are not well.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Unwelcome guet away—I was thinking of—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I ha forgot—would they would all love me—
I am mot trangely alter'd on the udden:
My friendhip (I fear) will be too weak a tye
To make me ilent.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Thou hadt a Mater did deerve thee better.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But he is dead, and I am yours by his
Lat Legacy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What wouldt thou ay?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I hope y'are well.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: He has found out an alteration in me:
I mut beware of publick igns. I was Privately
Full of Carionil; my thoughts were buie
Concerning him:
Madam, I pray you pardon my neglect
Of frequents viits; I have been too guilty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You have not offended.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Tis your great goodnes to ay o.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: This, Sir, is too importunate.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: To lack (dear Mitris) but wink at my inufficiency.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.l: You aid, you love no woman in the world
But me.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: And may you hate me if I do.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: As I ee you ready to give me full atisfaction that you mean faithfully, o hall you find me willing to requite you.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: No man can boat uch happines.

sp.speaker: Nent.
sp.p: Sir, be moderate; y'are not o ure of me, but (upon occaion) I can retire; neither would I have the company take notice of us.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.l: You hall command me (Mitris)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thee paions are new to me: woo'd I were private.
I never did oberve her o well before.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What ay you (Madam?)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You aw not my brother Philander to day?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No truly Lady I did not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Your brother (Nentis aies) hall hortly be married to
The rich widow her iter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: So he doth hope.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: Madam, dinner tayes of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You hear my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Nay Anclethe, tay not for me, wait on the Lady: Ile follow immediately.
sp.l: What ailes me? let me ee
What is the caue of uch an alteration
I find within me: doubtles it is Love.
To whom? to whom but to the worthiet
And weetet Lucora? Take heed, tis dangerous
A udden ruine o will eie my friendhip,
And prove my former protetations
Feign'd untruths. Cannot the noble name
Of young Carionil prevent me? No,
Nor certainty of all the evil wills
Of all the friends I have;
Were both our better Genius Orators,
And here embraced fat my knees, and wept
Miraculous tears (to quench the riing flames
Lucora's irreitible eyes have kindled
In me, or to drown this late impresion Love
Hath eald upon my heart) I'de be as remoreles
As the mot tern and unremoved Scythian,
And deafer then the people that inhabit
Near the Egyptian Cataracts of Nile.
But I am bae, bae to infringe the knot
Of amity a long and erious knowledge
Of each other hath tyed betwixt us. Twere afer
Sayling with drunken Mariners between
Hard Sylla and Charybdis, then to uffer
My much divided thoughts, and forth of them
To work uch a concluion to my pasions,
As might hereafter confirm me noble in
Th' opinion of the world: but I'me mot ignorant,
And know not what to do. Wood I were o
Ditraught, that my own elf I could not know.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Sweet Mitris, your bounty will become
An envy unto future times.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: So let your love Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But peak (my Dear) what happy day hall give
A fair concluion unto all my wihes?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: What hate good ervant?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay be not angry Sweet.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Madam (and pleae you) your own good ervants deire to hew your Worhips ome pretty patime.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: It pleaes us well: when begins it?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Eene preently; Ile goe and tell them all what a good woman you are.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is not uual with you?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Indeed Servant o eldom, that I remember not the like:
Sure tis for your entertainment; they think I have
Been a niggard of it, and help to make it out.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are too good.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: So you can never be.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And yet I will not fail to do my bet.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I pray you do not (dear Lorece) for tis a good reolution.

p.U: ee we hall have ome odde thing.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I wih Sir it may prove worthy your laughter.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: My fair Vandona, I believe you will have your deire.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Iaques is among them: he may move you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.

l.hi: An'ether of you ask what's here, tis a Mask
Which we Actors do hope will content you:
If not, when it ends let us all part friends,
And of your attention go in and repent you.

sp.p: I hope your Worhips will ay I have pronounc'd this well enough.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To my content honet Iaques.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: I'me glad you like it.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Come Hymen, thou fellow that always wear't yellow,
Draw near in thy Frock of Saffron;
Once more I ay appear before this gentleman here,
And this Lady in the white apron.
If the boy thou dot bring hath a voice fit to ing,
Lets have a merry new Ballet:
Begin thou the Song, and it will not be long
(We hope) before he will follow't.

sp.speaker: Hymen.
sp.l: Say, Boy, who are fit to be
Ioyn'd into an unity?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: They that will permit their wives
To live pleaant quiet lives,
And will never entertain
Thoughts of jealouie, if vain.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Now Boy let this couple hear
What hould be the womans care.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A wife hould be ecret, true,
Mot obedient, and no hrew;
Should obey her husbands will,
While therein he finds no ill.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Such a Wife and husband too
We do wih both him and you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Prithee Sweet lets be married this afternoon, and this hall be our Epithalamion.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Stay my leiure good ervant: t'will not belong.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Now if you pleae to cat a glance Hither, ye hall ee us dance:
