sp.l: Fidlers play, begin and trike: What ye ee do not dilike.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: What a mad toy tis Mitris!

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Iaques! this day ue my wine-cellar, you and your company
May be as free in it as you will.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Her Ladyhip ayes well: Good now ho lets go thither,
Without more ado.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Goodman Wedlock, where was your mind marle? Is there not a piece behind yet? Ile not budge a foot till I have dicharg'd it.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.p: Out with it then.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Mr. Marriage, put me not out with your grining: for an you do all's poil'd.

lg.l: Gentleman and Madam, you have een
What our Mask and performance hath been:
If you like both tis well; and if but one,
Of the other wood we had done none.
For clapping of hands we care not two chips;
We are atisfied if you joyn your lips.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I thank you all.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: And o do I: you now may go.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: And o we mut, for I ha done. All's done: this lat (what do you call,) was the full end of it.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.p: Why go we not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am very dry with inging and dancing.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Follow me to the wine-cellar.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: You mut keep your promie: you are expected by this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Lady, I ki •• your hand: This is my vale as often as I come.
Ile eal my welcome on your lips. Farewell widow.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Remember my ervice to your brother.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The tedious winter of my many griefs
Her calmer heavenly breath hath now blown over;
And all my tears and ighes are now converted
Into a happines will oon be perfect.
The gallant Courtier Paris Alexander
(When he had tole the young Atrides Bride,
The iter of the two Tindarides,
And with great triumphs entred into Troy)
Was ad and melancholy unto me.
How wie the Fates are! Ere we can obtain
Perfect frnition of the thing we love,
We mut break through great difficulties & tedious,
Unto the end that we may more eteem
And prize our happines when we atchieve it.
Thanks (excellent Lady) for your gracious promie:
May every Lover henceforth bles your tongue.
• he hath prefix'd this hour to be the time
Wherein I hall out-grow all hope, and fix
Upon the proudet height of fortunes wheel.
Hail happy hour! This is her chamber window,
And this the door whereby he mut ecape.
Shine well ye tars, and let this project find
Your influences to a lover kind.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: See Madam, he is come: My Lord Tucapelo has not trepas'd on a minute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then is our parting near: your new ervant hath prevented your journey.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nentis!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Mot honoured Tucapelo, I am here
In preence to give anwer to my Love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Are you ready worthiet Lady?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am, my Love.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Neglect your Jewels: Gamara hall upply you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I care for nothing if I have but you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Decend (my Dear) each minute is an age
Until I crown my joyes with your poeion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I come. Nentis farewell: report that my
Ecape was uuto thee unknown, and that
I tole away when thou wat fat aleep:
I would not have thee blam'd for me. Excue
Me to my father all the wayes I have
Intructed thee in.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Cinthia, triumph; and let thy brother hear
His eyes did never witnes uch a tealth:
Be proud in thy pale lutre, and make known,
Apollo doth tell tales, but thou relt none.
Not yet! how tedious eems a moment!
Delayes in Love
Would raie impatience in Olympick Iove.
But he is entred! welcome weet Lucora,
Above expresion welcome, my crown of joy
I would not change for an imperial Scepter.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am mot happy in your love (dear friend)
sp.p: Thanks good Nentis: My woman cannot go with's.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Then farewell Nentis.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: May the propitious heavens crown both your heads with all fair fortune.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Our thanks go with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is your promie, Sir, that I hall live
Without contradiction in my Religion,
Enjoy my concience freely: your vow was olemn.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do acknowledge it, and will perform it.
sp.p: —True—not to be denied, what a great frot chils my affection!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then Ile be confident.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You may:
I am amaz'd, and lot within a wonder.
Let me conider; have I caue to love
A Lady that hath o much neglected me,
That he hath prefer'd a Negro? And tis likely
(When he knowes me) will care as little for me
As ere he did, and (if he meets with one
Of this complexion I feign) conferre
Her perfect love upon the lave? Tis clear,
I have no reaon to do it, neither will I;
For I am free, know liberty again:
This poor unworthines in her hath loos'd me.
Would it not be a weaknes in me (let me argue it)
To betow my elf upon a woman of
So obtinate a nature, that he lov'd me les
When he believ'd that for her ake I had
Done violence upon my elf? It would be
A matchles one, beyond example, and which
Future times would admire, but not parallel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come, hall we hence? delay is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No; be it what it will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: VVe mut not tay here long.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Nor will we.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Alas! what ailes my noble Tucapelo?
You had not wont to anwer me o lightly.
Do you not love me till?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The heavens forbid! I am Lucora.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do confes you are, but mut deny
I love you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I could endure your Sword with better eae:
Us't, and revenge what ignorant ill I have
Committed againt you. I had rather dye
By your dear hand, then to return from hence
With this trong poyon in my breat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Kill you!
Lady, I would not do it to obtain
The Soveraignty of the Sea-parted Earth
Live many years in happines: I wih it
With all my oul, ele may I dye unwept for.
But give me leave to leave you, and betow
Laughter, not tears for my incontancy.
Think me unworthy of your worthy elf;
For I cannot love you, nor will marry you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Surely you will. Have you a caue to be
So merciles unto a paionate Lady,
One that o truly wonders at your worths?
I pray you (Sir) jet not o olemnly:
Thunder is Muick in my ears to this.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do not: credit me (mot fair Lucora)
I am in earnet, nor would I pend the time
In words. Shall I call Nentis?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Rather call Bailiskes to look me dead
Then her, to help to mourn your unkind parting.
O! do not thus: wherein am I deform'd
So uddenly, that you o oon hould leave me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This is a trouble to your elf: you cannot
Speak words enough to make me yours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Can I not peak ufficiently! Then I
Will try if there be Magick in my knees:
Look (Sir) a Lady kneels to you for love, She kneels.
To whom the noblet in the Realm have u'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: All is in vain.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou man (that art more lating in thy fury
Then the Egyptian wonder through the tormes
Of many bleak tempetuous winters)
Say worthles man, if it becomes thee well
To let a loving Lady kneel to thee,
And thou be merciles and not raie her • p.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I pray you rie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And will you then be reconcil'd unto me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No I cannot.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I will turn a Statue.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I pray you leave me and forget me ever:
Henceforth you hall not ee me any more,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Not ee you any more!
O faithles man and full of perjuries!
Thy nature is tranparent, thou art fale
As is the mooth-fac'd Sea, which every wind
Diturbes; a fale Barbarian, and born under
Deceitful Mercury. A Britain would
Rather have died then thus have wronged me:
Thou art inhumane, and mayet boat the conquet.
Tell your mot alvage countrey-men this Act,
(If the jut God of Seas revenge me not)
And number it 'mongt your proud cruelties.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be pacifi'd: I pray you leave this rage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When I am dead I hall, and not before,
And that hall not be long; For thou halt ee me,
Merciles man thou halt, and adde that to
Thy bloody conquets; boat how a lighted Lady
For thy unkindnes made her elf away.
This hand (wherewith I would have given my elf
To thee) hall take me from my miery.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold: I am Carionil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How! ay that again.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am Carionil.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That breath hath rais'd me, and made me my elf.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I counterfeited the Negro to obtain you,
The wihed period of my griefes; and might,
But will not love that woman that hall corn
All my endeavours, and entertain a tranger,
An Ethiopian, and prefer him, no:
Judg (fair Lucora) if I have not caue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yes, yes you have: But now you do not need
More of your Rhetorick to diwade me from you.
There are not in the world temptations
Can make me yours: I cannot give a reaon,
Tis in my nature, and a ecret one.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I am glad it is o.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This is the happiet hour
My life did ever pas, and quickly chang'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I rejoyce at the alteration: Madam, you hall
Command me to do any thing but marry you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Then I command you never move me more.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I will obey you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now you may call Nentis:
She is not yet in bed; I ee a light yet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mot willingly.
Nentis, Nentis.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What's the matter, marle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Come down.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: I wonder much: I come (Madam.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You will be ecret, Sir, of what hath pat?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You may be confident I will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I ele hall uffer much in my honour.
Women! take heed: the men whom you deny
May win you to be theirs by Policy:
They Proteus-like will vary hapes, until
Beyond their wihes they have plac'd their will.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Your woman's come: Good night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Good night (Sir)
Nentis, I now will never pas the Seas:
Tucapelo is become Carionil.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: Amazement ceaeth me!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Anon thou halt know all.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: I hope that now you will be rul'd by your friends, and take the Lord Falorus to your husband.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hang husbands!

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: The Gods bles them all I ay, and end me a good one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let's to bed: lock the door after you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: How joy fully the birds alute the morn,
Warbling a welcome from their gentle throats!
But I am of another mind (poor maid!)
Aurora doth no ooner bluh upon
The world, but I make my complaints afreh.
I am in love, and for my wretched State
Can blame no body but initer Fate.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Well met (Anclethe) I will hide no longer
My elf in this diguie. Again thou halt
Be my Anclethe: wilt thou be my Boy,
And ing me ongs, as thou hadt wont to do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You have obtain'd your Mitris I ee, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I have not (boy) nor will I eek her more:
Some other time thou halt receive the tory.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My hour is come: dear Cupid be my aid.
And will you never have another Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I do not know Anclethe, but if I have,
She mut not be o obtinate as this.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But ay a Lady of a noble houe
(One that is not unhandom) were in love
With you, did love you violently (my Lord)
Would you not pity her, but be unkind?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Boy, I do know what tis to love in vain
So well, and what a miery is in it,
That if he were but reaonably well,
She hould not grieve for me, indeed he hould not.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You are mot noble: old Philoophy
Never defin'd a virtue which you want.
There is a Lady Sir, and not ill-favour'd,
Born of an ancient honourd family,
So much in love with you, that if you do
Refue her (my Lord) you do deny her life.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What is he cal'd Anclethe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: My Lord, my Commision doth not reach o farre;
She'd have her name conceal'd until y'ave een her.
Tomorrow morning you may meet her here:
She with a gentleman (a friend of hers)
VVill here expect you about ten a clock.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVell, I will ee her (boy) and if I find
Her anwer thy report, I will be kind.
He that neglects a loving Lady for
VVeak caues, may the Gods that man abhorre.

div.stage: A Banquet et forth: Then enter Polidacre, Antiphila, Servants and M • itians.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: YOu will pardon a udden entertainment.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I hope we need not complement.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You do intruct me.
Sit down (my weet Antiphila) and tate.
Fill wine:
All health and happines to you (dear Mitris.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: A true return of loyal thanks.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Play a more merry tune: I do abhor
What ever reliheth of melancholy.
Sing, the pheres are dull—
Apply it to your elf that bet deerve it.

lg.l: The Spheres are dull, and do not make
Such Muick as my ears will take:
The lighted Birds may ceae to ing,
Their chirpings do not grace the pring:
The Nightingal is ad in vain,
I care not to hear her complain:
While I have ears and you a tongue,
I hall think all things ele go wrong.
The Poets feign'd that Orpheus could
Make tones to follow where he would:
They feign'd indeed, but (had they known
Your voice) a truth they might have hown.
All intruments mot adly go,
Becaue your tongue excels them o:
While I have ears, and you a tongue,
I hall think all things ele go wrong.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Tis pretty.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Reiterate again your yielding, Lady,
And once more let your breath perfume thoe words.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: And I my fair Antiphila's, your tongue
Hath made me happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: May your joy lat long.

div.head: Scena ecunda.
div.stage: Enter Philander and Roinda in womens apparel.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: How glad I am to ee you like your elf!
Dear mother; pardon an exces of joy.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Such ignes of true affection need no pardon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: For me! from whom? the hand reolves me;
Preent my ervice to the Lady that ent it.
Tell her, ere long I will come kis her hands.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Mother, I writ unto Antiphila,
And did deire her (for guerdon of my love)
To hold me econd in her thoughts, and (if
She married not my father) to have me.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: She may perform
What he believ'd would never come to pas.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: SIR, I confes I am not contracted, and that I told you o to make you deit. I hould be exceeding ungrateful to deny you o mall a requet. There is nothing hinders me from being yours, but your Father: And I olemnly vow unto you, that (if I have not him) you hall have me. But let not this beget any hope in you; for (if I be not his) it hall be his refual. Let it onely manifet o much, that (had I never een him) I could have lov'd you mot truly. I pray you, let this uffice, and ue me o. Chooe another Mitris, and let me be her econd: You will love me well enough, if you love another better. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: What writ you to her (Son) concerning her
Pro •• ing a contract betwixt us two?
<…> my rage I met with Tandorix,
<…> him of his life;
<…> he was a woman
And for a Gentleman cal'd Perimont,
(Who often had deni'd to marry her)
That habit did aume, thereby to learn
More eaily what did prevent her joy,
And whether he affected any other.
Thus I your being kept unknown.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: I'me gald you did o.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: You do well, Mother, to wear a mask: you hall
Thereby be ure to be conceal'd untill
You find the fittet opportunity
Your elf (unto my Father) to reveal.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What will become of me (unfortunate man)
Who needs mut live in fire or live in hame?
I know not what to peak nor what to do,
Both fear and grief do o confound my ences
I fear to wrong Carionil o much
As to be traiterous againt our friendhip;
And griefs unufferable endure for the
Fairet of Ladies, incomparable Lucora:
I would he had been kind unto my friend,
Unto him then I never had prov'd fale;
Nor will I: I will rather earch out frozen
Climates, and lie whole nights on hills of Ice,
Or rather will take powerfull potions, and leep
Out thoe unpleaant houres I have to live;
But then I hall not ee that beauty: who
But enceles frantickes would have thoughts o poor?
My reaon forakes the government of this
Weak frame, and I am falne into diorder.
Oh! I could igh my body into air,
And weep't into a Lake, if merciles nature
Had made it of a ubtance uitable
Unto my wih now: methinks I could level
A Promontory into a Province, and tread
The centre through to read the detinies
Of outhern tars, and bles their fortunes that
Are born under their light; for (I am confident)
Their influences are more mild then ours.
There is no other Fate can fall on me
Shall awe me now; I will be proud and daring
As the ambitious waves, when wrathful blats
Of Northern windes do hoit them violently
Againt the highet cloudes, and rather will
Detroy my elf then wrong Carionil.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Cleanthe in womans apparel, and Phygionis.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: And erv'd my iter well to leave her o.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: How much (dear Madam) have you impoverihed
Mens cies, by hiding your perfections
In their apparel? indeed I flatter not,
I do not know the Lady owns o much beauty.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: If my Carionil will like me, then
I hall attain the end of my deires:
May I appear but lovely in his eye,
And what I eem in others I will light.
But (good Phygionis) tell me I prethee
In your affection what ucces you have.
Is Nentis won, or do you hope he will?

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: She's mine, we are contracted.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Joy wait on you,
And make your lives of many years pas pleaant.
Is it not ten? are all the clocks grown envious
Againt my blis, and will not let me know
How nigh his coming is? for I eteem
My elf mot happy in his company.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: This is the place Anclethe nam'd.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Madam he's here.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Be friend me my good tars!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Here is a Lady and a matchles one!
Wood two years ince I had beheld this beauty,
When firt I came from Spain and had my heart free,
Then many a ad day had been merry unto me,
For unto her Lucora hould have yielded.
Sweet Lady, you that are the fairet creature
Nature did ever form, vouchafe o much
Of happines unto me as to give
Me liberty to touch your lips—do you
Know me? and have your ears ere heard
So poor a name as is Carionil?
But I am much mitook; you are not he
Whom here I was to meet: I needs mut doubt
The fates did not intend me uch a joy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Deceiv'd Pythagoras! hadt thou but dream't
The weetnes of this voice, the muick of
The Spheres thou never hadt recorded. Speak,
Fairet and bet of Ladies, let me hear
If you have o unmatch'd a pity in you
As to look on me with a friendly eye.
Can you love me?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Mot noble Sir, I do mot violently.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If that to live with you detain'd me not,
I hould be griev'd that my joy for o great
A fortune did not tupifie my enes,
And cat me into an eternal leep.
Where is Anclethe? he is much to blame
In not attending you.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Whom peak you of dear Sir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My boy.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I do not know a boy of that name truly:
Nor (I think) is there.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: You do amaze me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: You may believe me, Sir, for I am he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Wonders in Riddles!

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I am your Page Anclethe, and iter to
Lucora, who for love attended you
Diguis'd, becaue (I found) for the great enmity
Between our families) my father never
Would give me where I would betow my elf.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Nure did teal you when you was a child?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Mot true: This gentleman her on, my friend,
Occaioned my ecape, by giving me
A knowledge of my birth. His true relation
Can vindicate me from upicion.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I need it not:
Were you not he (as I believe you are)
And mean of birth, I hould account my elf
A gainer by you. Sir, you have done that
Hath plac'd you in my heart among thoe friends
For whoe akes I my life will acrifice.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: My Lord, you do indebt me to your ervice:
In your acquaintance I hall be mot honour'd.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, if you pleae he will relate my Story.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: By no means: keep it for your father, when
You do dicloe your elf. But can you pardon
Thoe incivilities I did commit
When you was Anclethe?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Wrong not your elf: you did make more of me
Then I deerv'd, or could.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But why, my weet Cleanthe, would you not
Let me know who you was before?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Dear Sir, I aw how violent you was
In your affection to my careles iter,
And had no hope you would leave her for me:
And (if you did obtain her) meant to do
What my diatrous fate hould prompt me to.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Sweetet of all your ex.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: But (if you never got her, and orecame
Her obtinacy) to declare my elf;
If not (but Love had triumph'd in your fall)
I'de not have liv'd to ee your Funeral.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: The Gods requite this goodnes, and make me worthy
Of you, my dear Cleanthe; I contract
My elf upon your lips: which we will perfect
Ere you own publikely your Father, for
The enmity will make him charge you otherwie.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I pray you let us.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: A thouand thanks, come hall we walk (fair Mitres)?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Concluions fair the fates to them do give
Who contant in their loves, and faithful live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Stay, dear Cleanthe, here is my friend, he hall
Partake my joy; well met my bet Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It eems you are not Tucapelo now:
Where is Lucora? have you married her?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: No, I have not, friend.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Refrain:
I am your enemy, embrace me not,
Receive my word, and peace this heart (Carionil.) Gives his word.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: He hath not yet decri'd you:
Withdraw a little (dear Mitres) Sir, I pray you
To bear her company, for who can tell
What in this phrenie he may do?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Hereabouts we will await your leiure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: What ailes my friend? let me but know the man
Is caue of this diorder in you, and
He hall not ee the gray-ey'd morning break
From th' oriental Mountains any more:
Let me partake of that unwieldy grief
Hath bowd my friend o much beneath himelf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Leave complements Carionil, and make
A paage for my oul, that it may leave
So vile a habitation as this body;
And (when I'me dead) rip out my heart and in't
Survey my fault, for I want words, and have
Not impudence enough to tell it you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: O what might be the caue this matchles frame
And worthiet Cabinet that ever man
Inclos'd his ecrets in, is o diturb'd!
Noble Falorus, think to whom you peak,
It is Carionil, whoe life you do
Make burthenous to him by the upicion
Of wronging him whom you have ever lov'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You do deceive your elf; I lately have
Trangres'd againt our league of amity:
If you deire to be a happy man,
And to enjoy what mot you eek, be kind
Unto your elf, and run my body through.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Can I be happy and Falorus dead!
No, I hould live a deolater life
Then ere the trictet Anchorite hath done,
And wear my body to an Anatome,
For real orrow at uch a dire mihap:
Live then (my friend) and may you number daies
Until Arithmetick grow faint, and leave you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You know not how much hurt you wih your elf.
Would you torment me twice? If not, forget
Falorus utterly, and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I undertand you not.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would you have me blat my own fame by peaking
My fault? And have me Executioner
Unto my elf?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Releae your Soul of all her griefes, and ay
From whence your orrows have original.
Have you not oft told me of my impatiency?
Give me now leave to be as plain with you:
The angry winds never enrag'd the eas
So much as ome mall grief hath done my friend.
I do conjure you by our former loves
(For ure not long ince we were friends indeed)
To let me know why you are thus ditemper'd:
I do not fear but I hall free you from
This pasion o precipitate and dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are mot good, and get your elf, Carionil,
A name above the ablet character,
None (like it) can decipher you; and would
I alwayes had continued Falorus,
Then I yet had remain'd your friend. But (if
You needs will know the reaon of my fury)
Draw out the word, that (when you have receiv'd it)
Your hand, and not your words may trike me dead.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be not importun'd longer; eae your heart:
For (credit me) I grieve to ee you thus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am in love, uppoe the ret, and kill me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVith Lucora?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Too true, now cure me into dut, and with
Your breath dipere me into aire: but pare me,
Chide me not for my falhood, and inflict
But one punihment on me, and be that the word;
Yet hear me peak one word or two before.
I have not woo'd her, nor have ought performance
Of that free promie that her father made me,
But faithfully have temporiz'd with him;
Nor did I willingly conent unto
This paion, it did eie me violently.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Be you more calme, take her (Falorus) you have
A liberty for me, I peak in earnet.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Then all is well, return my word (dear friend)
Carionil, I will not hinder thee:
My name hall not be blated in thy ighes;
Fall worthles man, tis pity I hould live.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: VVhat mean you (my Falorus?) for heavens ake leave,
And your own light rahly extinguih not:
I for Lucora do not care, and have
All my affection unto her recal'd,
And am engag'd unto another Lady;

l.U: tole her from her chamber in my diguie,

sp.l: And then (bethinking me how he had us'd me)
I told her that I would not have a Lady
VVho would prefer a Moor before me. Her
Slighting of me made me to leave her o.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Is this not policy to delay my death?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: If ere you found me fale, believe me not.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: It then is true?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mot true, Falorus.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Licence me (friend) now to embrace you; well met
(Carionil) and welcomer indeed
Then ever yet man was unto me: I
Will live and owe my life unto you, and (when
You pleae) I for your ake will lay it down:
Freely I may Lucora now adore;
And (rather then to loe her) I will try
All waies that are contain'd in policie.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But ay he never will conent?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I am
Mot confident he will to pleae her Father:
But (if he hould not) I could uffer it;
'Twas not my Love made me thus paionate,
It was becaue in it I wronged you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Did you not marke (when you did ee me firt)
A joy unuual it upon my brow?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I had o much of orrow in my heart,
That with it all my ences were poet.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But you perceiv'd I had left my diguie;
What out of it did you collect?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I thought
Lucora had decri'd you, and you had
A peremptory denial to your uit.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, eeing you had made a fair concluion,
And meauring each minute for an hour
Until I were with you, I rudely come
Uncal'd for to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Ever mot welcome my Cleanthe; friend,
This is the Lady I did mention to you,
She was Anclethe, b • t is iter to
The Mitres of you • thoughts, and cal'd Cleanthe,
Whom long ince all her friends believed lot,
And have thee many years left mourning for.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: A trange dicovery and admirable!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Some other time command the hitory;
This mutually among our elves we'l pend.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Lady, account me ervant to your vertues,
And you, Sir, may command Falorus alwaies.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Your love will honour me (mot noble Lord.)

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Sir, I for you will interceion make
Unto my iter, and do hope hall proper:
I will make known how much you are her ervant,
And what affection my ears have witneed;
For I (uneen to you) did hear what pa'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You will oblige me everlatingly.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Now let us walk.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Whooever loyal friendhip doth regard,
With fair events the Gods will him reward.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
I have a Licence for my Lady, & the brave gallant Mitres Lorece, But it cot too much a concience,
I wood a writ five times as much for halfe I gave for it: But t'is the fahion among great ones, o they have their wills they care not at how dear a rate they buy them. This marriage is like Chritmas, when it comes it brings good cheer with't, we have fat Venion, hold belly hold: and wine I am ure we hall want none, for the Vintner had twenty pounds on me this morning. I ha bepoke a merry company of Fidlers; O they are boon fellows! and there will be old dancing, for I mean to weat my doublet quite through ere I leave.
Madam, her'es the Licene your Worhips ent me for, the Paron and this will make all ure.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Tis well done Iaques, for this, be thou the Neptune of the Cellar, raie a tempet, and drown who ever doth go down the taires;
Like old Silenus behave thy elf.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: When we have din'd, lets go to my Lord Polidacres, and invite that houe.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: We will (my dear Widow.)

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Twill be a merry time I ee.

div.head: Scena exta.
div.stage: Enter Polidacre, Lucora, Antiphila, and Nentis.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I wonder we have not een the Ethiopian Lord to day.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: He'l not be long abent.
Lucora, thou hat my heart for thy conent:
Falorus is a worthy Gentleman,
And one of an approved fahion,
He doth deerve a Princes; my Lucora,
I know his nature is mot noble, ele
I would not move thee for him, and (although
The time is not expir'd) will you teal
So much from age, and be his wife? I long
To ee thee well betow'd.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: VVhat ere you pleae t'command I will perform.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Here is Falorus! welcome my Lord, I hall
Shortly ay my on; my daughter I have won,
And when I pleae, unto you he will give
Away herelf.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: You are mot noble:
But can you (fairet Lady) look o low
As is Falorus? can there be uch a vertue
Of rare humility within you, that
You thus confer affection upon me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My Lord, my father deires to make me yours;
And I have learnt o much obedience,
As willingly to do what he commands.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I wih I could (mot excellent Lucora)
Thanke you in all the languages are worth
Your dear attention, you have made me o
Exceeding happy, I envy not his wealth
That ownes the inhautible mines of fam'd Peru.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: I thank you for this love, and have a hope
Requite you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: My joy hath dul'd my enes.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now brother! have I not ended happily?
Vandona is my own: We onely want
The ceremony Ecleiatical.
My Lord, I am your ervant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I have a Mitris got, the richet beauty
Great Brittain ever was renowned for.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Much, very much y faith; have you won her
For whom hopeful Carionil did dye?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I won her not (Lorece) her fathers deire
Meeting with her conent, have made her mine.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Siter, you have been a tranger to me, I pray you be not o.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.p: You hall ee me oftner.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Thou mait be Mercury, and I will glory
Thou art my brother.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.p: Madam, I'm very glad to meet you here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I as joyful of your company.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Wonders Carionil's alive again, and here.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: For ome trange end he did give forth his death:
But what yong beauteous Ladie's that?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It is a face worthy of admiration.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Rie Lady: kneel not unto me.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: Then I were mot unfit to be your Child.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: How my daughter that was lot?

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: Yes my Lord, and beg your bleing.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: May the good heavens make of thee (my daughter)
(If you be he) an old and happy woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am a Siter to you: Spare ome time
For me to hew how much I do rejoyce
At this unlook'd for good: none of your kin
(Fair Siter) are more glad then I to ee you,
Whom we had never hope to ee: I am
Mot proud to be alli'd unto
So excellent a creature as you are.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: I am mot joyful of your love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: We are mot glad to ee you afe.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: As if you were our Siter.

sp.speaker: Clea.
sp.l: My thanks (weet Ladies)

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Dearet Cleanthe, confirm thy father in
His joy: relate thy life, that out of it
I may grow confident thou art my daughter.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Lady, leave that to me: My Lord (and if
You with her ilence can o long dipence)
I would do that.

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: He is my Nures Son, to whom (my Lord)
I owe all thanks for my ecape.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Sir, when you pleae you may begin.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: What, not a gentleman! I am undone,
But mut be ecret in't.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: My Lord.
This Ladies Nure, my mother, had a Sonne
Older then the Lady Cleanthe is by even years;
Whom he did love o extraordinarily,
That for his ake he foulely er'd from vertue:
She thought it was an eaie thing for her
(If that their lives attained to thoe years)
To make your daughter wife unto her on;
Which is the caue he privily ecap'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Mot trange!

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: By chance I heard this of my brother, who
Told me (againt my mothers trict command)
What a great marriage he hould have, and that
Cleanthe was the daughter of a Lord,
Your Honours child,
Whom all we thought but of a mean decent:
(For he had won the country to believe
That he did find her in the open field:)
I pittying her hard chance, did tell her all,
And promis'd her I would attend upon her,
Until he had her parents happy made
With knowledge of her afety.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: The ret I mut relate:
Dear Sir, be kind, and (if I have done ought
You hall dilike) pardon my firt offence;
I was no ooner come to town, but aw
This noble Gentleman, with whom o violently
I fell in love, that for his ake (pray pardon me)
My own apparel I did lay away,
And did become his Page: And (when I did
Dicloe my elf) he kindly did requite me.
In brief we are contracted,
I did not well without you to do thus;
But your forgivenes, Sir, I cannot doubt:
He told me that there was a difference
Between our families, and therefore you
(If your conent was ask'd) would never yield.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Wood I were it'h Cellar, I care not for thee drie and tedious tales.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Whether I hould or no I cannot tell,
But I am glad that it hath chanced thus;
This match an ancient dicord will conclude,
And may the Gods be favourable to it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Mot Worthy Lord, my faithful thankes.

sp.speaker: Phy.
sp.l: Here alo is a ring which by
Your Father (my Lord Falorus) was given her,
When at the Font he for her anwer'd;
She wo'rt about her neck when he was tolne.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I know it well, and am confident
Thou art my lot Cleanthe: Be his wife,
And may the heavens make up the match mot fortunate.
Carionil, I now am glad I have
A man o honour'd to my on in law.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord (if that I can perform my will)
You never hall repent your daughters choice.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: I do not doubt I hall. Now I would know
Why your death was reported.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I was in love long which your eldet daughter
The fair Lucora, but could never win her;
Brought almot to depair I did aume
The habit and colour of a Negro.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then you was Tucapelo.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: I was indeed
Knowing he had refu'd the greatet Marriages,
And many of the handomet of the Kingdome,
I fully did believe he never would
Like any man of this Complexion,
And therefore feign'd my elf an Ethiopian.
But firt gave out my death, and that unto
My elf I had done violence, for her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Surely, he will not do o unworthily
As to make mention of my fond affection.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: But all could not prevail.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: I am glad he ends o.

sp.speaker: Cario.
sp.l: And therefore I deited wholly: which when
She did dicloe her elf.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: I do perceive the Heavens intended you
Should reconcile our Families.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Her's love, and love agen: I wood ome body would love me.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: My dear Siter, you mut not think me rude
Becaue I do expres my love o fully.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Be my Carionil;
All that •• e mine repect this Lady: For
I do intend to make her o.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: We are her Servants, and mot joyfully
Shall kneel unto a Lady of her vertues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: What Lady's that?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: She's masked, and I cannot gues.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Philander, this Lady is thy Siter, the lot

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Grow not to weak, my body, to contain (Cleanthe.
My oul within thee at thee joyes:
Fair Siter, I am glad that I can name
So beauteous a Lady as you are o;
For you the heavens be thanked.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Carionil's alive, and mut be tyl'd your brother,
Cleanthe him hath choe:
Perfect thy joyes (Philander) when thou wilt,
And hear their Hitories;
This Lady you mut call mother.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: But I mut not.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: This here I will;
Dear mother, now confirm my words.

sp.speaker: Poli.
sp.l: Welcome to life Roinda: Thy face and beauty
I do remember well: But wherefore did you
Raie the report of your untimely death?

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: That at a fitter time. This give me leave
To pend in joy.
My dear Cleanthe (for I do believe
Becaue thy father doth acknowledge thee,
Thou art Cleanthe my o long lot daughter)
Never was mothers heart o light; I cannot
Utter my joyes, my tears mut witnes them.
To time I am indebted, that he hath
Spared my life untill I ee thee afe.

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.l: I want expreion: But my life hall be
A comment on my heart, wherein you hall
Perceive what your Cleanthe is.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Now you are mine (fair Antiphila.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I will perform my promie.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Both your conents I begge.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: How's this!

sp.speaker: Anti.
sp.l: I did engage my elf,
That (if I were not yours) I would be his.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: Then may the knot prove happy, and continue
A firm one, while the Gods do lend you breath.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: It is my wih.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Was you her ervant too? Wife, chide me in ecrer, I was forworn.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: We all are frail; Mortality may boat
Of trength, but many concluions deny it.

sp.speaker: Nen.
sp.l: Away, I will have none of you, I will not begge.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.l: You hall not need, I (for his love and care
Unto my daughter) will give him means befitting
A Gentleman, which hall decend unto
His poterity, poverty hall not poil his fortune.

sp.speaker: Vandon.
sp.l: 'Tis nobly aid, If you do like him, take him iter.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Now I'm content.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: My joy is great: My thanks (weet Mitris) My Lord Polidacre, I am your grateful, though unworthiet ervant. Now, Mitris, you hall know the policy I won your affections with; my affections being etled o high, and I poor, I made my elf Draculemion; But your promie, worthiet Lord hath now enriched me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: O me! Was you that merry fellow? you have a parlous wit.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: One thing I mut crave of you.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: You hall obtain Sir.

sp.speaker: Phyg.
sp.p: That you will pardon my Mother.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.p: I do for your ake.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Since I perceive you in the bounteous way
Of granting Boons, Sir, I aume the boldnes
To become a Petitioner to you.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: My dear Lucora freely ask, for I
Doubtleely hall conent to thy demand.

sp.speaker: Luco.
sp.l: Seeing the gracious Heavens have bleed our houe
With the recovery of my long lot Siter;
And ince the powers divine have link'd her heart
To the affections of a noble Gentleman,
A marriage like to grace your honour'd Age
With hopeful Nephews; I humbly crave your licence
To enjoy the freedom of a ingle life;
For I've no inclination to become
A ubject unto Hymens glorious bondage.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: Remember (my Lucora) all your promies,
And uffer not your obtinacy to cloud
The happines of this Evening.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: My excellent Mitris, you have rais'd me neer
The Zenith of all happines, and will you
Now leave me on that mighty precipice,
To fall into a ad Abys of miery?

sp.speaker: Clean.
sp.l: My dear weet Siter, give me leave to trouble you
With a few words aide;
I aw the Lord Falorus for your ake
(Between a great affection and firme friendhip)
In as high a paion as you can imagine.
A noble and a faithful Lover to you;
He in his oul adores you, I am confident;
And I'm obliged by promie to become
His Interceor for your kind affection:
I do beeech you therefore grace your Siter
(Though bold, being younger, to importune you thus)
T'honor the Lord Falorus with your Love.

sp.speaker: Lucor.
sp.l: I dare not (my fair iter) be o cruel
As to deny you in your firt requet;
I'le entertain his flame and be his Bride.
I will be plain with you, had you been ilent,
In a hip bound for Spain I had gone to night
With ome Ladies of our neer kindred towards Lisbone,
And o avoided the Courthip of Falorus,
And all my Fathers continual importunities.
To make this ecape more unexpected, and
The better to provide me for this journey,
I had conented when my father pleas'd
To marry him; but your intreaties have
Prevail'd above all my reolutions.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: Dear Madam, let me beeech your aitance.

sp.speaker: Roin.
sp.l: My Lord, I will deire her, and am confident
I hall obtain. I pray thee (my Lucora)
Submit to the intreaties of thy friends,
And let not thy refual of Falorus
Beget a ad look on this happy evening.

sp.speaker: Lucor.
sp.l: Madam, you and my iter hall overcome;
And though (my Lord Falorus) you may taxe me
For an obtinate dipoition, you hall find me
Throughout my future dayes) to made amends,
And prove a very loving wife unto you.

sp.speaker: Falor.
sp.l: Now you have fixed me in a fortunate
And glorious life.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: I thank thee my Lucora.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Every body has his Sweetheart but I; one or other take pity on me, and let me not be a Cypher and tand here for nothing. I ee the fault is in my years, otherwie Serving-men are not o lighted by Ladies.

sp.speaker: Polid.
sp.l: Let us withdraw; you all
Shall uppe with me to night, and we'l deign
The happy day that hall each couple joyn.

sp.speaker: Cario.
sp.l: You that have Mitries, do not depair
To get them, be they nere o proud and fair;
One way or other (you have een it done)
The Obtinatet Lady may be wone.

sp.speaker: Lucora.
sp.l: THe obtinate Lady yet is obtinate,
And (careles either of your love or hate)
She dares continue o: Nor will I beg
Some friend within to come with his low leg,
And's hat in's hand to woe your praie: It is
So poor, that I had rather hear you his.
Our Poet bad's be bold, For's Play was good,
And that t'would take, if it was undertood;
And o we are: For what's our fate we mut
And will endure, be't lawful, or unjut.
Unto your jutice we appeal, which lies
Within your hands: Do what you pleae, and rie,

sp.speaker: Cleanth.
sp.l: O iter! This is likely to poil all:
Gentle Spectators, alo give me leave.

lg.l: Ladies and Gentlemen, if we have aid
Ought that hath pleas'd your ears, or patime made
Our time we have pent well but if that we
Have tedious been, and you did it and ee
With we arines, our Poet will repent
That you this Comedy we did preent.
Y'ave paid the Actors wel, we thank you & know it,
And wih that you would gratifie our Poet
He wants no money as the cae now tands,
Yet • rayes you to be liberal of your hands.

div.p: Trappolin creduto Principe. OR TRAPPOLIN Suppos'd a Prince. An Italian TRAGE-COMEDY. The cene part of Italy. Written by Sir ASTON COKAIN.

row.cell: Son of the Duke of Savoy.
Hymen, Luna, Mars, Mercury, Iupiter, Venus, Saturn, Sol:

lg.l: GAllants, be't known as yet we cannot ay
But this our Poet hath licens'd us to tell,
Ingenious Italy hath lik'd it well:
Yet is it no tranlation; for he nere
But twice in Venice did it ever hear
There it did take, and he doth hope (if you
Have your old humors) it will pleae here too
He wears he hath not poil'd it, and protet
We think it good, though he doth none ot'h bet
You often have heard wore it'h houe before,
And had we made the Prologue wee'd ay more
That labour he hath av'd us, caue he wood
No partial friend hould crie it up for good;
An excellent new Comedy as you ay,
When you have een't, he o will judge his pla •
He is not peremptory, like to ome
Who think that all is bet from them doth come
Ladies and Gentlemen, you that do know
To cenure rightly as you think o do:
Our Poet cornes to beg your hands, yet aith,
That at the end if he the favour hath,
This hall not be his lat, that he'l endeavou •
To gratifie you hortly with another:
How ere it takes, he for your preence ends
His thankes by me, and hopes we hall par • friends.

sp.p: MY wench Flametta is a dear rogue, the pretty fool dotes on me; my Lord Barbarin can do nothing with her; his pitols and jewels he cares not for. And tis a handome thing: no Pomatum ere toucht her lips, or painted her cheeks, yet are they cherries and roes; I am mot happy to be what I am, and to have the love of uch a one as he.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Good morrow Trappolin, how does my Love?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Firt let us kis, and after I will tell,
For ever thine Flametta.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: O thanks my dear.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: The villain Trappolin has a handome wench, and (which angers me) an honet one; I have pent many weeks about her, but could never do any good, he will not neither for love or money; and ee where they are a talking together.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yonder is my Lord Barbarino.

My dear Flametta, I am your Honours ervant; this free promie of thine, I can never enough thanke thee for—at your Lordhips command. How happily hall we live together in marriage, both loving o well and truly? Your Honours humble lave. Let us kis agen—your poor vaal my Lord, thus will we pend our daies in thee delights; o will we kis Flametta—I beeech your Honour to pardon me: we nere will be a weary of our elves, if thou dot igh, thy Trappolin will weep,—your Honour hall command me alwaies; and when thou ingt thy Trappolin will dance.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: And I am thine my honet Trappolin,
And ever will be contant unto thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'le attend your Honour preently.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: There's no man alive hall make me prove
Unfaithful unto thee, o much I love.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Your Lordhip mut pardon me a little,
I am omething buie.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: My Trappolin hall not betow a kis,
But I will pay it him with uury;
It is impoible for thee to be
More thy Flametta's then Flametta's thine.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I will come to your Honour preently.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Pardon Sweetheart that now I mut be gone,
My tay another time hall make amends:
A kis my dear, my lovely Trappolin;
With uch I hall be never atisfied.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Farewel my dear rogue; my Lord I come,
sp.p: Your Honour mut pardon me, you aw how I was employ'd, I could not leave the poor fool, your Lordhip ees he loves me, and protet her labour is not lot: now if your Honour hath any thing to command me, I am ready Trappolino, your poor ervant.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: You are a awcy peremptory villain,
And I have well perceiv'd your bae demeanor;
Although I ee the wench is yours, you hall
Repent the freedome of your evil language,
Be ure you hall.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Good morrow my Lord,
sp.p: Let him do his wort I care not a ruh for him; he would ha my wench, and I am glad I abus'd him, I ha made his Honour omething collerick, let him diget it how he will.

div.stage: Enter Lavinio the great Duke, Prudentia, Barbarin, Machavil and others.

sp.speaker: Lavin.
sp.l: The Tucane glory have we yet upheld,
And from the fierce aaults of enemies
Recued our cities, et them in a peace
As happy as the Gods did ere vouchafe.
Sforza the Duke of Milain our old friend,
Who hath in all our wars till ent us aide,
Hath promied me the matchles Iabella
His iter for my wife; and eeing now
We have no more to do with enemies,
I will to Milain go and marry her,
And quickly unto Florence will return,
Where I will celebrate our nuptial
With that magnificence becomes our tate.
You, whom I ever have found faithful to me,
Lord Barbarino, and Lord Machivil,
To you I do commit the government
Of Tucany until I return;
And full commiion to do what you hall
See neceary for the good of Florence:
My dear Prudentia, the onely joy
Of our deceaed Father, the lat Duke,
Live happy, and enjoy thy own deires,
Which I do know are vertuous all.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Mot noble Sir, it is impoible
That I hould happy be, and you not preent:
But I am unworthy to beeech your tay;
Go and be fortunate in a worthy choice,
While I to heaven pray for your afe return.
Dear weet Prudentia, and alo Lords,
Look well unto my prioner Brunetto;
Yet let him want nothing but a free releae,
For ure he is more then he eems to be.
I have been long about this journey; now
All things are ready, my Prudentia
Farewel; and iter, be not melancholy,
For in few weeks I will return, and bring
A iter home to keep thee company,
The beauteous Milanes.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: And may he prove
According to your wihes, noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: And be a joy unto the Florentines.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: And be a happy mother, that there may
Not want an heir unto your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Our thanks;
Onward, tis time I were upon my way.

sp.speaker: Barba.
sp.l: Now will I be reveng;d of Trappolin,
Who hath o boldly to my face abus'd me;
I have authority to do't withall,
I'le make him to repent his awcines.
He's here, but I will do't as if by Jutice.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I can think of nothing but my pretty villain Flammetta; O 'tis a dear rogue, and he aies he loves me, and I know he does: when I have married her I will betake me to the country, where we will live as jovial as the day is long.—

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: I'le fight for Florence while I have a vein
To hold my heart from falling unto death;
Nor hall the Longobardy Mantuaus
Ere win a Flag while I am in the field;
I'de make the Tucan Duke to know the man
Whom he hath truted to conduct his troops,
Durt but Gonzaga ever tir again.
Methinks there is no nobler thing on earth,
Then to ee hills of bodies, lakes of blood:
No braver Muick then the Martial Drum;
Nor Diapaons weeter to the ear,
Then unto it the Warlike Trumpets make;
When I but hear this harmony, I could,
Full of delight, venter my ingle peron
Againt an armed Troop. Away with peace,
It is the Canker and the bane of minds;
'Tis that which makes us to forget our elves,
And pend our lives in enuality.
Then glorious war advance thy armed arm,
That oldiers may have waies to hew themelves;
Wo'd Gothes and Vandals once again would come
Int' Italy, or Moors into our Spain,
That Mattemores might wear out his word
With hewing bones, and cleaving armed men:
Each thing doth to his centre fall, and I
Would unto mine, which is to fight or die.
Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I!

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: I you! what are you to good to be asked?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I am Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: By that I know not, art thou a man of war?
Is Trappolin in any Captains roll?
I't writ?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yes (Seignior Captain) in the Parons book,
The day thereof my baptime is et down.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And in that honour oft hat thou ere fought
With Infidels, and lain a core or two?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not I, Heavens be prais'd, a core or two aid you Captain? then hould I ure never ecape, for I promie you many an one is hang'd for killing of one.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Fie, what an ignorance is this! hat thou a mind to become now a ouldier?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Indeed, Seignior Captain, I cannot reolve you as yet, I am about a wife, Ile ask her if he will turn ouldier too, and then if I like it ther's an end. But I pray you Captain what is a ouldier?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A ouldier, Trappolin, is he that does
Venter his life a hundred times a day,
VVood in his countries, and his Princes caue
Stand canon hot, and wood of teeled pikes
VVood when his bodie's full of wounds all night,
Lie in the field and leep upon his helm.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good Captain pardon me, neither I nor Flametta will be ouldiers; heavens defend, venter my life o many times a day! there is more afety and gain in turning thief: I love my countrey and Prince well, but my elf better; 'tis good leeping in a whole skin, tis better lying with Flametta in a warm bed; marry I had thought a ouldier had not been uch a fool.

How many of them might there be in Florence,
Sir Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thou coward, many hundreds.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Gods end them more wit, thats eene all that I can ay: but I pray you Sir Captain, now I think ont' • perwade my Father and mother, iters and uncles, and aunts, and all the kin I have to turn ouldiers, that they may be kil'd quickly and I be their heir; I wear Captain you hould loe nothing by't, I would give you a good preent for't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Bae coward.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good Captain, what is the meaning of coward? I have often heard that word, and would fain know the true meaning of it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A coward is a fellow bae as thou,
One that doth pend his precious time in loth,
Cares not what alterations kingdomes have,
So he at home may welter in his pleaures;
A fellow that had rather it all day
Drinking tobacco, and carouing cups,
Then die his word in blood of enemies.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVhy then Captain, in faith I am a very coward; tis better by half then a ouldier, I know there is far more pleaure in a glas of good wine and a pipe of true Varines, then in bullets whizzing about ones ears, and pikes or halberts, or what you will abeating out ones teeth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Thou dunghil wretch.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Seignior Captain, be not angry, for I vow I mean earnet, I hould never diget the ouldiery
life, nor am I ure wood Flametta, and the Gods help them that do.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.p: Thou earthen-minded lave, tis pity thou houldet eat or drink that hat no better thoughts,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not as long as I pay for't; what the Devil have I to do with your ouldery Sir Captain? give me leave to be of my own mind, and a Coward; for i'me ure no wie man but wood ay as I do, let thoe follow your wars that are aweary of their lives.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.p: Thou art as dunghil a minded Racal as ere I heard in my life; I would not for any thing thou wat a Spaniard, thou wouldt be a lander to the whole Nation. And Villain, I tell thee if thou wert one, I would kill thee; Mattemores would do it, and o I leave it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Farewel my Sir Don, go hang your elf, what have I to do with your wars tro? for nothing would I venter to fight but Flametta, and for her I durt not exceed about it fifty Cuffs, or about with a little pair of Cudgels at the mot: I hould never endure to hoot off a Gun, not I, the very noie of it would make me endanger my Breeches,

Brunetto, honet Brunetto, how dot do? be merry man, this time will have an end man, and till it come be as jovial as thou cant, thou wouldt ene a ble ••
thy elf to a een how I vext the patience of my Lord Barbarin.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: You have not ure.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Marry but I have, and to the purpoe too.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: Then you are undone Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why man?

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: The Duke has left him and the Lord Machavil governours till his return,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Devil he has.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.p: Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Troth then I am but little better I fear.
Thats he,
Lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Brunetto, I am und • n, thy Trappolin mut to the Jayle, pray you my mall friends give me leave to peake but one word, Remember me to my ugar-candy Flametta.
Away with him.
To prion with the aucy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.l: I came to Mantoa to ayde the Duke
My Uncle gaint his foes the Florentines,
Where hearing every man to praie the beauty
Of weet Prudentia, the report did win me;
Being taken in the wars, I was not ad,
Becaue I was to go where he did live:
But eeing o many Princes all deirous
To marry her, I knew the great Duke never
Would betow her on Savoyes econd Son.
And therefore yet I have concealed my elf;
Nor doth he know I am Horatio:
For want of opportunity I yet
Could nere o much as igh within her hearing.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: The Lady Iabella, by her picture,
May be uppoed to be a matchles fair one;
Each feature of her face is wondrous good,
And her fine head of hair's a curious colour.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: In her we hall be happy all, for he
The world reports hath equal to her forme
A noble and a vertuous mind; Whoe that?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He is your brothers prioner, called Brunetto,
That in the wars of Mantoa was took.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Tis a handome man.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: And thought by all the Court a Gentleman
Of good decent, but he hath not dicloed
His parentage to any.

sp.speaker: Prude.
sp.l: Why doth he not?

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: That no man knows yet beides himelf.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: How melancholy he doth eem?

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He hath good caue for it Madam:
Who can be merry in Captivity?

sp.speaker: Pruden.
sp.l: Tis true;
A Gentleman of good decent uppo'd,
I never aw a man of braver Carriage,
Nor one that pleas'd me better then he doth;
Aha!

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Why igh you Madam?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: To think of fortune; perhaps this prioner
Is of a houe as good as the Medices,
Hath lived before the wars of Mantua,
In all the happines you could deire,
And now we ee him thus.

sp.speaker: Hipol.
sp.l: Methinks I hear him igh.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: And o do I.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: But with how ad a gate?
Methinks I am not as I was before.
Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Preethee go tune my Lute, I have a mind
To ing a little, I hall forget to play
If I o eldome ue it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I go Madam.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I have ent her hence that I might earch my heart,
For ure it is not as it lately was;
It is o full of thoughts, I cannot find
The free acces into it I had wont:
What hould the reaon be, what have I don
To breed this alteration? nothing I,
Ere I came here I felt my elf as free
From this trange—what it is I cannot tell,
The place is not bewitched ure, nor have
I een ought but this haples prioner.
'Alas poor Gentleman, (for in his looks
And in his carriage I can gues him uch)
How little to the fates art thou beholding
To let thee live a prioner thus? how now!
What i't I ay, talk of Brunetto? Oh,
I am in Love, the Gods will have it o.

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Barbarino, Machavil, Mattemores, and Officers leading Trappolin after them.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: This man, Lord Machavil, is one of thoe
That doth in Florence nourih vice, he is
A pander, one that if he ees a tranger,
Straight makes acquaintance with him, for what end
Your elf may gues; o he may gain thereby
He would betray our daughters, lead our ons
To Brothels, vicious and full of rottennes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I wonder how the Divel he came to know any thing that I did.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: This writing yeternight was preented to me:
Here you may ee what enormities he is guilty of.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: His Lordhip would hew himelf a great hater of bawdery.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Tis good we did examine him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And there is not uch a coward in Tucany; He's able to corrupt an army.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Seignior Captain, never fear it, for I nere mean to come into one.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Bring him before us.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Ah that I durt tell my Lords Excellence why
he deals thus with me, tis for a wench, and yet how eager he is againt bawdery.

sp.speaker: Offic.
sp.p: Forward Trappolin, go before their Excellencies.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Sirra, this paper doth not onely hew
You are a rogue, your looks declare you one,
Thou hat as ill a face as ere I aw.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: And yet Flametta think't as good as his,
I did not lie and if I aid a better.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Ere we come to his pandarime, I'le examine him about other matters;
Sir, do you never ue to carry pitols about you?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sometimes and pleae your Excellence I do.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Write down that Notarie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: What does your Lordhip mean, I did not teal them.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I know well enough what I do; irra, you went to hoot ome body.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beeech your Honour to take me along with you, I mean money.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: That's vain, then Notarie tear it out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Do you nere carry other armes neither?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Many times my Lord.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Nota • ie down with it, he hall be talk'd with for that.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Honour is deceivd agen, I mean onely armes upon eales, or cutchions from the Heralds.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: This is nothing Notarie, tear it out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: A pimp I'me ure he is.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Do you never carry no Love Letters, as from a Gentleman to a Lady, or a Gentlewoman to a Cavalier, or o?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: O very oft my Lord.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: Do you o indeed? Notarie write it down.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Honour mut undertand me, Letters of Love, of friendhip, as when a Lady writes unto her brother at Siena, a wife to her husband at Pia, a on to his mother at uch a place, a father to his daughter married at uch a town, I am often hired, and carry them to the Pot.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Notarie, you mut tear out this too.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: But irra, to come nearer to the matter,
Do you not keep intelligence with Whores?
Have you nere plaid the Ruffian? by your means
Hath no man been provided of a lodging?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: This I have no excue for, the whole city knowes me a pimp.
And that it is very nigh my living.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: What ay you irra?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My Lords, I am but a poor fellow, and mut live.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: By Bawdery?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Tis but a friends part.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: A wicked ones, Notarie down with this at large.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Alas my Lord, what hurt is it, if I help a Gentleman to a ound wench, where is there any fault? good your Honours, conider me, think not I am a man alone in this buines, that many others live by it as well as I.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What an impudency is this?
Not onely to do ill, but to defend it,
Is a trangreion exceeds forgivenes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Good my Lord take pity on me, wel a day what hould I do!
I have not onely done a favour in it for my elf, but alo a courteie for many a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Do not teare out that, Notarie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beeech your Honours let him tear't out.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: What hall we do with this villain?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Why let's hang him and ther's an end of him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: That's true I faith, conider my Lords, that never man was put to death for uch a matter, but rather that they have been beloved, and well paid by noble men and cavalieres.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: Had we not bet to condemn him to the Gallies? or lets banih hm.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: I that's the bet.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beeech your Honours pity me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: After to morrow, Trappolin, if thou be't een in Florence thou halt die, be hang'd; we banih thee for term of life, therefore prepare againt to morrow to be gone.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Pray your Honours.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Notarie, write down he's banih't.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: You rogue, it is irrevocable, and therefore make you ready.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I think I am the firt man that ever was banih't for uch a matter; were all of my profesion in
the City erved o, I think we hould make an Army Royal of us.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: This matter is concluded, Trappolin;
Go eek your fortune. My Lord Machavil;
We may depart.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: Thou man of durt, hadt thou a Souldier been,
This banihment had never been pronounc'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: But Sir Captain, I fear I hould have been kil'd, which is wore.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: If for thy Country, t' had been a noble death.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I had rather live Cap. then die nobly.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: Thou man compos'd of and, in vain I pend
My breath to talk with uch a lave as thou;
Go and be hang'd, for • o thou do dot deerve,
And might I judge thee, it hould be thy end.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Thou brazen-headed Coxcomb, may't thou go to the divel with a Drum before thee; I had as leeve be banih't out of my Country and walk in peace, as be out on't in the wars.
Brunetto, O Brunetto, I mut leave thee, I mut be gone Man to morrow, farewell Florence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter Trappolin?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why, I have banih't the Lord Barberino, and the Lord Machavil.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: How! you banih't them?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
They have banihed me, or I them, 'tis all one, I mut be gone, and the divel a bit a mony I have: hall I help thee to a Wench Brunetto? Or if thou
hat no mind to one, know't thou any body that has? I'de fain be earning a little mony.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I wih thee well, live honet Trappolin,
And o thou halt be ure to proper better;
This Ring I give thee, ell it, and the mony
Spend to maintain thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Honet Brunetto, faith
An ere I can I will requite thee fully;
Farewell, I mut alo take my leave
Of my Flametta we hall cry together
Like unto School Boys that are to be whipt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Alas poor imple Trappolin, I pity
Thy fortune, yet 'tis better far then mine;
Of all mankind I am mot mierable,
And lead a life would make a oul prove mortal,
Yet do I not repine: Mot dear Prudentia,
I never can endure enough for thee,
So that at lat I may attain my wihes:
There's not a grief mankind did ever uffer
Nor pain, I would not pas to make thee mine;
Thou art the Centre of my wihes, all
Horatio's thoughts upon thy beauty fall.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: O Heavens, be merciful, and if I tell
Him I am his, let him ay he is mine
I have a fire within my breat mut out,
Longer I cannot hide it, if he now
Do's not wooe me, I hall olicite him.
How ad a pace he walks? how melancholy
Do's he look? Love compels us unto things
In others we would corn; I'le peak unto him,
Becaue I fear he dares not unto me.
Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Divinet Lady.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I thought a Gentleman (for o I gues you)
Could have endured affliction better far,
That in the wars durt venter o his peron.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mot Excellent Princes, many thouand men
Can uffer well the dangers of a battel,
But there are few or none at all that can
Bear out the paions of a mind afflicted.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Then you are dicontent: Alas, you long for
Your liberty, and (truth) I cannot blame you.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Then hould I hate my elf, being a lave to one
Whom I deire evermore to erve.
Ye that command the detinies of men,
Now let me die, and if I hall not proper:
Know, Noblet Lady, that the prioner
That peaks unto you is a Prince by birth;
I am Horatio, econd on unto
The Duke of Savoy, and the Piemondt Prince;
At Mantoa the fame of your perfections
Captiv'd my oul, and when that I was took,
I did account my elf a happy man,
Being to go where you did live; I know,
Mot dearet Princes, that I am unworthy
So great a happines as is your love;
Yet if you deny me, witnes heaven,
I never will return unto Turin,
But here die languihing for your refual.
The Duke my father oon would pay my ranom,
But thraldom for your ake I have eteemed
Above liberty and pleaures of a Court.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My thanks, mot gracious heavens—Brunetto is
A Prince, mot worthy brave Horatio,
I corn to dally with my happines,
Like ome that love to counterfeit their joys;
Know I do love thee dear as my own oul,
And that if thou hadt now been ilent, I
My heart unto thee had dicloed, live happy,
And if it in my power lies thou halt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Doubt, fear, depaire be gone, I am a man
That envy not the bleed lives of Kings;
Now he hath dain'd to ay thee happy words,
I care not though all mankind threaten me.
Mot excellent and mercifullet Lady,
Y'ave raied me to a joy beyond my thoughts,
May all the Gods requite you for this goodnes,
And I wear out my life to do you ervice.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My dear Horatio enough, I doubt not
Thy affections equal unto mine; we will
Love while we live, and may we dye forgotten
When we do ceae to love, ay I not well?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Admired Princes, you out-peak me much,
But never hall out-love me.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Heavens be kind,
And make us in two bodyes have one mind.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
THis banih't life is very doleful, I walk I know not whither, and every tep I go Flametta comes into my mind, I think how he cried when we parted, and wore that he would go too, and certainly o he wood, if I had not told her he was not baniht, and might not. Farwel my true Flametta; and the Divel take the two curvy Lords Barbarino, and Machavil, for Captain Mattemores he is a pratling ae; but by my concience, he could nere ha turn'd me looe for uch a matter. Farwel my draughts of Montefiacone and Bologna Sauages, me thinks this is a very melancholy place: I have not een a living body thee two houres, but they had wings, or four legs: let me bethink me whither to betake my elf; for in Tucany tay I mut not, Ide to Rome and turn Frier if I had any Latine in me; there is nothing of Millain or Naples, without I mean to turn ouldier for one dinner a day. Farwel all my good uppers I was wont to have, the wenches I helpt Gentlemen to: Venice, I that's the likeliet place of all, and there I'le follow my own trade, I love to be fingring of Mons, and Polax Ryals, well then I'le to Venice, and turn pimpe; it is a good gainful life in Italy, full
of eae and pleaure, epecially if the fleh be young and handome. Methinks I hear a buling in yon trees, I hope it be not a thief; for then I hall loe the ring Brunetto gave me, and may go hang my elf. Yon's an old man, an he be one I care not, for ure I hall be good enough for him.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Son, you are baniht, I know all the matter.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Tis true, old friend, I am indeed; but how the Divel came you to know it?

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Why the Divel told me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Alas that ere I was born! I pray you father conjurer do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Son Trappolin, I am o far from hurting thee, that thee I do intend to make a Prince.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I pray you pardon me father conjurer, I have no mind to domineer or wagger in hell.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: You undertand me not, thou halt return to Florence.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And be hang'd there for my labour.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Be honoured there, and be uppos'd the Duke,
Who now in Milain is about his wife.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Faith if you can bring this about, father conjurer; I hould laugh indeed; but uppoe it could be done, when his Highnes comes
Woe be to my neck.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: No fear at all, leave all to me, and but remember what I ay and thou art afe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Faith I know not what to think of this; but
Conjurers can do much.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I'le do it never doubt, come near to me, within this circle go, and do not fear though thou eet divels skip about thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Father Conjurer farewel, I had rather live in banihment then ee the Divel.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Thou illy fellow do not fear, in this
Myriades of fiends dare not, nor can they hurt thee;
Here thou halt tand as afe from any danger
As ever thou didt yet in any place.
Think't thou I have o little power over pirits,
As they dare diobey what I command?
Tell me thy wih, and if thou hat it not,
Before thy face I'le ink away with fear.
Give me thy hand and come.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Father conjurer, I faith I wih nothing more then what you have promied me already; could that be done I need nere be a pander agen.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Why do you tay?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Shall I be afe?

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: As free from peril as you can deire.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Why then I'le venter, being for uch a matter;
But honet father Conjurer, if for fear I chance
To die, let not your divels take my body.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Come, do not fear at all, there is no need.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I will venter, but I pray you let not the divels come too near me.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: You that below frequent the Stygian lake,
And in Cocytus waves do bathe yourelves,
You that upon the trands of Phlegetov
Do ue to walk, attend unto my charmes,
Appear, I charge thee to appear, thou fiend,
Thou that over mans head power hat, appear
Eo thou pirit come,—

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Good father conjurer
Let not the Divels be too ugly, let
I play the loven and annoy your noe.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Fear not.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Honet Mater Counjurer, yonder comes your Divel, pray you circle me once more, for I'me afraid he'l be too bold with me.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Not all the fiends that are in hell can do
The leat annoyance to thee, Trappolin:
Thou art afe, and o believe thou art, come Eo
Give me that hat unchanted.

sp.speaker: Eo.
sp.l: Here it is,
Command me ought ele.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: No, vanih now:
Son Trap. oberve me well, this hat
Keep alwaies on thy head, 'tis Eo cald,
One of the things will make thee thought a Prince.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Tis none of the handomet, mine's of a better block, I think ome Naples Devil made it, tis o high crownd, • one that aw me in this would rather think me a fool then a duke.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Meo thou pirit of magick glas appear,
I charge thee in dread Plutoes name to come;

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: More Devils yet! is the Circle ure, Father Conjurer? and t' be not I pray you take an order with it, I have no mind at all to venter my elf againt the Devil.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Have I not told thee thou art afe? fear not,

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yonder's another Devil I think of M • ran, for he brings a looking glas with him.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Deliver it, be gone.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thank you for it, (beworn) for in good earnet father Conjurer I would have as little the company of your Devils as is poible.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: But before I give you this mirrour (Sonne)
Receive this powder by Magick art compos'd,
And ecret pells; he upon whom thou flinget it
(It hath uch hidden vertue in it) will
Be took by all for Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For me?

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Yes certainly for thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Say you o? why then I faith with all my heart: Give it me, I wear unto you (old father) the very bet man in Tuskany hall be Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Here put it up and keep it afe.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And I do not hang me.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.p: Now are you ready for the looking glas?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am very ready indeed.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Son Trappolin, this looking gla • was wrought
In the deep Caverns of the dark Abye, I
Compos'd of the mud of Phlegeton,
And with the blood of tortur'd Micreants,
It is a Mirrour I have tudied long
And now have brought unto perfection:
This upon thee I do betow, a gift
Such as the Crowns of Emperours could not buy.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And yet Father Conjurer, I have een half a dozen better old for a pitol.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: They were the works of mortalls: When thou hat
A cloke Ile give thee two: but look in this
And thou halt ee thy elf the Duke; and if,
When he returnes agen, thou meetet him
(But throw the powder on him firt) and he
Begins to rage, bid him look in't, and it
Will hew him the reflexion of thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Say you o? why then give me the glas.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Here, tand till, I will now raie up the fiend
That hath the Cloke which I have promied thee.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Father Conjurer, as you love your on Trappolin, give me another
Circle or two, for I promie you I fear this almot worne out,

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Still thou dot fear; be bold and confident,
Hell cannot hurt thee as thou tandt.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Why then let him come.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: In Proerpin's dread name our Soveraign Queen,
Thus by th • croat of this enchanted Wand
I do command thee fiend unto this place.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
No more Father Conjurer, hold, here comes the Devil, he's a Taylor in hell ure, for he brings
a cloke.

sp.speaker: Areo.
sp.l: Thou againt whom fierce Cerberus dares not bark,
Here is the Cloke, which, to obey thy will,
We (that thy ervants are) have made.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Tis well:
Be gone, I licence thy depart; this Cloke,
Son Trappolin, doth perfect thee the Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I know not, but on my concience the pooret of his Highnes ervants near wore a wore, it eems to me to have been made of thee mierable thefts of a beggerly Taylor, t'is of o many Colours; and for the fahion of it (by your leave Father Conjurer) tis very clownih, and omething inclining to the fools fahion.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Thy words, Son Trappolin, are vain. Thoe Counts
And Marquees that wagger it in Gold,
Shall not appear o glorious to the eyes
Of men as thou in this.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Father Conjurer, Ile be rul'd by you, put on.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Thou art the great Duke now in hew, the wiet
Judgements will believe thee o, now take the glas and ee thy elf in't.

sp.speaker: Trap.
