sp.l: Beeech your Highnes pardon me, I am
A poor ubject of yours, for a mall matter
Banih't by envious Lords.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Why Trappolin what folly is this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Beworne to you Father I thought I aw his
Highnes, and was a begging to be pardoned:

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Away with ignorance, twas thy Reflexion,
As thou didt eem unto thy elf, o thou
Shalt likewie to the world appear; now mark me,
Not one of thee can make thee like the Duke;
They altogether do: nere leave them off
Without thou art ecure, for one but miing
Thou wilt appear thy elf: The Hat is cald
After the Devills name that brought it, Eo,
The Looking Glas Meo, the Cloke Areo,
And there are fiends within them.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Father Conjurer, I thank you for your kindnes, take all your ware agen; carry o many Devills about me? o I hall be ure to be carried to the Devil by um.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Supect no hurt, they can as well detroy
Their immortality as do thee harm.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why then (honet father Conjurer) Ile venter my elf among them, but I wear unto you if they begin to tir Ile ene fling them all away without more a do.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: Farewell on Trappolin, return to Florence,
And flourih in the pleaures of the court:
Other affairs command me to be gone,
Give me thy hand; farewell on Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Be not o haty (my dear old father) one word before you go: how hall I ay, that I bring not my Dutchee with me, but come alone?

sp.speaker: Mago
sp.l: Why any thing, what you will.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Ile make um believe then that I licenced her
to tay as long as he pleaes, and that I came alone to ee how they governed in my abence.

sp.speaker: Mago.
sp.l: 'Twill do, now have you done with me?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have: I thank you for all your things here, fare you well honet father Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Now Trappolin is no more Trappolin,
What I am in my glas I'le look again:
The great Duke, ha! tis well, 'tis very well;
This curvy Cloak doth eem his gallant one,
And this bae Hat his Highnes Beaver; my face,
My body, leggs and all eem changed; I faith
The Conjurer is a wondrous learned fellow.
You coundril Lords that banih't me, I'le make
Sport with your curvy Honors, that I will.
Eo, Meo, and Areo attend
Unt • your offices well, and guard your friend.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Sforza the Duke of Milain, Hortentia the Dutches, Iabella his iter, Lavinio the great Duke with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Mot noble brother (for o the Temple Rites
Of Hymen done do licence me to call you)
Honour our entertainment one half hour
Longer, and we will leave you with your Bride.

sp.speaker: Lavinio.
sp.l: Great Prince, the glories you have done me here
I leave to future Chronicles to tell,
And till you do increae them; ure no man
In Milain ever did receive uch honours;
You always hall command me.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Sir, we deerve no complements, we have
Our wihes, if you but ret atisfied
Of our good meaning.

sp.speaker: Lavinio.
sp.l: Mot gracious Madam, the Roman Emperours
Would have wondred at your Court had they but known it:
Which of them all would not have blet his fates
For the fruition of o rich a Beauty,
As is the matchles Lady Iabella?

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: Sir, of your own you may ay what you pleae,
But I am ure you over-praie me much.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Dearet of all the world, thou dot deerve
Princes and Poets both to peak thy worth.
Bles'd be the powers divine, that me of all
Mankind did chue to make mot fortunate,
In giving me the glory of the earth.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: Sit down mot noble brother, from your Bride
We will not part you: iter, this place is yours;
So let them now begin.

div.stage: Enter Hymen, Luna, Mars, Mercury, Jupiter, Venus, Saturn, Sol, after Muick.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: Hither we are decended from above,
To gratulate your nobly grounded love;
That you mot worthy happy paire hould know
The Gods themelves are pleas'd with what you do.
Me you have honoured, and to honour you,
I have brought the Deities along, which do
Command and rule the dayes, that they may bles
You all the year with plenteous happines.
May Tucanes Cities boat of Milains Spoue;
And future Ages, when they would compoe
One grac'd with all the vertues, her expres
To be a Lady like this Milanes.
And may the mot ingenious Florentines,
Your Citizens (Great Duke) buie their minds
In writing, and in inging Marriage-ongs,
Delectable Epithalamiums.
While you do live love ever, and may you
Continually your generous heats renew.
Thus Hymen wihes, and it will go hard
If what a god ays gods do not regard.
Thus I could pend the night, but that would prove
A wrong unto my Rites and to your love.

div.stage: Here they dance, and Hymen leads it.

sp.speaker: Luna.
sp.l: Cinthia I am, that with my borrowed light
Out-hine the Stars, and do command the night:
Many a time, when ele I vail'd would ride,
I will appear to ee you with your Bride.
Lamps nor wax lights you hall not need, for I
Intead of them will ever more be by.
And may you in this life you have begun,
Equal in love me and Endymion.

sp.speaker: Mars.
sp.l: Though my apect be fierce, and wars preage,
To you they hall be uch as Lovers wage
Sweet kies, oft embraces, and uch things
As amorous Queens enjoy and amorous Kings.
You therefore without pity both may fight
Battailes, not full of danger but delight:
And may they lat until I part you two;
Which I do promie I will never do.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hermes I am, Maja's wing'd Son, and hine
Among the Planets in a Globe of mine:
And though 'tis true I favour thefts and leights,
Yet will do none t' diminih your delights.
Love therefore, laugh and kis, embrace, and be
Secure, nothing can hurt you without me;
And if I ever do, may I forgo
My Sphere, and live among the fiends below.

sp.speaker: Iupit.
sp.l: Of all the Gods and Goddees I am
The mot upreme, and bear the chiefet name
For Love what is it that I have not done
To bring my wihes to concluion?
I for my elf have done no more then I
Will do for you, to make you live in joy.
Therefore mot happy pair of Lovers, fear
Nothing, ince Iove himelf doth hold you dear;
Live merrily, and let this be your mover,
That Iupiter himelf was once a Lover.

lg.l: Since in my Orbe I hined fair,
And Lovers did befriend,
(The morning and the evening Star)
I never could commend
(Heaven bleed paire) none like to you,
Whom time hall never make untrue.
May Heperus and Veper loe
Their lights, fair Venus fall;
If all her power he doth not ue
To proper you withal.
May other Dieties grant you life,
I'le make you loving man and wife.

sp.speaker: Sat.
sp.l: Though I am old and rigid in apect,
And cold and youthful ports do not affect;
And though my influences many ways
Advere to others be, and cros their days:
For you, heaven-loved pair, my elf I'le force,
And run a milder and a gentler coure;
His ancient cutome Saturne will forget,
Rie for your pleaures, for your pleaures et.
Doubt me not therefore, for my vow is trong,
That for your akes again I wih me young.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: Phoebus I am, the glorious guide of day,
That all the Planets lighten with my ray:
I am the brightome, lightome Charioter
That heaven and earth adorn within my Sphere;
And know what 'tis to be in love ince I
Followed my Daphne, who from me did flie.
May I loe all my glory, all my Beams
Fall like my Phaeton int' Ocean treams,
If all my faculties I do not try
To make you live in joy, and love in joy.
In Summer time when you int' Arbors go,
I will not hine to trouble you below,
Will onely peep to ee you kis and mile,
To make me think, this I have done ere while.
In Winter eaon when the Frot doth tay,
And hinder Rivers to go on their way;
When flakes of Snow do cover earths green face,
I for your akes will thaw off both apace.
In pleaures evermore you hall accord;
Apollo cannot falifie his word.

div.stage: Here they dance another dance which Hymen leads.

sp.speaker: Hym.
sp.l: The gracious Planets which command the days
By powerful influences, you have heard
To bles you both according to their ways,
Vowing to be your keepers and your guard.
Them for your akes with me I brought along,
That they might proper you as well as I,
Becaue this marriage knot I'de tye o trong,
That it there nothing ever hould untie.
You whom the heavens will proper all your life,
You whom on earth ther's nothing can offend,
Mot happy pair, mot happy man and wife,
Your lives in love wear out and in love end.
Nor hall a Poet hired for his gain,
Vpon your Tomb a feigned vere engrave;
Mens tongues and tears hall make you both remain
Above the power of an Epitaph.
But may you live till you aweary be,
Not of your elves, but of thee earthly ports;
And the eternal joys above would ee,
Which ever are in joves immortal Courts.
Thus unto you do gods their wihes give,
And unto them may you according live.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: I think, Hortentia, now the Mask is done,
Our brother gladly would go to his ret.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: And it is time, mot noble brother, when
You pleae we will attend you to your Chamber,
And iter, we will ee you laid in bed;
Methinks it is a very pretty thing
To ee a Virgin bluh, look pale and bluh.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: 'Tis port to others, to the Maid 'tis none.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Mot excellent, Princes when you pleae let's go,
For now each minute is as tedious to me
As years have been, o much I do deire
The chat embraces of my matchles Spoue.

sp.speaker: Sfor.
sp.l: And worthy friend, let us entreat your tay
As long in Milain as is poible;
You cannot be in Florence more beloved,
Nor by the better nor the meaner ort.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What I can do you know you may command
Unto my utmot power.

sp.speaker: Hort.
sp.l: Lights.

sp.speaker: Lavi.
sp.l: My fairet, dearet love, your hand, this part
Of happines makes me uppoe the ret.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Thoe lazy times that do degenerate minds,
And breed new thoughts in mot Heroick hearts,
By noble pirits are to be abhor'd,
And lothed as the ruine of their ouls.
Whilt I did follow the Triumphant War
Through fire and blood, I was a happy man;
I thought no pleaure was a parallel
To the loud cry of mortal wounded foes:
But now I am transformed from my elf,
Hipolita hath charm'd me with a look;
May I but hear her peak, how I rejoyce
M ay I but hear her ing, I think me blet.
O how my heart's ahamed of my tongue,
W hich never until now effeminate thoughts
C ould win upon. O would to heaven this Lady
W ere but a man, and circled round with death,
That I might kill her, and releae my elf:
Or were he like the Warlike Amazon,
VVith whom renowned Theeus did contend,
That with my honour I might challenge her
For an enchanter, and a witch. How fondly
And foolihly I rave! tronget reolutions
A womans powerful beauty doth detroy;
He that can conjure men, unpeople towns,
Cover the ea with Fleets, drink rivers dry
VVith armed quadrons he conducts to fight,
VVhom potent monarchs fear, and Emperors wih
To make their friend, a Ladies mile, or eye
Subdues above reitance, and makes die.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mot dearet worthiet Princes, I am blet
Above the proudet of my former wihes;
Your love to me was like a thing deired,
But far from expectation: as men
Forlorn and wretched, being content to die,
And ure to uffer, wih to live, although,
They fully do depair of life; of late
Even o was it with me, I lov'd you
Above my lives expreion, but did ever
Depair the bleednes of uch an honour.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My dear Horatio, I cannot peak
So well as you, but I can love as truly.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A trange dicovery! I will retire
More cloe and hear the ret.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And <…> Sir,
Becaue I know my brother the Great Duke
Will not at all, or carce allow this match,
I will with you whenoever you command
Leave Florence, and what fortune it hall pleae
The Gods to end us, bear with cheerfulnes.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Excellent merciful Prudentia,
I mut pray Heaven make you a full requital,
For I hall ever be unable.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: I cannot tay longer with you now, at our next meating I'le cloy you with my company. A kis.
sp.l: Farewel my hearts bet pleaure.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Let others travel Italy all over,
To talk of uch a City, uch a place:
Go to magnificent and holy Rome,
Once the ole Empres of the conquered world;

To Venice
• i • h, commanding, politick;
Unto weet Naples plenteous in Nobility;
Unto great Milain; unto at Bologna,
Civil Ferrara, Arriotoes town,
Strong-walled Padua which Antenor built
The Trojan Prince, and Titus Livius fames
For his nativity and epulchre;
To ubtile Burgamo, mot highly honoured
For neer relation to Tarquato Tao;
To proud and •• a • ely Genua renown'd
Worthy Varona, old Catulius city;
Bloody Peruggin, warlike Beia,
Glorious Man • ua, Virgilius Maro's birth-place,
Good Rimini, iron Pitoya,
Fine languag'd Siena, and indutrious Luca,
Odd-humor'd Forly, honet old Ravenna,
Ill-aired Simegallia, Capua
Effeminate and amorous, wherein
The Carthaginian Captains Souldiers were
Spoil'd and debauch'd with pleaures; Pia hanging,
Pearo a garden of bet fruits, Ancona
Prays'd for the Port Loyal, and true Urbino,
Round Acoli long Recanati, built
Upon a teep hills lage, Foligno full
Of ugry treets, among the Ap • nnine,
Faro for handome women mot extold,
And Modena happiet of them all
From beauteous comely Florence when I part
Without Prudentia, thunder trike my heart.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A gallant reolution; for the man
I cannot blame him, but the Princes, he
To look o low, and dote upon a • ive,
Seems very trange, and full of wonder to me.
Had Dolphian Oracles, ever ador'd
For uttering truth, poke this, I hould have doubted:
She whom we thought? Saint •• pattern for Nunnes,
Thus to forget her elf, it doth amaze me.
O women, I could rage againt the ex!
And lov'd I not Hipoli • a I wo • ld.
She cannot hear me, and I needs mut peak
A word or two, they are all fale and fickle all,
The poyon of mens happines, within
(Though they are fair without) mot full of in.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Good morrow Captain Mattemores.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: How do you Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Honours humble lave, I am well, but ad;
And o had all the Court good caue to be,
Did they but know o much as I.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why Captain,
What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'le not be ilent for her Honours ake;
Prudentia the Princes is in Love,
With whom do you uppo • e my Lords?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I think with none, for we all know, he yet
Hath lighted Modena's and Parma's Duke,
And eem'd careles of mankind.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Alas!
She were mot happy were it one of them:
It is Brunetto he's in love withall.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Impoible!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: It is a thing mot true, my eies and eares
Have een and heard it, while I tood uneen.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: You amaze us.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: It is a thing I never hould have thought,
Though pent my life in fond imaginations.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: As I have een an amorons cloud receive
A tately hil into her lovely breat,
And of his lofty head our eyes bereave,
And eem to lull his ences unto ret:
So did the corneful Lady daign to leave
All her majetick tate, and ore oppret
With inward flames, her eager armes he cat
About his neck, kit and embrac't him fat.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Wonders.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: How the Great Duke will rage?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And do you not my Lords in time prevent them,
They'l teal away I fear, for o he vow'd,
When he but aid the word he wood.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: By his imprionment we'l hinder that.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Here is the man we pake of.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: For the Princes honour let us keep it cloe
As poible we can. You of the guard.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Seie on Brunetto, carry him to prion,
Bid Puchannello keep him afe,
Tis our pleaures.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: What violence is this? O had I been uffered to wear a word, ome of you hould pay dearly for it

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: My Lords, you have done wiely to prevent
So great a dihonour as might have enu'd
Tainted the family of the Medices,
And been a lating orrow to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: His Highnes is returned.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: Great Sir, upon our knees we welcome you;
You come unlookt for, we did not expect
This happy time o oon by fourteen dayes.
Where is our Dutches?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Dutches will not come till the Gods know when, for I do not, I have gin her leave to tay as long as he will, but beworne I fear you have governed but •• rvily in my abence I hear that you have baniht an honet poor man cal'd Trappolin is it true?

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes he deerv'd no les.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why what hurt had he done, had he knockt any body oth the head?
What was his fault?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He was a pander, and corrupted youth.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You lie Sirra not panders but whores do that, and not they neither if they be ound: banih one of my ubjects for uch a matter? beides were there no more in Florence but he?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Be not dipleaed we humbly pray your Highnes,
For we did think we did it for the bet.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I wonder at our Duke in this.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Well, I am very weary, I left all my train behind with my wife, and rid as fat as I could drive that I might come unlookt for the better to ee now you behav'd your elves, which you have done
bad enough. When I was almot at Florence a aucy Varlet rob'd me and tole my hore from me, o that I was beholding to my leggs to bring me hihither. Barberino and Machavil come you hither both of you.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: What is your Highnes pleaure?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra Barberino hold by Mach's breeches, and toop, for on thy back I will ride to my Palace.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Ile go fetch a Coach for your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Devil take your Coaches, toop I ay without more ado: where is your obedience?

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.p: I think the Duke's run mad, or foxt oundly at the leat I know not what to think of this.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You Sirra Don, run by my ide, upply my Lackeys office, wonder not but obey.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: There is no remedy: heaven be merciful, I think his Highnes run mad for fear when he was robd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Now on and do not loyter:
Thus like the Roman Emperours will I ride
To triumph through Florence; tumble not you had bet,
Chariots them carried, a Tucan Noble me; mine is the tarelier and the braver way;
Eo, Meo and Areo thanks.

sp.speaker: Matte.
sp.l: He jeers us and micalls us.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: On apace,
That I may quickly be in my Palace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: UNto the man enthral'd black and obcure
Is the clear beauty of the brightet day;
Through Iron Grates he only ees the light,
And thereby doth increae his miery;
Thoe whom he doth perceive in joy to pas
Augment his wretchednes, by making him
To think that thus I lately was my elf:
But admirablet Lady of the world,
Divine Prudentia, may I die abhor'd
By all mankind, if I repine at all,
Seeing for thy ake I do uffer this;
The exquiitet tortures curious inventions make,
For thee I would think ports, and undergo;
Mayt thou live happily and free from care,
And all my mieries of no moment are.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Eo, Meo and Areo, faith you are all brave Devils all on you, and my father Conjurer an excellent fellow; I love to ee my elf, Meo thou art not the work of Moran; No, the Duke himelf I eem. I now mut learn to walk in tate, and peak proudly, Ile play uch tricks with my Lord banihers, hall make me port enough: banih a poor
man for doing courteies! it is againt the law of friendhip, I am uppo'd a Prince, the Florentines acknowledge me the great Duke; what ever I do tho never o bad paeth with approbation: poor Trappolin turn'd Duke! tis very trange, but very true;
sp.l: Would the fates favour panders in this wie,
He were a fool beworn would not turne pimp,
Seeing Pandors Dukes become, he is an ae
That may hav't will let the office pas.
sp.p: O me Brunetto, alas for thee man! how camt thou there? I think in my heart an there be a michief in the world thou wilt be at one end orother on't,
sp.l: So ho Pucchanello, Pucchanello!

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: Who calls:

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: That do I Sirra, let me Brunetto out preently, and bid him come to me.

sp.speaker: Pucch.
sp.l: Your Highnes pleaure hall be done.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Alas poor Brunetto! marl what he has done to be lockt in uch a place, I think in my concience tis not for any Lechery, for I could never get him to't, and many a time I have offered him many a good bit: Brunetto to come into the Jayle! I cannot tell what to think of it, but be't for what it will out he goes; my good friend Brunetto who gave me a Ring hall not lie there;
sp.l: Honet Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Great Prince:

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: He makes a very low leg, but I will not be out-gone in courteie;
Dearet Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Your Highnes doth forget your elf exceedingly, I am your prioner.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My bet friend good Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Beeech your Highnes to remember your elf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: So I do but never mut forget thee. I am glad to ee thee in good health, dear Brunetto.

p.U: hall fall to the ground even now in this alutation; beeech your Highnes, I am your prioner, your lave.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am thy ervant Brunento.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Wonders! I am atonihed; upon my humble knees I do congratulate your afe and peedy return.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And upon my knees I do embrace thee Brunetto, thou art an honet man my mot weet Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I know not what to think, nor what to peak;
Beeech your Highnes rie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Not without thee, up Brunetto, honet Brunetto up I ay.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Beeech your Highnes, I am your humble lave.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I am thy ervant Brunetto, and as long as thou liet on the ground o will I too; up therefore, let us rie and talk, away with your complements; I cannot abide them, up I ay, lets rie; thou halt
not tay I wear.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I am amazed, by force I mut obey: Great Sir, I know not what to think, you honour me above all expreion.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Honour a fig, I love thee Brunetto, thou art a good honet fellow, I love thee with all my heart: Complement with me, and I will be very angry; without more ado I tell thee I love thee. Puchanello o ho!
Sirra Puchanello, bring two chairs hither preently.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Away with Highnes, I ay away with it, call me Lavin Duke, plain Medices, I cannot abide your Highnes, your Excellency, your Worhip. I hate uch idle limflams, dear Brunetto, how I love thee I faith I do with al my heart, and if I lie unto thee I would I might be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Sure I am awake, this is no dream.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: We will live merrily together, I faith we will Brunetto, how glad I am to ee thee in health! come Sirra, what a while ha you been a bringing a couple of chairs! et them here Sirra and be gone.

p.U: it thee down, it down man I ay.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I will attend your Highnes on my knees.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why I am not thy Father, am I? leave fooling and it thee down, that we may talk together, it thee here I will have it o,

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I am atoniht, I humbly pray your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Pray me no praying, but it thee down, it thee here man.
Brunetto be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: On the right hand, I know not what to think

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am omething aweary Brunetto, and will not not it without thee, therefore I pray thee make me tand no longer; obey, me for I am the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mora.
sp.l: Here then o pleae your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why an thou wilt have it there, there let it be, but I am mitook thats on the left hand, what do you think me a clown and without breeding, that I ha no more manners in me? for hame of the world, it thee down Brunetto, it thee down & without more bidding, without thou wilt ha me lie on the ground, for I am o weary I can cant tand.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: There is no remedy, I mut obey.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: So, well done, it till man, what art doing, art afraid of me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What does your Highnes mean?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Marry and thou drawt back Ile draw back too; Brunetto it thee till and let us talk.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I will obey your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Highnes me no more highnes, I cannot abide it, my name is Lavin, call me Lavin Duke, and tis enough a concience.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Great Sir, I am far unworthy of thee honors,
The noblet Florentines would be mot proud
To be thus graced by their Prince.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I like not thee et peeches neither, let us talk as we were companions in a Tavern together, and notafter the Court fahion, I am as weary of it as a
Dog, I am Brunetto; prithee man how cam't thou into the Gaol?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: O pardon me Dread Soveraign.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: On thy knees man? what meanet thou by this, dot take me for Mahomet? as well as I can pardon thee I do, any thing what ere it be, though thou hat kil'd every body; rie therefore I ay Brunetto, and et thee in thyplace again or Ile kneel too.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mot merciful Prince, hear me before, let you
Repent your kindnes towards me afterward.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Up I ay Brunetto, up, I pardon thee any thing, upon condition thou wilt rie and it thee down.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: It is your Highnes will.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Now good Brunetto without any fear (for I wear unto thee I do not care what thou hat done, and forgive thee whatoever it be) tell me the caue.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Dread Soveraign, I was for love put in.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Who put thee in?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Your Highnes Governors, Lord Barberino, and Lord Machavil.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: They are a couple of Coxcombs for their pains; who art in love withal?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: O pardon me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sit till or I will not, and if thou dot I will.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Your Highnes Excellent iter—O great Prince!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Sit till Brunetto, wat thou laid up for that?
Alas for thee, hat thou married her?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: So pleae you Highnes no.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It doth neither pleae my Highnes nor Lownes neither, I wo'd thou hadt, and that's all the hurt I wih thee: co ldt thou think I that loved thee o would be angry with thee for this, hat thou her conent?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am very glad of it, and I here give thee mine too: prethee Brunetto do me the favour to go and bid Barberino or Machavil come to me, I'le end for my iter preently, and if he ays o to me, I'le oon have you married.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: You Highnes hall command me to my death,
More willingly unto my life, for o
This buines doth importt; he heavens be praied,
And ever be propitious to you, bles you
According to your own and my deires.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: This Brunetto is a good honet fellow, and hath always behaved himelf very well, and whatoever he be I'le give him Prudentia for the Ring he gave me, I will not be ungrateful; he aid he was in love with my iter, and if he had them all, I wo'd een ay much good do his heart with them but he means the Princes, and though I have little to do with her, yet if I can give her him I will, Brunetto's Ring I hall never forget.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Your Highnes pleaure.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My Highnes pleaure, Sirra Lord, is, that you go and tell my iter Prudentia I would peak with her preently, I will expect her here: be gone.

The Dukes life is very pleaant, I take great content in it, and were it not for one thing I were mot happy, which is, I dare not dicloe my elf to my dear Flametta, for he is a woman, and full of title tatle as the ret are; nor if I could win her without making my elf known, durt I lye with her, by reaon of putting off Eo, Meo, and Areo; otherwie ure I hould get her; for ure he would not refue a Duke.

sp.speaker: Flametta.
sp.l: Here is the Duke alone, whom I o long
Have ought for to petition for the repeal
Of my dear Trappolin. Great Prince, as low
As truet humility can make a Suitor;
Before you I protrate my elf; Mot excellent
And merciful Sir, pitty a loving Maid,
Who is bereaved of her joys; I beg
Poor banih't Trappolin might be recalled,
Whom (when your Highnes was to Milain gone,)
Was by thoe cruel Lords whom you did leave
Our Governors, ent into banihment.
Great Duke, you that have noble thoughts, and ure
A heart full of commieration,
Kill me not with a cruel hard denial.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ah Eo, Meo, and Areo, hinder me! I mut counterfeit with her; fair Maiden rie.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: O let me kneel (Great Sir) until you ay
My Trappolin hall be repeal'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Rie I ay, & we will talk of it; I cannot abide to ee any body kneel unles they are in the Church that have leggs to tand on: how may I call you Maiden?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: So pleae your Highnes, my name is Flametta.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Mris. Flametta, I ay give me your hand, rie without more ado, rie without you mean to ay your Beads over; Mris. Flametta be rul'd, good Mris. Flametta be rul'd, wo'd I were hanged i • ever Trappoline come home and you get not up; up I ay therefore.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I mut be mot rude.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Why that's well done Mris. Flametta: Trappolin for whom you are a petitioner, young Mitris, is banih't you ay, for what it matters not, tell me what you'l give for his repeal.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Even any thing I have, all that I have.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Are you a Virgin? tell me true, if you are not it is no wonder beworn, it is more wonder by the half if you are, for I think there be not two of your age in the City that be.

sp.speaker: Flain.
sp.l: May I not proper in my wihes Sir,
If I be not a Maid.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And will you give your Maidenhead to have him recal'd from banihment?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: To him when he comes home, and we are married.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Well aid Mitres, But tell me now what will you give me for to have him come home?—

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Even any thing I have.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am a great man, and like them, will not do favours for nothing; will you give me your Shoos?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: My Shoos! your Highnes jets.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I wear unto you (Mitris) but I do not, and if you do not give me what I ask (how ridiculous oever it eems to you) Trappolin nere comes in Florence again.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I wonder at the Duke, but will obey him;
Here are my hooes dear Prince.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Well done I ay, but I mut have your Stockings too off with them therefore without any more arguing.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: My Stockings with all my heart to have my Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Very well done Mrs Flam. you do very well, give me your gown too; Do not wonder, thee will do nothing without it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Then hall your Highnes have it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I ee you love that fellow well, 'tis well done of you, I think he be an honet man, which makes me the willinger to yield to his repeal; I ay I mut have that Petticote too, ele all this is not worth a ruh i'faith.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I think the Duke's mad—And will you give me then your Highnes word?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I cannot help it, here it is.

p.U: wear unto thee, young Wench, give me thy under Petticote and thy Smock, and I will give thee my word, and end for him preently to night • this Wench makes me cure Eo, Meo, and Areo.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Mot excellent Sir, there is not in the world
The thing that in my power lies I wo'd
Deny to do for my dear Trappolin,
But modety forbids me to do this.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I beeech your Highnes pardon me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I am very orry I could not ee her naked, but it cannot be help't; well how many kies wil you give me my young Mitris?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Kies?
Mot Gracious Prince, a thouand and a thouand times.
I'le kis your hand upon my humble knees.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have no pleaure in that: how many kies upon lips will you give me?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: For Trappolins ake, I'le do any thing that modety will give me leave; do what you pleae Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ah honey weet Flametta, how I love thee prithee kis better: dear lips! I could almot wih Eo, M • o, and Areo i'th' fire; again, again, again, weet Flametta.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Shall Trappolin come home?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Do but let us kis, and thou halt have any thing.
O me! what a miery 'tis to be a great man? again, again Flametta, Trappolin hall come home.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I am aweary.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: So hall I never be; again, again.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: The Princes, your Highnes iter:
You have gin your word.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Young Mitres, I have not leiure to anwer you now, come to me ome other time, and I'le talk with you further: now take up your things and be gone.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I am aur'd I hall prevail: heavens guard your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Now I expect my brothers rage, for ure
(Though nere o ecret kept) my Love unto
My dearet Horatio by ome uncouth means
Is known: ay what he will, or can, I am
Reolv'd, and my affection's etled.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Fair Lady, come hither, you are my iter, are you?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I am your iter and ervant Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Complement with me no more then I complement with you; good Madam iter it you down, I would talk with you a little.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.p: He talkes as though he were ditracted. I obey you Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Tis well done, good Lady iter.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I never aw my brother thus before;
Sir, I am exceeding glad to ee you
sp.p: Return'd in afety out of Lombardy; but hould have been more joyful had you brought your Dutches with you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: She'l come oon enough nere fear't; but iter, I mut be omething brief, for I am a hungry; as oon as I came home I aw Brunetto in the Gaol, who after many circumtances and fears, told me 'twas for love of you that he was put there; tell me iter Prudentia, do you love him? I'le beworn the man is a good honet fellow, if you have a mind to him I'le give you my conent with al my heart: I vow as I am an honet man, and the Duke, I do not jet.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Mot worthy brother, thanks; I do confes
I love Brunetto, and were very guilty
Of cruelty if I did not; for he
Loves me I know as his own happines:
Nor, Sir, have I plac'd my affections
Unworthy; Brunetto is a Prince,
His name is Horatio, and he's econd on
Unto the Duke of Savoy; for my ake
He chang'd his name and lives a prioner.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: How's this! is Brunetto a Prince? you love him Lady iter you ay.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Mot truely Sir I do.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Are you content to marry him?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I do deire no greater blis on earth,
So that your Highnes will conent thereto.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Lady iter, here is my hand, I am content i'faith, without more words I am.
• am an hungry now, and would be brief, iter mine I ay marry him when you will, behrew my heart and I be not content;
I had rather you had him then any man in the world.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I know not what to think, he's trangely chang'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Let this uffice Madam iter; I am very hungry I ay, have you any good tore of meat in the houe? I could eat oundly now iter of a dih of Sauages: come Lady iter, lets to dinner, be gone, I have a good tomach as I am an honet man.

sp.speaker: Mat,
sp.l: I that have led a life until of late
In pite of death, pas'd through the dangers of it
Dreadles without regard; whom never men
Conducted by brave Captains to the field,
Did yet withtand, am won and vanquihed:
Hipolita, heroick Amazon,
In Love hath conquered me with amorous miles;
Methinks it is a thing mot full of wonder,
That what not maie pikes, nor murtherous guns
Could ever do, a Ladies miling eyes,
The beauty of a timorous woman hould;
Her eyes have darted fire into my breat,
Which nothing but her kindnes can extinguih,
And be he cruel I hall oon be ahes.
Do I thus yield? hall I forget the ound
Of martial Drums, the warlike noie of Trumpets,
To lit to the lacivious harmony
Of intruments touched by Hipolita's hand?
Shall I forget the ordering of a Camp,
To ride great hores, to beiege a city,
To undermine a Catle, to raie Bulwarks,
All for the love of a fair fearful woman?
It mut be o; thee legs that wont to lead
Arm'd men to battel, I mut ue in dances:
This hair that us'd to be covered with a helm,
Cloggy with weat and blood, I now mut powder:
Thee hands that wont to wave a dreadful word,
Intead of iron gauntlets now mut wear
Perfum'd gloves: I that had wont to be
Under the Chirurgions hands to cure my wounds,
Mut have a barber now to keep me neat:
O Love! thou art divine, and cant transform
A man from what he was: it is in vain
To think to hun the thing thou dot contrain.

lg.head: I.
lg.l: Tis idlenes that is the caue
We loe our liberties:
The buie Cupid never drawes
To yield unto his vice.
Away with love, it is a thing
I hope I nere hall know;
When many weep o I hall ing,
Have joy while they have woe.
The happines of love is poor,
Compar'd to liberty;
Blet lovers do hard things endure,
Their pleaures to enjoy.
May I live ever as I do
Free from that foolih pain;
I wih that no man may me woo,
Until I love again.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Heavens, is thus her mind compos'd! if I
Can win this Lady, it will be a conquet
Deerves a Trophie far above my bet
Of Victories, I will go trie her: hail
Glory of Italy, compar'd to whom
The fam'd Egyptian Queen would yield, weet Lady,
Mot excellent Hipolita vouchafe
To hear me tell your conquet and my foile;
Whom the Great Dukes greatet foes could never vanquih,
Your powerful beauty hath; know Mattemores,
(Whoe valour Spain not only doth report,
But Mantoa hath prov'd your matchles eyes
Trancendents of the brightet lightet tars)
Have wounded fatally unto the heart,
Unles you prove as kind as you are fair.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Do you jet with me Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: My hearts delight, weet centre of my thoughts,
I vow by your rich beauty, if my heart
Could peak, it would agree full with my tongue,
I would tell my lover more then I can expres.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: What ill fortune, good Seignior, you have had,
To fall in Love with one deerves it not,
Nor doth not care for you? and I do hope
I nere hall bear affection unto man.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Patience ait me mightily; not all
The murtherous canon bullets I have heard
Fly buzzing by my ears, nor dimal cries
Of dying ouldiers, nor the horrid noie
Of rough tempetuous eas have ever mov'd me,
Onely your harh unkind reply hath truck
Unto my very oul.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I cannot help it;
Had you now, Captain been abroad it'h field,
This nere had happened to you; and to cure you
The field will be the bet; go to the wars,
Buie your elf in fights, and you will oon
Forget you ever aw Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Mot cruel fair one, be aur'd that ere
I would forget you (which I know's a thing
For me impoible to do) I would
Into oblivion cat my bet of pleaures,
Even all my pleaures, I would forget to ue
My word, and all the Militarie cience;
Witnes triumphant Son of Iove, Great Mars,
I vow by all the Honours of a ouldier
I love thee dear as mine own heart, but this
Admirable Lady much above it:
Nor do I dipleae thee in't, I know that thou
Preferd't the embraces of the Cyprian Queen
Above the glorious battels of the field.
Therefore (dear Lady) be mot confident
While I have memory, above all things,
Your beauty will be fixed in't.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Good Seignior,
Trouble me not to anwer you agen;
Let this uffice, I wih you lik'd me not,
Becaue I neither would have you nor any
To love a woman will not return affection.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: O Heavens!
Will you continue thus obdurate ever?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Alwaies believe it Captain.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I have not patience to contain my elf;
An angry cloud full fraught with thunder bolts
Work't by the Cyclops on Campagnia's Stithy,
Now hanging ore my head, menacing death,
Preaging peedy ad detruction,
Could not compel my ilence, 'tis decreed
By my advere malignant tars that I
Shall die detroy'd by a fair cruel woman;
Which ere I do, I will a little eae
My troubled heart of woe: heare merciles woman:
(Whom I do cure becaue I love o dearly)
Hear me, and afterwards go glory that
Your wondrous beauty, and your avage heart
Hath made a man ditracted, kild a ouldier.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A Captain and be thus mov'd by a womans refual!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sweetet Hipolita, be merciful, and ave
His life that honours you above the world.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Pray you Seignior be anwered.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: You are reolv'd then to ruine me:
Curs'd be thoe battels all that I have fought
And conquer'd in, t'had been more honour for me
To have been lain by my incened foes
Which were brave ouldiers, then to die in peace
By the unkindnes of a proud fair woman.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Beeech you leave your rage, and leave me Captain.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: More cruel then Hyrcanian Tigers, hear
Me take my leave before I go.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Thou God of love, and if thou art a God
Revenge thy elf and thy wrong'd deity
On this unmerciful Lady; make her fall
In love with the baet of all mankind,
A man o full of ignorance, that he
In hape alone may differ from a beat,
Not know that he is fair and light her beauty;
And he himelf the mot deformed thing
That ever burthened our mother earth
With his unworthy teps: Cupid attend,
And yield unto my jut requet; make this
Lady run mad for uch a monter, hed
A thouand thouand tears upon her knees,
While he tands laughing at her: may you die
Raging for love, Hipolita as I.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I do begin to pity him; ure I never
Shall have a man to love me better, and though
I once intended alwaies to live ingle,
His words have altered my reolution:
Nor, if I take him, hall I do a thing
Will misbecome me, for he is a man
High in the Great Dukes favour. Noble Captain,
It is your happy fate to conquer alwaies;
I vow unto you by my honour, I think
Mot eriouly, no man upon the earth
Beides you could have won; I'me the lat
Of all your victories, Theeus like you have
Overcome Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And will you love me then?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I do and alwaies will.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Blet be the tars that hin'd at my nativity,
I want words to expres my joyes; but dearet Lady,
My weet Hipolita, my forward actions
Shall make you know my heart above my tongue;
I am a ouldier, and was never wont
To peak amorouly.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: You have aid enough.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Love is but thought by words, by deeds tis known;
Shew me you love me, and let words alone.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Worthiet of Ladies, when I ceae to do
All that I can, then may your love ceae too.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: HE cannot counterfeit o much.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I know not,
But if he do not urely he is mad;
What wild phantatick things he does, and talks
Of Eo, Meo, and Areo, names
Unheard i'th the Court before!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Some Milain Counts
I warrant you he means by them.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The tranget thing of all is the releae
Of Brunetto, and his extraordinary love unto him,
Whom he hath caued richly to be clothed.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And ueth him as if he were his better.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yonder's the man we talk of; what a change
We ee! A prioner but lately lockt up afe,
And now to be the wonder of the Court.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Next Eo, Meo, and Areo, the Duke
Doth wear he loveth me; but who thoe are
I cannot tell nor learn: my Lords, good day,
Saw you his Highnes lately?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: No ir.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: You peak as tho you were dipleaed.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: We are not well contented Sir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: The Duke is noble, utter your grievances to him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So we will Sir.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: And now Sir,
Know worthy Prince we are your loyal ubjects,
And what we ay is for your honour.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: If it be for my honour Ile hear you,
But be as brief as you will.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your Highnes hath lately releaed Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Tis a thing very certain.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: We doubt not but done out of clemency,
Not knowing why he lay there.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Well, why was he put there?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: Even for your Honour ake (mot Gracious Sir) The Lady Prudentia your iter loves him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Say you o? So ho Puchanello, So ho!

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His Highnes; come hither preently.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Bid the guard enter.
You ay Brunetto was put in prion becaue my iter lov'd him, you think it good and fitting he were there again.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes, yes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Puchanello take me thee two Coxcombly Lords into your Cutody; they are never well but when they are banihing ome body, or doing ome michief or other: Brunetto was laid in prion becaue my iter lov'd him, and lay me thee there
becaue I love them.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Beeech your Highnes not to deal o hardly
With us whom you have known o faithful to you.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Puchanello, away with them I ay: you of the Guard ee them in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Mot worthy Prince be merciful, if we
Have done amis twas out of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra rogue away with them, or Ile lay up you too.

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: Your Honours mut have patience and walk.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The heavens be merciful to Florence;
VVhat ill malignant tarre hath o depriv'd
Our wie and noble Duke of all his reaon,
That he remembers not who are his friends?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The Gods be ever mot propitious;
Great Sir, unto you, and continue long
Your life, chief honour of the Medices.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Prince Horatio I am your ervant, I pray you forgive me my calling of you by your nick-name of Brunetto; my iter hath told me you are the Son of the Duke of Savoy, beworn unto you I am very orry I have not ued you as befitted you, but it was your fault that told me not who you were: I have talked with Prudentia, and he loves you he aies, which I am glad on, and Ile marry you as oon as you will

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Sir, it is true I am Horatio,
Son of the Piemond Prince; but being his econd,
I durt not think me worthy of uch honours
As your Highnes hath do ne me; and therefore told
None but your beauteous iter who I was.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Enough my friend; and Prince Horatio,
Could you uppoe I would deny my iter,
Though he were made of Gold and precious tones,
Unto your Highnes, and to uch a friend?
You do deerve a better wife then he;
She's not half good enough for you, and if
I had another iter, you hould have them both.
My friend a Prince! I'm very glad i' faith,
But orry that I did not know you uch,
That I might have done you right: wood I were hang'd
If you are not far a better man then I.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Great Prince, you do forget your elf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your Highnes mut pardon me, I do remember my elf well enough, yet Eo, Meo, aad Areo, have made me omething proudih, but howoever I am your ervant, Prince Horat. i' faith I am your very dutiful ervant: how a you now, the Duke of Savoyes on! i' faith I am your poor ervant Lavin the Duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I am amaz'd; he's mad:
Beeech your Highnes leave, I pray you Sir.

div.stage: Enter Mattemores the Spanih Captain with petitioners.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: What have we here now, do's the Captain bring us Morris-dancers? what lobs are thee tro?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So pleae your Highnes, being importun'd much thee I have brought before you, that you might, do jutice.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Captain Mattemores, jutice I'le do with all my heart, but execution let do who will for me.

sp.speaker: Calfshead.
sp.l: Great Duke of Tucany, vouchafe to hear me,
For what I peak is out of concience;
This fellow Mr. Bulfleh a Butcher, I aw
Verily with mine own eyes even yeternight
(When he was drunk) to kill my man, which he
Swore was good Beef, and he would ell it dear.

sp.speaker: Bulf.
sp.p: Sirra Puritan you are a bae coundrel, was not I drunk in your company to make you merry?

sp.speaker: Calfes.
sp.p: But Mr. Bulfleh, you do know, and that full well, that I praied you on my knees for your own ouls ake to drink no more, and profe'd to you that it was a great abominable in in you to fox your elf, or be foxed.

sp.speaker: Bulfleh.
sp.p: Goodman Calfeshead, you are a bae curvie Companion; do you not know that for your ake I killed your man, (yet I meant but only to beat him oundly) becaue he pour'd not the wine into your Codpiece? did not I do it out of friendhip unto you? did I not you puritan you, and you to complain? O the ingratitude of Puritans!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Peace both of you. Mater Puritan hold your tongue I ay: wil not Calfeshead be drunk Bulfleh?

sp.speaker: Bulf.
sp.p:
So pleae your Highnes no, he will let a man
ooner hang him then make him drunk; Beides, he is a fellow of trange opinions, and hath ent his onne to Geneva, to hear Iack Calvin preach. He tole a Surples to make his Amoroa a Smock of; and hath writ a paultry Book againt the Bihops, printed at Amterdam in Decimo exto. He will lie and teal without comparion; is both for Boyes as well as Queans when he hath mony And like a true Italian Hypocrite, is for any in or michief but our Drinking.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Then know I very well how to do jutice: Mr. Calfeshead, you ay the Butcher kild your man when he was fox't, be you fox't when you will and then kill him for' •

sp.speaker: Calf.
sp.p: Heavens defend, I nere was drunk yet, and never will be.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: There is mad jutice; he doth increae my wonder.

sp.speaker: Calfs.
sp.p: Bles me, murther! I would not do it for the world.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: This is trange jutice, the Butcher doth very wel deerve to be ent into the Gallies at Ligorn.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have done with you Mr. Puritan, you may be gone to the Tavern; and Bulfleh you may get you to the Shambles as oon as you will, for I have no more to ay to either of you.
I am ready for the next; peak therefore.

sp.speaker: Barne.
sp.l: Mot excellent Prince, pity a childles father;
As yeterday my only Sonne did walk
Under an houe, this fellow Gaffer Tiler,
Who was a working on it, did fall down
Upon my on, and kil'd him with his fall.

sp.speaker: Tiler.
sp.p: Mr. Barne be not o eager, you know I bore your on no malice, and that it was a hundred to one I broke not my own neck.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: This is an eaie matter to conclude;
Friend Barn, you ay this Gaffer Tiler
Fell off a houe, and o did kill your on;
I will be very upright in my jutice,
Go you upon the houe from whence he tumbled,
(And he hall tand beneath) and fall on him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: And the Duke be not tark mad, I am to think him o.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: So I may break my own neck.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He trangely is ditracted.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Neighbour Barn, get you about your buines, for I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Barn.
sp.l: I mut have patience.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Now let me make an end with thee, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fine.
sp.l: Daign, Noble Duke, to hear my jut complaint,
I am a poor and an unfortunate widow;
This man Dick Whip, as the other day he drove
His coach, run over a little child of mine
That was playing in the treet, and kild it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Sirra Whip, is this true?

sp.speaker: Whip.
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes I confes it is.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
It doth not pleae me, nor dipleae me, for I
neither did it, nor was the child mine.

sp.speaker: Whip.
sp.p: It was againt my will, a thing of chance, Mrs. Fine cannot deny it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Mrs. Fine, you are a widow you ay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fine.
sp.l: A poor unhappy one I am.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You ay that Whip the coachman hath kil'd your child; and how he did it I have undertood.
sp.l: This is my jutice, I will do you right;

l.U: hall lie with you untill he get you another.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Madder and madder.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I cannot chooe but mile.

sp.speaker: Whip.
sp.p: Mot willingly, o pleae your Highnes I am well content to do her that atisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fine.
sp.p: You hall be hang'd firt, that you hall, is thus my expectation fail'd?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Mrs. Fine be rul'd, I will have jutice done, Whip hall lie with you; you may marry him and you will: he kil'd your child, and he hall get you another, I ay but right, and Sirra Whip look unto't, and you play the bungler and fail, you hall to Ligorn and learn to row: Mrs. Fine be contented, and you do not like him you might have held your tongue, for I know no body that ent for you, and o get you both gone.

sp.speaker: Whip.
sp.l: The Heavens preerve your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: My friend and Prince Horatio, go unto
My iter, bid her to prepare her elf,
I'le have you married within this day or two;
I long to ee you both in bed together.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mot willingly I will do uch a meage,
The Gods preerve you happily.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A trange dicovery if true.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Seignior Captain, I ay I have done very good jutice, and in a little time too, I am not like your carlet coats that will do nothing without mony; a company of fellows they are whoe beards and hearts agree not together.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your Highnes doth dipatch things very oon.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Though I am the Duke yet I love to do no hurt, as other men in authority would, I hate to banih men as Machavil and Barb. ha done: alas poor Trappolin, I hear they have baniht an honet poor man cald Trap. what the Divel Seignior Mat. came in their heads to end a poor fellow away out of his country without any money? though men may ometimes gather a reaonable Sallet abroad, he hall get no oyle to eat it withall.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Great Duke of Tucany, our noble Mater,
That Trap. of whom your Highnes peaks,
Had little fault in him, (good faith) at all
Saving he was a mot notorious coward.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Why you Don of guns or pikes, do you think every mans mind is given to the wars? Trap. was addicted to the peace, a poor fellow full of courteies; one that will never deny to do a favour for a friend I will have a little port with my Don of the wars; O me, Sir Captain, look yonder: Eo, Meo and Areo, I will put you off for a while, I
will try ome concluions.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Highnes! wher's the Duke gon I marle;
What Trappolin, art thou come again?
Faith many a wench in Florence will be glad;
Follow thy old trade, be a Pander till.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Seignior Captain I am your humble lave, and if I can do you any kindnes at any time, i'faith Don Mathemores you hall command me—and if you have but a mind to any Beauty in Florence, pay but me well for my pains, and her well for hers, and I will not fail you; and Captain I can give you a delicate poyon to dipatch any enemy with whom you dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I ee thou art reolv'd to be a rogue,
Tis pity that his Highnes did repeal thee;
Next time I ee him, irra Pimp, I will
Make uit to have you ent into Ligorn.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You Spanih coxcomb, go hang your elf, do your wort.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Wer't thou a ouldier I wood fight with thee,
Being a rogue thou dot deerve my foot;
Take this you racal.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I will preently be out of his debt—who's yonder? it is the Duke or I am deceiv'd; Eo, Meo, and Areo, on agen, my hat, my glas, and cloke, it cloe: how now irra Captain, where are your manners? what do you think of me, who am I tro? I am not your Lieutenant am I? toop and take up your hat, and let me ee if it will not become your hand as well as your head in my preence.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I did not ee your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Will you lie too? take that and learn to peak truth.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Mot Noble Prince, and my mot royal Mater,
Pardon the error which unwillingly
I have committed; in Tucany there lives not
A man that freelier for your ake would loe
His life then I.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Well, get you gone, I do
Forgive you; but my Don at armes, remember
The Duk's to be oberv'd, he is the man
That doth maintain you.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And mot worthy Prince,
Did but occaion hew it elf, I would
Venture and loe my life to do you ervice.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: And my Father Conjurer would come into Florence, I would make him the next man unto my Highnes; he is a good man, and it is great pity that he hould go to the Divel, as they ay Conjurers and Witches do: well, I am a brave fellow, I love to ee my elf in my glas, I am the Duke ifaith, the very Duke, I ee me.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I will go and petition him agen.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My rogue Flametta, I could kis her to pieces, bite off her lips, and uck out her eyes I love her o well.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: The great Duke of Tuskany the gracious heavens
Proper your Highnes ever, I am the ame
That lately did intreat for the repeal
Of my Beloved weetheart Trappolin:
Mot excellent Sir, pity my earnet uit,
And let me have my Trappolin recal'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: This is a very precious villain, how he loves me! and I ever marry while I am a Duke by Eo, Meo and Areo's leave I will have her,—your name little maid, is Flametta, as I remember?

sp.speaker: Flam
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes, yes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You ue to have baniht Trappolin come home?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Mot humbly, mot excellent Sir, I do.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Well 'tis all as pleae Eo, Meo and Areo, I can do nothing witho t them, and (my young Mitres) as long as they are in authority, I can do little for you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Then by your Highnes leave, do I wih Eo, Meo, and Areo in the fire.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Methinks they hould be enough in that already, for the Divel made them all; now I think well on't, ometime when I have good opportunity I will off with my things and have a little port with her: ince, fair Maid, you are o earnet for your weetheart Trappolin, he hall come home very hortly, he hall believe me, but upon condition I will do it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: On any condition except my honour Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: That he hall lie with you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Were we but married, mot willingly.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: If he gives you his oath to have you, will not that uffice?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I had rather we had married before.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You need not fear, hould he wear unto you and break his oath, I would hang him, and yet (though I nere mean to break my word with her) I faith I hould very hardly hang my elf for any thing; the rope is a very dimal thing.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Shall he come home, ay the word Noble Prince.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Well on my word he hall as oon as poibly I can, but on that condition that you will accept of him without marriage, upon his oath to have you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I ee his Highnes is mad (as every body aies) otherwie what hould ail him to talk thus? mot excellent Prince, he and I would not diagree.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Well here is my hand, he hall come home hortly, now I mut have a kis and leave you: I am very hungry, I ha been o long a doing jutice that I am very hungry, give me a bus weetheart.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Heaven bles your Highnes.

div.head: Actus quartus cena ecunda.
div.stage: Enter Lavinio the great Duke, Iabella the Dutches with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My hearts weet olace, my dear Iabella
You are mot welcome unto Florence;
Live according to your wihes happily,
And may I perih if I do not trive
In every thing to pleae you to my power;
I'm orry at my coming home I find
Such trange and unexpected alterations,
That for to quiet them I mut deprive
My elf ome houres of your company.

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: Mot Excellent Sir, I do account my elf
Mot highly blet, that am not onely married
Unto a Prince, but one that can
And doth vouchafe his love unto me, being
Defective of thoe beauties hould deerve it.
To your affairs betake you Worthy Sir,
I will expect you till your leiure erves.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You are good unto a miracle
Sweet Iabella—attend the Dutches in;
Adieu my Love, ome few but tedious minutes
Pat over I will come unto you.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I will await your leiure.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What mad fantatick humours have poet
In general the heads of the Florentines?
They have amaz'd me, peak as if I
Had been with them before my Dutchee came.

div.stage: Barbarino and Machiavil appear in prion.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You great commander of the Tucan Cities,
Pity your ubjects, and your loyal ervants;
In what we ued for we had no deign,
Neither the leat intent for to offend.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Be merciful therefore mot gracious Prince,
Let not the noblet of the Florentines
VVear out their daies and thraldom in a Prion,
Being men not long ago high in your favour.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am lot within a Labyrinrh of wonders,
I know not what to think, the chiefet of
The Florentine Nobility in prion,
And ue to me as if I had commanded
Them to this place; ure ome ill pirit hath
Poet mens minds while I was abent: do you
Know me?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Your Highnes is the Duke our Mater.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Are you not called Barb. and you
Macha. the Lords unto whom I left
The government of Tusk any in
My abence?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: We are your loyal ubjects though your prioners; and were left your Deputies when your Highnes went to Milain.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How came you there?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Great Sir, you know mot well,
At your command.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I mut be atisfied in this:

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: Who calls? whats the matter I wonder.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Releae me the Lords preently, and end them
To me hither:
The more I think of thee accidents,
The more I marvel how they come to pas;
The men whom I did leave here governours
Are prioners (and which increaeth more
Amazement in me) they ay it was I
That made them o; ome unheard malady
Unknown unto the world before it eems,
Hath infected all my ubjects with a frenzy.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: He hath chang'd his humor it eems.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.p: And may he continue in this if it be a good one.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am atonihed to ee the things
I every minute do, epecially
You two (to whom I left the weighty charge
Of rule) in prion; reolve me for heavens ake
How you came there.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sure he doth jet with us.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your Highnes is dipoed to be merry;
sp.p: You know (mot excellent Sir,) full well that none except your elf could do it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I do it?

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: He doth things in his madnes he remembers not when he's in's right ences it eems.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Florence I left a wie ingenious City;
But I have found it now at my return
Poeed with a trange unheard of madnes:
Who put you in prion? collect your wits in't order
And anwer wiely.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I vow by the properity of Tucany,
Your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Mot trange! Why did I o?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Becaue we did (mot gracious Sir) give notice
Unto you how the Princee Prudentia,
Your machles beauteous iter lov'd Brunetto.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Whom? what Brunetto!

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your prioner taken in the Mantoan warrs.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My iter o forget her elf! I am
Full of amazement: he that had refued
The youthfull Dukes of Modena and Parma,
Dote on a lave lighted by all the tarrs!
My iter alo o to loe her ences,
She that was wie, and honoured for her vertues!
Sure alo this ame trange infection
Of madnes wood ha eis'd upon my elf
If I had tayd at home. I will not now
So marvel at the common people, eeing
The mot dicreet of the Nobility,
And my own iter equally ditracted.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.p: I hope he comes to himelf again, he talks omething more wiely then of late.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: It is a frequent thing to ee a City
Mierably groan under a heavy icknes,
To have the Plague, or fierce dieaes full
Of danger, rage and even unpopulate places;
But uch a general phrenzy to poes
And to ditract all Florence, is a wonder,
A miracle unmach'd in hitorie.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: How he talks as if all we were mad, and he had done nothing!

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Are you ure you are both in your right ences?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Did once your Highnes know us o?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: VVe are as free from any ditraction
As ever yet we were ince we were born.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: You mut both of you tho give me leave to think what I know.
I • e trie an he be mad too. Cap. thee Lords ay I put them in prion, how ay you?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: So your Highnes did—he's ditracted another way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Good Gods be merciful. Why?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Becaue they poke againt Brunetto's liberty.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: He's in the ame tale;
Though they are all deprived of their ences,
They do not differ.
But why (good Cap.) anwer me a little,
Should I deire Brunetto's freedom, being
Beloved by my iter as they ay?
Wood it not be a great dihonour, think you,
Unto the Family of the Medices,
That he hould cat her elf away upon one
VVe do neither know whom, or whence he is?
I pray you Captain, if that yet you have
Any mall remnant of your wit remaining,
Reply according to it.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And he be grown wie again, Heavens be praied.
It is a certain truth your Highnes peaks,
That if your iter hould betow her elf
(Being a Princee meriting o much
For her unequal'd beauty, and her vertues)
Upon a man uch as you plea'd to mention,
It would be a great weaknes in her; but you
Your elf I heard (mot excellent Sir)
To call Brunetto Prince Horatio,
The econd Sonne unto the Duke of Savoy.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How, I call him o! truth Captain you
Have heard thee things which I did never ay.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: You never heard him call Brunetto o.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Never, this is the firt time I ever heard of it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My wonder is o great, I do want words
VVhereby to give it vent; I ee that all
My ubjects being ditracted think me mad.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: And more, o pleae your Highnes, you did end
Brunetto, whom you Prince Horatio called,
Unto your iter, to bid her prepare
Her elf; for you within a day or two
Would ee them married.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Enough,
Captain, I wear unto you by my Dukedome,
That rather I would end Brunetto (though
He were the Duke of Savoys econd on)
To have his head truck off, then on that meage
You ay I did.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: He doth remember nothing.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: If the Duke be come to his right ences again,
I beeech the Gods keep him o.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Beeech your Highnes look, let your own eyes
Be witnes of their mutual affection;
Behold the Princes your iter and Brunetto:
Let us withdraw where we may tand uneen,
And you hall hear them talk what I have aid.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Dear Lady, you have raied me to a fortune
So high, that when I look upon my elf
I am amaz'd, and wonder at your goodnes.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Mot noble Prince, let my unfeigned love
Excue the weak expreions of my tongue;
I'm glad my Brother bears o noble a mind,
As to be willing to unite our bodies
As we have done our hearts.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Not only willing, divine Prudentia,
But earnet for us; he doth eem to grieve
That two uch faithful lovers as we are
Should live o long a under.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: It is a worthy nature in him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I can contain my elf no longer: though this
Be out of madnes done I will not uffer it.
Siter!

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Live long mot worthy Brother happily.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: So hould I wih for you, bore you a mind
Deerv'd your elf.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good Heavens be kind, and do not now undo
What you have almot brought unto perfection;
I fear his m adnes that once favoured me;
Hath chang'd his mind to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I will but pend few words; are you a Son
Of the Duke of Savoys?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Your Highnes knowes I am his econd.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Whether
You are or no I care not; and if you be,
My iter once deerv'd a better husband,
And he hall rather in a Monatery
Spend all her future dayes then be your wife:
And be you what you will Sir, I will hew you
That you have wronged me, and I do not fear
The Duke of Savoy if he be your father.
Puchanello, Puchanello come hither.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I like this.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: He's wonderfully ditracted—mot worthy Brother,
Be not o much unmerciful.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Peace Prudentia, I never thought
You had o weak a reaon.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He's mad to my undoing; gracious Gods,
Soon make him leave this humour.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I hope he's come unto himelf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sirra, convey Brunetto into prion,
Lock him up cloe.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Here's do and undo—Will our Duke nere be in his
Right ences again?

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: My dear Horatio, love me till, for I
Unto thee will be contant though I die.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Though I be tortured unto death my Dear.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I know not what to think of thee alterations.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thus (but the heavens ait) I hope to bring
Int' order from confuion every thing.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: THe Duke is come home, and therefore my hardet part is behind; Father Conjurer and you be not my friend now I am undone; Eo, Meo, and Areo it you all cloe and loe not a jot of your vertue: happen what will as oon as I meet him his Highnes, I will try the vertue of my powder on him, let him take it how he pleae.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Here is my brother, I will try him, perhaps
He may have chang'd his ullen humor now,
And et the Prince Horatio at liberty.
Mot excellent noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My dear iter, how dot thou do? why look you o ad, ha you got the green icknes to night with lying alone? and you have I will take an order for your cure very hortly, and to your liking too, I'le have you married within thee two days at the furthet.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Married Sir! unto whom?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Unto my friend your lover, Prince Horatio

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: I am glad of this: Alas Sir, why then have you
Made him a cloe unhappy prioner?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I ee the Duke hath met with him:
You do deceive your elf Lady iter, indeed
You do put up my friend in prion? heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Sir, pardon me for peaking truth, I heard
When you commanded it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Siter mine, if I did I was drunk, and now I am ober I will let him out. Sirra Pucchanello, o ho.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: May he continue always in this vein
Of kindnes; thus his madnes is not grievous.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Madam iter, I am very orry I was uch a beat as in my drink to commit uch a fault; I pray you forgive me.

sp.speaker: Pucch.
sp.l: What is your Highnes will?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It is that you et Prince Horatio at liberty, and end him hither preently.

sp.speaker: Pucch.
sp.l: I wonder—mot willingly.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: You are a gracious Prince, and the high Gods
Will recompence your pity unto lovers.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: What a Swine was I do uch a thing! I am ahamed as often as I think on't, I hall be ahamed to look on my friend; iter, you mut pray him to forgive me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Sir, trouble not your elf, and be aur'd,
Unles you part us, you can never do
Offence either unto the Prince or me.

sp.speaker: Hora,
sp.p: It eems his mind is changed, the heavens be praied.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Prince Horatio, an you do not forgive me my locking of you in prion, I hall never be merry again; I did it when I was drunk, and my iter knows that as oon as he told me on't, I ent for you; I pray you therefore forgive me good Prince Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Mot excellent Sir, I was a man unworthy
Of this weet Ladies love, did I not freely.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thank you i'faith Prince Horatio with all my heart I wear unto you, here take you my iter, take her by the hand, lead her whether you will, and do what you will unto her with her conent: I am very orry I parted you o long; I know Lovers would be private, though they do nothing but talk, therefore I will not hinder you: fare you well both my Princely friend and Lady iter.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: The Gods preerve you.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And reward your goodnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Thus what the Duke doth I will undo—uch excues will erve my turn well enough.
Here are my Lord banihers, it eems the Duke hath et them at liberty, but in they go again as ure as the cloaks on their backs.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: May the good angels that attend upon
Princes on earth, defend your Highnes always
From every offenive thing.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.l: And may you live
A long and happy life, enlarge your tate,
Excel in fame the firt great Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Your good wihes I like, but credit me my Lord Banihers, neither of you. Who let you out of prion?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He's mad as ere he was—your Highnes Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You lye Sir: Pucchanello come hither quickly.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.l: Heavens be merciful, we mut in again I ee.
He do's and undo's, and remembers nothing.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra Rogue, why did you et thee two at liberty?

sp.speaker: Pucc.
sp.l: Your Highnes did command it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: If our Duke mut be mad, the Gods grant him
That which he had the lat.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You ill-fac'd racal you lie.

sp.speaker: Pucc.
sp.l: Beeech your Highnes remember your elf, it
Was at your command.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It may be o, but I am ure I was drunk then, and now I am ober they hall in again; therefore take them with you, be gone I ay.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.p: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Macc.
sp.p: Good gods pitty Florence.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Eo, Meo, and Areo, thanks i'faith yet I am uppos'd the Duke, Father Conjurer, by thy Art I am uppos'd a Prince; tick to me till and be my friend.
Here is the Dutches! Eo, Meo, and Areo, be true to me, and I'le have a kis or two at the leat.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Sir you are fortunately met.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Who are you Lady Madam?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Do you not know Sir?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I'de have you tell me.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I never knew him o before, I am your Wife.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I'me glad on't I promie you, come and kis me then.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: You are wondrous merrily dipoed.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Madam Dutches I am omething jovial indeed, I have been a drinking Montefiacone very hard, kis me again my dear Lady wife.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: He's drunk.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You are a handome woman I promie you: prethee tell me my Lady Dutches, am I a proper handome fellow?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: Do not jet with me Sir, you know you are
Him whom above the world I do eteem.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Well aid my Ladie wife.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I nere aw him o ditempered before.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Have you nothing yet in your belly?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: You know I am with child Sir.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Faith but I do not, for your belly wells not.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: I am full of wonder.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Lady wife get you in, I am halfe drunk, and now am unfit for you, but give me a kis or two
before,—Madam Dutches fare you wel.

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: I had thought he had not been addicted to
A vice o loathome as drunkennes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Yet all happens very well; protet the Dutches is a gallant woman, I almot like her as well as Flametta; I could lie with her and I woo'd, but I am half honet, and will not wrong the Duke nor Flametta. Why is not my wench as good as he? wherein do they differ, but onely in clothes? Flametta's a woman as right as he, and perhaps naked as handome: what good in the night do jewels and fine clothes to a woman when he hath them not on? beworn I am very merry; Eo Meo and Areo are brave tame Devils, and my Father Conjurer an excellent learned fellow.

l.hi: Trivigi tripes, and a Venice wench in bed.

lg.l: YE glorious Plannets that do rightly guide
The giddy hips upon the Ocean waves,
If ome of your malignant influences
Have rais'd this madnes in my ubjects heads,
Let ome of your benigne influences,
Again retore them to their former ences:
Thoe Florentines whom all their enemies
Could not impeach, could not withtand in armes,
Suffer not, you immortal powers divine,
Thus to be ruin'd, by ditraction.

sp.stage: Machavil and Barbarino appear in prion.
sp.p: I am atonihed, O Heavens, I know not what to think!
Puchanello, Puchanello, let me out the two Lords, and end them to me preently, I'le talk unto um here at large.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: His ill fit's off.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The goods be praied.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I do not think that ince the infancy
And firt creation of the world, a madnes
Petiferous and equal unto this
Was ever known; good Heavens reveal (and oon)
The caue, that I may do my bet to help it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Long may this fit continue.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: If it hold alwaies, ure he's in's wits agen.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: I wonder, Lords, and jutly, that you whom I have known to have the noblet judgements, hould thus become ditracted; you in your fits of frenzie run to prion of your elves,
And think I ent you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Mot royal Sir, we grieve to ee thee daies;
You did command us thither.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Your Highnes elf.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You are both deceiv'd; to do uch idle errours,
And lay the blame on me doth more amaze me.
Puchanello how came thee in prion?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes, you were angry with them
And did commit them.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I commit them?
That thou art mad is not o great a wonder;
I tell you both with orrow, witnes heaven,
You are trangely bereav'd of your reaon.
Well, go ye in, and pray unto the Gods
That they hereafter would be kind unto you
And keep you from relape.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Heavens bles your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And be unto you a perpetual guard.

sp.speaker: Lav.
