sp.l: Famine, plague, war, the ruinous intruments
Wherewith the incened dieties do punih
Weak mankind for mideeds, had they all fallen
Upon this city, it had been a thing
To be lamented but not wondred at.
O my dear Iabella! I have brought thee
From Milain flourihing in all delights,
Into a city full of men ditracted.

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: He is not ober yet. Go in and leep Sir,
You do not well thus to bewray your weaknes
Unto the publick view.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My wife and all! O heavens!

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: What ay you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My Iabella, thou hat caue to cure me
For bringing thee into a place infected:
The aire is ure petiferous, and I wonder
Now how I have ecaped.

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: Good Sir, I pray you leep.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wherefore my Iabella?

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: Why you have drunk too much.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Madnes unmatch'd!
Dear Iabella, withdraw thy elf into
Thy chamber, I will preently come to thee,
There we will pray unto the angry Gods
That they would from's remove this heavy ill.

sp.speaker: Iab.
sp.l: I will obey you Sir to get you home;
Good Gods nere let him thus offend again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What have I done o much offenive to
The upreme powers, that they hould punih me
Not onely with the madnes of my ubjects,
But the ditraction of my wife and iter!
What do I ee? they do embrace and kis:
My iters madnes will undo her, how
He came at liberty I marvel much;
sp.p: Whom I would have to lie in prion, walke in freedome, and whom I would have in freedome run of themelves to prion.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Mot noble Brother.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Siter, I grieve to ee thee thus.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Excellent Prince!

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sure the good Angels that had wont to guard
The Medices in all their actions,
Have for the horrid ins of Florence left us,
And fled to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: His mind again is altered.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Dear brother, do not frown and look o angry.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Peace ister, I'me aham'd to hear you peak,
Each word you ay is poyon in my eares.

sp.speaker: Puchanello,
sp.l: Jailor.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I mut again to prion, fickle fortune,
How oon a happy man thou maket wretched

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Sirra, why did you et this man Brunetto,
Or this Horatio (I know not what to call him,)
At liberty?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Will he nere be wie! your Highnes bade me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I! Bethink you, and anwer truly.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Your Highnes knowes I durt not for my life
Ha don't without your licence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Sweet Brother.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Silence would become you better far.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Life of my heart, do not diturb your elf,
I am unworthy you hould peak for me.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Sirra, take him again, and look to him better then you have; your madnes hall not excue you, if once more you erve me thus.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I mut be patient: good Heavens, oone alter this ullen fit into his former kindnes:
sp.l: Farewel my weet Prudentia.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I wonder Brother, what pleaure you take
In croing me after this ort.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: It is in vain to anwer frantick people.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I, I am mad, 'tis your pervernes makes me.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: YEt I cannot meet with the Duke, I long to ee him look like me, I would fain powder his Highnes. Eo, Meo and Areo, I thank you faith, my hat, my glas, and cloke; honet Father Conjurer, I will love thee while I live.
Hel's broke looe again, I do what the Duke undoes, and he undoes what I do.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Long live your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And happily.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Amen I ay; but how my mall friends came you hither? I thought you had been under lock & key.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I fear he's ill as ere he was.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra Puchanello, o ho, o ho! come hither you rogue.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We mut in again.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Good Gods, will this frenzie never leave him!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
Goodman durty-face, why did you not keep
me thee in prion till I bid you let them out?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: So pleae your Highnes o I did.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Dare you lie o boldly? you take me for a Doctor, Gracian of Franckolin I warrant you, or a fool in a play, you'r o awcy with me.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Good Gods!

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Was ever heard the like?

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Beeech your Highnes to remember your elf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Now I bethink my elf, perhaps I might do it when I was drunk; if I did bid you give them their liberty it was when I was fox't, and now I am ober lay them up agin; walk my good Lord Banihers, your Honours know the way.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: Will this humour never leave him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: We mut endure it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: There is no remedy.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My Lord Prioners get you gone, I am an hungry and cannot tand to hear any upplication.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.l: You mut obey my Lords.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yet all goes well, all goes exceeding well;
My wil's obey'd, I am uppos'd the Duke;
My hat my glas and cloak retain their force,
And Father Conjurer does not forake me.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Mattemoros the Spanih Captain olus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: THough horrid War, thou bear't a bloody word,
And marchet o're the world in dreadful arms;
Though fearful mankind on their humble knees,
Beeech the Gods to keep thee from their homes,
Yet art thou (when trick'd up in dimall robes,
Preaging death and ruine to a State)
More lovely to a valiant ouldiers eyes,
Then are the pleaures of a wanton Court.
And ure if our great Duke Lavinio
Had been i'th field expecting of a foe,
He nere had been ditracted as he is:
'Tis peace that doth bewitch us from our elves,
Fills mot Heroick hearts with amorous toyes,
But for Hipolita's ake I mut not peak
Any thing ill of Love; Love I mut ay
Is good, but war leads the more noble way.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How do you Captain?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am your Highnes creature.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Saw you not lately Barbar or Maccha?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Highnes knows in prion.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: O heavens, in prion again! Good gods, when will you remove this frenzy from the Florentines?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I ee there is little hope on him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why are they in prion?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Becaue your Highnes did command.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: Never, Captain, I never did command it; go and bid Pucchanello let them out.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Sir, he dares not at my bidding.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Here take my Ring and do't.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: One humor in the morning, and another in the afternoon, will it never be better?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wo'd I did know what hainous in it is
I have commited that is o offenive
Unto the Gods to caue this punihment,
That I might ue unto them for forgivenes,
And they be reconcil'd and pitty Florence.
I'm f • ll, and full of wonder; perhaps ome fiend,
Permitted by the heavens, aume's my hape,
And what I do undoth; was ever known
Such a ditraction in the world before?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: At lat I have found him.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: This the Impotor is that hath deceiv'd
The eyes of all, it can be nothing ele.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p:
I vow and wear I am omething afraid, but
will be bold; Eo, Meo and Areo, it cloe, come out powder, come out, father Conjurer I rely on your powder;
Take that for my ake.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: What rudenes is this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have don't i'faith, Trap. I have repealed thee for Flametta's ake.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: How is this?
If thou art a fiend, the gracious heavens be kind,
And give a period to thy wild proceedings;
But if thou art a Conjurer, I'le have thee
Burnt for thy Magick, as thou dot deerve.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Trappolin talk wiely.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Why dot thou call me o?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Aha! A man forget himelf o! art thou not he?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Beware of treaon; do you know your own face if you ee't? look here; what ay you now?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewich't, thou art a Conjurer,
And hat transformed me to a banih't Rogue.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For Flametta's ake I pardon thee this language, but learn to peak better let you walk again.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Heaven, earth and hell, have all agreed together
To load me with a plague unknown before
Unto the world: The heavens have given conent
Unto my miery, hell hath plotted it,
And the deceived earth believes me mad,
And now will take me for a banih't Rogue.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: O joy above expreion! behold
My Trap. is come; Love, welcome home;
Thou art beholding unto me (my Dear)
'Twas I that won the Duke for thy repeal.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am amazed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Give me a hundred kies; let us pend
An hour in kiing, afterwards we'l talk.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Have you forgotten me o oon? I am
Thy true Flametta (lovely Trap.)

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Be gone I ay.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Dot thou reward me thus for all the pains
I've took to get thee home again?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Leave me
Thou impudent whore, or I will kick thee hence.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: O faithles men! Women, by me take heed
You give no trut unto this perjur'd ex.
Have I all thy long banihment been true,
Refued Lord Barbarino with all his gifts;
And am I lighted thus? I will complain
Unto his Highnes of thee.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Have you don't?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Have you let the Lords at liberty?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Give me my Ring.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: He has heard the Duke ent me with his Ring, and this impudent Rogue dares think to get it. Sirra, is it not enough to be a Coward and a Pander, but you wo'd be a thief too?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I fear my Trappolin is turned mad man.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Suffer not this ye Gods.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: I have et the Lords Barbarino and Macc. at liberty according to your Highnes order; and here is your Ring again.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Better and better—I ma • le where the Prince Horatio is.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: He forgets every thing, he's in prion.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sure he is not.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.p: How this Impotor divel acts me!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your Highnes did commit him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Fie upon't, what things do I do in my drink? here take my Ring, go and et him out, and come hither with him preently.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke, and will be obey'd,
Go not upon your life, he hall lye there.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Sure my Trappolin's run mad for grief in his banihment.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Peace (frantique) peace, do not diturb his Highnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Regard not mad men, go.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou traitor.

sp.speaker: Fam.
sp.p: Dear Trappolin be ilent, regard my tears, thou wilt undo thy elf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Maiden and your Sweet-heart continue thus, I'le have him ent abroad again.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Sweet Trappolin for my ake hold thy tongue

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I rage in vain, good heavens be merciful.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Dear brother pity me, regard my orrow,
Releae the Prince Horatio, and no longer
Separate their bodies whoe hearts the Gods have joyned.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Siter, have patience a little, a very little, Prince Horatio will be here preently, and Ile make an end with you.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Prudentia, art thou not aham'd?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: What awcines is this
sp.p: Mot worthy noble Brother all my heart is full o • thanks for you: wood Ide a tongue could utter them.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Your Highnes ring.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Tis well: Captain, Siter, and Prince Horatio,
Here take my ignet, by the warrant of it, go
And get you married,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Our humble thanks.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I do want patience.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tis bet to do it while he's in's good humor:
Are you content Sweet Princee?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: With all my oul I go.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Siter, iter.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Peace let you be oundly puniht Sirra.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Good Trappolin be quiet.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am the Duke, I am Lavinio;
This is a fiend of hell or an Impotor.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Will your Highnes uffer this?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I pity him, he knows not what he aies.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I am bewitched.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I am ure thou art ditracted.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: A done you had bet.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Thou enemy unto our happines,
Know the Gods will relent; in time be wie.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: There is no remedy, he mut go to Puchanello: o ho, Pachanello, o ho.

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: I come.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: There could come no better of it, beeech your Highnes pardon him, he's ditracted.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You are all ditracted, all bewitched.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Sirra take Trap. and lock him up afe.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: You'd take no warning.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: O Florence, how I pity thy decay.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Puchanello take him, and be gone.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: You of the Guard ee him laid afely up.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I will not go.

sp.speaker: Puch.
sp.l: We then might force you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Alas poor Flametta! Thy Trappolin cares not for thee, I beeech the Gods to give him his right ences again.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Come Captain.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I attend your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Mach.
sp.l: The trange ditraction of our Duke will give
Sufficient matter unto Chronicles
To make whole volumes of him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yet he believes himelf right in his ences
And we out of our wits think him mad.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Wood I had been born to a mean etate,
So in't I might have lived happily.
The greater honours that men have, the greater
Their troubles are; the begger that hath nothing
Lives a more quiet life then Monarchs do.
Lord Barbarino and Lord Machavil,
Get me releas'd, I am the Duke Lavinio,
Bewitched as you are by an Impotor.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Go Trappolin and leep: we have heard al l,
Thou art run mad.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Go leep poor Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Lavin.
sp.l: Be kind good Gods, pity our mieries.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Leave talking and go leep.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: His Highnes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How fares our noble mater?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I have not been ober a day together this good while; Eo Meo and Areo have made me fox't, but now I will leave it.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Who are they?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: It's in vain to lay them up any more, I having had port enough with them. Trappolin whom you baniht is come home tark mad.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: And raves mot trangly in prion.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Here is his Highnes, I will not leave him till
He doth releae from prion Trappolin.
Mot excellent Sir, perfect your noble kindnes;
Give liberty unto poor Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: With all my heart I would, wood he be quiet.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Alas he is ditracted, and doth not know
sp.p: VVhat he ayes; and therefore why hould you regard him?

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVell, fair maid, for thy ake that lovet him o he hal come out. Puchanello o ho! come hither.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He will do any thing, and undo any thing.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Sure there was never uch a Duke i'th world.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: VVelcome Siter and Brother (I hope I may ay,) are you married? are you content? tell me if any thing remains that I can do for you, peak it, for I am ready, the Duke
Your ervant.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Mot worthy brother, you have perfected our joyes, for we are married.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: I am very glad Lady iter that you are o.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Here is your Highnes ring.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: You Sirra of chains and keyes et me Trappolin at liberty preently, and end him hither.

sp.speaker: Puc.
sp.p: VVill he never be wie? I wood he wood make another Jaylor, I am weary of the place, I can never be at quiet for putting in and etting out.

sp.speaker: Flam
sp.l: The Heavens reward your goodnes.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Brother and Prince Horatio, I am omething given to be drunk, Eo, Meo and Areo are good fellows: but I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Sir, you wrong your elf.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: My friend, and Prince Horatio, I'le nere wrong my elf I warrant you; but you I have, and my iter Prudentia: but it was when I was fox't, and I will never be o again.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am glad he will once let us be quiet.

sp.speaker: Bar:
sp.l: I hould be very glad if he would continue it.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Ho now Seignior Captain ha you got a weetheart?

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: A fair Mitres o pleae your Highnes.

p.U: ee, my Don at Armes, when you cannot follow the wars of the field, you will of the bed.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Prethee my Trappolin, now hold thy tongue.
Be wie weet Love.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Leave me thou frantick fool.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: For Flametta's ake I have given you your liberty, ue it well.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: O Heavens, endure not this impotor thus
With his enchantments to bewitch our eyes.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Will he uffer him?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Perhaps one mad man wil pity another.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ye Florentines, I am Lavinio,
I am the Tuskan Duke, this an enchanter,
That by his magick Art has raied all
Thee trange chimeraes in my Court.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.p: Your Highnes is too patient, it were more fit he rav'd in Prion.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Sweet Trappolin be rul'd.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Hold your tongue I ay.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Poor Trappolin, art thou ditracted too?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: You Lords of Florence, wie Machavil, and
You Lord Barbarino, will you never come
Out of this frenzie? Valiant Mattemores,
I am the Duke, I am Lavinio:
This whom you do uppoe is me, is ome
Hellih Magician that hath bewitched us all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: He will not be rul'd: Puchanello take him again

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Beeech your Highnes: Trappolin, come away.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Was ever een the like?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Ah my poor ubjects! how I pity you,
That mut obey the montrous wickednes
Of one that works by Necromantick means,
And is foraken by the bleed Gods!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Away with him.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Yon's Father Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What new accident is this!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I hope he'l do no hurt.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What will the event be (marle?)

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: What old Long-beard's this?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: A word with you,
Will you, if I clear every thing,
Pardon what's pat?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Do you know me then?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: You are the Duke.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Father Conjurer, do no hurt, and I'le give you a hundred pitols to buy you allets and oile it'h wood.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'le talk with you even now;
Will you promie me?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I wear by all the honours of my tate,
By both my Dukedomes, Florence and Sienna,
I will forgive what ever's pat.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Him and all?

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Him and all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Good Father Conjurer, remember your on.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: What will come of this?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Be not affrighted.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Never, not I.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: What ere you ee,
Fear not, nothing hall hurt you.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: This is a Conjurer.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: Sweet Captain tand cloe by me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What trange events are thee!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Eo, Meo, and Areo, appear.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: I am undone I fear.
sp.p: Father Conjurer, remember your on, I'le give you two hundred pitols.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Appear I ay.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Hipo.
sp.l: Oh me!

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Be bold, I am here Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Go take the hat, the glas, and cloke from him.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Ah me! Ah me! here, here, here, here, come not too near me.
Eo, Meo, and Areo, farewel all on you; Father Conjurer has undone me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Trappolin.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Two Trappolins.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: I know not which is mine.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: Attend a while.
Thus with the wate of this enchanted wand
I do releae your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: The Duke.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Wonders.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: You have engaged your word, y'ave pardon'd all, me who have done and undone every thing, and him, and every body.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: The Heavens be prais'd; long live your Highnes.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Long live the Duke.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What will become of me?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: I'le perfect every thing;
Brave Prince Horatio, your elder Brother,
Prince Filberto is dead. Sir, you cannot,
With reaon dilike this match, they are
Married, and your conent doth perfect it.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: Now I am aured he is a Turin Prince
Heir to the Dukedome of Savoy, I am glad
They are epoued: iter I wih you joy;
Sir, I intreat forgivenes for what's pat.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: All's forgotten.

sp.speaker: Prud.
sp.l: Thanks gracious Heavens.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: I'le have your wedding olemnized with tate.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am glad this Gordian knot's untied.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: The Duke hath pardoned you and me all.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: Then let Eo, Meo, and Areo go to the Divel from whence they came. Flametta, I am thine.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.l: Ah my dear Trappolin!

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: Here is your Highnes ring.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.l: From henceforth I abjure my wicked art.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I for thy love to me will end thee into
Piemondt, and give thee an Earldome in Vercelly.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: The Heavens reward you: you know I alwaies made much of your Highnes Majety. Fla thou halt be a Countes.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Son Trappolin, I am thy natural father, twenty years ince baniht ten years from Florence: through my misfortune I have erved the Turk in his Gallies.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: By your leave Father you have erved the Divel too I'me ure: for you are one of the bet Conjurers in the world. Welcome unto the Court, your on of Honour, and to Flametta's Earlhip: will your Honours forgive me too?

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: For the Princes ake I do.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.p: I thank you both: now all's well agen, henceforth I will live honetly and be the Divels Butcher no longer.

sp.speaker: Lav.
sp.l: My Iabella welcome; every thing
That did molet our happines in Florence
Is took away, now we will pend our time
In Courtly joyes; our famous Tuskan Poets
Shall tudy amorous Comedies and Masks,
To entertain my beaute ous Millanes:
I have a tory full of ridiculous wonders,
Within to tell thee at our better leiure.

sp.speaker: Trap.
sp.l: The weaker ide mut yield unto the tronger,
And Trappolin's uppos'd a Prince no longer.

lg.l: LAdies and Gentlemen, you that now may
Approve (or if you pleae) condemn our Play,
We thank you firt; for here it was not writ
In weet repoe and fluencies of wit;
But far remote, at Rome begun, half made
At Naples, at Paris the concluion had.
Yet the perfection is behind, which (if
You give's a Plaudite) you in England give;
Our Nation's courteous unto trangers, nor
Should you refrain unto this Traveller.
I mut not ue; Ther's nothing now remains,
Saving the Guerdon of our Poets pains:
He for himelf is careles, onely wo'd,
That for the Actors akes you'd ay 'tis good.
We are doubtful yet, your hands will et all right;
Do what you pleae, and (Gentlemen) Good night.
